Vision: We are committed to making disciples by educating and equipping students in biblical foundations, Christian disciplines, and the development of spiritual gifts in order to prepare them for witness and service on the campus, in the local church, in the marketplace, and in world missions.
summary: Community at Berkeley seeking to share the Gospel with students, primarily those who identify as being Asian American.

name: Asian American Law Journal
description:
The Asian American Law Journal (AALJ) is the preeminent law journal in the United States, and only one of two in the country, focused on Asian American communities in its publication agenda. Known as the Asian Law Journal until 2007, AALJ was first published in October 1993 in a joint publication with the California Law Review. AALJ’s first independent issue was published in May 1994.

AALJ’s purpose is to explore the unique legal concerns of the South Asian American, Southeast Asian American, East Asian American, and Asian Pacific American communities, while recognizing the diversity and intersections within Asian American identities. By providing a scholarly foundation for a wide range of Asian American voices, we aim to mobilize the scholarship into action and to promote national understanding and empowerment of Asian Americans.

In pursuit of these goals, AALJ strives to provide a forum for the many voices and opinions of Asian American communities through events such as its annual Spring Symposium and Neil Gotanda Lecture in Asian American Jurisprudence. AALJ is published annually, and each volume typically contains articles, book reviews, essays, and other contributions from scholars, practitioners, policymakers, and students. AALJ consists of Berkeley Law students, external members from nearby Bay Area law schools, and UC Berkeley undergraduates in the Undergraduate Fellows Program.
summary: The Asian American Law Journal (AALJ) is the preeminent law journal exploring Asian American issues, based at Berkeley Law.

name: Asian American Research Journal
description: The Asian American Research Journal (AARJ), co-sponsored by the Asian American Research Center (AARC) and the Asian American and Asian Diaspora studies (AAADS) Program at UC Berkeley, seeks to provide a platform for research and scholarly work centered on Asian American experiences, identities, and communities. The AARJ is published annually with the intent to uplift and direct power towards undergraduate and graduate research. The journal welcomes works centered on Asian American experiences, identities, and communities.
summary: We seek to provide a platform for research and scholarly work centered on Asian American experiences, identities, and communities.

name: Asian Americans at Haas
description: Our mission is to build a greater sense of community among Haas students in the U.S. who are of Asian descents and spotlight their intersectional identity. We aim to provide resources for members educationally, professionally, and socially.
summary: Our mission is to build a greater sense of community among Haas students in the U.S. who are of Asian descents and spotlight their intersectional identity. We aim to provide resources for members educationally, professionally, and socially.

name: Asian Community Health
description:
Asian Community Health is an organization dedicated to supporting Asian and non-English speaking communities. Our goal is to provide free health services and resources to overcome barriers to accessible care.

Check out our website for more info!
summary: Asian Community Health is an organization dedicated to supporting Asian and non-English speaking communities. Our goal is to provide free health services and resources to overcome barriers to accessible care.

name: Asian Pacific American Pre-Law Association
description: APAPLA aims to provide guidance for Asian/Pacific Islander undergraduate students who are considering law school. We collaborate with the Asian American Law Journal (AALJ) at BerkeleyLaw to create a mentorship program for such students to explore the legal field and current API issues. We hope to continue cultivating a tight-knit community of pre-law API undergraduates, addressing inequities by hosting workshops and panels open to the community, as well as fundraise for local community organizations.
summary: APAPLA aims to provide guidance for Asian/Pacific Islander undergraduate students who are considering law school and to continue cultivating a tight-knit community of pre-law API undergraduates.

name: Asian Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus
description: The Asian and Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus is a group of MSW students at UC Berkeley who self-identify as Asian and/or Pacific Islander (API). The purpose of the group is to promote networking and connection amongst emerging social workers of API backgrounds, as social services catered to the broad API community are so sparse and limited. API Caucus was also formed to create a safe holding space for API folks to build community with each other and reflect about their experiences in and out of the MSW program. API Caucus also serves to empower and uplift the voices of self-identified Asian and/or Pacific Islander students within a program that lacks representation of this community.
summary: The Asian Pacific Islander Social Worker Caucus is a group of MSW students at UC Berkeley who self-identify as Asian and/or Pacific Islander (API).

name: Association for Computing Machinery at Berkeley
summary: Our mission is to promote education and interest in computing through knowledge sharing, fostering communication, and community involvement. As a student chapter of ACM, we are dedicated to advancing modern computing.

name: Association for Socially Responsible Business
description:
ASRB is a Haas-sponsored and SERC affiliated organization that brings together an interdisciplinary group of individuals dedicated to using business for positive change. 

Through educational events, community-building, and social impact consulting projects, we aim to help you in exploring, defining, and progressing toward the personal social impact you wish to achieve. 

Join us and learn about how to mobilize the positive potential of business to create a more responsible, equitable, and sustainable society. 

This is what we do:

  • Foster a community of interdisciplinary individuals passionate about sustainability and social impact dedicated to challenging the status quo of business 
  • Develop students to be highly effective in their future career paths and connect them to opportunities, resources, and mentorship
  • Learn about how to mobilize the positive potential of business to create a more responsible, equitable, and sustainable society.  
  • Apply our values to hands-on projects that create measurable positive impact through working with campus, clients and the Bay Area community
summary:
ASRB is a Haas-sponsored and SERC affiliated organization that brings together an interdisciplinary group of individuals dedicated to using business for positive change. 

Join us and learn about how to mobilize the positive potential of business .

name: Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs at Berkeley
description:
Founded in 2012, Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs (ACE) at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to connect entrepreneurial individuals, consolidate entrepreneurship network, and incubate future industry leaders.

伯克利华人创业者协会 (Association of Chinese Entrepreneurs，简称ACE) 于2012年成立于加州大学伯克利分校，目前已发展成旧金山地区最大的华人创业组织，辐射面覆盖硅谷地区华人，面向全美。 ACE以人为本，是融合投资人与创业者的社区，致力于培育未来的创新创业型行业领袖。
summary: Founded in 2012, ACE at Berkeley is the largest Chinese entrepreneurial community at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to connect entrepreneurial individuals, consolidate entrepreneurship network, and incubate future industry leaders.

name: Association of Korean Artists
description: AKA: Association of Korean Artists
summary: AKA, officially known as Association of Korean Artists, is the one and only platform for networking and communication between Korean musical artists at UC Berkeley.

name: Association of Public Health Infectious Disease Students at Berkeley
description: The Association of Public Health Infectious Disease Students (APHIDS) is a student group representing graduate students within the Infectious Diseases & Vaccinology program in the School of Public Health. The primary goals of APHIDS are to foster a sense of community in the IDV cohorts, serve as student advocates, and provide peer support. To meet these goals, APHIDS holds social events, establishes a mentoring system, and provides professional development resources to support IDV students in their academic and professional endeavors. In addition, APHIDS holds monthly meetings where students can discuss classes, talk about current events, share insights about SPH programs or just socialize.
summary: The Association of Public Health Infectious Disease Students (APHIDS) is a student group open to all graduate public health students with an interest in infectious diseases.

name: Association of Women in EE&CS
description:
AWE is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that seeks to connect, inspire, and empower female and non-binary undergraduate students in electrical engineering, computer science, and adjacent disciplines. AWE hosts a variety of academic, industry, and social events throughout the year to support and connect our members.

AWE members are welcome to the socials, technical workshops, company events, and all other kinds of events hosted throughout the year. Members stay in touch through our club-wide Slack, and receive opportunities through our weekly newsletter and resume book. We also encourage members to join our mentorship program to give back and get involved! Our office is also open as a study space and a social space for members during AWEffice hours.

Being a part of AWE means joining a community of inspiring and supportive women in EE&CS here at Berkeley. Learn more about membership on our website!
summary: AWE is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that seeks to empower female and non-binary undergraduate students pursuing Computer Science and/or Electrical Engineering disciplines.

name: ASUC - CalTV
description:
CalTV is online, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week on YouTube, Instagram, TikTok and Facebook. Since its founding in 2005, CalTV has grown into one of the largest student-run television organizations on the West Coast.

If you're interested, or just curious about in the on-camera and behind the scenes workings of broadcasting and digital media, check us out at caltv.berkeley.edu!

Spring 2023 Application: Opens August 23rd
 
Recruitment Events
• Info Session #1: Monday August 28th (Dwinelle 219) 8PM-9:00 PM
• Info Session #2: Tuesday August 29th (Dwinelle 219 AND Zoom) 8PM-9:00 PM
 
We are tabling on Sproul Wednesday 8/23 to Wednesday 8/30 from 10AM-3PM. Drop by and chat with our directors!
 
Fall 2023 Application closes Friday September 1st at 11:59 PM.
 
Follow our Instagram @caltv for recruitment updates!
summary: Since our founding in 2005, CalTV has become the premier student-run media and entertainment organization at UC Berkeley. Our departments include Studios, Entertainment, News, and Marketing to help students explore all aspects of content creation.

name: ASUC - Democratic Education at Cal
description:
The DeCal Program (or just DeCal) is a student-run democratic education program at the University of California, Berkeley - here, students create and facilitate their own classes on a variety of subjects.

Each semester we support over 150 courses facilitated by students, for students. These are accredited Pass / No Pass courses on our campus. To facilitate a course, a student must find a faculty sponsor.

Around 3000-4000 UC Berkeley students take DeCals each semester.

What the DeCal Board does:

  • Manage the online course listing / this website.
  • Help facilitators get funding from the ASUC, get publicity, make copies for their course, or simply help them fill out the paperwork.
  • Put on pedagogical workshops, connect people to UCFTR resources, foster an academic dialogue on education.

 

You can contact anyone on the Board via email:

decalprogram@gmail.com
summary: The DeCal Program (or just DeCal) is a student-run democratic education program at the University of California, Berkeley - here, students create and facilitate their own classes on a variety of (often unorthodox) subjects.

name: ASUC - Elections Council
description: Each year the ASUC holds a regular election to choose its five Executive Officers and twenty-one members of the Senate.  All members of the Association, that is all undergraduate and graduate students at UC Berkeley, can vote. Regular elections are held the second week following the Spring Break in early April. Students vote using the Ranked Choice System which guarantees diverse and proportional elections results. Furthermore, students can vote on referendum propositions. Referendum propositions can be placed on the ballot by the ASUC Senate, Graduate Assembly, or a petition of the student body. Lastly, special elections can occur to recall officials or in some other limited circumstances.
summary: The ASUC Elections Council administers the ASUC Elections.

name: ASUC - Innovative Design
description:
Innovative Design is a family of designers, photographers, web developers, and videographers at the University of California, Berkeley. We are creative individuals who are continuously evolving by collaborating, inspiring, and educating one another. It is through our different artistic tools and talents that we are able to create novel photography and designs for our peers and professional clients.

We provide pro-bono creative services and teach popular DeCals to the Cal community. 

Website: https://www.innovativedesign.club/

Creative Services
Innovative Design has five tiers: Blue, Gold, Photo, Video, and Web. Throughout the semester, we also host several educational and industry events.

  1. Gold and Blue: There are two design tiers, Gold and Blue Tier. Blue Tier is a group of intermediate to advanced designers that offers more professional design services while Gold Tier offers graphic design education and experience for beginner to intermediate designers as they service on-campus groups and professional clients.
  2. Photo Tier provides members hands-on experience as they provide photography services such as shooting professional headshots, event photography, stock photos, and more.
  3. Web Tier works for clients that are in need of technical help in designing their websites. Tier members learn new skills and put existing knowledge to use through hands-on experience.
DeCals 
Innovative Design teaches 3 DeCals:
  1. Introduction to Photoshop and Illustrator
    This introductory course teaches graphic design through the use of Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop. This class is built for students who do not have any prior experience or knowledge of these programs. We work with students in developing a thorough understanding of these programs with weekly lessons and hands-on tutorials. In addition, students complete relevant homework exercises which aim to give students the opportunity to practice tools, develop original designs, and channel their creativity. Lastly, we explore graphic design trends, principles, and applications.
  2. Graphic Design Principles
    This is a technical course in which students are taught extensive knowledge of Adobe programs (such as Illustrator and/or Photoshop). The class also covers conceptual and theoretical aspects of design such as color theory, branding, and user interface design. At the end of the course, students have a portfolio of work showcasing extensive knowledge on several design topics and an understanding of various elements of design.
  3. Photography Principles
    This DeCal is for students interested in learning photography. We start off with the basics (camera manipulations and shooting in RAW) and quickly move onto composition rules and tricks to get better, more thought out photos, and from there move onto how to be a professional photographer, photo ethics, and integrating art into photography. By the end, students will feel strong in their photographic abilities, be able to critique their own work, and see the world through an artistic eye, so they can further grow as a photographer. It is intended to be for beginners with little to no knowledge of how to use a dSLR or other camera with manual capabilities.

Throughout the year, Innovative Design hosts a variety of events, from our annual designathon CMYK: Come Make Your MarK, speaker and workshop series RGB: Reach / Grow / Build, and an educational weekend series of creative workshops HEX: Hone and EXplore. Check out our Facebook Page or website for our most up-to-date announcements!
summary: Innovative Design is a team of graphic designers and photographers that provides services to campus organizations and local businesses.

name: ASUC - Office of Academic Affairs
description:
About AAVP:

The ASUC Office of the Academic Affairs Vice President (AAVP) focuses on enhancing students’ academic experience by identifying barriers to academic success and creating proactive solutions through the development of  innovative campuswide programming, supportive services, and policy initiatives. Our agenda for the year includes the revitalization of the Undergraduate-Graduate Mentorship Program, advocacy for more supportive and mental health-conscious advising services, the distribution of over a dozen scholarships and grants, and so much more.  AAVP community members can expect to gain valuable leadership experience in a supportive and dynamic space, collaborate with campus leaders, and make powerful, positive academic change at UC Berkeley.

AAVP Mission Statement:

The ASUC Office of the Academic Affairs Vice President works to cultivate an inclusive and enriching learning environment at UC Berkeley that supports students’ holistic well-being, celebrates intellectual curiosity, and encourages critical thought. Grounded in the values of community and collaboration, we are committed to building student power in academic and administrative decision-making, developing innovative programs and services, and empowering scholastic excellence and engagement through grants and scholarship awards.

Departments:

  • Policy
  • Communications
  • Committees
  • Equity & Inclusion
  • Systemwide Affairs

Applications for select positions due on 8/26; see the application link below for more information.
summary: AAVP focuses on enhancing students’ academic experience by identifying barriers to academic success and creating proactive solutions through innovative programming, supportive services, and policy initiatives.

name: ASUC - Office of the Executive Vice President
description: The Office of the Executive Vice President supports student organizing in all spheres. The office is a supportive partner and ally to the ASUC Senate, facilitating the success of the Senate’s collective vision while assisting with its outreach and visibility. Offering financial and networking resources, leadership development, and empowerment opportunities, we strive to provide students with an environment that allows them to create positive change in their areas of their interest. We will revamp the ASUC’s infrastructure and modernize it by leveraging technology to provide for an efficient, effective, user-friendly, and transparent ASUC. We seek to increase resources for student leaders through collaboration with other campus departments to bring affordable, accessible space and all kinds of resource to support their endeavors. We work to build a more vibrant and inclusive campus community through collaborative events, coalition building, and engaging as many students as possible in major campus decisions. Our hope to is to develop a better UC Berkeley founded on values of inclusivity, Cal pride, and thriving student life.
summary: The Office of the ASUC Executive Vice President is committed to developing quality student life and a stronger culture of community on the UC Berkeley campus.

name: ASUC - Office of the President
description:
The ASUC Office of the President is the main point of communication between students and the administration. Our power lies in our ability to advocate administration, unify the student body, and lead groundbreaking, campus-wide initiatives. This year our office has combined with the ASUC Executive Vice Preisdent's office to complete more projects. Our office has established nine departments to empower students and generate a better Berkeley. They are:
 
- Communications
- Environmental Justice and Sustainability 
- Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging 
- Research and Policy 
- Academic & Professional Opportunities 
- Student Wellness
- Operations and Finance 
- THON
- Administrative
summary: Departments: Projects/Programs, Outreach/Internal Affairs, Policy Initiatives, Partnerships (Resources, Alumni, Financial), Commercial Development

name: ASUC - Open Computing Facility
description:
We don't use CalLink! See the links below for how to join.

 

The Open Computing Facility is a student volunteer-run organization dedicated to free and open source computing. We run a computer lab at 171 MLK Student Union and provide free services for the Berkeley community such as website and email hosting, shell accounts, and high-performance computing.

 

If you’re interested in joining the OCF, no application is needed! Join our Slack or Discord and introduce yourself as a first step. Also, check out ocf.io/getinvolved to learn more about how to get involved.
summary: The Open Computing Facility (OCF) is a student volunteer-run organization dedicated to free and open source computing. We offer free web hosting, file storage, Unix shell accounts, high performance computing, and printing.

name: ASUC - Senate
description:
The 20-member ASUC Senate is the legislative branch of the student government. They control the ASUC's $12 million budget, update the governing documents, and represent the voice of UC Berkeley students. Senators work on a wide variety of issues such as campus safety, healthcare, affordability of education, and improving academic services.

ASUC Funding to student programs is allocated by the ASUC Senate. See www.asuc.org Funding page for a complete description of the different ways students can apply for support from the ASUC.

The ASUC Finance Committee reviews spending decisions of the ASUC Senate and Student Groups according the ASUC By-Laws Title III. Groups seeking permission to use funds for a normally restricted use (see By-Laws) should initiate the appropriate waiver request available through the form links further down this page.
summary: The 20-member ASUC Senate is the legislative branch of the student government. They control the ASUC's $1.7 million budget, update the governing documents, and represent the voice of UC Berkeley students.

name: ASUC - Student Legal Clinic
description:
The ASUC Student Legal Clinic is a student-run legal resource center that helps students and community members make informed decisions about legal problems. We provide free legal assistance and tax filing for Cal students and the Berkeley community.

The Clinic has proudly served the Berkeley community for over 30 years, providing free and confidential legal research catered to the particular issues our clients are facing. Clients can walk-in or schedule an appointment to discuss their legal questions, and our trained caseworkers will provide clientele with fully researched case reports, outlining possible legal options and pertinent information about their rights. In the spring, the Clinic also participates in the Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA) program to provide eligible students and community members free tax-filing services. All of our caseworkers are IRS-certified tax preparers. The Clinic aims to foster a nurturing environment where caseworkers can interact with peers who share similar interests and hear from a wide range of guest speakers, including Berkeley Law admissions officers, local attorneys, and Cal alumni. 

Office: Eshleman Hall, 312F

Email: legalclinic@asuc.org

Website: https://www.asucslcberkeley.org/
summary: The ASUC Student Legal Clinic is a student-run legal resource center that helps students and community members make informed decisions about legal problems. We provide free legal assistance and tax filing for Cal students and the Berkeley community.

name: ASUC - Student Union Board
description: The Board is composed of UC Berkeley students, staff, and faculty. The Board establishes policy and provides oversight for all Student Union commercial activities in a manner consistent with University policies. The ASUC Student Union reports to both Student Affairs and the Student Union Board of Directors. The Chancellor and the ASUC give the Board the authority necessary for it to carry out its functions. This Callink Page is for the two undergraduate representatives appointed by the ASUC and their support staff.
summary: The Board is composed of students, staff, and faculty. The Board establishes policy and provides oversight for all Student Union commercial activities. The Student Union reports to both Student Affairs and the Student Union Board of Directors.

name: ASUC Admin Office
description:
The Administrative Office is comprised of a General Manager, 2 Assistant Managers, and typically 6-7 Administrative Assistants. We advise the student government offices and handle general office tasks on the fourth floor of Eshleman. You will often see us staffing the front desk when you visit the ASUC office.

 

We have many responsibilities, some of which include: advising student government, managing student government budget and reimbursements, reserving rooms, renting equipments, managing important ASUC documentation, and handling general campus and public questions.
summary: The Administrative Office is comprised of a General Manager and typically 8-9 Administrative Assistants. We advise the student government offices and handle general office tasks on the fourth floor of Eshleman.

If you are interested in learning more, please fill out the New Student Interest form that is linked above! They are always welcoming new members!
summary: ASUC Disabled Students Commission

In doing so, the commission builds bridges for cross-cultural understanding and uplifts the voices of underrepresented communities to create a united student body.

If you need to contact us, please email cfo@asuc.org and CC cfochief@asuc.org.

Henry F. Isselbacher
Email: cfo@asuc.org

name: ASUC Financial Wellness Commission
description: The purpose of our Commission is to increase students' awareness for and accessibility to financial resources and opportunities provided by campus offices, programs, and organizations; engage in dialogue with campus offices, programs, and organizations involved in work related to financial wellness, financial literacy, food security, health affordability, and housing affordability; determine issues pertinent to student financial wellness that the Commission should prioritize; host workshops and other events that improve overall student financial wellness; and most importantly, incubate a campus policy advocacy agenda that is supportive of financial wellness of students on campus, one which ensures affordable living expenses.
summary: ASUC Financial Wellness Commission

name: ASUC Grant & Scholarship Foundation
description:
Fall 2023 ASUC Grant applications will be available from Wednesday, August 23, 2023 to Thursday, November 30, 2023. Below is a summary of each of the grants available this Fall. To apply click on the link of the respective fund in the forms section of this page. Any questions can be directed to the Executive Director of the Foundation, Henry F. Isselbacher, at grants-asuc@berkeley.edu. 

 

The deadline to spend Fall 2023 grant awards is Friday, December 15, 2023 by 5:00 pm. Any awarded funds that have not been put toward purchase requests at that point will be returned to the Foundation and will no longer be available to awardees. Please plan accordingly. 

 

Applications for the grants will be reviewed in two stages: a priority deadline for first reads will be on Saturday, September 30 at 11:59 pm. Once initial applications are reviewed and decided on, applications will be accepted and reviewed on a rolling basis and will remain open until November 30, 2023 at 11:59 pm. 

 

Academic Opportunity Fund (AOF):

The Academic Opportunity Fund awards grants for academic travel that enhances student access to valuable educational experiences beyond the classroom. The program provides opportunities for individuals and student groups to represent and further UC Berkeley's academic prestige and dedication to education. While most ASUC funding is restricted to on-campus activities, the Academic Opportunity Fund subsidizes off-campus academic pursuits, such as professional meetings, research conferences, academic competitions, and independent research.

 

Arts and Creativity Fund (ACF):

The Arts and Creativity Fund provides financial assistance to students and student groups that seek to enhance the exposure of visual, performing, and creative art endeavors on campus. The objective of the program is to foster greater creativity through arts on campus.  Funding is allocated to students or groups that organize and widely advertise artistic events.

 

Intellectual Community Fund (ICF):

The Intellectual Community Fund provides monetary support to collaborative events planned by and for Cal students. The objective of ICF is to fund programs that aim to foster a unified campus community that is conducive to free intellectual exchange. Through the distribution of small grants, the Intellectual Community Fund promotes joint campus programs that serve the diverse student population of UC Berkeley. Funding is allocated to student groups that cooperatively plan and advertise academic events serving multiple communities of interest.

 

Public Service Fund (PSF):

The Public Service Fund provides monetary support to increase and facilitate public service efforts targeted towards communities outside of the UC Berkeley campus. The objective of this fund  is to encourage students to partake in philanthropic or humanitarian based projects. The Public Service Fund strives to develop a sense of community awareness and enrich students’ community service experiences. Funding is allocated based on the impact the activities/events have on the targeted communities.

 

Greek Opportunity Fund (GOF)

The Greek Opportunity Fund provides monetary support to empower students and chapters that are members of the Interfraternity Council (IFC), Panhellenic Council (PHC), National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC), or MultiCultural Greek Council (MCGC) to engage in meaningful community-based initiatives which focus on community service and philanthropy, scholarship and educational enhancement, leadership development, professional and career development, and/or health and safety, including alcohol education. Funding is allocated to fraternities and sororities that are members of IFC/PHC/NPHC/MGCG that organize philanthropic activities.

 

Student Organization Travel Grant (SOTG):

The Student Organization Travel Grant awards grants for travel that enhances student access to valuable educational and cultural experiences beyond the classroom. The program provides opportunities for individuals and student groups to represent and further UC Berkeley's student group's influence and missions. This grant prioritizes monetary support to student organizations that represent the university on a larger platform in order to compete, build, or share knowledge at a local, state, and national level. Funding is allocated to student groups that organize and widely advertise and promote their group and UC Berkeley. 

PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS GRANT IS INTENDED FOR REGISTERED STUDENT ORGANIZATIONS ONLY AND CANNOT BE AWARDED TO INDIVIDUAL STUDENTS WITHIN RSOS. ORGANIZATIONS MAY ONLY SUBMIT/BE CONSIDERED FOR ONE APPLICATION FOR A GIVEN EVENT THAT ORGANIZATION MEMBERS WILL BE TRAVELING TO.

 

Student Technology Grant (STG):

The Student Technology Grant provides financial assistance to students and student groups that seek to provide access to or enhance the quality of technology and technology-adjacent services and resources on campus. The objective of the program is to enhance the student and instructional technology landscape on campus and to promote equitable access to necessary technologies for all students. Funding is allocated to students or groups that work toward these criteria.

name: ASUC Health Advocacy Commission
description:
Mission

The mission of the Health Advocacy Commission shall be to act as a body for campus organizations to advocate for progressive, equitable, and accessible health policies and programs at the campus, local, state, and national level in order to promote individual and community health on the UC Berkeley campus and the greater community. We work to support the advocacy missions of student organizations and wellness of individuals through advocacy work, campaigns, and lobbying events. If you have a passion for health, law, policy, or advocacy in general, we'd love to have you!

________________________________________

Student Organizations Represented on this Commission: Fall 2022

● American Medical Student Association

● American Medical Women's Association

● Bhagat Puran Singh Health Initiative (BPSHI)

● Blood Pressure Project

● California Health Professional Student Alliance 

● Nutrigenomx

● Phi Chi

● Students vs Pandemics at Berkeley

● Student Nutrition Advocacy Club

● Undergraduate Street Medicine Outreach

● United for Health

● Volunteer Health Interpreter Organization

________________

Notes for Contacting

As of Fall 2022, we regularly check our emails and Instagram DMs. We try our best to respond within 1-3 business days. Thank you for your patience and please follow us on Instagram at @asuchealthadvocacy to keep updated about future events, campaigns, and application cycles.

name: ASUC Judicial Council

All decisions of the Judicial Council shall be final unless reversed by subsequent council action.

Pre-Law Students, Pre-Health Students, DSP/ Disabled Students, SVSH/ Mental Health, The Queer Community (LGBTQIA+), and Cross-Cultural Collaboration.

name: ASUC Office of Senator Andrea Jimenez
description:
Our first vision for the upcoming semester is to begin discussions about how we can ensure proper undocumented student representation within the ASUC by adding an elected representative for that community, similar to the transfer representative. We will be collaborating with the Latinx Caucus to pursue this goal.

We will be working with the Marina Orth Foundation in helping recruit Latin American students for internship opportunities in public service in Latin America. This will entail frequent meetings with their foundation and workshops for interested students.

Our office will be collaborating with Cal in the Capitol to host career and development workshops for students interested in interning in Washington DC, in the Public Service industry, or just applying for Cal in the Capitol.

Our office will be partnering with the California Common Cause to increase voter participation on campus for students of color. 

Our office, in collaboration with ASUC Senators Torres Murray and Massuh, as well as Transfer Representative Tigue, will be hosting a Latine Heritage Month Event in collaboration with Latine RSO’s on campus.

Our office will also be aiding efforts to reestablish the Latinx Community Resource Center through frequent check-ins with Lucha4LSRC.

description:
The ASUC Publications and Media Board (PMB) is a chartered program of the ASUC that is responsible for managing an a budget of approximately $10,000 and several ASUC-allocated spaces that are dedicated to bettering the publications/media community on campus at Cal. Learn more about what the Board is and does here.

 

The PMB engages Berkeley Student Media (BSM), a campus department within the Student Union, to offer ffree programs to registered members of Cal’s 100+ student publications and media groups. These programs include free Equipment Checkouts, Graphic Design Services, Space Reservations, Marketing, Distribution, and Storage. Visit www.studentunion.berkeley.edu/student-media-center for more information.  

For questions, email: studentmedia@berkeley.edu. Follow us on Instagram @berkeleystduentmedia!

Further, they provide a cross-campus lens to ensure all such efforts are intersectional, welcoming, and considerate to all who have been impacted by sexual violence and harassment.

name: ASUC Sustainability Commission
description:
The Sustainability Team is a commission of the ASUC, and one of the oldest commissions in the ASUC. We create and implement a variety of projects that help establish sustainable practices and promote environmental awareness on campus. Project committees within STeam work as a tight unit to accomplish their goals, and leadership capacity is shared equally.

We meet all together once a week to update each other on the progress of our projects and brainstorm strategies for successful implementation. The team also spends time outside of meetings through our STeam Socials a few times per semester.

Interested? Here are some of our current projects:

Ethical Eats, one of our latest projects, centers around giving students access to sustainable restaurants. Our website grants sustainability ratings to local Berkeley eateries. This semester we are working toward creating a website to increase student awareness regarding restaurant sustainability, as well as to help restaurants work to become more sustainable.

Another program STeam began is Environmental Justice and Education (EJ&E), where we teach a 5-week long curriculum that we create to elementary aged students in the area.

This semester we are starting our Green Event Fund project, where we create and implement criteria through which we can fund other RSOs as they demonstrate how they are working to be more sustainable. This program will fund events, projects, printing, and anything else an RSO may need money in order to do more sustainably. 

Finally, STeam organizes Sunstock, a solar-powered music festival held on campus annually. STeam works hard year-round to prepare a venue, local lineup, sponsors, merchandise, and cuisine. Sunstock aims to unite students through music in an environmentally conscious way that brings light to improvements the music industry can make to be more sustainable. Our wide range of project niches displays how sustainability can be brought into all aspects of life and even combined with personal passions!

We are always open to new ideas. The next project we work on could be yours! So come check us out at our meetings and initiate your own ideas. Follow our instagram, @asuc.steam for meeting time updates and come to any meeting, no application necessary.
summary: The ASUC Sustainability Team (STeam) is a commission established in Fall 2005. As a team, we create and implement a variety of projects that help establish sustainable practices & promote environmental awareness on campus. There is no application to join

name: Atrium
description:
Mitochondria are the powerhouse of the cell, mass can neither be created nor destroyed, and one of our editors called 9-1-1 for the first time after her dad fainted from low blood pressure.

In undergraduate education, the sciences and humanities are treated as disparate fields, and we are led to focus on the former aspects of science far more than the latter. In reality, scientists, engineers, and researchers all work towards improving human lives and often need to tap into the vast resources of human creativity and empathy to do so.

Art and creative writing allow us to consider these implications with an expressive freedom not afforded by lectures and laboratories. We believe that exploration of this intersection of sciences and humanities is just as crucial to scientific knowledge as concrete theories and research. We intend for Atrium to be a space that humanizes the sciences through the sharing of creative student reflections on these subjects. As such, if you’re a STEM student, we warmly welcome you to submit work that reflects on the human aspects of your career aspirations and extracurricular experience. On the other hand, our magazine is open to all students with a story to share, regardless of major and career plans.
summary: Atrium is a magazine dedicated to creative student exploration of the intersection between the sciences and human experience.

name: Aurum Cosmetics
description: Interested in cosmetics, chemistry, product development, beauty tech, or marketing? AURUM is the first and only club at UC Berkeley that comprehensively follows the beauty industry. We take a holistic approach, looking at everything from the science and formulations, to marketing and networking. The beauty industry will only keep growing, and we strive to be a resource to our peers and share our passion. Come join the AURUM movement!
summary: AURUM is the first and only club at UC Berkeley that comprehensively follows the beauty industry. We take a holistic approach, looking at everything from the science and formulations, to marketing and networking.

name: Azaad
description: Auditions for this coming season will be held in early September. Please follow our Instagram @ucbazaad for updates on recruiting events and everything else we're up to!
summary: Azaad, UC Berkeley's co-ed collegiate competitive Bollywood/Fusion dance team, creates productions that entertain audiences and motivate them to connect with the Hindi-Film/Bollywood culture.

name: Azerbaijanis at Berkeley
summary: Our goal is to promote, and embrace the cultural heritage of Azerbaijan. We would like to create an environment where Azerbaijani students, and those who are interested in our culture can bond through academic, professional, and social events.

name: Azure
description: Azure—the first premier organization at UC Berkeley that intersects business, consulting, fashion, and beauty! We believe that every student should have the opportunity to succeed and work with exciting brands in these rapidly changing industries. Whether you're interested in streetwear, skincare, or anything in between, we provide a platform for students to find business-related roles and work on consulting engagements with important brands in these industries. Our goal is to equalize the business community playing field at Berkeley and add new, fresh perspectives by providing professional resources and opportunities for everyone, regardless of what you're studying or your background. AZURE is not just an organization, but a movement towards a more equitable and diverse business community at UC Berkeley. Our group's beliefs center around the idea that business is a space for all, regardless of interests or background. Besides students, we are thrift shop advocates, sneaker collectors, skincare enthusiasts, and more. At AZURE, there is a space for all. Join us and be a part of the future of business in fashion and beauty at UC Berkeley!
summary: Azure is UC Berkeley's first premier business organization which intersects business, fashion, and beauty. We provide a platform for students to work on consulting engagements with important industry-leading brands in these spaces.

name: B-Side, The
description:
Love going to concerts and talking about music? Passionate about social justice and equity? Hate the fact most art clubs on campus are exclusive and lack diversity? Join The B-Side! 

As a member of The B-Side, you can participate as a journalist, photojournalist, web designer, graphic designer, event manager, producer, marketer, or public relations member to satisfy your creative drive. Our members are both passionate about music journalism and social culture and work to create content combining the two. We regularly update our website, and once a semester, we collaborate on a print magazine to show off our most interesting pieces, photos, and designs within a thematically centralized magazine. You can check us out at @berkelybside on insta or at berkeleybside.com !!!
summary: A music magazine working to combat white supremacy and the historic oppression of marginalized groups in both music and general media. Passionate articles, evocative short films, and community events are just a taste of what to expect at the B-Side!

name: BACC Campus
description: BACC stands for the Bay Area Christian Church. We are a non-denominational church that builds convictions solely off the Bible and Jesus' teachings. We are made up of different counties across the Bay Area, as well as international churches such as the BACC in Russia and India. The campus organziation related to the BACC provides an opportunity for students to discuss and question God's purpose for their lives. It's a great way to meet people and connect with other Bay Area college students.
summary: A place where people can discuss their ambitions and move forward during their college career in developing a relationship with God. This organization teaches the basics of who God is, what it means to follow him, and how to discover your destiny.

name: Backstage At Berkeley
summary: With the support of the Theatre, Dance, and Performance Studies department, we strive to connect and provide support to all students on campus who are trying to pursue a career in technical theatre,  theatrical design, and/or theatrical management.

name: Ballet & Books at Berkeley
summary: We forward Ballet & Books’ nationwide mission of bridging the literacy gap for children aged 3-9. The organization utilizes a hybrid program of reading/writing instruction and creative dance movement to inspire and educate youth.

name: Ballet Company at Berkeley
description:
The Ballet Company at Berkeley (BC@B) is UC Berkeley’s first ballet company, committed to excellence in ballet and the enrichment of the arts community on campus, as well as expanding the aesthetic horizons of both dancers and audiences. As a completely student-run company, it will strive to provide a professional environment in which dancers and choreographers can share the joys and innovations of the art of ballet with the UC Berkeley community.

Ballet Company at Berkeley holds auditions at the beginning of each semester for those interested in joining our performing company. In addition, our classes are also open to those in the UC Berkeley community who are not a part of our company. Classes will be offered Mondays 6-7 PM and Wednesdays 6-7 PM, which will be available to take as drop-ins for anyone interested. The end of semester showcase will be offered to performing members, with rehearsals on Mondays 7-8 PM and Wednesday from 7-8 PM.

Our directors for Fall 2023 are Diana Barbacioru, Lucy Lee, and Ina Nierotka. Please don't hesitate to contact us at ballet.berkeley@gmail.com! 

UPDATED PLANS FOR FALL 2023:

For Fall 2023 we will be offering an in-person semester, consisting of weekly classes, rehearsals, and an end of semester showcase. We will be adhering to CDC and university guidelines. Weekly class/practices days and times are not set yet as we are working to finalize it. Our classes are open to drop-ins as well. The end of semester showcase will be offered to performing members (acceptance offered through auditions). 

On Friday, August 25, we will be having an open class from 6-7pm in Eshleman Hall room 10 where we will be teaching a simple ballet class and discussing the plans for Fall 2023 along with the audition process. We highly recommend attending our open class if you are interested in becoming a member of our performing company or a drop-in member for Fall 2023.

Auditions will be held on Tuesday, August 29th 6-7pm in Eshleman Hall room 10 and Wednesday, August 30th from 6-7 pm in Eshleman Hall room 10. Please arrive at 5:30pm to check in for the audition as the class will begin promptly at 6:00pm. A make-up audition will also be held on Friday, September 1st from 6:00-7:00pm in Eshleman Hall room 240. We will be teaching a simple audition class and all are welcome, even if you are not interested in joining the performing company. All dancers seeking to join the performing company in Fall 2023 must audition, even if they are returning members. Virtual auditions will be available upon request, please email ballet.berkeley@gmail.com.

If you have any questions, please email ballet.berkeley@gmail.com. We look forward to dancing with you all soon!
summary: The Ballet Company at Berkeley (BC@B) is UC Berkeley’s first ballet company, committed to excellence in ballet and the enrichment of the arts community on campus, as well as expanding the aesthetic horizons of both dancers and audiences.

name: Ballet Folklorico Reflejos del Sol
description: Ballet Folklorico Reflejos del Sol, referred to as “Reflejos”, is a Mexican folklorico dance group that promotes cultural diversity at UC Berkeley and in the greater San Francisco/Bay area. Our hope is to educate the university and the community about the Mexican culture through music, art, and dance. We are one of only a handful of Latinx/Chicanx performing groups on campus. We require no experience, so anyone interested is free to join us for practices Monday 6 to 7:30 for the beginners group and Tuesdays 6 to 7:30 for the intermediate/advanced group. Please feel free to e-mail us at reflejosdemexico.cal@gmail.com for any questions! Or follow us on Instagram @reflejosdeucb.
summary: Ballet Folklorico Reflejos del Sol, referred to as “Reflejos”, is a Mexican folklorico dance group that promotes cultural diversity in the SF Bay Area.

name: Bamboo Abroad at Berkeley
description:
WE SUPPORT A NEW GENERATION OF LEADERS AND ENTREPRENEURS TO LEAD SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL REGENERATION OF OUR BIO-REGIONS AND COMMUNITIES.

 

Through education work and demonstration, our mission is to support farmers, builders, entrepreneurs and designers to conduct socially and ecologically regenerative work. 

Join Regeneration Field Institute: a network of students, researchers, scientists, and leaders. Together we can take action for the regeneration of our world.
summary: Our mission is to provide the opportunity for students of all backgrounds to learn about sustainable bamboo architecture and agriculture, and eco friendly cultivation of many other crops in Manabi, Ecuador

name: BAPS Campus Fellowship
description:
The BAPS Swaminarayan Sanstha strives to better society through individual development by instilling values, promoting spirituality, cultivating skills, and nurturing growth.  We aim to preserve Indian culture and the Swaminarayan ideals of faith, unity, and selfless service in diverse communities around the world.  We envision a society whose joy lies in the joy of others.

BAPS Campus Fellowship, based on the teachings of Bhagwan Swaminarayan and under the leadership of Param Pujya Mahant Swami Maharaj, provides for the spiritual, cultural, physical, and emotional needs of people from all walks of life.

We aim to get together weekly to discuss the Swaminarayan teachings of the faith and hold festivals to show our rich Indian culture.
summary: BAPS Campus Fellowship, based on the teachings of Bhagwan Swaminarayan, and under the leadership of Mahant Swami Maharaj, provides for the spiritual, cultural, physical, and emotional needs of people from all walks of life.

name: Barbell at Berkeley
description:
Join Barbell at Berkeley, a diverse and inclusive community where everyone passionate about lifting, from Olympic lifting and powerlifting to bodybuilding and strength training, finds a supportive space. We welcome individuals from all backgrounds, regardless of race, gender, sex, or sexual orientation.

Why Join Us?

  • Inclusive Training Community: Our weekly group sessions, PR nights, and advanced lift nights cater to lifters of all levels, offering a nurturing environment for growth and success.

  • Holistic Development: We go beyond lifting, providing specialized content on nutrition, meal planning, and injury prevention, along with beginner-friendly workshops and speaker events that enrich your fitness journey.

  • Community, Empowerment, and Merchandise: Join us for mixers and weekly lifting sessions where we build a community that changes the broader weightlifting culture. Celebrate this spirit with our upcoming Barbell at Berkeley merchandise line, symbolizing our unity in fitness.

  • Partnerships & Collaboration: Through partnerships with facilities like Max's Gym, enjoy access to top-tier equipment and expert coaching at special rates, enhancing your training experience.

Barbell at Berkeley is more than a club; it's a collective where strength is celebrated by all. Join our community and be part of an inclusive strength journey, lifting and growing together.
summary: Our student-led organization celebrates every aspect of lifting, from bodybuilding to powerlifting, Olympic lifting, and beyond. We're dedicated to creating an inclusive space where all students can thrive regardless of their fitness journey.

name: BARE Magazine
description:
BARE Magazine, UC Berkeley’s premier fashion, arts, and lifestyle publication, is a foundational organization within the UC Berkeley community. Our mission is to foster an inclusive and self-expressed community on the UC Berkeley campus, to effectively offer valuable work experience to students, and to encourage and acknowledge the creative power of UC Berkeley students. Producing a biannual print magazine and regular online content, as well as multiple in-staff and student body oriented events throughout the academic year are means to this end. 

 

If you are interested, join us for our info sessions to learn more!

1. August 24th at 7pm on Zoom

2. August 28th at 8pm in Wheeler 202
summary: BARE Magazine is UC Berkeley's premier fashion and art publication.

name: BareStage Productions
description:
BareStage Production's is a CalLink organization. BareStage Productions is the oldest and largest student-run theatre company at the University of California, Berkeley. BareStage offers student actors, directors, writers, musicians, and designers unique experience to practice and hone their craft outside the classroom. We pride ourselves on the pre-professional quality of our work, diversity of available opportunities, and supportive, inclusive environment. In addition, BareTroupe, BareStage's musical theatre group, and BarePage, BareStage's new writing and directing group, provides students with opportunities to perform regularly throughout the school year.

 

......................................................................................................................................................................

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JI9fZXi6ZNQ

 

 

BareStage Productions was formerly named Friends of the Theatre.
summary: BareStage Productions ((Formerly Friends of the Theatre) is a CalLink organization. BareStage Productions is a student-run theatre company that produces two fully-staged plays and musicals every semester.

name: BATS - Association of Taiwanese Students at Berkeley
Bay Advisory Group
summary: Bay Advisory Group is a student-run consultancy at UC Berkeley focused on equipping its clients with strategies to compete in the 21st century.  Leveraging diverse skill sets, BAG approaches contemporary issues through a multidisciplinary lens.

name: Bay Area Environmentally Aware Consulting Network
description:
BEACN will be recruiting new members for the Fall 2023 semester! We will post recruitment info and dates soon, but visit beacn.org/join for more information (or sign up for our mailing list and interest form to get updates). We'll have tabling, so be sure to stop by and learn more about us! 

BEACN is a non-profit business consulting organization focused on sustainability and social responsibility. We've worked with a range of clients, including Fortune 500 businesses, non-profits, government agencies, startups, and law firms.

As a BEACN member, you'll gain valuable project experience by working with real clients to implement sustainable business practices. You'll also join BEACN's vibrant community and make lifelong friends who will support you at Cal and beyond. 

Each of our project teams consists of 5-6 undergraduate students majoring in a diverse set of disciplines, including Chemical Engineering, Business Administration, Environmental Economics and Policy, Music, Energy Engineering, Political Science, City Planning, and Data Science. We offer a variety of consulting services including:

- Business Strategy: Providing management, sales, business development consulting services.
- Policy Analysis: Generating policy reports and white papers outlining policy proposals around sustainability, carbon neutrality, zero-waste, etc.
- Marketing/Branding: Create a brand image and developing marketing strategies through market analysis and consumer research.
- Energy & Environmental Metrics: Calculating cost and energy savings of green products. Creating financial models to assess the feasibility of new policies
- Sustainability: Formulating carbon neutrality policies and renewable energy strategies. 
- Data Visualization: Measuring cradle to grave environmental impact and creating visualizations to represent it.

Prior consulting or business experience is *not* needed to apply—we will teach you the skills needed to perform the tasks listed above!

 

 

beacn.org

facebook.com/beacn

instagram.com/cal.beacn

info@beacn.berkeley.edu
summary: BEACN is a non-profit business consulting organization focused on sustainability and social responsibility. We've worked with a range of clients, including Fortune 500 businesses, non-profits, and government agencies.

name: Bay Area Optometric Council Mentorship Program at Berkeley
description:
The Bay Area Optometric Council Mentorship Program at Berkeley is a professional development initiative that aims to improve optometry student involvement in local optometric societies, California Optometric Association (COA), and American Optometric Association (AOA) through networking, legislative awareness, and career guidance.

(1) Networking:

For many students, it can be difficult to approach and initiate conversation with optometrists at networking events. We hope students will benefit more from attending meetings with a doctor who they can converse with during the event and help make the initial introductions to other optometrists. These students will in turn help their colleagues by opening the door for more students to enter the conversation.

(2) Legislative Awareness:

Optometry is a legislative profession that heavily relies on its advocates to improve scope of practice and community access to vision care. It is important to stress the importance of the students' role in local issues, COA, and AOA in order to improve participation in legislative activities through their school years and post-graduation. The Bay Area Optometric Council Mentorship Program at Berkeley seeks to involve students in local community events, legislative days, and general membership meeting business talks.

(3) Career Guidance:

The program’s mentors come from a wide variety of backgrounds and have varying modes of practice and specialties. Students will gain career guidance by shadowing their mentors and learning about how they have achieved success. Students are encouraged to talk to all mentors in the program, not just their own, to be exposed to a larger variety career options. Mentors can share what they wished they knew as a student and to make the most of their educational experience for their future goals.
summary: The BAOC-MP at Berkeley is a professional development initiative that aims to increase student involvement in local, state, and national optometric associations through networking, legislative awareness, and career guidance from a mentoring optometrist.

name: Bay Area Scientists in Schools at Berkeley
description:
Bay Area Scientists Inspiring Students (BASIS) volunteers foster scientific curiosity by connecting with kids and teachers through hands-on classroom experiences.

BASIS is a science role model volunteer program that connects UC Berkeley graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and undergraduates with students in public elementary schools within the East Bay. There is a huge demand from teachers and students in our community to bring hands-on science and engineering lessons into the classroom! "Tremendous! More, please!" is the top comment from teachers who've had a BASIS visit.

Program Goals

The goals of BASIS are to (1) connect a diverse range of scientist volunteers to elementary school students and teachers, (2) inspire students with examples of real-world science careers and issues, (3) engage with students in hands-on, inquiry based learning experiences, and (4) create effective teaching links between scientists and public elementary schools in the East Bay.

Program Mechanics

UC Berkeley science and engineering students interested in becoming a BASIS volunteer must first sign up for a one-hour on-campus orientation (held on campus). Sign up for an orientation online (http://www.crscience.org/volunteers/signup).

BASIS volunteers then form a teaching team (or join a pre-existing team) comprised of friends and colleagues in their field of study. Volunteers choose dates and times that they are available to visit classrooms and present a one-hour hands-on, inquiry-based lesson with their team. BASIS ensures that these lessons are age-appropriate and aligned with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Teams generally present in one classroom per month over the course of a school year (~10 lessons/year) though there is a high degree of flexibility to accommodate your schedule.

BASIS teams begin by teaching one of the lessons from our database of kid-tested, teacher-approved lessons. Experienced volunteers may also take advantage of training opportunities to develop their own lesson.
summary: Bay Area Scientists Inspiring Students (BASIS) volunteers foster scientific curiosity by connecting with kids and teachers through hands-on classroom experiences.

name: Bay Area Vision Research Day
description: BAVRD is an annual meeting hosted and organized by Vision Science graduate students at UC Berkeley. It is dedicated to facilitating collaboration and discussion among vision researchers in the San Francisco Bay Area across many fields – including neuroscience, computer science, psychology, immunology, molecular biology, bioengineering, optics, optometry, and ophthalmology.
summary: BAVRD is an annual meeting hosted and organized by Vision Science graduate students at UC Berkeley.

name: BBSA at Haas
description:
The Black Business Students Association was established in 1999 and is committed to enriching the academic, professional, and social experience of Haas students from and interested in the African Diaspora. 

Our mission is to foster professional and leadership development, academic excellence, and community involvement.
summary: The mission of BBSA is to uplift and empower the Black community at Haas.

name: BCS Organizing Committee
description:
BCS Organizing Committee aims to organize the event Berkeley China Summit each October. Berkeley China Summit is a full-day on-campus conference organized by UC Berkeley alumni and students. By building a platform where great minds from US and China collide, BCS aims to connect China’s businesses and investors with the technology, engineering, and business innovation expertise on UC Berkeley campus and across the Bay Area.

 

The Theme of past years focused on state-of-art technologies and innovations that have seen a rapid growth in recent years, of which US, especially the Bay Area, and China will continue to be the main contributors and beneficiaries. Potential topics of discussion include Blockchain, Deep Learning, Fintech, Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligent, Business, and Entrepreneurship, etc.
summary: Berkeley China Summit is a full-day on-campus conference. By building a platform where great minds from US and China collide, BCS aims to connect China’s businesses and investors in the bay area.

name: Bear Brain Initiative
description:
GET UPDATES ABOUT BBI -> Instagram: @ucbbbi

The Bear Brain Initiative focuses on a vast variety of neurodegenerative diseases by tackling these issues not only at an interpersonal level, through direct volunteering with affected populations, but also at a federal level via advocacy campaigns. This organization emphasizes the importance of integrating public policy with community service, which is an angle that differs from strictly community service based organizations that focus on such neurodegenerative diseases. Additionally, the inclusive focus on multiple diseases within an overarching category, rather than specifying an exclusive focus on Alzheimer’s Disease, Parkinson's, etc., contributes to the Bear Brain Initiative’s efforts in promoting a safe-space for those who have had personal experiences with, or interest in, neurodegenerative diseases in general.
summary: We aim to promote understanding among students of varying neurodegenerative diseases that affect the elderly population through working with various groups in the Bay Area that focus on providing help to those with neurodegenerative disorders.

name: Bear Closet
description:
MISSION
 

Bear Closet aims to create a platform for LGBTQ+ students to share their personal narratives with middle and high school students in the Bay Area. We encourage members and supporters of the LGBTQ+ community to serve as mentors and advocates for the equality of all identities by sharing their personal journey toward self-love and acceptance. Through class discussions and projects, we will explore LGBTQ+ experiences and learn more about the community and how we can best serve it. In addition, students will also be provided with public speaking opportunities that will help inspire Bay Area youth to take pride in their identity and fight for a stronger, more inclusive future.

WHAT WE DO

Bear Closet is a community-based organization and DeCal course offered at UC Berkeley dedicated to training and preparing students to speak at middle and high schools regarding LGBTQ life at college, through the Pacific Center’s Speaker’s Bureau program. Such services are essential to motivate LGBTQ adolescents to pursue higher education with the reassurance of a better, more inclusive future they may look forward to in college. Our organization and course are open to students of all genders and sexualities (including straight, cisgender allies), and will facilitate students’ volunteer work with LGBTQ support organizations, including the Pacific Center and Center for Educational Partnerships.

We welcome anyone interested in sharing their queer-related stories and experiences (i.e. personal, of a friend/family member, etc.) at middle and high school classrooms, in hopes of motivating out or closeted youth to pursue college education with the assurance of a better future. Rather than strictly focusing on assignments and deadlines, our two-unit DeCal prioritizes class discussion and bonding among its members, for the sake of establishing a strong base for community service.
summary: Bear Closet aims to create a platform for the LGBTQ+ community to share their personal narratives with middle school and high school students in the Berkeley area.

name: Bear Power Fund
description: We are an organization dedicated to the support of Air Force ROTC through fundraising and community service.
summary: We are an organization dedicated to the support of Air Force ROTC through fundraising and community service.

name: Bearettes Drill Team at Berkeley
description: Since our founding in 2015, the Bearettes' mission has been to serve underrepresented communities and the greater Cal community as a group of students who demonstrate diversity, inclusion, and empowerment through performance and discipline. We strive to create a space where students from different backgrounds, communities, and cultures can come together to portray Berkeley through a different lens. The Bearettes aspire to bring spirit to people of color and provide a space for people of color to feel proud showcasing their talents on Berkeley's campus—doing so by honoring and recognizing the history of dance and majorette dance to minority communities.
summary: The Bearettes serves as an essential component of the Cal spirit teams that showcases diversity, inclusion, and empowerment through performance and discipline.

name: Bears for Birds - Audubon at Berkeley
description:
With birdwatching at its nexus, Bears for Birds aims to inspire a connection to the environment and species that we share it with. This club is a campus chapter of the National Audubon Society, a nonprofit with national acclaim that aims to empower citizens with scientific tools to educate themselves and others in their community about ecology.

 

Members of Bears for Birds have full access to Audubon’s network, resources, and employment opportunities — both professional and volunteer — in environmental conservation, ecology, and science. While there are certainly many environmental clubs on campus, Audubon at Berkeley is unique in that it directly associates students with an established and respected national nonprofit that will foster their ability to perform legitimate science without the gatekeeping that often prevents students and budding scientists from participating. 

 

Birdwatching is a unique form of citizen science that has dozens of intersections with ecology, culture, conservation, and education, and because it is so vast in its reach, the opportunities for community engagement and betterment are limitless. Bears for Birds focuses on ways to enable members to learn about the “urban wilderness” of Berkeley and encourage them to conserve birds and their habitats through sociological as well as ecological lenses; the club also extends beyond Cal’s campus and engages in projects to make the broader Bay Area more bird-friendly.
summary: Bears for Birds aims to educate students about local bird species and engage them in regional ecology through citizen science.

name: Bears for Israel
description:
Bears for Israel aims to be an inclusive, pro-active, and pro-Israel voice that promotes open dialogue on the UC Berkeley campus. We advocate for the existence of the Jewish and democratic state. We work to build relationships with various student groups and on and off campus partners in order to form a more educated and informed pro-Israel student body.

We are a mix of students politically, religiously, and ethnically who are interested in learning more about Israel and exploring it from political, cultural, and social perspectives. 

The best way to stay connected is to Like us on Facebook and subscribe to our newsletter (also through Facebook)!
summary: Bears for Israel aims to be an inclusive, pro-active, and pro-Israel voice that promotes open dialogue on the UC Berkeley campus.

name: Behavioral Economics Association at Berkeley
description:
At BEA, you'll get to hear from esteemed speakers, design your own experiments, and work on client facing roles.

Speakers range from Industry Veterans to esteemed professors. 

At the experiment design workshop you'll get to design and pitch your own hypothesis to a panel. 

Through client facing roles, become industry ready on early pipeline work, focus groups, data analysis, and the hypothesis based approach. 

Looking forward to meeting you!
summary: Serve as a common meeting ground for extraordinary minds interested in Behavioral Economics, research, or experiment design.

name: Bellydance at Berkeley
description: Bellydance at Berkeley’s main goal is to provide a space for students to take care of their minds and bodies while learning an underrepresented style of dance. For many busy Berkeley students, finding the time and space to exercise or be involved in leisure activities can be challenging. Dance is a creative outlet where students can express themselves while getting in exercise for the day. Bellydance at Berkeley also aims to highlight the culture that surrounds bellydance and what it means to be a dancer appreciating a non-native style while being aware of boundaries. Bellydance is often overlooked even in the dance world, amongst a wide variety of more Western styles. Bringing this to Berkeley opens up a space for experienced and non-experienced dancers alike to expand their horizons and gives them an opportunity to find a style that sparks interest in them.
summary: We provide a space for students to learn an elegant, stylistic, and underrepresented style of dance. Together, we will appreciate its rich technique and culture.

name: Bengal Gazette
description:
The original Bengal Gazette was started by James Augustus Hicky in 1780 in Calcutta, the then-capital of British India. Hicky’s Bengal Gazette was the first newspaper to be printed in Asia and prided itself on producing provocative, independent journalism. While Hicky’s Bengal Gazette only ran for two years, its spirit lives on in contemporary journalism about the subcontinent, including this very publication. [1]

Today’s Bengal Gazette is a student-run publication based out of Berkeley dedicated to all topics related to Bengal, uniting the voices of Undergraduates, Graduates, Faculty and Alumni here at Cal.

From our history, politics, culture, tradition, art, and literature, to our food, the Bengal Gazette strives to be a timeless platform to write and learn about Bengal.

We are both a print magazine and a mobile platform, hoping to make a presence not just at Cal but throughout the Bangali Diaspora. Hope you read us!
summary: Publication devoted to covering all Bengali related events and topics, such as culture, politics and history

name: BERC Law
description: The purpose of BERC Law is to connect, educate, and engage law students with an interest in energy and resources law. It does this by (1) connecting students at Berkeley Law to energy-related education, opportunities, and resources at UC Berkeley, particularly through the campus-wide Berkeley Energy & Resources Collaborative (BERC) and (2) compiling special information, guidance and peer support to empower students to pursue their education and career goals in energy and resources law.
summary: The purpose of BERC Law is to connect, educate, and engage law students with an interest in energy and resources law.

name: BERC Undergraduate
description: BERCU is a community for undergraduates to plug into all the opportunities that BERC has to offer, addressing global and local energy & resources issues with respect to emerging energy technologies, environmental management, and policies. BERCU helps undergrads find their passion within energy and resources by offering educational events, industrial panels, graduate student mentorship programs, career fairs, and info-sessions, professional networking opportunities, hands-on project-based learning, as well as social events to find like-minded people.
summary: BERC Undergraduate supports students in finding their passion within energy and resources and to provide a network which supports them to take action.

name: BERKE1337 Cyber Security Team
summary: BERKE1337 provides a space for students interested in learning about cybersecurity through talks, competitions, workshops, and industry interactions.

name: Berkeley Art Museum Pacific Film Archive Student Committee
description: The BAMPFA Student Committee aims to connect students to the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive (BAMPFA) through outreach and events. Each semester, we organize activities, small film screenings, and multimedia parties for students. The Committee also has an important role in advocating for students’ interests within the museum operations and on the Board of Trustees. The Student Committee takes applications for new members at the start of every fall semester.
summary: The BAMPFA Student Committee works to connect students and the BAMPFA through outreach and events aimed at all members of the student community.  Each semester, we organize activities, small film screenings, and multimedia parties for students.

name: Berkeley Ballroom Dancers
description:
Berkeley Ballroom is a student-run organization that has been providing classes and ballroom events for dancers in Berkeley and the East Bay for the past 50 years!

We cater to the needs of all dancers, whether experienced or not. Our social dance lessons are taught at the beginner level, but everyone is welcome to attend our dance lessons and events. For all of our events, no partner or experience is required, but if you have one or the other or both we would be happy to see you as well! We also provide dance lessons for engaged couples preparing for their big day, customized to suit their dance levels and personal preferences.

Please contact us for any questions about joining.
summary: Berkeley Ballroom is a student-run organization that has been providing ballroom classes and events for dancers in Berkeley and the East Bay for the past 50 years!

name: Berkeley Business Society
description:
Berkeley Business Society is a tight-knit community of diverse individuals who tackle real-world business problems for leading industry clients. Our consultants choose from one of five consulting projects, each encompassing a different concentration of business. Tailoring the club experience to every individual is our highest priority. We seek to build lasting relationships, as well as provide an unparalleled network of mentors and archive of professional resources. It is our hope that in BBS you will find an area of business that interests you, meaningful professional experience, and a lifelong community.

 

Our 5 Consulting Concentrations

  1. Media: Work with a large-scale, industry-leading media corporation to solve real-world business problems while honing your research and analytical skills
  2. Finance: Develop quantitative strategy for a corporation or financial services firm by identifying and modeling novel opportunities for growth via investment
  3. Marketing: Design innovative solutions for a company to advance its branding and customer relations by developing campaigns and strategies that combine performance with creativity
  4. Social Impact: Deliver actionable recommendations for a nonprofit organization to solve its business problems through the employment of strategic analysis to create sustainable social impact
  5. Technology: Create high-impact solutions while gaining a deep understanding of the unique problems faced by a technology-based company through hands-on experience alongside entrepreneurs

Visit our website for more information: berkeleybusinesssociety.com
summary: Berkeley Business Society is a tight-knit community of diverse individuals who tackle real-world business problems for leading industry clients through one of five consulting projects, each encompassing a different concentration of business.

name: Berkeley Cambodian Students Association
description:
