The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Cambodian culture by fostering an appreciation of that culture.

Over the years, the BCSA has evolved to place greater emphasis upon recognizing and sharing the Cambodian-American experience with the UC Berkeley community. The Cambodian-American story is neither a relic of the past nor an inert fact of today. Thus, the Berkeley Cambodian Student Association aims to reclaim Cambodian cultural and political histories, create socially aware individuals, inspire leadership and service, and bridge generations. We aim to eliminate the invisibility of the Cambodian-American community and empower its members.
summary: The Berkeley Cambodian Student Association was originally founded to unite and support people who share an interest in Cambodia and Southeast Asian culture through healing, acknowledgement, and community. We welcome all students from AA/NH/PI communities

name: Berkeley Carillon Guild
description:
If you are interested in playing the carillon or play the carillon and want to become associated with the Sather Tower Carillon here at Berkeley, please contact us (calbells@gmail.com) or the University Carillonist Jeff Davis (ucbells@berkeley.edu) for more information.

For more information about the Campanile, please see http://bells.berkeley.edu
summary: Berkeley Carillon Guild fosters relationships among students, alumni, and staff of the Sather Tower Carillon, addresses the problems of carillon students on campus, and provides awareness regarding the carillon program to the campus and community

name: Berkeley Chinese Students and Scholars Association
description: Berkeley Chinese Students and Scholars Association (BCSSA) is a student organization registered at ASUC (Associated Students of the University of California) on Berkeley campus. We are a non-profit and non-political organization dedicated to social, intellectual and cultural activities for Chinese students and scholars at UC Berkeley as well as other interested members in the Berkeley community. We have nearly 5000 registered members and is still in rapid growth.
summary: Berkeley Chinese Students and Scholars Association is a non-profit organization dedicated to promote social, intellectual and cultural activities for UC Berkeley Chinese students.

name: Berkeley Christian Fellowship
description:
We are a student Christian fellowship brought together by faith and biblical truth.

This semester, our theme will be "Redeeming the Times" based on Eph 5:15-16, so we will be studying how we can make our lives useful and meaningful in the eyes of God.

If you are interested in joining or attending our meetings, please contact us via our Instagram page www.instagram.com/berkeleychristianfellowship or to find our more about our beliefs, you can visit www.tjc.org.
summary:
We are a student Christian fellowship brought together by faith and biblical truth.

If you are interested in learning more, please contact us via our Instagram page www.instagram.com/berkeleychristianfellowship

name: Berkeley College Republicans
description: The Berkeley College Republicans is one of the largest and most active student run organizations at UC Berkeley and is the largest College Republican organization in the state of California. BCR offers Berkeley students the opportunity to have truly civil, open discussion of the issues of the day.
summary: The Berkeley College Republicans is one of the largest and most active student run organizations at UC Berkeley and is the largest College Republican organization in the state of California.

name: Berkeley Consulting
description:
As Berkeley’s first established consulting organization, BC has the privilege of providing its services across a broad spectrum of organizations. We work on semester-long engagements to provide valuable research insights and actionable recommendations to our clients. We are devoted to delivering high-impact solutions and pride ourselves on our ability to catalyze meaningful change within the organizations we work with as well as our close-knit culture. 

 

Check out our website at bc.berkeley.edu for more information
summary: Berkeley Consulting (BC) is an student-run nonprofit management consulting organization that provides innovative solutions to core business problems faced by its clients. Founded in 1996, BC is the first established consulting organization at UC Berkeley.

name: Berkeley Disaster Team
description:
The Berkeley Disaster Team (BDT) is a volunteer, student-led organization that helps prepare UC Berkeley for disasters and aids in non-medical campus disaster response. We are sponsored by the Office of Emergency Management (OEM)

The BDT's Mission:

  1. PREPARE the campus for disasters through presentations and outreach
  2. TRAIN students to perform non-medical disaster response
  3. AID UC Berkeley in disasters when mobilized by the OEM
  4. FOSTER interest in disaster management, preparedness, and resilience

The BDT augments campus response by:

  • Staffing the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) and supporting ESF Operational Centers
  • Managing resources and disaster logistics
  • Supporting victims through psychological first-aid
  • Organizing mass care (shelter setup and operations)
  • Registering and supervising spontaneous (untrained) volunteers
  • Distributing food, supplies, and information

Interested in getting involved? Check out our website at bdt.berkeley.edu or email us at BerkeleyDisasterTeam@berkeley.edu. And follow us on Facebook page to stay in the loop about campus preparedness!

Formerly known as Berkeley Disaster Response Team (BDRT)
summary: The Berkeley Disaster Team (BDT) helps prepare UC Berkeley for disasters and aids in non-medical campus disaster response by staffing the Emergency Operations Center and performing field work. Sponsored by the Office of Emergency Management and UCPD.

name: Berkeley Energy and Resources Collaborative (Graduate group)
description:
The Berkeley Energy & Resources Collaborative (BERC) is a multidisciplinary network of UC Berkeley students, alumni, faculty, industry professionals, and advisors who seek to turn world-leading research into world-changing solutions by tackling tough and timely energy and environmental challenges.

More specifically, BERC’s mission is to connect, educate, and engage its members in order to foster innovation and action. To that end, BERC:

  • Connects nearly 3,000 members as a part of a broad, cross-disciplinary network of students, faculty and professionals in the fields of energy and resources;
  • Educates students about cutting edge work in energy and resources through organizing events, lectures, and treks; and
  • Engages members by providing opportunities to address global energy and resources issues and collaborate on real-world projects.

Please signup at http://berc.berkeley.edu by clicking the 'join' button in the top right corner.

Find our full events calendar at http://berc.berkeley.edu/events
summary: BERC is a multidisciplinary network of UC Berkeley students, alumni, faculty, industry professionals, and advisors who seek to turn world-leading research into world-changing solutions by tackling tough and timely energy and environmental challenges.

name: Berkeley Environmental Economics and Policy Students
description:
BEEPS builds an academic, professional development, and social community for all students interested in Environmental Economics and Policy. They cultivate a hub of resources and support that connects students with peers, professors, alumni, and industry professionals through networking events, a mentorship program, and speaker events. Most importantly, BEEPS fosters a community of connected students interested in EEP by hosting social events. https://linktr.ee/calbeeps

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=79ZMK-LcIlI
summary: BEEPS connects current and prospective Environmental Economics and Policy students with their peers, professors, alumni, and relevant industry professionals.

name: Berkeley Fiction Review
description:
The Berkeley Fiction Review is a UC Berkeley undergraduate, student-run publication and is one of several descendants of UC Berkeley’s Occident literary journal, which was published from 1881 to the 1960s. Established in 1981 by Julia Littleton, Jenne Mowry, Joe Sciallo, and Paul Wedderien, BFR is now UC Berkeley’s oldest prose journal. In 2012, the Berkeley Fiction Review was named “Best Literary Publication” on campus by the Associated Students of the University of California.
 
We look for innovative and reflective short fiction from new and emerging writers from around the world across all genres that play with form and content, as well as traditionally constructed stories with fresh voices and original ideas that say something new or bring nuance and perspective to an ongoing cultural conversation. We invite submissions of previously unpublished short stories year-round and publish annually. We nominate to O. Henry, Best American Short Stories, and Pushcart prizes.
 
Our DeCal class takes place during both semesters of the school year. Members of the class read submissions for the journal and vote on them in class. The goal of the class is to teach foundational skills within the publishing and media industry as well as giving students experience in publishing quality short fiction.

Over the course of the semester we will determine qualities of a good story, as well as learn about the publishing process. The class is graded pass/not pass, and can be taken for 1-2 units. No experience is necessary; all Berkeley students are welcome. We also welcome auditors.

 
Berkeley students interested in enrolling in our DeCal class for Spring 2024 can fill out this enrollment form: TBA
 

Berkeley students interested in enrolling in our DeCal class must also attend a mandatory info session on DATE TBD.
summary: The Berkeley Fiction Review is UC Berkeley's premier prose journal. We publish a print anthology that includes artwork and 12-15 short stories from around the world as well as an online magazine focused on book reviews, culture, and personal essays.

name: Berkeley Forum, The
description:
The Berkeley Forum is a non-partisan forum for the expression and debate of a wide range of ideas. Founded in 2012, the Forum organizes panels, debates, and talks by leading experts and distinguished persons on issues both topical and timeless. Forum events are open to the public and will be broadcast online and shared on our YouTube channel.

The Forum is run entirely by undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley, and it is advised by a committee of distinguished professors. Members of the Berkeley Forum are motivated, intellectually curious students from a diverse range of academic and professional backgrounds. The Forum provides students valuable first-hand experience and a channel to explore and challenge the ideas that motivate them.

Our Organization

The guiding authority of the Forum rests in the President and an Executive Committee, composed of the President and six Vice Presidents. The President and Executive Committee of the Forum are responsible for the day-to-day operations, the long-term growth, and the success of the Forum in leading with all general members and Leadership.

Forum operations are carried out by six standing committees, each of which is chaired by a Vice President and supported by Leadership and general members. Each standing committee plays a central role in the planning and realization of Forum events. The Programming Committee recruits a diverse lineup of guest speakers. The Events Committee handles travel and accommodation arrangements and creates the program of Forum events. The Communications Committee publicizes all Forum events and serves as curator of the organization’s brand and graphic standards. The Finance Committee handles all monetary expenditures of the Forum and ensures our events stay free to the student body. The Moderating Committee trains and develops student moderators to write well-researched questions and moderate each of our events. The Systems and Technology Committee supports cross-functional projects benefiting the Forum in the spaces of Multimedia, Software, and Data Analytics.

The Forum also houses a variety of divisions that give members the opportunity to work on specialized tasks and projects. Each division is chaired by a Director. A Membership division oversees membership recruiting and retention; a Social Affairs division oversees the integration and social culture of the organization via Retreat, socials, and Banquet; a Development division serves to continuously involve members in the growth of our organization, housing special projects, our DEI Working Group, Professional Development, and Alumni Relations.

Our Mission

The mission of the Berkeley Forum is to provide the Berkeley community a non-partisan forum for the presentation and debate of a wide range of ideas; to reaffirm the value of a liberal arts education; and to regularly organize, promote, and broadcast debates, panels, and talks by distinguished persons, and any such events, activities, or conversations as shall engage and challenge the faculties of the mind.

Admission to Forum events

Admission to Forum Events is free for all members of the Forum and persons affiliated with the University of California, Berkeley. This includes students, professors, administrators, and other staff members.
summary: The Berkeley Forum is a non-partisan forum for the expression and debate of a wide range of ideas. Founded in 2012, the Forum organizes talks, panels, and debates by leading experts and distinguished persons on issues both topical and timeless.

name: Berkeley Graduate, The
summary: The Berkeley Graduate

name: Berkeley Immigration Group (Formerly Boalt Immigration Group)
description:
Berkeley Immigration Group’s (BIG) mission is to support the rights of detained immigrants by doing pro bono work through an abolitionist lens. Students will have the opportunity to work alongside attorneys and other BIG members to provide legal services to non-citizens held in immigrant detention.

This group Berkeley Immigration Group was formerly named Boalt Immigration Group - 9/3/20 IZ (PLC)
summary: BIG aims to unite a community of students passionate about immigration law.

name: Berkeley Indonesian Student Association
description:
The Berkeley Indonesian Student Association (BISA) was established in 1985. BISA's main purpose is to create stronger friendships between Indonesian students at UC Berkeley and help create greater awareness of Indonesian culture. BISA strongly believes in the essentiality of this action because there is something uniquely diverse and fascinating about being able to speak your own language with a close group of people, in a setting so foreign and far away from home.

Indonesia is a rapidly developing country. It is one of the fastest growing economies in the world and is home to a multitude of great historical monuments and young intellectual minds. Through connecting students with keynote characters, alumni, and each other, BISA aims to be a platform of learning for its members where they can also inspire, and more importantly, be inspired.

BISA was created by the students and for the students. Through continuously building a larger and closer community, we aim to support each other as the people we are now and the people we will soon become.
summary: Berkeley Indonesian Student Association (BISA) was established in 1985. BISA hopes to foster a strong sense of community among Indonesian students and create greater awareness of Indonesian culture at UC Berkeley.

name: Berkeley Innovation
description:
Berkeley Innovation is a human-centered design group at UC Berkeley. Founded in 2003, our members come from a wide range of disciplines, but share a common love for design thinking and innovation.

 

Each semester, we work on design projects that give members hands-on experience with the entire design process, from conducting user research to building and marketing prototypes. We exist as a community for students who are interested in design to develop their design thinking skills and experience. We also run the Human-Centered Design DeCal—an introductory, project-based course teaching the fundamentals of design (learn more at hcd-decal.org).

 

Engage with us! Follow our Instagram @berkeleyinnovation and learn more about our process and work at berkeleyinnovation.org

 

*Name approved by OMBO 3/17/09
summary: Berkeley Innovation is a human-centered design group at UC Berkeley. Founded in 2003, our members come from a wide range of disciplines, but share a common love for design thinking and innovation.

name: Berkeley Investment Group
description: We run a student-raised investment fund, giving the Berkeley Community the opportunity to participate and gain experience in the world of investing. We bring in numerous financial speakers, run specialized educational programs and mock trading competitions, and organize professional workshops.
summary: Semester long Analyst Internship; Lectures on Investment Strategies; Open-Forum Discussions; Hands-On Analysis of Companies/Industries; Real and Virtual Investing; Guest Speakers on Special Topics; Professional Workshops; Career Leads for Finance Jobs

name: Berkeley Journal of Criminal Law
description:
The Berkeley Journal of Criminal Law provides a forum for the discussion of regional, national, and international criminal law issues. Since its inception in 2000, the journal has published cutting-edge scholarship by professors, judges, research fellows, clerks, and law students from across the country. In addition to our publication, we host regular events to engage students, faculty and the larger community in discussions about important contemporary topics in criminal law and social justice.

We seek submissions from scholars, students, and practitioners in both the private and public sectors. In addition to traditional scholarly articles, BJCL will consider book reviews, practice-oriented pieces, and student notes. While the journal publishes work covering a broad range of traditional topics in both substantive and procedural criminal law, we are also interested in articles that discuss issues unique to California and other western states.

BJCL publishes on an ongoing basis and is completely digital (though authors can get hard-copy prints). We publish our Fall Edition in January and our Spring Edition in June.
summary: The Berkeley Journal of Criminal Law provides a forum for the discussion of regional, national, and international criminal law issues. The journal regularly publishes cutting-edge scholarship from professors, judges, research fellows, and law students.

name: Berkeley Journal of Employment and Labor Law
summary: The Berkeley Journal of Employment and Labor Law (formerly Industrial Labor Relations Law Journal) presents current developments in the labor and employment law field to scholars, practitioners, and students.

name: Berkeley Journal of Entertainment and Sports Law
description: The Berkeley Journal of Entertainment & Sports Law (BJESL) is a student-run publication and scholarly community dedicated to fostering high-level, timely discussion of legal issues that contemporaneously impact the entertainment and sports world, both domestically and internationally. As an interactive and completely-online law journal, BJESL presents a unique platform for rich, diverse legal analysis that will serve scholars, practitioners, and students in these fields. Issues will contain approximately four articles by professors, practitioners, or students on current topics relating to sports and entertainment law.
summary: The Berkeley Journal of Entertainment & Sports Law (BJESL) is a student-run publication and scholarly community dedicated to fostering high-level, timely discussion of legal issues that contemporaneously impact the entertainment and sports world.

name: Berkeley Journal of Gender, Law & Justice
description:
BGLJ’s primary activity during the school year is to publish one annual volume of intersectional feminist legal scholarship. This process includes selection of scholarship through a consensus-inspired process of voting by our membership, and through the multi-phase editorial process. Members meet on a bi-weekly basis to discuss the merits of proposed academic articles.

In addition to the publication of our journal, we sponsor and co-sponsor events relating to the editorial mandate of our journal such as our own annual symposium and other co-sponsored symposia, lectures, and discussions.  This year we also plan to host more social events related to gender’s intersection with other axes of subordination such as race, class, sexual orientation, and disability.

Since we also act as a source of community and belonging for members, we also provide a number of supportive programs and services particularly for our members, such as an outline bank, a library of study aids, office resources, membership mentoring, and alumni networking.
summary: Our mandate is to publish feminist legal scholarship that critically examines the intersection of gender with one or more other axes of subordination, including, but not limited to, race, class, sexual orientation, and disability.

name: Berkeley Journal of International Law
description: Please see https://www.law.berkeley.edu/library/ir/bjil/ for further information.
summary: BJIL is a student-run journal at Berkeley Law publishing on a broad range of scholarship in public international, private international, and comparative law.

name: Berkeley Journal of Sociology
summary: A graduate student journal that publishes essays, photo essays, commentary and interviews on contemporary social and societal issues, online and in print.

name: Berkeley Law & Organizing Collective
description: The Berkeley Law and Organizing Collective (BLOC) provides law students with an opportunity to provide legal support for worker organizing on the Berkeley campus.  BLOC members work closely with UAW Local 2865, the largest academic student employee union in the country. Students gain familiarity with national and California labor law by doing legal research to support the union’s organizing goals. We approach our work from a movement lawyering perspective focused on building the capacity and power of working people.
summary: The Berkeley Law and Organizing Collective (BLOC) introduces law students to the world of labor advocacy. BLOC members work closely with UAW Local 2865, the largest academic student employee union in the country.

name: Berkeley Law Anti-Trafficking Project
description:
BATPro’s mission is to prevent, address, and combat all forms of human trafficking occurring in the Bay Area. BATPro was formed to address the high rate of Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC) in Alameda County. Today, BATPro continues its work to prevent domestic CSEC while also addressing international trafficking by supporting legal advocates of trafficking survivors. BATPro is also committed to raising awareness about local human trafficking issues on the law school campus and in the Berkeley community at large.

More information can be found at https://berkeleylawantitraffickingproject.wordpress.com/ as well as https://www.law.berkeley.edu/experiential/pro-bono-program/slps/current-slps-projects/boalt-anti-trafficking-project-boalt-atp/
summary: Berkeley Law Anti-Trafficking Project is a Berkeley Law Student Lead Program (SLP) aimed at combating human trafficking worldwide.

name: Berkeley Legal Studies Association
description: The Berkeley Legal Studies Association (BLSA) strives to create a community of individuals interested in law. BLSA events include LSAT workshops, lunches with Legal Studies professors, speaker panels, The Living Catalogue (where professors speak about their upcoming classes), and many, many other enjoying and interesting opportunities! BLSA also organizes and publishes the California Legal Studies Journal, a forum for high-quality undergraduate research relating to a large range of law-related topics. For more information and event updates, please feel free to join our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/berkeleylegalstudies/?ref=bookmarks
summary: The Berkeley Legal Studies Association (BLSA) is a pre-law organization affiliated with the Legal Studies Department, but open to ALL STUDENTS interested in law.

name: Berkeley Medical Reserve Corps
description:
The Berkeley Medical Reserve Corps (BMRC) is a deployable unit of healthcare volunteers that can be called on to serve in times of local, state, or federal emergencies. We are composed mostly of EMTs, and provide opportunities for members to use their licenses, refresh their skills, and serve the Berkeley community in a number of efforts. We work closely with the Office of Emergency Management and University Health Services in preparing campus for emergency scenarios. We currently provide medical support for Cal Athletics events such as Cal football and basketball games, participate in several large-scale emergency drills in the Bay Area, regularly teach CPR classes for community members, and partner with other local healthcare organizations to provide a diversity of experiences for our volunteers. 

To join, look out for our First General Meeting at the start of every semester! Follow us on our Facebook page in order to receive that information and more!
summary: To unite student EMTs (emergency medical technicians) and those interested in being EMTs on campus, providing opportunities to use their licenses, refreshish their skills, and offerish a forum to discuss EMS as it relates to Berkeley and beyond.

name: Berkeley Model United Nations Conference (Formerly known as Berkeley Model United Nations)
description:
A little about us:

Berkeley Model United Nations is a student-run organization on the UC Berkeley campus dedicated to planning and hosting the biggest Model United Nations conference on the West Coast. Every March, over 2,000 high school students from all over the world come to Berkeley to participate in Berkeley Model United Nations. Entering its 72st session, BMUN’s mission is to spread awareness of international issues and the spirit of diplomacy through UN simulations. We also aim to create an educational experience for high school students, to help them realize their potential in public speaking as well as policy debate. We do this by serving as head chairs on a diverse group of committees in which we help to facilitate delegate education through substantive diplomatic debate.
summary: We are an International Relations Non-profit that works to provide educational opportunities for students in the Bay Area. We host a 2000+ person conference in the spring of each year to raise money for our chosen philanthropic cause each year.

name: Berkeley New Music Project
description: The Berkeley New Music Project (BNMP) is a collective of UC Berkeley's graduate-level composers and composition faculty within the UC Berkeley Department of Music whose aim is to promote contemporary music and art. As a result of our efforts, we have been able to organize public concerts of our music in collaboration with esteemed local and international artists.
summary: BNMP helps to produce new music works by UC Berkeley Graduate and Faculty composers, as well as those artists affiliated with the university.

name: Berkeley Organization for Animal Advocacy
description:
The Berkeley Organization for Animal Advocacy (BOAA) is Cal's premier animal justice organization! Join us if you're an animal lover, life-long vegan, or anywhere in between. We are completely inclusive and love any students who want to change the world, undergraduate or graduate!

Our vision is of a world where all individuals are safe, happy, and free. We host community events, do political outreach, and hold non-violent demonstrations to create social change. In the past we've lobbied at the Berkeley City Council, passed a local Animal Sentience Resolution, and hosted panels on intersectionality between animal rights and other issues.

In addition to taking action for animals, we frequently host solidarity events with labor groups, houseless communities, and food justice organizations on-campus. Factory farming and animal oppression affects the non-human world, but also low-income communities, people of color, and the health and culture of our society. We stand in firm solidarity with other social justice groups and are dedicated to total liberation for humans and animals alike.

Join us in Fall 2023! You can join just to come to animal sanctuaries, hikes or veg-friendly cooking socials! OR, join our intern program to campaign for animal liberation. Weekly general meetings are Thursdays, 7-8pm in Dwinelle 179.

Follow us for updates on Instagram: @boaa_ucb

Or join our Slack: https://boaa2022-2023.slack.com/join/shared_invite/zt-24cjvsslz-QaYTDIHzQHOKhXEuQnuu7g#/shared-invite/email
summary: BOAA is Cal's premier animal rights organization! We take political action for animals and create a community for activists at Berkeley.

name: Berkeley Poetry Review
description:
The Berkeley Poetry Review has been published at the University of California, Berkeley, since 1974. It has earned the distinction of being one of the premier student-managed journals in the country. We’ve featured the work of both new and established poets and writers, including Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Yusef Komunyakaa, Brenda Hillman, Czesław Miłosz, Cole Swensen, Robert Hass, Ishmael Reed, Thom Gunn, and many others from the Bay Area poetry community. We seek language-based and/or experimental writing, translations, art, and (less frequently) essays and interviews. We are particularly interested in work that complicates prevailing conceptions of race, gender, sexuality, ecology, poetic form, and narrative voice.

 

Berkeley Poetry Review is distributed nationwide through bookstores, libraries, and our online store.
summary: Berkeley Poetry Review (BPR) is the University of California, Berkeley's longest-running poetry journal, published annually since 1974. It is widely regarded as one of the premier student-managed journals in the country.

name: Berkeley Political Review, The
description:
The Berkeley Political Review was founded in the aftermath of the September 11, 2001 attacks by UC Berkeley students who wanted to offer a source of impartial analysis on the issues that most affect students and the world we live in.

Since then, BPR has covered five presidential elections, the war in Iraq, the expansion and subsequent erosion of the European Union, immigration raids, drone strikes, the Great Recession, 20 years of Berkeley protest movements, the politics of ethanol, the approval of new medications, divestment from fossil fuels, the COVID-19 pandemic, and everything in between.

We strive to provide cutting, original journalism on both the topics that dominate global headlines and those that slip beneath the radar of major press outlets. We have always been and remain entirely run by undergraduate students, from our newest staff writers to our most veteran editors and from our financial management to our coverage of Indian politics.

If you would like to support our mission of producing a free and high-quality campus publication and cultivating the next generation of truth-seeking journalists, please donate here using our name.
summary: UC Berkeley's only non-partisan political magazine. Read the Review and learn more at bpr.berkeley.edu!

name: Berkeley Public Policy Journal
description: The Berkeley Public Policy Journal is a student-led publication of the Goldman School of Public Policy at the University of California, Berkeley. The Journal engages readers in a public dialogue on current policy issues, reflecting the diverse views of our students, faculty, and alumni. We publish articles that critique, analyze, and provide recommendations on critical issues with the goal of influencing policy leaders.
summary: As the student-run journal of the Goldman School of Public Policy at the University of California, Berkeley, we are dedicated to providing a forum for policy-related articles that span a wide range of topics.

name: Berkeley Science Review
description: The Berkeley Science Review is a magazine run by graduate students that aims to educate the campus community about groundbreaking research at UC Berkeley and to foster discussion of current science policy issues facing the Berkeley community. We also aim to train scientists and nonscientists to communicate scientific research to the public in a manner that is engaging and accessible to nonspecialist readers.
summary: The Berkeley Science Review is a graduate student volunteer-run magazine that aims to educate the campus community about groundbreaking research at UC Berkeley and to foster discussion of current science policy issues facing the Berkeley

name: Berkeley Scientific Journal
description:
BSJ is the premier undergraduate research journal of the University of California, Berkeley. Every semester, our undergraduate staff publishes independent research done by undergraduates at UC Berkeley, interviews with faculty members, and features articles on current issues in science. All research papers and features articles are reviewed by faculty members. The initial purpose of the journal was to provide an official forum in which Berkeley undergraduates could publish their independent research. But since its inception in 1996, the purpose of the journal has expanded to give the Berkeley scientific community a better understanding of how events here at Berkeley impact global concerns. The focus of the journal is broad, spanning scientific disciplines ranging from ecology to engineering, from astronomy to biochemistry. Our intended audience includes, but is not limited to, UC Berkeley students, faculty, and the surrounding community. A new issue of BSJ is published twice a year on eScholarship, Issuu, and our website. 

See our website, bsj.berkeley.edu, for more information on the journal, and decal.berkeley.edu for a link to our application. You must submit an application to our DeCal for consideration as part of our journal; we do not accept membership requests through CalLink.
summary: BSJ is a biannually published, student-run journal featuring interviews with faculty members from various fields, undergraduate research projects spanning a broad range of scientific disciplines, and features articles revolving around a central theme.

name: Berkeley Student Leadership Academy
description:
The Berkeley Student Leadership Academy is a series of engaging workshops and customized experiences that help undergraduate students develop leadership competencies. The workshops relate to leadership, engagement, and diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB) on campus.

Registered participants will receive information about Berkeley Student Leadership Academy workshop series, specialized content, and access to mentorship and networking opportunities.

Visit the Berkeley Student Leadership Academy website for more information.
summary: The Berkeley Student Leadership Academy is a series of engaging workshops and customized experiences that help undergraduate students develop leadership competencies.

name: Berkeley Technology Law Journal
description:
The Berkeley Technology Law Journal is a student-run publication of University of California, Berkeley School of Law. We started in March 1985, published our first issue in Spring 1986, and have since covered emerging issues of law in the areas of intellectual property, high-technology and biotechnology. BTLJ strives to keep judges, policymakers, practitioners, and the academic community abreast of this dynamic field.

The Journal’s membership, typically over 100 students, publishes four issues of scholarly work each year, including the Annual Review of Law and Technology. The Annual Review is a distinctive issue of the Journal published in collaboration with the Berkeley Center for Law and Technology and is dedicated to student-written case notes and comments discussing the most important recent developments in IP, antitrust, cyberlaw, telecom, biotech and business law. In addition, the Journal co-sponsors an annual symposium on an emerging area of technology law.
summary: The Berkeley Technology Law Journal is a student-run publication of University of California, Berkeley School of Law covering emerging issues of law in the areas of intellectual property, high-technology, and biotechnology.

name: Berkeley Tennis Association (Formerly Tennis at Cal)
description:
Since its establishment in 2003, Berkeley Tennis Association (formerly Tennis at Cal) has expanded into the largest tennis club on campus with over 150 members in 2023 and growing. BTA provides its members with experiences, lessons, and memories that will last a lifetime!

Our purpose is to provide opportunities for the UC Berkeley community to compete and socialize with other members of the tennis community. BTA is a social and casual club that encourages members of all levels to not only better their tennis game but to connect with others who share the same passion for tennis.

We hold optional practices, social events, and tournaments throughout the semester. It's a great way to meet other tennis players, learn, or improve your game. All skill levels are welcome!

In order to become a member of BTA, you must fill out our membership form and pay dues. Our Facebook group is our primary method of communication. Check out our promo video for 2020-21 on YouTube.
summary: Our purpose is to provide opportunities for the UC Berkeley community to compete and socialize with other members of the community who share an interest in tennis at the Berkeley campus.

name: Berkeley Undergraduate Journal
description:
Established in 1987, The Berkeley Undergraduate Journal is the oldest undergraduate research journal at UC Berkeley. We publish exemplary, original undergraduate research papers in the social sciences and humanities. 

Submission applications will soon be open in September for Fall 2023. See our website for details. 

Fill out our interest form here! We will finish Fall recruitment Wednesday, 9/20.
summary: Established in 1987, The Berkeley Undergraduate Journal is the oldest undergraduate research journal at UC Berkeley. We publish exemplary, original undergraduate research papers in the social sciences and humanities.

name: Berkeley Urban Studies Student Association
description: BUSSA is a community of Urban Studies majors, City Planning minors, and other students interested in urban and regional planning. BUSSA hosts events—including urban walks, firm visits, and speaker events—for students to network and experience the Bay Area’s urban environment. In Spring 2023, we will meet every Wednesday 5-6 PM in Wurster 314B. For more information, please fill out this interest form: https://forms.gle/JEYtPUV53fcvafVu5.
summary: BUSSA is a community of Urban Studies majors, City Planning minors, and any other UC Berkeley student interested in urban and regional planning.

name: Berkeley Women in Business
description:
Berkeley Women in Business (BWIB) was founded in 2005 by a group of dedicated and enthusiastic female Berkeley students hoping to pursue professional careers in business.

The current purpose of Berkeley Women in Business is to foster professional development, provide career-networking opportunities, and educate our members about the contemporary issues that continue to dominate the world of business today.

We strive to develop our members into well-rounded individuals with the skills necessary for future employment in professional industries. Our workshops are aimed at increasing our members' understanding of areas such as finance, consulting, and technology.
summary: The mission of Berkeley Women in Business (BWIB) is to empower the business leaders of tomorrow through leadership development and discourse about gender equity in the workforce.

name: Best Buddies at Berkeley
description:
Best Buddies is the world’s largest organization dedicated to ending the social, physical, and economic isolation of the 200 million people with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD). Our program is dedicated to establishing a global volunteer movement to empower the special abilities of people with IDD by creating opportunities for one-to-one friendships, integrated employment, leadership development, and inclusive living.


Founded in 1989 by Anthony K. Shriver, Best Buddies is a vibrant organization that has grown from one original chapter to nearly 3,000 chapters worldwide, positively impacting the lives of over 1.3 million people with and without IDD. Best Buddies engages participants in each of the 50 states and in 50 countries around the world.

By joining Best Buddies at UC Berkeley, you will form meaningful one-to-one friendships with those with IDD, which will help them secure successful jobs, live independently, improve public speaking, self-advocacy and communication skills, and feel valued by society. https://www.bestbuddies.org/
summary: Best Buddies is a nonprofit organization dedicated to establishing a global volunteer movement, creating opportunities for one-to-one friendships, integrated employment, and leadership development for people with intellectual & developmental disabilities

name: Best Laid Plans
description: Best Laid Plans aims to provide an open space for people to be creative and have fun, through improvisational theater, comedy, and performance. BLP members will work hard to hone improv skills, learn, entertain others, and have an enjoyable experience.
summary: Best Laid Plans aims to provide an open space for people to be creative and have fun, through improvisational theater, comedy, and performance. BLP members will work hard to hone improv skills, learn, entertain others, and have an enjoyable experience

name: Beta Corporate Solutions
description:
At Beta Corporate Solutions, we provide our consultants with invaluable experiences by developing their teamwork, communication, and analytical skill sets in real-world consulting projects for our corporate clients. Our mission is to establish a relationship of mutual benefits between students and businesses by providing innovative research and viable solutions.

Each year, our student consultants pursue successful careers in management consulting, finance, and technology, at firms like McKinsey, Bain, BCG, Deloitte, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley, Apple, Facebook, etc. 

To learn more about how to get involved, please contact Leon Jia at leonjia@berkeley.edu.
summary: Our mission is to establish a relationship of mutual benefits between students and businesses. We strive to improve a business' potential by providing innovative research and viable solutions to external clients.

name: Beta Sigma Kappa
description:
Beta Sigma Kappa (BSK) is an International Optometric Honor Society, which serves more than 2,300 active members worldwide. The mission of BSK is to stimulate scientific achievement, academic excellence, and the ethical practice of optometry; and to promote and provide financial support for worthy research projects relating to vision care and the eyes. Membership in BSK is yearly, and eligibility is based on academic grade point averages.

The goal of the Berkeley chapter of Beta Sigma Kappa is to help optometry students achieve academic and clinical success through our tutoring service. In order to provide enough tutors, BSK requires its second-year and third-year active members to complete 2 hours of tutoring to underclassmen per semester. These hours can be fulfilled by tutoring for didactic courses and clinical skills, participating in BSK-sponsored events, or contributing to BSK-sponsored academic resources for students.
summary: Beta Sigma Kappa is an optometric honor society. The goal of the Berkeley chapter is to help optometry students achieve academic and clinical success through our tutoring service.

name: Beyond Academia
description:
Beyond Academia is a grassroots student organization that helps PhD students and postdocs find careers outside of the tenure-track. We offer free seminars and heavily subsidized conferences to help our fellow graduate students learn about rewarding careers where their skills are needed and appreciated. We help to bridge the gap between the between graduate students and postdocs and the career opportunities that exist for them in various fields.

Want to join us?

If you're a Berkeley graduate student or postdoc, please get in touch: info@beyondacademia.berkeley.edu. We'd love to chat more. 

Want to attend an event?

Sign up for our mailing list at https://beyondacademia.berkeley.edu
summary: Beyond Academia is a career education group that exposes UC Berkeley PhD students and postdocs to career options outside of academia. Panels, workshops, and networking events give attendees the opportunity to interact with successful professionals.

name: Bhagat Puran Singh Health Initiative at Berkeley
description:
Bhagat Puran Singh Health Initiative is a group of wellness advocates devoted to eliminating health and social disparities within underserved and underprivileged immigrant populations by creating spaces of community engagement and providing access to health education for the betterment of the mind, body, and spirit. We work to provide opportunities to engage with each other, volunteering at our free clinics, pursuing research and data collection, and working with nurses and doctors. Read the application descriptions below to learn more how you can be involved in BPSHI!! We hope everyone has an equal experience and a platform to voice their opinions. Everyone is welcome to join and apply. 

General Member Apps: bit.ly/bpshigenmem22

Intern Apps: bit.ly/bpshi-intern22

 

To join our newsletter for frequent updates, please sign up here bit.ly/bpshinewsletter
summary: Bhagat Puran Singh Health Initiative is devoted to eliminating health and social disparities within underserved and underprivileged populations by creating spaces of community engagement and providing access to health education.

name: BIA at Berkeley
description: BIA at Berkeley is on a mission to co-create benefits with all students at Berkeley. We provide free services and campus information to all incoming students, with a special focus on international students. Our open, free membership welcomes everyone to enjoy discounts at more than 25 local businesses around Berkeley, as well as regular free movies, arts and crafts, culture festival events, and recreational activities.
summary: BIA at Berkeley is on a mission to co-create benefits with all students at Berkeley. We provide free services and campus information to incoming students. Our free, open membership welcomes everyone to enjoy discounts & to attend recreational activities.

name: BicyCal
description: We seek to provide a space where members of this community can learn how to maintain, operate and love their bicycles in an inclusive and friendly space. We offer free access to a variety of bike-specific tools and maintenance education in a positive environment. BicyCAL is a politically neutral organization.
summary: BicyCAL is a cooperatively run and student founded organization at UC Berkeley that aims to empower UCB students, faculty and staff to successfully integrate the bicycle into their daily lives.

name: Big Data at Berkeley
description:
Big Data at Berkeley (BDAB), established in 2019, is one of the largest data science student organizations at UC Berkeley, comprising 80 members across three departments (Bootcamp, Online Course and Projects) and three committees (Internal, External, Development). BDAB has a dual purpose to provide data science education to high school students and data science consulting services to clients.

 

Our Bootcamp department holds a seven-week in-person data science course called “Big Data Bootcamp” for high school students at UC Berkeley twice a year during Fall and Spring semesters. To date, we have taught 600+ students over 8 bootcamps.

 

Our Online Course department recently launched (in Spring 2023) a free, self-paced data science online course called “Data Science Demystified” for high school students to make data science accessible to everyone. The course features 120+ minutes of video content, 12 lesson and assignment notebooks, and 8 modules. It covers an Introduction to Data Science, Python, NumPy, Pandas, Data Visualizations, the Data Science Life Cycle, an Introduction to Machine Learning, Statistics in Data Science, and SQL. Our course is accessible to all via our website at https://bd.berkeley.edu/online_course/intro/.

 

Our Projects department provides data science consulting services to 3-4 paying clients each semester. To date, we have consulted for 20+ companies ranging from startups to Fortune 500 companies in diverse industries. Our previous clients include American Eagle, Ulta Beauty, Tripadvisor, Hologic and Intuitive Surgical.

 

In addition, BDAB provides professional development opportunities for our members planned by our Development Committee. For example, we hold resume workshops, technical interview workshops and alumni career panels exclusively for our members.

 

We also have an External Committee that plans major data science events open to all members of the UC Berkeley community such as “Breaking into Data Science Research”, where we invite professionals involved in cutting-edge data science research to talk about their work and offer advice to aspiring data practitioners.

 

Furthermore, BDAB provides a social and supportive community for our members. We have an Internal Committee that plans fun social events exclusively for our members such as a weekend retreat, an end-of-semester banquet and social mixers with other student organizations.
summary: Big Data at Berkeley (BDAB), established in 2019, has a dual purpose to provide data science education to high school students and data science consulting services to clients.

name: Bike Builders of Berkeley
description: Bike Builders of Berkeley is a club dedicated to all forms of bike engineering. The main focus is the design, fabrication, and testing of bike frames. However, we also welcome research into other bike components such as rims, shifters, pedals, etc. We are a student run organization and we bring our nicest bike to NAHBS every year.
summary: To build a bike from the ground up as a team. Throughout this process we will explore bike design, fabrication, and assembly.

name: Bio-Business Initiative
description: At BBI, we aim to bridge the gap between the fields of biology and business, inspire the next minds of our generation by supporting high school students in the Bay Area through workshops and mentorship, and provide professional and academic support to our members through Haas and LSBE program application support, biotech symposium, resume/LinkedIn workshops, and more! Join one of our 4 committees: consulting, finance, operations, or outreach. BBI is looking to recruit eager and dedicated UC Berkeley students who can embody our values: boldness, balance, and integrity.
summary: We are an interdisciplinary, service-oriented organization motivated to link underprivileged high school students in the Bay Area with UC Berkeley students to promote careers in the fields of biology and business.

name: Bio-Inspired Design at Berkeley
summary: BioD is a supportive community focused on the interdisciplinary principles of bio-inspired design. We aim to use nature/biological concepts as inspiration to generate new ideas and solve problems, welcoming individuals from all fields and backgrounds.

name: BioE Mentor Program
summary: BioE Mentor Program (BMP) at Berkeley aims to provide opportunities of mentorship and networking for BioE students to cultivate academic, social, and professional communities that will lead to professional relationships and long-term friendships.

name: BioEngineering Association of Students
description: The BioEngineering Association of STudents. Every UC Berkeley-UCSF Bioengineering PhD student is automatically a member of BEAST. Its purpose is to facilitate student involvement and leadership in areas ranging from social activities to prospective student visit weekends, from running the annual retreat to organizing BESTs (BioEngineering Student Talks). There are several elected positions, but the structure is informal and anyone wishing to volunteer with any activity is welcome.
summary: The Bioengineering Association of Students (BEAST) is the official student organization for the UC Berkeley - UCSF Graduate Program in Bioengineering, facilitating student involvement in the program and leadership opportunities in a variety of positions.

name: Bioengineering Honor Society
description:
The Bioengineering Honor Society (BioEHS) aims to advance bioengineering within the University of California, Berkeley, and beyond.

BioEHS honors and encourage academic achievement among undergraduate bioengineering students at UC Berkeley. It does so through study groups, professional development workshops, community service events, socials, and outreach projects.
summary: The Bioengineering Honor Society (BioEHS) aims to advance the bioengineering discipline within the University of California, Berkeley, campus and beyond.

name: BioethiCAL
description:
Are you pre-med, pre-health, or pre-biotechnology? Apply to BioethiCAL! Studying ethics allows future doctors, engineers, businesspeople, and researchers to develop a unique critical skill set that will aid them in their future high-stakes professions! 

 

About Us: We are UC Berkeley’s Undergraduate Bioethics and Medical Humanities Society. The discipline of bioethics explores the intersection of biological advancements and their moral implications. We enjoy grappling with tricky ethical questions in our two central committees: Debate and Journal. The interdisciplinary field of bioethics is concerned with the ethics and moral implications of biological and medical procedures, businesses, technologies, and treatments (from genetic engineering to patient accessibility of treatments, and more). We aim to expose students to this critical and often overlooked scientific division through targeted discourse, case studies, debates, and events.

Linktree: https://linktr.ee/bioethi.cal
summary: UC Berkeley’s Undergraduate Bioethics and Medical Humanities Society. We bring bioethical events, programs, competitions, speakers, case studies, and research to the undergraduate student population.

name: Biofuels Technology Club
description:
Interested in sustainable fuels? Find your place in BTC! 

Research team conducts bench top experiments in a lab in the College of Chemistry. Using waste cooking oil from Crossroads Dinning Hall, we determine optimal reaction conditions, test catalysts, pretreatment and purification processes. Design your own experiments, work with a close team, and present biofuel literature to peers!

Scale up team's runs a 50 gallon batch reactor in Richmond! We go to this facility most weekends during the semester implementing our engineering designs and creating usable fuel! After fueling in a car for the first time in Spring 2022, we are excited for regular production, improving quality, and getting our fuel into campus vehicles! Plus we have fun on the trips!

Outreach and Logistics teams work with campus and local leaders in sustainability to host seminars open to all of campus. The liaise with campus, dinning halls, and various companies working to keep our processes running smooth. This year we are expanding this team to lobby for campus to move to sustainable options in their diesel vehicles. If you are interested in gaining the communication skills that keep organizations running this is the team to join.   

Finance team raises and maintains our funds. We use our sponsorship package to secure industry sponsors, apply for both campus and industry grants, and host fundraisers such as selling donuts in SF! We are always looking for new ideas for funding our club and welcome anyone interested in finance to this team! 

In addition to working with your team, BTC hosts many socials! Look forward to a retreat, studying together, getting food after meetings, game nights etc. We also provide resume and interview resources.
summary: We are dedicated to student led campus sustainability. Members convert dining hall waste cooking oil to biodiesel both on the bench top and in off campus batch reactors. We lobby campus for cleaner fuel practices, host sustainability seminars, and more!

name: Biomedical Engineering Society
description:
The Biomedical Engineering Society student chapter is the largest bioengineering club on campus. We serve as a vibrant community dedicated to professional, academic, and social development in bioengineering. BMES members are students of unique backgrounds, identities, and areas of study. Our club welcomes all students who have an interest in the field.

We invite you to get involved by applying to a committee, and engaging with us at our events throughout the school year! For more information, visit bmes.berkeley.edu and make sure to follow us on instagram and facebook @calbmes to stay in the loop about upcoming events.

 

Fall 2021 Recruitment Timeline

Committee Applications Released – 8/30

General Member Applications Released – 8/30

Welcome Week – 8/30 to 9/2

General Meeting #1 – 9/8

Committee Applications Due – 9/14
summary: The Biomedical Engineering Society student chapter is the largest bioengineering club on campus. We serve as a vibrant community dedicated to professional, academic, and social development in bioengineering. Visit bmes.berkeley.edu for more information.

name: Biophysics Club
summary: Biophysics club will facilitate networking and community building within the biophysics and quantitative biology graduate programs at UC Berkeley by hosting networking, informational, and social events.

name: Bioprinting at Berkeley
description:
Bioprinting at Berkeley is an interdisciplinary team of undergraduates, united by an interest in the engineering and scientific processes behind the tissue engineering method of 3D bioprinting.

We have an application process at the start of each semester for prospective members who would like to join as part of the engineering or biosciences team. We also offer a 2 unit DeCal every semester (apply for Fall '22). For more details, please see: DeCal (berkeley.edu)

If you have questions about the club, please email calbioprinting@gmail.com instead of requesting to join on this website for a faster response!
summary: Bioprinting at Berkeley is an interdisciplinary team of undergraduates, united by an interest in the engineering and scientific processes behind the tissue engineering method of 3D bioprinting.

name: Biostatistics Graduate Student Association
summary: The BSGSA is designed to represent the interests and needs of graduate students in biostatistics.

name: Biotech @Berkeley
description: Biotech @Berkeley (B^2) seeks to connect and represent all graduate students from UC Berkeley who are interested in biotechnology. Our group aims to create a student biotech community that serves as a gateway to exploring biotech-focused resources and opportunities at Berkeley. This includes organizing engaging events around education, career exploration, networking, and other opportunities for students to become familiar with biotech-related industry, the public sector/government, and entrepreneurship. We also hope to use our group as a platform for promoting diversity and equity in biotechnology by taking actionable steps to enable and shape our next generation of industry leaders.
summary: Biotech @Berkeley seeks to connect and represent all graduate students from UC Berkeley interested in biotechnology. Our group aims to create a student community and gateway to exploring biotech-focused resources and opportunities at Berkeley.

name: Birders of Berkeley
description: Birders of Berkeley is a birdwatching club dedicated to avian ecology. BOB hosts bird walks and field trips on and around campus. In addition to field trips BoB hosts lectures by ornithologists and bird enthusiasts. BoB seeks to provide its members with opportunities to experience the joy of bird watching by offering access to binoculars, spotting scopes and field guides.
summary: Birders of Berkeley is a birdwatching club dedicated to avian ecology. BoB hosts bird walks and field trips on and around campus. Join us for our weekly campus walks! Meet in front of Mulford Hall at 9am every Thursday (Spring Semester 2022)

name: Black Advocates for Equity in Health
description: Black Advocates for Equity in Health (BAEH) was founded in 2018 to provide space and resources to support and empower Black students in the School of Public Health. We aim to foster community, create networking opportunities, and provide opportunities to connect with fellow students at SPH across disciplines. BAEH exists to promote health equity and address/dismantle structural anti-blackness on campus and beyond. Our vision is that the UC Berkeley School of Public Health and the field of public health at large are more diverse and representative of Black communities in the United States. We see a future in which Black-identifying individuals are empowered to be leaders in the field of public health and racial/ethnic health disparities are eliminated. The group is comprised of students, faculty and staff.
summary: Black Advocates for Equity in Health was founded to provide space and resources to support and empower Black students in the School of Public Health. BAEH exists to promote health equity and address/dismantle structural anti-blackness on campus and beyond

name: Black Campus Ministries at Berkeley
description: BCM (Black Campus Ministries) is a ministry of Intervarsity Christian Fellowship, an evangelical campus mission serving students and faculty on college and university campuses nationwide. Our vision is to see students and faculty transformed, campuses renewed and world changers developed. See more of our events on http://bcm.calivcf.org/
summary: Black Campus Ministries (BCM) is a club that aims to provide a space for black students on campus to explore and grow their relationship with Jesus Christ!

name: Black Caucus (AKA Masters of Social Welfare Black Caucus)
summary:
The Black Caucus is a group of MSW students
at UC Berkeley who self-identify as Black or
African decent. The purpose of the group is to
promote networking and connection amongst
emerging social workers of similar backgrounds.

name: Black Engineering and Science Students Association
description:
​The Black Engineering and Science Student Association, also known as BESSA, is the University of California, Berkeley chapter for our parent organization the National Society of Black Engineers (NSBE). We are a student run, non-profit organization that thrives on its members support, success, and commitment. We diligently work to provide academic and social support not only to our engineering and science community but to the entire Black community. In addition, we happily coordinate programs during the year to integrate our greater Bay Area community. Through these events, we are able to form and foster relationships that bridge the gap between the prestigious university and our close-but-distant community. This organization is a strong believer in academic excellence, personal growth, and a commitment to minority communities in and out of the classroom.

Our Objectives:

  • Retain, support, and increase the number of Black students within the College of Engineering (COE) as well as other science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields.
  • Introduce and develop the professional skills needed to succeed in the professional field.
  • Cultivate a network between students, professionals, and companies. 
  • Give our greater community access to our resources for support in areas that are lacking.
summary: To increase the number of culturally responsible Black engineers and scientists who excel academically, succeed professionally, and positively impact the community

name: Black Geographies at Berkeley
summary: The purpose of this organization is to provide a space of support, group discussion, reading, and collaborative publication, for all students who are currently engaged or interested in topics of black geographies at UC Berkeley.

name: Black Graduate Engineering and Science Students
description: The Black Graduate Engineering and Science Students Society is an academic and social support network that targets black graduate students and allies of black students within the University of California at Berkeley’s STEM disciplines. Through our programming, we help ensure that black graduate students can successfully contribute to both scientific research and the college’s learning environment.
summary: BGESS is a graduate organization that strives to improve the graduate experience of African American students as well other minority groups at UC Berkeley. This is done through a collaborative effort from the students, staff, industry, and community.

name: Black Graduate Student Association
description: The Black Graduate Student Association primarily seeks to build community amongst incoming and continuing graduate students of African descent across the African diaspora. We also seek to reach out and support other members of the Black community on the UC Berkeley campus and in the East Bay. BGSA's creation was sparked by graduate students' firm belief in the power of having an organized and active space for Black graduate students to know each other, support each other, and address various concerns of the Black community both inside and outside of the University. We also seek to build alliances and partnerships with other organizations across campus.
summary: BGSA was founded in the fall of 2004 by graduate students of African descent from across various disciplines at the University of California, Berkeley.

name: Black Pre-Law Association at Berkeley
description: The Black Pre-Law Association at Berkeley believes that the catalyst to more representation of the Black Community, among other minorities and disenfranchised peoples, in the legal sphere is access to more educational and legal resources. We believe in promoting diversity of thought, space, and individuals and in addressing key legal issues (mass incarceration, housing crisis, sexual assault, wealth inequality, immigration, etc.) and connecting students with real legal actors, we create an outlet for potential lawyers to thrive.
summary: We aim to bridge the gap between the undergraduate pursuit of law & legal learning opportunities for black & underrepresented students by providing an infrastructure of skills, resources, and networks in order to cultivate professionalism & leadership.

name: Black Student Union
description:
The University of California, Berkeley Black Student Union is a student-led organization that cultivates an intersectional framework for all levels of Black consciousness. We are here to foster Black liberation and the progression of the Afrikan diaspora through political activism, community building, and leadership development.

 

To be added to our list serve or if you are interested in interning send an email chair.bsu@gmail.com
summary: The Black Student Union at UC Berkeley serves as the unifying, political body for Black organizations and the Black student body on campus. For questions please contact Alexis Turner at chair.calbsu@gmail.com.

name: Black Students in Health Association
description: BSHA serves to provide guidance to Black students interested in the health sciences, medical education, and allied health fields; facilitates advising and special counseling of students interested in health professions and allied fields; provides students with career-advancing opportunities; provides a forum for the dissemination of information relevant to the education of students interested in health fields; and provides students with opportunities to support the Black community in a health-related manner.
summary: Provide guidance and outreach to Black and underrepresented minority students interested in the health sciences, medical education, and allied health fields.

name: Blockchain at Berkeley (formerly Bitcoin Association of Berkeley)
description:
Blockchain at Berkeley (B@B) is Berkeley’s hub for blockchain innovation. We specialize in educating the community, facilitating innovative projects and discussions, and helping companies benefit from blockchain technology by identifying use cases, building out prototypes, and integrating solutions.
 
Blockchain at Berkeley (B@B) may hold educational events; disseminate educational materials to members of the campus and community; provide support for like-minded organizations; bring in outside speakers; host hackathons; host networking events.
 
Blockchain technology is a powerful platform that touches on a large number of different areas of interest, from computer science to economics to social justice.
summary: To educate and connect members of the Berkeley community who share an interest in blockchain technologies. To support and foster cryptocurrency-related projects and innovation.

name: Blockeley
summary: Blockeley’s mission is to serve as a living monument as a one to one Minecraft recreation of the UC Berkeley campus, and be a representation of UC Berkeley students, staff, and alumni, as well as Cal’s culture & history.

name: Blood Pressure Project
description:
The Blood Pressure Project (BPP) is a UC Berkeley student organization founded in Fall 2013. We are an organization committed to bringing blood pressure awareness and education to Berkeley’s underserved communities in order to improve and create a healthy, sustainable society. We are partnered with Heart 2 Heart, a collaboration between the City of Berkeley’s Public Health Department and Lifelong Medical Care. We also work with organizations such as Suitcase Clinic and the South Berkeley Senior Center. Throughout the semester we invite health professionals from the community to speak at our general meetings.

Check out our website at bpp.berkeley.edu, or follow us on Instagram at @bloodpressureproject and like us on Facebook @Blood Pressure Project for the most up-to-date information on upcoming meetings, events, socials, and more!
summary:
BPP's purpose is to:
(1) Provide underserved communities regular and consistent blood pressure screenings
(2) Promote health education
(3) Increase community involvement in healthy habits
(4) Utilize the campus to promote our cause

name: Blue and Gold Yearbook
description:
Mission: Our mission is to truthfully encapsulate the current, unique Berkeley identity — its culture, events, and lifestyle — as students, for the students.

The Blue & Gold Yearbook is the official yearbook for UC Berkeley. Published since 1875, the yearbook provides coverage of events, issues, and trends within the Berkeley community. As a historical record, the yearbook includes graduating seniors’ portraits and majors, as well as campus facts, figures, and people.

The Blue & Gold Yearbook staff is composed of over 50 individuals who produce, market, and distribute the yearbook. Members are split across 5 teams: Copy, Design, Photo, Marketing, and Tech. Financially self-sufficient, the organization earns its revenue without aid of grants or outside funding. The Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC) formally sponsors the organization and provides it with office space.

We recruit at the beginning of every semester, so keep an eye out on our social media for more information about recruitment and our activities! 

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1YQoRvijY_c
summary: The Blue & Gold Yearbook is UC Berkeley's official yearbook. Published since 1875, we provide coverage of events, issues, and trends within the Berkeley community and include graduating seniors’ portraits.

name: Blueprint, Technology for Nonprofits
description:
Blueprint strives to make technology accessible and useful for those who create communities and promote public welfare. In practice, we're a team of students that develops software pro bono for nonprofits and promotes technology for social good.

Each year, teams of 1 project manager, 1 technical lead, 1 designer, and 4 to 5 developers work with non-profit organizations on projects to help them better serve their communities. We've designed and built a customer rewards program and store locator mobile app to increase access to affordable healthy food in DC's food deserts, a web portal for Black, LGBTQ+/SGL, and other marginalized communities to find and connect with organizations nationwide, and much more!
summary: We are a community of students who strive to use their skills to support nonprofits by making beautiful engineering accessible. We build and design software solutions for nonprofits and promote technology for social good.

name: BMO Student Organization Grant Program
description:
Believe it or not, about $9 out of every $10 you deposit into the bank is sent out to finance other programs and initiatives. At BMO, we know money deposited in a bank has the power to finance positive change. That's why we take everyday action to support activities that help protect the planet, improve people’s lives, and strengthen communities.  Please visit the branch in the ASUC Student Union, located on the lower level of MLK Hall.

 

BMO Grant Program

All registered student organizations (RSOs) and recognized CalGreeks fraternities and sororities can apply for the BMO Student Organization Grant Program. The program provides funds for events, activities, projects, or programs that advance one of the Bank’s interest areas:

  • Sustainability
  • Financial Literacy
  • Women’s Empowerment

To be eligible, events, activities, projects, or programs must happen before May 15, 2024. No retroactive funding will be provided.

 

HOW TO APPLY

Fill out the application form. The application deadline is October 22, 2023. Applications will be reviewed by campus staff and BMO. BMO will determine what student organizations to fund and how much to fund them. Applicants will be notified of the award and amount by November.
summary: The BMO Student Organization Grant Program provides funding for student-led initiatives (events, activities, projects, or programs) to registered student organizations focused on women's empowerment, sustainability, & financial literacy.

name: Board Games at Berkeley
description:
We are a social club that hosts two game nights a week and has thriving D&D and Magic the Gathering communities! All game nights are completely free, and there are no commitment or membership requirements for the club. For up-to-date info on our game nights and events, please use the following link for our email newsletter!

http://bit.ly/BGBEmail

 

Game Nights (discord)

Follow our discord for when game nights occur, or to organize meetups with other board game enthusiasts!


Magic: The Gathering (discord)

  • Join us for our online meetups where we play on Magic: The Gathering Arena
  • Thriving EDH community with online and in-person play!
  • Deck-building challenges and casual competition!
  • New to Magic or need help creating your deck? We can help you get started!


Dungeons and Dragons (discord)

  • Join us for our one-shot game nights to learn the basics or for a quick game
  • Join a campaign regardless of your skill level
  • Become a Dungeon Master and start your own campaign

 

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

One semester the two club founders independently came up with the idea to start a board game club. Each went through the process of starting a club without knowing the other existed. Only after the advisor to both clubs noticed the two applications did Board Games at Berkeley coalesce into a single organization that exists to this day!
summary: A social club where students can meet and make new friends playing board, card, and role-playing games. Whether you're a board game veteran or haven't even touched a game before, be sure to come by and play some board games, MTG, or Dungeons and Dragons!

name: Board of Advocates
description:
The Board of Advocate’s general membership includes over 90 students who participate in both regional and national competitions in four main areas: Alternative Dispute Resolution, Trial Advocacy, Appellate Advocacy, and Technology & Intellectual Property. Competition for a place on these teams is fierce during the Board’s yearly try-out process, with multiple students vying for each spot. Teams receive coaching from professors, Executive Board Members, alumni, and fellow students.

The Board also places a strong emphasis on training fellow students and future members through internal competitions, offering scholarship money and the opportunity to be heard by federal judges in mock argument. The Board of Advocates provides further opportunities for students to hone their advocacy skills, hosting multiple skills workshops throughout the year. 

The Board recognizes the importance of diversity in the legal profession.  The Board acknowledges the systemic exclusion of marginalized groups, especially people of color, from legal advocacy spaces and from the legal community at large.  Each of the Board's branches will maintain inclusive policies for recruitment and admission that increase diversity within the teams and the broader legal advocacy community.  All Board members commit to valuing diverse perspectives, experiences, and opinions in all areas of their work.  The Board and its branches commit to leveraging their power to dismantle systems of oppression in all forms and make legal advocacy inclusive for everyone.
summary: Board of Advocates consists of the Alternative Dispute Resolution, Appellate, and Mock Trial teams of U.C. Berkeley School of Law.  BOA has won competition awards at multiple levels and consistently outperforms other top-ten law schools.

name: Bone Health Initiative
description:
Bone Health Initiative provides education, resources, and tools to help students and local communities understand bone health and bone disease. Our mission is to spread timely bone health information that supports the development and maintenance of strong and healthy bones as well as the prevention, detection, and treatment of bone diseases. BHI builds capacity for local community outreach through our projects for elementary schoolers, high school students, fellow UC Berkeley students, parents, and seniors.

Please feel free to contact us at bonehealthinitiative@gmail.com.
summary: Bone Health Initiative (BHI) provides education, resources, and tools to help students and the local communities understand bone disease (e.g. osteoporosis, arthritis) and bone health. This includes applications to sports medicine, nutrition, and more!

name: Bootleg Comedy
description: • Bootleg Sketch Comedy will write, produce, and perform original sketches and comedic content. In addition, we teach new members to write and perform sketches.
