As it is practiced at The Second City and the Upright Citizens Brigade, Mainline Comedy Force will be a collaborative ensemble of creative, funny students who enjoy writing and performing their own original sketches for a live audience. We will generate sketches on a weekly basis using improv, lesson plans, and our own inspiration to tackle current events and comedic tropes in funny ways. At the end of each semester, we will perform our best sketches for a live audience!
summary: Bootleg Sketch Comedy is a live sketch comedy ensemble. We write, produce, and act out our own sketches in a manner similar to that done at The Second City and UCB Theater.

name: Boricuas at Berkeley
description: As a student organization, our mission is: 1. To create a space for UC Berkeley students (undergraduate and graduate) from Puerto Rico to connect and share academic, professional and personal experiences in order to promote a spirit of community. 2. To provide a means for fostering dialogue on issues concerning Puerto Rico, such as our status as minorities in the United States, our history, social justice, food sovereignty, politics, science, amongst others. 3. To create a space for the creative expression of Puerto Rican culture, customs and traditions including art, music, literature, amongst others. 4. To create an inclusive environment in which Puerto Rican students can interact with students of other nationalities and share our respective cultures.
summary: Our purpose is to create a space for students from Puerto Rico to connect and share academic, professional, and personal experiences. We also promote an inclusive environment for students from other nationalities in order to foster a spirit of community.

name: Brain Exercise Initiative at Berkeley
description:
We are a 501 C3 non profit organization that is completely student run. We work with the Alzheimer's Services of the East Bay to do simple brain exercises with people with Alzheimer's consisting of writing, math, and trivia questions. Everything we do is based off the research of the Japanese scientist Ryuta Kawashima from Tokyo University. He’s been researching the brain for the entirety of his career and has found that simple brain exercises done with Alzheimer’s patients for just 30 minutes a day, five days a week can really improve cognitive function and memory by activating the prefrontal cortex. We are operating 100% remotely over Zoom this year to do brain exercises and build friendships with people in the community to promote brain health and sustained independence.

 

Supporting research:

1.https://www.tohoku.ac.jp/en/research/research_highlights/research_highlight_22.html

2. https://academic.oup.com/biomedgerontology/article/60/3/380/630607.

We are NOT currently recruiting volunteers, but feel free to email rwoody@berkeley.edu to find out more about how you can be involved.
summary: We are a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization that uses simple math, writing and reading aloud exercises as an intervention to improve cognitive function in those with Alzheimer's Disease while encouraging intergenerational collaboration.

name: Brain Like Bookeley
summary: To indulge in an exchange of cultures, ideas, and values through discussion on literature composed by authors of diverse backgrounds from different stratas and regions of the world.

name: BrainTrust
summary: Through the facilitation of peer support group meetings, a one-on-one buddy volunteer program, and lectures by physicians and researchers, BrainTrust seeks to create a powerful social support network for individuals with brain injury.

name: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu at Berkeley
description: The purpose of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu at Berkeley is to provide UC Berkeley students with an opportunity to learn about, practice, and compete in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu with the greater Bay Area community. All members of the UC Berkeley community who are interested in the sport or seeking a way to stay in shape shall benefit from this organization.
summary: A student organization focused on teaching the UC Berkeley community the grappling martial art Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.

name: Bread & Roses
description: We are a group of PhD-student geographers interested in deploying sensorial methods in research and artistic practice, and thinking critically about the role the senses play across the social sciences.
summary:
Bread and Roses has two aims:
1.	To provide a space for the discussion and appreciation of sensorial methods in geographical research.
2.	To develop and carry out sensorial research projects in and around the Bay Area.

name: Bridge Club
description:
About

The Bridge Club at Berkeley welcomes all students, faculty, and staff who are interested in the game of bridge. Bridge is a fun and strategic game for four players (two teams of two) using a standard deck of playing cards.

 

We are a teaching club and everyone is welcome, even if you’ve never played bridge before. Our meetings are casual and focus on playing the game socially. We also play in club games and tournaments in the Bay area, and compete in national tournaments against other college bridge clubs.

During fall and spring semesters, our weekly casual games on campus (Sunday 1-4pm) focus on teaching, learning, and informal play. We compete in local club games and local and national tournaments, and are several-time Collegiate Bridge Bowl champions.
summary: The Bridge Club at Berkeley welcomes all students, faculty, and staff who are interested in the game of bridge. Bridge is a fun and strategic game for four players (two teams of two) using a standard deck of playing cards.

name: Bridge Network
description: Advocating mental health in education through teaching, community engagement and services.
summary: This organization is committed to providing safe, mental health support of the same cultural connotation to Asian/Chinese students and promote the importance of mental health, and de-stigmatize mental illness.

name: BridgeUSA at Berkeley
description:
The United States’ political climate needs drastic change. Politics has been rendered easy and dualistic, making blind-partisanship not only permissible, but the principal mode of political practice. It has become acceptable to immerse oneself in echo-chambers of like-mindedness, to label and blindly dismiss ideological opposites, and to violently rebuke instead of constructively disagreeing. There is no productive way forward so long as this persists.

 

BridgeUSA wants to move the conversation forward, by allowing it to happen in the home of academic progress and innovation; the college campus. If we wish to create a better national sphere of politics, we need to start by creating better collegiate political spheres open to BridgeUSA’s guiding principles of responsible discourse, true diversity of ideas, and the creation of listening spaces. Our chapter will be at the forefront of this movement to fix national governance, by starting in the spaces where they learn, live, and grow into tomorrow’s leaders.

 

We are recruiting for the fall semester and are excited to meet you! Please don't hesitate to contact us if you have any questions. 

 

Past events: 

2020 Berkeley Mayoral Debate + District Debates

A Discussion With Former Members of Congress

Post-Election Student Forum

Voter Suppression in the Modern Era

The Future of SCOTUS

Understanding Your Vote

COVID-19 and Health Equity: Addressing Racial Disparities
summary: BridgeUSA believes that good governance starts with constructive political discussion.  Our organization works to foster spaces wherein a diverse range of ideas can engage one another through the practice of responsible discourse.

name: Brown Issues
description: Brown Issues focuses on organizing the next generation of Brown leaders. This can only be accomplished through civic engagement, social and emotional health support, and narrative change. Brown Issues understands that certain narratives about Brown folks continue to negatively impact our communities; therefore, we challenge the dominant discourse that erodes our communities. Thus, increasing the focus on community issues rather than mundane rhetoric that continue to divide and affect marginalized communities.
summary: To cultivate the next generation of Brown Leaders through civic engagement, community support, narrative change, and political awareness.

name: Buddies Without Borders at Berkeley (BWBB)
summary: Buddies Without Borders is a non-profit organization that fosters cross-cultural student connections, helping underserved communities, and promoting volunteerism for a more interconnected world.

name: BUILD Literacy Program
description: BUILD which stands for Berkeley United in Literacy Development is one of the largest reading programs in the East Bay, with 215 UC Berkeley student mentors providing one-to-one literacy support to 850 youth at 17 locations in Oakland and Berkeley. Each mentor is matched with 3 children with whom they work individually in 30-45 minute after-school sessions twice a week. Mentors work with the same children for at least one semester, and sometimes for years. In addition, all mentors attend an orientation, 3 trainings per semester, and weekly meetings with their mentor team. BUILD runs in fall, spring, and summer.
summary: BUILD is one of the largest reading programs in the East Bay, with Cal student mentor teams providing one-to-one literacy support at 18 after school locations in Oakland and Berkeley.

name: Burmese Students Association at Berkeley (Formerly: Burma Association at Berkeley)
description: This group [Burmese Students Association at Berkeley] was formerly named [Burma Association at Berkeley] - [08/15/2022] [EC]
summary: Burma Association at Berkeley (BAB) is dedicated to showcasing Burma's culture and traditions at UC Berkeley and serves as a support network and forum for students from Burma, Burma-affiliated, and general student body interested in Burmese culture.

name: Business Careers in Entertainment Club
description:
The UC Berkeley chapter of the Business Careers in Entertainment Club (BCEC) was established in the Fall of 2008 under the national organization, the Business Careers in Entertainment Association. BCEC was formed with the goal of helping students prepare for careers in the entertainment industry.

"Our mission is to provide all undergraduate, graduate, and doctoral students, regardless of academic degree, with the essential career development mind-set and hands-on experience vital to obtain professional entertainment networking connections, internships, and job opportunities within both the creative and business ends of the entertainment industry."

We serve students of all majors, providing them with the professional development, experience, and network to successfully pursue a career in entertainment. Whether you are interested in business development, corporate finance, accounting, marketing, engineering, creative roles, or any other roles in entertainment, or are simply looking for a community here at Cal, we hope to see you at our many events throughout the semester.
summary: Our mission is to provide internships, job opportunities, career information, and hands-on experience to undergraduate students interested in the business end of the entertainment industry.

name: Business Review at Berkeley
description:
So the legend goes, one fateful winter break, our founders were fed up with the business bro-culture into which they had become inculcated. They wanted to create a new model for intellectual-professional organizations on campus where students from all majors and backgrounds are encouraged to bring their best ideas about business, finance, economics and community without politics or peer pressure.

     Since then, BRB has strived to be the thought leader in business and financial literacy on campus. We are a student-led organization that publishes articles, interviews, and videos for people interested in business and finance-related content. Through its partnerships with other on-campus organizations and faculty, we seek to simplify the Berkeley business landscape while providing its members with the technical expertise and writing skills that are demanded in finance and journalism.

     Want to learn more about Business Review at Berkeley? To receive updates about recruitment events and key dates, fill out our interest form (Business Review at Berkeley Fall 2023 Interest Form (google.com)). Our President will also be available for virtual coffee chats for prospective members to learn more about BRB (Business Review at Berkeley Fall 2023 Coffee Chat Sign Up Form (google.com)).To join Business Review at Berkeley, our application will be released shortly. We look forward to welcoming new members soon!
summary: BRB aims to be the thought leader in business and financial literacy on campus by publishing articles about the investment landscape, global economics, financial literacy, updates in technology and the Berkeley business community.

name: Business Transfer Network of Berkeley
description:
The Business Transfer Network (BTN) is the first transfer oriented business club at UC Berkeley. BTN is a reflection of the ever-changing and diverse transfer community — a population of students whose specialized needs are only now being met. Comprising more than 10% of Cal's undergraduate population, BTN seeks to empower transfer students by growing a cohesive and dedicated community of student professionals. Through a carefully planned set of resources, events, and initiatives, BTN also aspires to amplify the voices of transfer students who wish to pursue professional and social opportunities that are often closed to them among other campus organizations.

To learn more about who we are and what we do, follow us on Facebook, LinkedIn, and Instagram.
summary: We seek to provide a community for transfer students and provide them with resources they need to be successful in their career.

name: Cal Actuarial League
description:
Founded in February 1998, The CALIFORNIA ACTUARIAL LEAGUE aims to…

  • Inform interested students of career paths available to actuaries and provide members with an ongoing opportunity to interact with companies seeking young actuaries
  • Serve as a professional and social network of persons with experience and/or interest in pursuing a career as a pension actuary, casualty actuary, consulting actuary, or other related designation
  • Serve as a contact for private and public organizations interested in recruiting for full-time positions, providing summer or co-op internship opportunities, giving corporate information sessions, offering scholarships for actuarial students, facilitating exam preparation courses to help prepare CAL members for professional actuarial examinations given by the Society of Actuaries (SOA) and the Casualty Actuary Society (CAS)
  • Advise members and non-members of appropriate agencies and resources that can answer questions or provide direction in the pursuit of one’s actuarial career
  • Have agencies permanently associate CAL members with genuine interest and determination in actuarial careers
summary: Cal Actuarial League provides resources to students aspiring to be actuaries, including company presentations, exam preparation DeCals, exam manuals for renting, an annual Actuarial Career Fair, Excel workshops, and a bi-annual Actuarial Case Competition

name: Cal American Civil Liberties Union
description:
Cal ACLU is a collegiate chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU). 

The ACLU's stated mission is to defend and preserve the individual rights and liberties guaranteed by the Constitution and laws of the United States. As a nonpartisan organization, the ACLU is also the nation's largest non-profit law firm and one of the leading activist organizations. Some of the ACLU's most famous legal battles include Japanese-American internment during WWII, the desegregation struggle, women's reproductive rights, and numerous free speech issues.

As CalACLU, our work follows and complements that of the overarching ACLU. We work to educate and advocate for students and local communities regarding current events, legislation, and major issues. We remain in close contact with the ACLU of Northern California, as well as the Berkeley/North East Bay Chapter of the ACLU. We host panels and workshops, rallies and events, and aim to advocate for civil liberties through our work. 

CalACLU was re-established in Spring 2017 (Formerly known as Berkeley ACLU)

Follow us on Instagram @calaclu
summary: Cal ACLU is a collegiate chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. The ACLU advocates for individual rights and liberties through litigation and organizing. We, as a campus chapter, focus on education and advocacy under the umbrella of the ACLU.

name: Cal Animage Alpha
description:
Cal Animage Alpha is UC Berkeley's anime club, founded all the way back in 1989!
Check our discord server and facebook page for information on our recurring events, which are open to the public!
We hold weekly Game Nights and Cosplay and Anime Art socials/workshops, in addition to weekly dinner socials and weekend events!
We make magazines and video content!
summary: Cal Animage Alpha is UC Berkeley's anime club. Every Wednesday we hold showings of currently airing anime and every Thursday we have game nights, where members come together to socialize. For more details, please see our website at cal.moe.

name: Cal Archery
description:
Cal Archery is a student-run Cal Sport Club that provides an opportunity for the UC Berkeley community to experience archery as a recreational and competitive sport. People of all ages and skill levels are welcome.

 

For Fall 2020, we will not be hosting practices on campus, but look for our FREE beginner sessions and class starting up again Spring 2021!

Please visit our website at archery.berkeley.edu and like our Facebook page for club information, events, and practice times! You can also contact our Club President at president@archery.berkeley.edu with any questions. 

 

Sign up for our newsletter to stay up to date!

We hope to see you on the field. Go Bears!

NOTE: Our roster is not processed through CalLink! Please DO NOT send us roster requests on this website, as we will not be able to accept them.
summary:
Cal Archery is a student-run Cal Sport Club that provides an opportunity for the UC Berkeley community to experience archery as a recreational and competitive sport.

The club provides open practices to members as well as team practices.

name: Cal Badminton
description:
Cal Badminton is a student-run Cal Sport Club that allows for players of all skill levels to participate. We have players who only play recreational badminton as well as players who do both recreational and competitive. 

For more info, you can visit:

https://badminton.berkeley.edu/

https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/badminton-club/

You can also contact us through email at calbadminton@gmail.com. 

*NOTE: Our roster is not processed through CalLink. Please DO NOT send us roster requests through this website. 

 

Send a request to our Facebook to join our community! https://www.facebook.com/groups/120351844689375 

Or follow us on our social media below!
summary: Cal Badminton offers players of all skill levels a chance to compete on both a recreational and intercollegiate level.

name: Cal Ballroom
description:
We are UC Berkeley’s one and only competitive International Ballroom Dance Team and the largest team on the West Coast. We offer Cal Students high quality dance instruction through our professional coaches and attend competitions throughout the state and nation. Our team members have both placed and won in national competitions on the East Coast.

Ballroom dancing is a partner-style dance which has risen in popularity across the world, especially in European countries. In International Ballroom there are 2 main styles of dancing called Standard and Latin, both with 5 types of dances.

Find more information about us at ballroom.berkeley.edu!

You can also email the president at president.calballroom@gmail.com. Feel free to get in touch with any questions!
summary: Cal Ballroom is one of the largest competitive ballroom teams on the West Coast. Our aim is to teach ballroom dancing to Cal students and provide a community for students.

name: Cal Berkeley Democrats
description: The Cal Berkeley Democrats was founded in 1960 and is the official arm of the Democratic Party at the University of California, Berkeley. We have a strong tradition of being involved in Democratic politics at the local, state, and federal levels—our members have worked on city council races, presidential campaigns, and everything in between. We have the largest active membership of chapters among the California College Democrats. We are also one of the most active chapters of the California Young Democrats. In addition to working to get Democratic officials elected, our annual events include the California Democratic Party Convention, various community service projects, partaking in debates on-campus, and our annual banquet. The Cal Berkeley Democrats are committed to making the goals of the Democratic Party realities; these include but are not limited to – affordable higher education, good jobs with good pay, responsible environmental use, and affordable health care for every American. For more information about our club, including how you can get involved, please visit our website at www.caldems.com.
summary: The Cal Berkeley Democrats was founded in 1960 and is the official arm of the Democratic Party at the University of California, Berkeley.

name: Cal Bhangra (formerly Golden Bear Competitive Bhangra)
description: We are a group of 40+ students who are all extremely passionate about Bhangra. We compete in Bhangra competitions all over the nation throughout the school year, perform at various on-campus events, and also take part in several off-campus performances. We're always looking to grow our family and are excited about any opportunity to share our love for Bhangra. Check out our Instagram, Facebook, or Tik Tok for some awesome videos!
summary: The purpose of Cal Bhangra is to promote awareness of the Punjabi Culture through the expression of traditional, Punjabi folk dance.

description:
IF INTERESTED, PLEASE FILL OUT THIS FORM

name: Cal Chorale
description:
Cal Chorale

Cal Chorale Rehearses on Wednesdays and Fridays 4-6pm in CRH, the Choral Rehearsal Room in SMA in the Caesar Chavez Basement (see below for directions; Actual start time  is Berkeley Time at 4:10. We also offer optional one-on-one and sectional rehearsals on Mondays 4-6 for students that would like extra musical support. Some singers have conflicts with some rehearsals time, and that is allowed in many cases.

Prior to fall 2022, the Cal Chorale was the Women’s Chorale and the Men’s Chorale, who sang some mixed-voice repertoire together. In fall 2022, the choirs officially merged to become Cal Chorale (SATB repertoire) with the subgroups Treble Chorale (SSAA repertoire) and Basso Chorale (TTBB repertoire). 

With approximately 50-60 singers, We aim to be Cal’s most inclusive choral ensemble. Where other ensembles at Cal focus on a specific type of repertoire choral (classical, a cappella, jazz) – we sing music of all styles and genres, including classical, folk, pop, and jazz styles in all voicings. We welcome singers of all genders and all ethnic & music backgrounds. We offer opportunities to develop vocal technique in a variety of styles and to strengthen theory and musicianship skills. 

The choir gives several performances each semester, including in UCCE (UC Choral Ensembles) concerts, Cal Rallies, Welcome Back A Cappella, our Fall Show, choral festivals, and other events. The singers socialize regularly and create a welcoming place for singers to connect.
summary: Cal Chorale provides an inclusive space for singers of all backgrounds to sing in a chorale ensemble at Cal.

name: Cal Christian Fellowship
description:
Cal Christian Fellowship (IV-CCF) is a multi-ethnic community of students seeking to learn more about Jesus and how He's relevant to our lives. We are part of the InterVarsity Christian Fellowship at Cal. We meet regularly for weekly small group bible studies and large group fellowship meetings to grow deeper in our faith, stronger as a community, and wider in our impact.

Our Vision: To be a community of students transformed by the whole Gospel to love God, the campus, and the world. 

Cal Christian Fellowship (CCF) is part of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship, which consists of four sister fellowships:
International Student Ministry (ISM), Black Campus Ministries (BCM), Cal Christian Fellowship (CCF), and LaFe. Together we seek to discover God's heart in an authentic community.

IV's Vision:
To see students and faculty transformed,
campuses renewed,
and world changers developed.
summary: We are a multiethnic Christian fellowship and one of the four sister fellowships (CCF, ISM, BCM and La Fe) of InterVarsity at Cal — Together we seek to discover God's heart in an authentic community.

description:
Welcome to Cal Climbing Competitive Team!

summary: Cal Club Baseball is a great opportunity for students seeking to play baseball at the intercollegiate level.  The team competes with other collegiate clubs in the state and across the West Coast.

name: Cal Club Golf
description:
The Cal Club Golf Team brings together talented golfers who want to play competitively in college while balancing the academic rigors of UC Berkeley. Composed of undergraduate and graduate students across a wide range of majors, the team allows for a fun environment built around a love for the game.

They compete during Fall and Spring in the Pacific region of the National Collegiate Club Golf Association. Through weekly practices at Berkeley Country Club and multiple 36 hole tournaments per semester, the Cal Club Golf team has risen into the top 30 clubs in the country. In the fall of 2019, Cal Club Golf had the lowest unadjusted scoring average in the nation. All interested golfers are encouraged to join.

For more information about the team, please visit our Berkeley Recreational Sports page, our National Collegiate Club Golf Association page, or our Facebook page.
summary: The Cal Club Golf Team brings together talented golfers who want to play competitively in college. Composed of undergraduate and graduate students, the team allows for a fun environment built around a love for the game.

name: Cal Club Roller Hockey
description: For more info see: https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/roller-hockey/
summary: The Cal Club Roller Hockey team competes in several tournaments throughout the year hosted by the Western Collegiate Roller Hockey League (WCRHL). These tournaments take place on weekends in various locations throughout California.

name: Cal Club Softball
description: Cal Club Softball is a team composed of women who strive to be competitive, communicative, and passionate on the field. As a team we practice weekly, play tournaments in the Spring, and have lots of team bonding events! Throughout the spring we will be competing in 4, triple-header tournaments against UC Santa Cruz, UC Davis, UC Merced, and Sacramento State. We are a part of the Pacific Region Central Conference. This fall we are planning on scrimmaging against other west coast teams including USC and Oregon. As our first official year as a recognized Cal Club Sport, we are excited to make history!
summary: The purpose of this organization is to provide an opportunity to play fastpitch softball for those who would prefer a lower time commitment than Berkeley's Division 1 team, and to promote recreation and team-building among Berkeley's students.

name: Cal Club Tennis
description:
Cal Club Tennis is a co-ed, competitive, club tennis team. In the fall season (which is on pause this semester due to Covid-19), we usually travel locally and play against other schools in the Bay Area, and in the spring we compete in Cali Cup and Nationals! We are the nine time defending Northern California Sectionals champions and finished second at Nationals last year.

 

We will be tabling at Calapalooza on:

- Wednesday, Sept 2 from 4-6PM PDT (https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/94512229967)

- Thursday, Sept 3 from 4-6PM PDT (https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/91404582883)

Visit our website to find our roster, news, schedule, contact, FAQ, and more.

 

For more information please visit:  https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/club-tennis/
summary: Cal Club Tennis is a student-run organization that practices and competes during the school year. The club plays in USTA Tennis On Campus Tournaments and we use World Team Tennis rules in match play, which emphasizes both singles and doubles play.

name: Cal Community Music
description: We are a music service group that connects student and alumni musicians and performs for local senior communities and at charity events. We meet every Saturday from 1-3PM in the Morrison Hall practice rooms! Email us calcommunitymusic@gmail.com with any questions!
summary: We are a music service group that connects student musicians and performs for local senior communities and at charity events.

name: Cal Copts
description:
This club serves the Coptic community at UC Berkeley. Join for the community, meetings, socials, and more!

Please use this link for more information and pop on by to our weekly meeting, Thursday nights at 8 PM!
summary: To educate members and interested community members of Coptic history and traditions through guest lectures and meetings, to serve the community and to form a well rounded environment for Coptic students to interact with as a family.

For more info see - https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/cycling/

name: Cal Dragon Boat
description:
Founded in 1998, Cal Dragon Boat is a competitive student-run dragon boat team at UC Berkeley that regularly participates in regional, national and international races. We are a diverse group of hardworking students studying various concentrations, ranging from medicine to engineering to architecture. We strive to make dragon boating more accessible to the students of UC Berkeley and recruit student-athletes twice a year. We are extremely proud to be one of the top college teams in the United States.

Dragon boating is a water sport in which a canoe-shaped boat of up to twenty people paddle together in synchronized rhythm to make the boat move, emulating a soaring dragon. Usually, races are 200, 500 or 2000 meters in length. Dragon boating is traditionally observed during the Chinese Duan Wu festival. However, it is now a much more common year-round activity and is one of the fastest-growing sports throughout the world.

We are not recruiting Fall 2020 due to Covid, but will still have engagement videos and events for people interested in Cal DB and especially those interested in trying out Spring 2021. Here is a link to our engagement mailing list: https://forms.gle/Kdot6zPN1brQMixJ9. Also, please check out our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/caldb/) or website (caldragonboat.berkeley.edu) for more info!
summary: Founded in 1998, Cal Dragon Boat is a competitive student-run dragon boat team at UC Berkeley that regularly participates in regional and international races.

description:

name: Cal Habitat for Humanity
description: Cal Habitat is a student organization that manages a variety of volunteer events and service projects to support local communities. We aim to tackle issues such as the housing crisis through service, education, and advocacy. We achieve our mission with the support of student volunteers, community partners, and our local affiliate, Habitat East Bay/Silicon Valley. Since our inception in 1999, thousands of students have joined our cause, and we have grown into one of the largest campus chapters in the country. Together, we are working towards a world where everyone has a decent place to live. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us over slack/facebook/instagram/email!
summary: Cal Habitat is committed to building affordable housing and strengthening communities in the Bay Area and beyond.

name: Cal Handball Club
description: For More Info See https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/handball/
summary: Cal Handball Club competes locally, regionally, and nationally at both collegiate and club tournaments. We offer instruction at all levels- our team is made up of players from novice to advanced.

name: Cal Hang-Gliding Club

summary: A group to promote awareness of and safety in the sport of hang gliding

name: Cal Hawai'i Club
description:
Purpose

A. To promote an understanding, awareness, and appreciation of the lifestyle and culture unique to the Polynesian islands. 

B. To teach students the beauty of Polynesian cultural song and dance. 

C. To help incoming students with similar backgrounds adjust to university life. 

D. To promote fellowship among students interested in Polynesian culture.
summary: Cal Hawai'i Club is an organization open to any students interested in learning about Polynesian culture and practices.

name: Cal Hiking and Outdoor Society
description:
The largest and oldest outdoor club on campus!

Community members, undergrads, and grad students get together to enjoy any and all outdoor activities. Hiking, camping, backpacking, climbing, yoga, slacklining... you name, we do it!

IMPORTANT: We only use this CalLink page for administrative purposes with the ASUC, and only add club officers to our roster. If you want to join CHAOS, please go to our "How to Join" tab on our our website, or come out to one of our weekly meetings (details below.)

We meet EVERY Wednesday at 7:30 pm! Locations are posted the Monday before on our Instagram (@berkeleychaos), our Discord (https://discord.gg/JbrP5HQmYA), our website (chaosberkeley.org), and on our Listserv (member access only). Everyone is welcome to stop by, grab dinner or just chill!

Membership is $15 FOR LIFE, and gains you access to the 3000+ email listserv (which includes signups for official weekend events) and the Gear Shed, which contains all types of outdoor gear you will need for your adventures, at no extra cost to you!

Keep it Chaotic! :)
summary:
The largest and oldest outdoor club on campus!

Community members, undergrads, and grad students get together to enjoy any and all outdoor activities. Hiking, camping, backpacking, climbing, yoga, slacklining... you name, we do it!

Wednesdays @ 7:30!

name: Cal in the Capital
description: Since 1965, Cal in the Capital is a student-led program has that prepares 75 UC Berkeley students in their search for a summer internship opportunity in Washington, D.C. Cal in the Capital interns come from all majors, backgrounds, and area of interests. To date, more than 3,900 Cal in the Capital interns have served over 1.6 million hours of service in hundreds of professional settings, including Congressional offices, think tanks, national non-profit organizations, media centers, private companies, and research institutions.  We welcome all students from all academic classes and majors!
summary: Cal in the Capital is a student-run program at UC Berkeley that helps around 70 students each year learn the application and professional skills necessary to find a summer internship in Washington, D.C.

name: Cal Japan Club
description:
Cal Japan Club 紹介動画はこちら！Watch this quick 1-minute intro about our club HERE!

詳細や連絡はこちらのFBグループよりどうぞ! Join our Facebook group for the latest details and event information HERE!

Cal Japan Club brings the Japanese student community together by providing networking, socializing, and career opportunities to Japanese, Japanese-American, and any other students involved with Japanese language or culture. We are a club open to everyone! 

Open to anyone involved or interested in Japanese culture, we aim to create an inclusive space for the Japanese community and beyond, providing support through social and preprofessional career events. 

The official language of CJC is Japanese. However, as most of our social and career events provide English translations, we hope this will not deter any future members from joining our events!

Our Social Team traditionally hosts the following events every semester; 1st General Meeting, Welcome Back Party, Halloween Party (Fall Semester), and the End of Semester Banquet. This year, we hope to host smaller and more intimate events in order to stay connected with our members on an individual basis. 

Our Career Team specializes in providing support for Japan-specific career opportunities. On top of host panel discussions, on-campus company info sessions, and career workshops, we also focus on providing and sharing information related to recruitment in Japan, as well as hosting an in-person job-related events.
summary: Cal Japan Club brings the Japanese student community together by providing networking, socializing, and career opportunities to Japanese, Japanese-American, and any other students involved with Japanese language or culture. We are a club open to everyone

name: Cal Lightweight Rowing
description:
California Lightweight Crew is the club rowing team. Known as the ‘Cal Lightweights’ or ‘Cal Lights,’ the team is a member of the Western Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

At Cal Lightweights, we work hard to foster a competitive yet friendly atmosphere as we work together to fortify our mental and physical strength and excel in regattas. Any experience level welcome!

For more information click the links below!
summary: California Lightweight Crew is the club rowing team. Known as the ‘Cal Lightweights’ or ‘Cal Lights,’ the team is a member of the Western Intercollegiate Rowing Association.

name: Cal Men's Club Lacrosse
description: For more info see: https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/mens-lacrosse/
summary: The Men’s Lacrosse club has existed for 55 years. It has prided itself on excelling in the classroom and on the field. Men’s Lax is dedicated to continuing its long tradition of success, and building into an even bigger and brighter program.

name: Cal Men's Squash
description: See https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/mens-squash/
summary: Cal Squash is dedicated to fostering mental and physical strength, good health, and a sense of community. Ending last season as the top club team in the nation, the organization has no intention of slowing down.

name: Cal Men’s Club Soccer
description:
See https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/mens-club-soccer/

Join our zoom on Wednesday and Thursday 4-5 PM PDT for more information at Calapalooza at: Calapalooza link
summary: The California Men’s Club Soccer Team is a competitive team of motivated players from around the world. They are self-coached and all players have significant high school, club, and/or college experience.

name: Cal Men’s Club Water Polo
description:
UC Berkeley Men's Club Water Polo is a competitive team composed of around 25 students. Our normal years consist of a fall season and a spring offseason. During the fall, we practice four times a week and compete in three to four tournaments against other schools in our area, including rivals Stanford and UC Davis. Each season we strive to win our region and qualify for nationals, which we've done in seven of the past eight years. Springs are more relaxed, although we continue to compete in at least a couple tournaments.

Outside of the pool, we're a closely knit group and are frequently found bodysurfing at nearby beaches, playing spikeball on the glade, and dominating the IM sports leagues. 

We look forward to talking to you at Caltopia! In the meantime, feel free to check out or reach out to us on our facebook page at the link below!

Facebook Page
summary: The Men’s Cal Water Polo Club is a competitive team comprised of players of many backgrounds. We are members of the Sierra Pacific Division.

name: Cal Men’s Ultimate
description:
Cal Men’s Ultimate is a D1 Ultimate Frisbee team that competes at high-level tournaments in California and the rest of the US. Cal Men's Ultimate prides itself on a well built culture of togetherness, competitiveness and fun! We have a strong tradition for success, placing 11th, 5th and 2nd at Nationals in past seasons, and earning trips to Nationals in 2019 and 2020. Cal players succeed at the highest level of Ultimate; current and former players have joined the ranks of professional and top-tier club teams such as Polar Bears, Revolver and the San Jose Spiders. The team is coached by Dan Silverstein, the head coach of the San Jose professional team. 

For more info - https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/mens-ultimate/
summary: Cal Men’s Ultimate is a D1 Ultimate Frisbee team that competes at high-level tournaments in California and the rest of the US. Cal Men's Ultimate prides itself on a well built culture of togetherness, competitiveness, and fun!

name: Cal Men’s Volleyball Club
description: For more info - https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/mens-club-volleyball/
summary: The Cal Men’s volleyball club is a nationally competitive part of the college club volleyball scene. The club fields 2 teams and uses Fall semester as a preseason. In Spring, both teams compete in the Northern California College Volleyball League.

name: Cal Pre-Vet Club
description:
Mission
The mission of the Cal PVC is to connect pre-veterinary students at the University of California, Berkeley, in a supportive community and to provide opportunities to learn about the field of veterinary medicine.  These opportunities include:
  • lectures delivered by professionals in the veterinary and animal science fields.
  • educational field trips to veterinary and animal care facilities.
  • community service for or with local animal welfare organizations.
  • informational meetings that address students' questions about academics and obtaining animal experience.
Why Cal PVC?
Cal PVC prides itself in being UC Berkeley's premier resource for pre-veterinary students.  Cal PVC aims to serve its members in all academic and extracurricular endeavors, and these services are unique to Cal PVC alone.  Through the club, Cal PVC members forge long-lasting relationships with local veterinarians, enjoy priority for behind-the-scenes tours of major organizations, and receive significant aid in preparing their applications for veterinary school.  Cal PVC hosts a wealth of knowledge and experiences, and we are proud to serve the UC Berkeley veterinary community.
 
 
We meet every Thursday at 7:00 PM in 3007 VLSB!
 
No membership is required! Any prevet student is welcome to attend any of our meetings!
 
Check our Instagram for weekly updates on all meetings: @calprevetclub
 
To reach out with any questions, contact: prevet.president@gmail.com
summary: The purpose of the Cal PVC is to connect UCB pre-veterinary students with one another in a supportive environment and to provide opportunities to learn about the field of veterinary medicine.

name: Cal Queer & Asian
description:
Dedicated to building community among Queer & Asian students, Cal Queer & Asian welcomes all interested students to join us. Whether you’re still questioning, seeking friends, looking for activism/leadership/educational opportunities and beyond, Cal Q&A is a great group to join. You don’t even have to be queer or Asian - anyone who has a genuine interest is considered family :) 

Cal Q&A was founded in 1995 on the UC Berkeley campus as a student organization dedicated to the intersectionality of the Queer and Asian identities. Through meetings, various monthly events, and our annual conference, Cal Q&A acts as a safe space, social group, and support network for any and every student on the UC Berkeley campus. Our meetings are casual and relaxed, and we invite students to come in at anytime and bring a friend if they like.

Resources | linktr.ee/calqa | https://www.instagram.com/calqanda/
summary: Cal Q&A was established to provide a space for safety, support, and empowerment for and to meet the needs of lesbian, gay, bi-sexual, transgender, queer and questioning individuals interested in queer and Asian topics.

name: Cal Racquetball Club
description: For more info see: https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/racquetball/
summary: The Racquetball Club provides a learning and casual environment for beginners and a competitive setting for advanced players. Our coaches provide weekly clinics during each semester that covers the rules, strokes, form, strategies, and more!

name: Cal Rotaract
description:
Check out our Website! calrotaract.org

Check out our Instagram! instagram.com/crotaract 

 

What is Cal Rotaract?

Sponsored by international service organization, Rotary International, Cal Rotaract is a service club for young men and women ages 18-30.

Modeled after similar goals and standards to those of Rotary, Rotaract brings together college students and young business professionals for the purpose of humanitarian service, networking, building goodwill and promoting peace around the world. As one of the fastest-growing Rotary programs, Rotaract on the international scale includes more than 8,000 Rotaract clubs in some 155 countries.

Each individual Rotaract club is sponsored by a local Rotary club, and is generally either university- or community-based. Each chapter has its own unique personality, sometimes with special emphases and focuses dependent upon the array of members and their particular interests. Like Rotary, Rotaract clubs meet on a regular basis, and are nonpolitical, nonreligious and open to anyone interested.

Rotaractors address many of global and local issues pertinent to today’s society, developing projects that promote service, build friendship and provide a forum for cultural exchange.

 

Why Join Rotaract?
  • Service opportunities: The main focus of Rotaract is humanitarian service on all fronts–locally, nationally and internationally. UC Berkeley offers a variety of community service opportunities several times a month, many of which are local. Additionally, transportation is always arranged for members, so members can always get to events regardless of distance.
  • Networking: Networking is key to any profession, so what better way to make connections than in a club that gives you direct access to Rotarians, all of whom are professionals at the top of their field, both undergraduate and graduate students in a variety of majors and fields of study, and young business professionals?
  • Awards & Scholarships: Rotaract will give you the inside on Rotary-related scholarship opportunities as they come along, including those that have specific scholarships set aside for Rotaractors. These include the extremely prestigious Rotary Ambassadorial Scholarship, The Scholar Ship and International RYLA (Rotary Youth Leadership Awards).
  • International connections: One of the key benefits of Cal Rotaract is our affiliation with Rotary International, an influential community service organization that has clubs all over the world.

For more information about Rotaract, how to join, and when our upcoming meetings are, please view our website and Instagram group above.

 

Sponsors

Cal Rotaract is proudly sponsored by:

Rotary Club of Berkeley
summary: Sponsored by the world's oldest service organization, Rotary International, Cal Rotaract is a service club for those interested in humanitarian service, networking, building goodwill, and promoting peace around the world.

name: Cal Sailing Team
description: For more info see: https://sailing.berkeley.edu

name: Cal Seismic Design Team
description:
Starting with the design process all the way to the construction phase, members will be utilizing their engineering skills along with other outside resources to perform successfully. Throughout the year, the group will meet to brainstorm ideas for the design, proposals for the overall look, and actual construction of the structure.  

Since the college does not have specified classes for this emphasis, this group focuses on applying their knowledge and intuition into a competition based team. Competing in the Undergraduate Seismic Design Competition, held by the Earthquake Engineering Research Institute (EERI), is the main focus of this group.
summary: The Cal Seismic Design Competition Team provides a unique opportunity for UC Berkeley students to learn about earthquake engineering. The group creates a five foot balsa wood structure built to withstand different earthquakes and competes internationally

name: Cal Super Mileage Vehicle Team
description:
Since the beginning of CalSMV in 1991, the Team has focused its ambitions towards small, single-passenger prototype vehicles designed to prioritize fuel efficiency before all else. As the world and as technology has changed, so has the CalSMV Team.

The revitalization of Super Mileage in 2013 brought along not just a new team of ambitious members from multitudes of practices, but a new ambition and new drive. Remembering the heritage and the history left by CalSMV alumni, the Team today seeks to expand the original mission of efficiency towards a larger, real-world scope — quite literally.

Starting in 2016, CalSMV began pursuing an ultra-efficient vehicle driven by a pure battery-electric drivetrain (a first for the team) on top of a large street legal carbon-monocoque.

The vehicle, aptly named Lux, features custom motor controller, and a design built completely in-house with our very own CNC router. To match real world expectations, Lux features safety designs such as dual-crumple zones and double-wishbone suspension systems. No detail is left behind, not even windshield wipers. The CalSMV Team is driven by curiosity and by enthusiasm; there are no bounds! We are now working on designing and manufacturing a new EV, Joule, and have also started a new Autonomous Programming team to compete in the virtual autonomous competition. 

The aim behind such a large ambition resides in our team’s shared desire to push beyond the bounds of competition in order to experience what it is like to build a vehicle for the real world. The challenges that reside with such a goal offer opportunities for stimulating innovations, new industry collaborations, and immersive hands-on experiences. And for the Team, beyond engineering and design, our number one goal is to bring together the CalSMV Family and develop firsthand skills to pass on as wonderful, insightful experiences.

– cal super mileage vehicle team
summary: The Cal Super Mileage Vehicle Team makes electric urban concept vehicles designed to prioritize efficiency before all else. Projects include powertrain, chassis, systems, and autonomous subsystems.

name: Cal Taiko
description:
Instagram: @calraijintaiko

Facebook: facebook.com/calraijintaiko

Watch our trailer/past performances on YouTube (youtube.com/caltaiko) to learn more about taiko!

Founded in 2005 by Tom Hata and Andrew Rowland, Cal Raijin Taiko has been a part of the UC Berkeley community as its only taiko, or Japanese drumming, team. Our group is highly committed to practicing the art of taiko and sharing the culture of taiko with the community. With roughly twenty members, Cal Taiko meets two to three times a week on campus to practice musical drills, songs, and prepare for performances. Outside of practice hours, Cal Taiko also writes its own repertoire and builds its own equipment. Whether it be practicing at night around campus or performing at events such as Calapalooza and Cal Day, Cal Taiko is excited to have become a regular part of campus activities and enjoys sharing the energy of taiko with the students of Cal.

 

If you'd like to contact us or request a performance, check out our website at http://www.caltaiko.org, or email us at caltaiko@gmail.com !
summary: Cal Raijin Taiko is a Japanese drumming team comprised of UC Berkeley students who love taiko! Cal Taiko members meet 2-3 times a week to practice and prepare for on and off campus performances. We are recruiting in the fall!

name: Cal Triathlon (Cal Tri)
description:
Cal Tri works to promote the sport of Triathlon within the Berkeley community by getting more athletes out in the water, on the road, and in races far and wide. With over 150 members, Cal Tri is one of the largest and most successful collegiate triathlon programs in the country. We see endurance training as a lifestyle, and we think of ourselves as both a team and a family. Here you will meet some of your best friends, and our adventures will take you all across California, the United States, and even the World.

We are open to athletes of all skill levels and abilities, from complete beginners to seasoned professionals. On Cal Tri, you will discover a unique group of people who will help you to become the triathlete and the person you want to be.

 

Be sure to join our recruitment mailing list and check out our Website, Facebook, Instagram, and Youtube Channel for more info. 

 

https://youtu.be/Bq-d5gyaBkY
summary: The purpose of the Cal Triathlon (Cal Tri) is to bring the sport of triathlon to the student community at the University of California, Berkeley and its surrounding environs.

name: Cal Undergraduate Public Health Coalition
description:
Cal UPHC gives students opportunities to lead service, research, and educational events in the areas of International Health, Health Policy and Advocacy, Community Health, and Environmental Health. Other past projects/events include teaching De-Cal courses, hosting internship workshops, holding nutrition fairs, promoting health awareness days, and sending opportunity updates. Future events will include career dinners, mixers with public health professionals, panels, and networking events.

Check out our website for more information!
summary: We are a professional organization that strives to give students the skills, experience, opportunities and support necessary to excel in the field of public health.

name: Cal Veterans Group
description:
The Cal Veterans Group (CVG) was created in 2004 by a UC Berkeley student veteran looking for a way to bring together military veterans on campus, reach out to returning vets across the community, and provide resources and mentorship for future students.

Currently, we engage in all of this work plus more. From philanthropic activities, outreach to local community colleges, and advocacy on legislation pertaining to veterans, we serve to become a beacon for vets hopeful of gaining access to and succeeding in higher education.

The Group is a student organization led by undergraduate student veterans. We usually hold meetings every two weeks during the Fall and Spring semesters, and encourage as many veterans as possible to be involved! During official meetings we invite representatives to give presentations on topics ranging from veteran’s advocacy to job recruitment.

Joining and becoming involved with the Cal Veterans Group is a great opportunity to expand your professional and social networks! Veteran alumni are great contacts whether you aspire to attend graduate school, or hit the ground running in the job market following graduation. Additionally, we throw social events like Tailgates (on Cal football game days), or just hang out!

Our Facebook page is our primary means of communication. Here you will be kept up-to-date with group happenings!

 

FB: Cal Veterans Group

IG: @cal.veterans.group
summary: The Cal Veterans Group (CVG) is UC Berkeley's largest veteran organization on campus!

name: Cal Women’s Club Lacrosse
description:
Since its founding in 2008, we have made a significant impact on west coast lacrosse. In the 2019-2020 preseason, we ranked among the top 20 in the country, and with continued success, finished among the top 10.

Preseason practice begins in the fall and resumes in the spring during our regular season. We travel all over the West Coast, and games are held on the weekends. We welcome all levels of experience!

description:
The Cal Women’s Club Water Polo team is a part of the Sierra Pacific League in the Collegiate Water Polo Association (CWPA). We attend several tournaments throughout the season including both invitationals and CWPA official tournaments, culminating in division championships and, if we win, Nationals! We practice 2-3 times a week in the Fall and 3-4 times a week in the Spring, which is our main competition season. name: California Mock Trial
description:
Mock Trial is a team-based speech competition that combines elements of law, speech, debate, and theatre. As a simulation of trial advocacy, Mock Trial also includes simulations of courtroom procedure and technique that reflect a real trial.

Cal Mock Trial is UC Berkeley’s official Mock Trial Team. Since its founding in 1999, Cal Mock Trial has been a nationally ranked program and has consistently competed at the top levels of collegiate mock trial.

As part of its competitive season, Cal Mock Trial regularly travels across the tournament to compete. Recent years have seen the Golden Bears competing and winning trials at locations such as Washington DC, New York City, Miami, Chicago, and Los Angeles. Cal Mock Trial is a constant presence at the National Championship Tournament each year, often qualifying two separate teams and placing among the top ten programs in the nation.
summary: Cal Mock Trial is UC Berkeley’s official Mock Trial Team. Mock trial is a team-based competition that combines the elements of law, speech, debate, and theater. Since its founding in 1999, CMT has been one of the top-ranked programs in the country.

name: California Public Interest Research Group
description:
CALPIRG Students is a student-run, student-funded nonprofit at eight of the UCs that, through grassroots organizing and advocacy, fights to protect our environment, make college more affordable, and reinvigorate our democracy.

 

CALPIRG stands for California Public Interest Research Group, so we fight against private/special interests who have a lot more money, but we have the people power. With over forty years of grassroots organizing experience, there is no other nonprofit like CALPIRG Students.

 

We've worked on things you now take for granted, such as mandatory seat belts in cars and nutrition labels on food. Just in the past couple of years we've committed California to 100% clean electricity by 2045 (we started the '100%' motto everyone now knows is referring to renewable energy), committed UC Berkeley to 100% clean energy (the first major institution to do so), passed a statewide bag ban (we were known as the 'bag people'), registered thousands of people to vote, and much more.

 

We're the largest student group in California with due paying members, so we're very supported! As our track record implies, we’re a very goals-orientated nonprofit. We have different campaigns (or teams) within our organization that have specific goals. This semester we have Plastic-Free Seas, 100% Renewable Energy, Zero Hunger, Save the Bees, and New Voters Project. We'll be fighting to ban single-use plastics on campus, commit UC Berkeley to Zero Hunger by 2025, and become the first bee friendly certified UC campus!

 

If you are interested in learning how to make make a campaign plan, build grassroots support, lobby your elected officials, and make real change, come check us out and see what we can accomplish together!
summary: CALPIRG Students is a student-run, student-funded nonprofit at eight of the UCs that, through grassroots organizing and advocacy, fights to protect our environment, make college more affordable, and reinvigorate our democracy.

name: Californians, The
description:
The Californians is a dynamic group dedicated to providing campus and community service, leadership development and class unity for the purpose of making today’s active students into tomorrow’s active alumni. We're bringing back our class council system Seniors! Anyone interested is welcome! 

During the fall, The Californians participate in Homecoming and plan the December General Commencement for graduating seniors. In the Spring, The Californians plan Career Networking Seminar (CNS), an alumni networking session, and Cal 101, a panel for prospective students and parents of prospective students during Cal Day.

Along with this, The Californians plan Senior Week, which include the long tradition of painting the Big C white and numerous other event, and May Commencement (Commencement speaker, performers, etc.)

If you are interested in joining, please follow our Instagram @berkeleyscc!
summary: The Californians is a dynamic group dedicated to providing campus and community service, leadership development and class unity for the purpose of making today’s active students into tomorrow’s active alumni.

name: CalSol
description:
Founded in 1990, CalSol, the UC Berkeley Solar Vehicle Team, is a student-run racing team that designs, builds, tests, and races next generation solar vehicles. CalSol provides its team members with real world engineering and project management experience while developing and raising awareness of clean energy technologies.

For more information, or if you're interested in joining, please visit our website, https://calsol.berkeley.edu/!
summary: CalSol, the UC Berkeley Solar Vehicle Team, is an ASUC-sponsored student-run racing team whose mission is to design, build, test, and race next generation solar vehicles.

name: Camp Kesem Berkeley
description:
With over 5 million children impacted by a parent's cancer, Kesem must continue expanding to meet this need. Kesem is the largest national organization dedicated to this unique population, and for many children, their Kesem experience is a life-changing event–providing them a community of children with similar experiences, and a safe and welcoming environment to have fun and rediscover their childhood.

Beyond that, our replicable and highly scalable funding model also allows for rapid expansion. Kesem now serves 10 times the number of children supported ten years ago. In summer 2019, more than 10,200 children attended over 100 week-long sessions of Kesem held at fun and exciting campsites from coast-to-coast. And with your help, we hope to continue supporting more and more children each year!

Thank you for being an important part of our growth as we support children through and beyond their parent's cancer with innovative, fun-filled programs that foster a lasting community!
summary: Kesem is a nationwide community, driven by passionate college student leaders, that supports children through and beyond their parent's cancer. Kesem provides free year-round support & summer camp for children who have been impacted by a parent's cancer.

description: We are UC Berkeley’s ASUC Student Union; the center of co-curricular life at Cal. Visit us to eat, shop, study, have fun, and access resources. We are located at the corner of Bancroft & Telegraph in the MLK Jr. Building and Eshleman Hall. We house the Cal Student Store, Amazon Hub+, Event Services, the Berkeley Art Studio, Creative Lab, Food Pantry, OASIS, Public Service Center, OCF, BWell at BNorth, the ASUC and GA Student Governments, and much more!
summary: GA DSSF

name: Campus Dept | Basic Needs Center
description:
The Basic Needs Center acts as a central hub to support students in their journey to access essential services that impact health, belonging, and overall well-being. The Basic Needs Center team is committed to fostering belonging and advocating for justice on the UC Berkeley campus through a robust model of prevention, intervention and emergency relief efforts addressing holistic needs. We define basic needs as an ecosystem that includes:

  • financial stability 
  • nutritious, accessible, cultural reflective, and sufficient food 
  • safe, secure and adequate housing (to sleep, study, cook and shower)  
  • health equity 
  • accessible transportation 
  • tech-equity 
  • equitable support for students with disproportionate basic needs experiences including but not limited to  students with disabilities, parenting students/students with dependents

name: Campus Dept | Bears for Financial Success
description: Bears for Financial Success is a peer-to-peer financial wellness program housed in the Financial Aid and Scholarships Office at UC Berkeley. We offer workshops and one-on-one appointments to help students manage their personal finances in college and beyond.
summary: .Peer-to-peer financial wellness program that helps students manage their personal finances.

name: Campus Dept | Bears that Care
description:
Bears That CARE (BTC) is an active bystander initiative to make our campus safer. Through interactive workshops about bystander intervention, Bears That CARE educates and empowers individuals to effectively and safely intervene in potentially harmful or violent situations. We strive to create a community of care.

 

Our staff is comprised of peer educators. Peer educators provide workshops to student groups across campus and actively promote violence prevention through a variety of programs, as well as lead workshops for academic and student affairs departments.

 

Our work is based off of using the CARE model to safely intervene in potentially harmful situations. Confront the situation, Alert others, Redirect attention, Engage afterwards. 

 

Our interactive workshops include a variety of topics and can be customized to your need! We host workshops on:

- General Bystander Intervention

- Consent

- Advanced Consent

- Alcohol Education

- Social Identities and Microaggressions

- Mental Health

- Suicide Awareness

Learn more at https://csi.berkeley.edu/prevention/btc/
summary: Bears that CARE (BTC) is active bystander initiative through the Center of Support and Intervention that aims to make campus a safer community by empowering individuals to intervene in harmful situations. Take care of your fellow bears!

The Berkeley Art Studio offers classes in ceramics, design, painting, drawing, and photography. The Studio has a rich history of providing quality art instruction for our members through our staff of professional artists. The Berkeley Art Studio is a welcoming place for students and artists at various skill levels. Berkeley Art Studio registration is open to the entire community as well as UC Students, Faculty, and Staff.

Over it's 40 year history the Berkeley Art Studio has proven to be more than just a space, but a community of artists committed to their craft.

Our creative community is enriched by the scientific and cultural wealth of a world-class public research university, one that is propelled by an historic public mission and committed to access and social impact.
summary: The UC Berkeley Arts + Design Initiative features, fortifies, and mobilizes existing excellence in the arts and design at Berkeley.

name: Campus Dept | Berkeley Student Leadership & Engagement (formerly LEAD Center)
description:
The Berkeley Student Leadership & Engagement website (formerly the LEAD Center) is your one-stop-shop to student clubs and organizations, fraternity and sorority life, student government, student leadership programs, and more. Our goal is to assist you as you explore your interests, pursue your passions, and create community at Cal.

We’ve structured our offices to better support you. 

Organization Advising & Student Involvement Services (OASIS)

Find support for creating and managing your registered student organization through OASIS. We’ll walk you through how to register your org, how to promote your org through our Callink portal, and more.

Learn more about student orgs

Fraternity & Sorority Life  

Learn how to connect with fraternity and sorority life on campus, or stay up to date on how to manage your chapter including information on CalGreeks policies.  

Learn more about CalGreeks

Student Governance & Program Advising

Learn about the Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC) or Graduate Assembly (GA) or connect with our Student Government Advisors. 

Learn more about Student Government

Student Leadership & Programs

Our new Student Leadership Programs team designs and implements leadership training, workshops, and leadership development programs that support holistic student engagement at UC Berkeley.

Learn more about our Student Leadership Programs

bridges Multicultural Resources Center (bridges MRC)

A coalition of student communities dedicated to outreach and recruitment of underrepresented students to Berkeley and uplifting and strengthening communities of color in all aspects of campus life: academic, social, and communal.

Learn more about bridges MRC

Queer Alliance & Resource Center

A student-run organization in charge of providing social, educational, and safe sex programming for the queer and trans community on campus, and also acts as an umbrella organization for all active queer/trans communities on campus.

Learn more about QARC

Cal Debate

A program teaching critical thinking skills and persuasive communication techniques to an elite group of students who compete at a national level. Cal Debate is one of the most successful intercollegiate debate teams in the country.

Learn more about Cal Debate
summary: The Berkeley Student Leadership & Engagement supports student-centered learning and development by cultivating student leadership. We advise and empower individuals, student organizations, student government, and various other campus communities

name: Campus Dept | Cal Interfaith Council
description:
“Cal Interfaith Council” is a group of committed local faith-based leaders who have agreed to meet approximately once a month, or at a times of crisis, to come together to engage with each other and the campus community to discuss and address issues that are pertinent to the University of California Berkeley community

This is a volunteer organization whose membership requirements are simply summarized by acknowledging the following:

  • A commitment to actively participate in regular meetings.
  • A respect for all faiths

Current membership roster is linked here

MESSAGE OF LOVE FROM THE CAL INTERFAITH COUNCIL:

We are clergy and faith leaders on and around the UC Berkeley campus and are members of the Cal Interfaith Council. We acknowledge that in this time of deep political division, the Cal campus is experiencing a heightened sense of turmoil and distress, particularly around a series of provocative high profile political speakers/events and a wide range of responses by members of the Cal community and beyond.

Our spiritual and theological traditions offer deep wisdom for turbulent times like the ones we are now experiencing. When our national climate sensationalizes division and violence, scapegoats and stigmatizes the vulnerable and disenfranchised, and gives a platform to hate, we are committed to embodying this wisdom here in Berkeley to amplify the voices of love, peaceful protest, civic dialogue, and zero tolerance for hate speech. As faith leaders from a variety of traditions and religions, we affirm the value of free speech and exchange of ideas, and honor a long legacy of respectful engagement across differences.

Honoring our differences, and the complexity of the present moment in our city and our country, we stand united in and for love, and we commit to working for a just world for all, starting here on the Cal Campus.

Signed by Cal Interfaith Council
summary: Cal Interfaith Council is a group of committed local faith-based leaders who have agreed to meet approximately once a month, or at a times of crisis, to come together to engage with each other and the campus community

name: Campus Dept | Cal Performances
description:
Cal Performances is the performing arts presenting, commissioning, and producing organization based at the University of California, Berkeley. The origins of Cal Performances date from 1906, when stage actress Sarah Bernhardt appeared at the William Randolph Hearst Greek Theater to help rebuild public morale after the devastating San Francisco earthquake and fire in April of that year.

Over the subsequent century, Cal Performances grew to become the largest, multi-discipline performing arts presenter in Northern California, and one of the largest university-based arts presenters in the United States. Traditional and non-traditional artists regularly appear on or near the UC Berkeley campus in the theaters and concert halls managed by Cal Performances, including Mikhail Baryshnikov, Wynton Marsalis, Cecilia Bartoli, Bryn Terfel, Mark Morris, Yo-Yo Ma, Philip Glass, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Merce Cunningham, Pina Bausch, Bill T. Jones, Peter Sellars, and Robert Lepage; as well as artists based in the San Francisco Bay Area like John Adams, Lou Harrison, Margaret Jenkins, Paul Dresher, Kronos Quartet, Joe Goode, Kaila Flexer, Jon Jang, and Sarah Cahill. Cal Performances is also instrumental in facilitating the touring of large ensembles from abroad and has hosted such companies as the Grand Kabuki Theater of Japan, the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballet companies, Lyon Opera Ballet and Orchestra, the Kirov Orchestra, the Russian National Orchestra, the Berliner Ensemble, the Beijing People’s Art Theater, the Gate Theater of Dublin, Les Arts Florissants, Ballet Nacional de Cuba, and Nederland Dans Theater, among others.

Cal Performances presents over 100 performances annually in five venues—Zellerbach Hall, Zellerbach Playhouse, Hertz Hall, and Wheeler Hall on the UC Berkeley campus, and First Congregational Church of Berkeley—and in site-specific locations and other spaces. The performances range among Modern and Classical Dance, Theater, Instrumental and Vocal Recital, Early Music, Opera, Chamber Music, Jazz, New Music, World Music, Dance & Theater, Circus Arts, and a speaking series. Cal Performances serves some 150,000 patrons annually through performances and arts education, residency, and community programs.
summary: Cal Performances presents phenomenal music, dance, theater, and circus arts performances from all over the world. Visit https://calperformances.org/ for information on the stellar artists on our 2021-22 season, access to student discounts, and much more!

name: Campus Dept | Disability Cultural Community Center
description:
The Disability Cultural Community (DCC) Center at UC Berkeley welcomes all new students to visit our Zoom room during the Fall 2021 GBO virtual resource fair. We are excited to meet you and share information that can help you transition into your experience and form community as a new Cal student. 

When: Friday, August 20, 2021 from 1:00 PM-4:00 PM

Where: via the Zoom platform, join by using the following link.

Join Zoom Meeting
https://berkeley.zoom.us/j/99043775635

We invite you to:

  • Get information about the Disability Cultural Community Center on campus
  • Obtain information on upcoming events and services offered
  • Learn about the history of the Disability Rights Movement and community
  • Honor the history and significance of how the center came into being
  • Discover information around Self-advocacy and how to connect with other disabled student organizations
  • Opportunities to be connected with other students
  • ...and more

 

Please contact us if we can provide any accommodations to facilitate your participation and access. Direct any questions, comments, recommendations, or requests to Ann Wai-Yee Kwong, Coordinator, at awkwong@berkeley.edu.
summary: The Cal DCC seeks to create and provide a safe and social space for the disability community to build authentic connections and support one another as the community continues to advocate, educate, and collaborate.

name: Campus Dept | Financial Aid and Scholarships
Campus Dept | Future Histories Lab
description:
Future Histories Lab is home for students interested in the intersection of social change, urban space, and the arts. By taking our courses you can earn an Undergraduate or Graduate Certificate in Urban Humanities. 

 

We research stories of place in order to propose new futures. We believe that understanding the history under our feet is necessary to plan for change in our communities. 

 

We use art, storytelling, technology, and installations in public space to illuminate and analyze questions of equity, race, and environment.

 

Faculty, students, and community members work together to conduct collaborative, place-based research and create public-facing websites, performances, memorials, artistic interventions, and policy proposals.

 

We are based jointly at the Arts & Humanities Division and the College of Environmental Design, with participation from many parts of campus. We welcome students from all disciplines to join our community.

 

Start your certificate this fall by enrolling in Restorative Justice in Urban Planning and Policy: Storytelling for Racial Healing & Justice or take our 1-2 unit colloquium Place-Based Storytelling Techniques and Technologies.

 

To find out more visit our website: https://futurehistories.berkeley.edu/
summary: We research stories of place in order to propose new futures. By taking our courses students can earn a Certificate in Urban Humanities while working towards a more socially just future. We welcome students from all disciplines to join our community.
