name: Campus Dept | Parking and Transportation
description:
For details about P&T's Mobility Programs, including recruiting for the AC Transit/ Class Pass Committee and the Mobility and Equity Committee, please visit our website. 

Our Vision and Mission

In support of the University's core academic and public service mission, Parking and Transportation is dedicated to delivering transportation systems that complement long-term growth and development, and enhance and protect the physical attributes of the campus and surrounding area.

To improve the quality of life for the UC Berkeley community by providing safe, convenient, and well maintained parking and transportation options, while promoting and facilitating alternative modes of transportation.

Berkeley Moves! Alternative Transportation Unit

Parking & Transportation provides, to the best of their ability, alternative campus transportation modes and opportunities and incentives for the campus to ditch their cars and use public transit, carpooling, active transportation (walking and biking) and much more. Berkeley Moves! also has a trip planning and ridematching website that allows for campus affiliates to connect with others for commuter opportunities, as well as trip planning throughout the Bay Area and beyond.
summary: The UC Berkeley Parking and Transportation Department provides a full range of transportation services, serving a diverse community of more than 50,000 campus affiliates to and from the City of Berkeley, as well as the San Francisco Bay Area.

name: Campus Dept | PATH to Care Center
description:
The PATH to Care Center leads the efforts to transform our campus into a community that is free of sexual violence, sexual harassment, intimate partner violence, and stalking through prevention, advocacy, training, and healing. We collaborate with the campus community to make social change with the goals of preventing, intervening in, and responding to harassment and violence, eliminating oppression, and creating the culture and environment we all aspire to and deserve. We envision a campus community free of violence and grounded in social justice. This vision will be realized when every member of our community is a beacon of support and respect for those around them.


Mission

The PATH to Care Center leads the efforts to transform our campus into a community that is free of sexual violence, sexual harassment, intimate partner violence, and stalking through prevention, advocacy, training, and healing. We collaborate with the campus community to make social change with the goals of preventing, intervening in, and responding to harassment and violence, eliminating oppression, and creating the culture and environment we all aspire to and deserve.

Vision

We envision a campus community free of violence and grounded in social justice. This vision will be realized when every member of our community is a beacon of support and respect for those around them.

Values

We believe prevention comes first. We know that with time and concerted efforts, violence is 100% preventable, and we believe that, as a UC Berkeley community, we have a moral imperative to prevent violence and suffering.

We center survivors. Survivors began and are imperative to the movement to end sexual violence across the country; their experiences and perspectives are critical to healing and transforming our culture in genuine and meaningful ways.

We are grounded in social justice. We understand that violence is rooted in oppression and that oppression is intersectional, so our approach must also be intersectional. We commit ourselves to expanding access, practicing inclusion, and undoing oppression wherever and whenever possible.

We believe safety is a right. Every human in our community should receive respect for their bodily and emotional integrity and autonomy — always, in every situation.

We practice self-care and kindness. Work grounded in these practices is more sustainable, effective, and transformative.

We seek and value the wisdom of our community. We take a communal approach to our work, knowing that we are all learning from each other.

We are optimistic and hopeful. We know that, as a community, we can eliminate violence and create the campus community we want.


_______________________________________

Opened in 2014, the PATH to Care Center quickly became a cornerstone of support for UC Berkeley students, faculty, and staff. The Center’s first big milestone came when the Chancellor announced Berkeley would create a confidential advocate position, a crucial resource for survivors seeking services, as well as for those seeking to understand or pursue a university disciplinary process.

Later in 2014, the first Bear Pact program launched, educating all incoming first-year and transfer undergraduate students about sexual violence prevention, with content designed and delivered by the University Health Services Health Promotion team. Following this, in the fall, the first advocate – who would go on to become the Center’s first director – was hired: Mari Knuth-Bouracee.

The Center saw an immediate and overwhelming demand for services, which led to the ASUC and GA passing the Wellness Initiative Fee Referendum – a commitment of student fees funding several initiatives, including a new advocate position for the Center. This Referendum solidified the University’s commitment to expanding the Center’s resources for all who need them, and helped lead to rapid growth: two advocates were hired, sexual violence prevention education was included for the first time in graduate student education, and an Assistant Director for Prevention joined the Center’s team. With the rapid expansion and demand for services, the Center quickly grew out of its one-room office and into a new space that included two counseling rooms for client meetings, crucial for confidentiality, in early 2016.

In mid-2016, the Center added an Assistant Director for Survivor Support, a Program Analyst, and two Prevention Program Managers. The need for the Center was clear – and in July, the US Office on Women’s Health awarded the University a grant, with the Center as the lead department, to continue to expand this work.

The Center then launched a peer education program, which began with the hiring of 11 peer educators, as well as a Care Line, the 24/7 crisis line for the University. Continuing its focus on graduate student sexual violence prevention, the Center hired its first Program Manager for Graduate Prevention. The Center also launched The Well, a Black healing space co-led by a Center advocate.

Since its launch, the Center has continued to deepen its focus on both survivor support and prevention. By late 2017, videos created by the Center highlighting these practices had been shown to over 15,000 students, faculty and staff (and continue to be shown each year); the Center launched Yoga As Healing groups; and the Center received further recognition when the Office on Violence Against Women awarded the University a grant, with the Center as the lead department. Another major milestone was successfully advocating for funding for a Prevention Manager for Staff and Faculty Programs; a role that was filled in 2018. Today, the Center continues to expand in both its staff capacity and in the services it provides, further solidifying its place as a key resource for the University.

Contact us today for support!
summary: The PATH to Care Center confidential advocates bring a holistic approach to supporting survivors. Advocates provide affirming, empowering, free, confidential support and bring a non-judgmental, caring approach to exploring all rights and resources.

name: Campus Dept | Student Learning Center
description:
The Student Learning Center is the premier undergraduate academic support unit at UC Berkeley. Founded in 1973, the Center was established to provide a rigorous and inclusive space for undergraduates to collaborate, learn, and grow. We view peer collaboration as the touchstone of academic and personal success. 

The Student Learning Center has grown to serve more than 10,000 undergraduates annually—approximately 30% of the university’s undergraduate population. Today, we’re recognized for our process-oriented, research-driven, and culturally informed approach to collaborative peer pedagogy.

With a wide range of classes, programs, and events, the SLC seeks to push the boundaries of traditional learning models, while advancing our mission of undergraduate empowerment. To further foster academic excellence, we will continue to expand the breadth and depth of our innovative services.

 

Our Mission

The Student Learning Center supports a global community of learners as they navigate the cultural expectations and academic rigor of UC Berkeley. Through service models that honor their diverse starting points and meet them where they are, we aim to empower all students to realize their full academic potential and aspirations.

 

Core Values

  • Deliver service with integrity
  • Approach learning as a process, not a product
  • Create innovative pedagogy and practices that optimize student learning
  • Operate from a student-centered framework
  • Respect diverse ways of knowing and learning

name: Campus Dept | Student Opportunity Fund (SOF)
description:
Welcome to the home page of the Student Opportunity Fund (SOF).  SOF provides funds to registered student organizations for co-curricular events and activities & to individual students for educational focused experiences like conferences and professional meetings.  

 

If you are traveling, please consider applying for funding through either the ASUC or the Graduate Assembly.  

 

If your registered student organization is hosting an event on-campus, please consider applying for funding through either the ASUC Grant & Scholarship Foundation or the Graduate Assembly GRSO Funding.

 

Purpose

The SOF is designed to provide support for events/activities, both co-curricular and educational, for Cal students.

 

--SOF supports programs that foster a greater sense of campus community and that are conducive to free intellectual exchange.
--SOF encourages more interaction and educational experiences for students outside of the classroom, such as visiting speakers, forums on topics of general interest, and special campus panel discussions.  

 

About the Fund

Requests for SOF funds are submitted through the application on the forms tab and are funded on a rolling basis only during the academic year.

 

Requests for both Co-Curricular and Educational Opportunities must be submitted at least two weeks prior to the first day of the event/activity – no exceptions.

 

  1. Co-Curricular Opportunities (student events and publications)

 

This fund provides monetary support to collaborative events/activities planned by and for UC Berkeley students. One of the objectives of this fund is to support programs that foster a greater sense of campus community that is conducive to free intellectual exchange; advance knowledge, such as visiting speakers or forums on topics of general interest; and support the initial creation of a student publication. Additionally, this fund is designed to encourage increased interaction outside of the classroom. Students are encouraged to craft proposals that will provide opportunities for UC Berkeley students to gain valuable leadership experience and knowledge. 

 

Please submit only one event per co-curricular request (a request with multiple events listed will be denied).

 

Funding requests are encouraged to demonstrate:
--Unique opportunity or experience for its participants
--Promotion of an issue/cause relevant to UC Berkeley students
--Significant contribution to the student body
--A broad view of cultural experiences and knowledge 

 

Who can apply for these funds?

 

All registered student organizations are encouraged to apply.

 

NOTE: Your organization will need to work with an OASIS, bridges, F&S Life, or Student Government advisor. Please visit student engagement and leadership to become more familiar with event planning guidelines and restrictions. 

 

  1. Educational Opportunities (off-campus domestic travel)

 

This fund provides support for student access to educational experiences "beyond the classroom," such as to professional meetings, research conferences, and academic competitions. 

 

Due to limited funds, a student can only receive one (1) Educational Opportunity award during the academic year. 

 

Funding requests are encouraged to demonstrate:

--Potential for the advancement of research or the promotion of academic success
--Orientation toward academic or professional development
--Direct relationship to the individual's declared major, field of study, or current course load

 

  1. SOF Director Discretionary Funds

 

This year, there are one-time available funds for initiatives that have substantial campus impact.  The SOF Director will review requests and if a request has substantial campus impact, the SOF Director will ask the student organization/student to meet with the SOF Director to discuss the request.  The SOF Director will decide, no later than two weeks following the meeting, if additional funds will be granted

 

Who can apply for these funds?

All registered students are encouraged to apply.

Note: For any event/activity that conflicts with your course schedule, you will need to review the campus guidelines related to missing classes and fulfilling academic requirements. 

 

General Guidelines

To be considered for funding, the project must:

--Demonstrate clarity of goals and thoroughness of planning.
--Adhere to University policies, campus regulations, and established procedures
--Provide detailed budget to support the event/activity
--Include information on attempts for additional and/or alternative funding
--Establish measures to prevent exclusion or alienation of any community
--Co-curricular events/activities must be sponsored by a registered student organization

If funding is granted, all paperwork associated with the expenses/reimbursements must be submitted within three (3) weeks following the event or funds will be forfeited.  

 

Restrictions

Funds will not be awarded for:

 

--Proposals submitted less than two weeks before the start of the event/activity.

 

--Co-curricular events and/or educational opportunities that have occurred prior to the submission of the SOF request (no retroactive applications will be accepted).

 

--International travel.

 

--Food and lodging associated with domestic travel.

 

--Ongoing educational experiences. Please apply for funding for one trip associated with the ongoing educational experience. 

 

--Commuting expenses related to research or volunteer activities.

 

–Clothes/professional attire. Professional clothing and accessories are not reimbursable.

 

--Support for research projects, research work, or thesis research.

 

--Support for the publishing of a thesis.  

 

--Graduate school tours.

 

--Relocation costs or expenses. 

 

--Educational opportunities occurring after June 1, 2024.

 

--Off campus events/activities (excludes educational opportunities).

 

–Insurance costs for off-campus events.

 

--On-going operating expenses.

 

--Stipends or salaries.

 

--Political events/activities unless all sides of an issue are presented.

 

--Religious services.

 

--Alcohol.

 

--Scholarship funds associated with co-curricular requests.

 

--ASUC funds used for expenses related to the co-curricular opportunity. 

 

--Funding towards any costs associated with an event that did not occur (any cancellation costs).

 

--Fees charged by the student club or organization.

 

--Graduations.

 

--Academic course or decal operation expenses, including texts, readers, field trips, and other expenses. SOF will not provide funding for any expenses related to academic courses or decals.

 

--Programs/Events designed to raise funds for off-campus agencies. SOF will not provide funding for events/activities/projects in which revenue is being given to a non-campus entity or nonprofit organization.

 

--Summer events/activities (events/activities taking place outside of the academic year). 

 

 

Please note:

 

–SOF funding does not carry over for any educational opportunities or any co-curricular events.

 

--SOF will provide funding support to publications only once, and not on an on-going basis.

 

--Payment checks for honoraria are paid once the event/activity is completed and all required paperwork has been properly submitted.

 

--Student organizations planning conferences happening (on-campus or virtually) should be submitted as a co-curricular opportunity and not as an educational opportunity.

 

Student Opportunity Fund (SOF) FAQ

 

Who can submit proposals?

Either registered students or registered student groups.

 

I notice that there are two categories for funding. Can one project qualify as both an Educational and a Co-curricular event/activity?

No.

 

Can I apply more than once? 

Due to limited funds, a student can only receive one (1) Educational Opportunity award during the academic year. 

 

Where can I pick up a funding request? 

All funding requests must be submitted through the application towards the bottom of this page.

 

When are funding requests due? 

Funding requests are accepted on a rolling basis during the academic year but must be submitted at least two weeks prior to the start of the event/activity. 

 

Can I submit a funding request after an event/activity has passed?

No.  Retroactive funding requests are not accepted. Funding requests must be submitted at least two weeks prior to the start of the event/activity.

 

Can I revise a request once it has been submitted?

Yes, unless the request is already under review.

 

When will we be notified of the selection committee's decision? 

The selection committee reviews funding requests as they are submitted. If you have fully completed your funding request, you will be notified by e-mail of the committee's decision within two weeks of submitting a funding request.

 

How much can I receive? 

Due to limited funds, the maximum amount for a Co-Curricular Opportunity is $5,000. The maximum amount for the Educational Opportunity is $2,800 for an individual. 

 

Can I be reimbursed for purchases using airline miles?

Purchases using airline miles are not eligible expenses. There will be no reimbursements for purchases using airline miles. 

 

Can I use previous flight credits to purchase airline tickets? 

Please do not use previous flight credits to purchase a flight as there will be no reimbursements associated with the previous flight credits. 

 

How does the funding work?

If your request is successful, you will receive an email from the Student Opportunity Fund Committee acknowledging your award. That email will tell you how much you have been awarded and the steps that you must follow in order to obtain the funds.

 

Can I apply for funding for an event/activity that will be held next academic year? 

No. 

 

Can a registered student group apply for more than one event/activity in an academic year? 

Yes, but please understand that funds are limited and previous requests will be taken into consideration when approving subsequent requests. SOF is not intended to be the sole funding source for your event or organization. 

 

Do I need to have insurance for my event/activity? What about Security? 

Yes, the advisors in OASIS can provide guidance on insurance and security requirements for campus events/activities.

 

Do I need to be a Registered Student Organization (RSO) in order to receive funding from the SOF? 

Yes. If your group is not currently an RSO, please go to lead.berkeley.edu to learn how to become one.

 

Who can I contact if I have more questions?

Please email sof@berkeley.edu.  We are happy to answer any questions.

 

Request Forms

Co-curricular Opportunities Request

Educational Opportunities Request

 

Additional Funding Options

Here's some additional funding resources to help with co-curricular events/activities.  

For educational opportunities, check with your department, the ASUC Grant & Scholarship Foundation, the funding opportunities through the Graduate Assembly, and crowdfunding your trip.  

 

You can visit 432 Eshleman Hall, 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM, Monday-Friday, or contact them at (510) 642-5171 or at sof@berkeley.edu.
summary: The Student Opportunity Fund (SOF) provides funds to registered student organizations for on-campus co-curricular events and activities & to individual students for educational focused experiences like conferences and professional meetings.

name: Campus Dept | Student Technology Services
description:
Student Tech Services (STS) is a program to ensure all graduate, professional and undergraduate students have access to:

  • Information and education about key technology resources
  • Knowledgeable, friendly, and responsive technical support
  • Policies that all campus members are expected to be familiar with
  • Opportunities to work in student IT jobs throughout campus

We welcome you to reach out to us if you have questions or difficulties with internet and WiFi, Zoom, campus software, your personal device, security, and much more. (510) 642-HELP, sts-help@berkeley.edu

name: Campus Dept | The Green Initiative Fund
description:
Do you...

  • Need funding for your campus sustainability project?
  • Want to know what projects have been funded by TGIF?
  • Want to serve on a committee that awards sustainability grants?
  • Need a student internship that will provide you with green job skills?
  • Want to learn more about UC Berkeley's campus sustainability efforts?
  • Need information regarding starting a green fund at your institution?

If yes, then The Green Initiative Fund is for you!


The Green Initiative Fund (TGIF) provides funding for projects that reduce UC Berkeley's negative impact on the environment and make UC Berkeley more sustainable. TGIF allocates funds to projects that promote sustainable modes of transportation, increase energy and water efficiency, restore habitat, promote environmental and food justice, and reduce the amount of waste created by UC Berkeley. Portions of the fund also support education & behavior change initiatives, student aid (via return to aid), and student internships. Students, faculty, and staff may submit project proposals, which will be selected for funding by an annually appointed grant-making committee (TGIF Committee), consisting of students, faculty, and staff, on which the students have the majority vote.

Learn more at http://tgif.berkeley.edu.
summary: TGIF is UC Berkeley's student-fee based campus sustainability fund. TGIF provides funding via grants for projects that reduce UC Berkeley's negative impact on the environment and make UC Berkeley more sustainable. Learn more at http://tgif.berkeley.edu

name: Campus Dept | Transfer Student Center
Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Campus Libraries
description:
vimeo.com/307130179

 

Welcome to the UC Berkeley Library!

 

Considered the crown jewel of higher education in the entire state, UC Berkeley relies on the Library every day to support its world-class teaching and cutting-edge research, and to enrich the experience of its thousands of students. Comprising 20-plus libraries, the UC Berkeley Library has something for everyone, whether it’s the trove of primary documents chronicling the West at Bancroft, the collaborative and innovative spaces at Moffitt, or the vast and unparalleled collections at Doe, a beacon of information standing in the shadow of the iconic Campanile.

 

The Library offers countless resources and perks, including:

  • Expert help from librarians.
  • Tens of thousands of films to stream.
  • Free e-books and audiobooks on OverDrive.
  • A bounty of employment opportunities for students.
  • A collection of more than 13 million volumes.

Learn how to get the most out of the Library as a new student, and visit lib.berkeley.edu for more information.
summary: Campus libraries support student studies, provide a space for learning, and a community for our scholars ....

name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Career Center
description:
We fulfill our mission through:

  • A wide range of partnerships with employers, graduate schools, and campus academic and administrative departments that contribute to the breadth and effectiveness of our services.
  • State-of-the-art technology that maximizes accessibility to our resources and services.
  • First-class customer care that represents the highest level of customized quality service, demonstrated by:
    • Providing accurate and consistent information and support, communicating in a positive and friendly manner
    • Responding promptly and effectively to customer needs, always respecting others’ diverse approaches and interests
    • Embracing flexibility, anticipating opportunities for change, and constantly seeking ways to improve our services.
summary: We prepare undergraduates, graduate students, and alumni to make informed decisions about their futures by providing comprehensive resources, programs, and counseling on career development, internships, employment, and graduate school.

name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Gender Equity Resource Center
description:
The Gender Equity Resource Center, fondly referred to as GenEq, is a UC Berkeley campus community center committed to fostering an inclusive Cal experience for all. GenEq is the campus location where students, faculty, staff and alumni connect for resources, services, education and leadership programs related to gender and sexuality.

The programs and services of the Gender Equity Resource Center are focused on four key areas:

  • Women*
  • Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender and Queer+ (LGBTQ+)
  • Sexual Harassment & Sexual Violence
  • Men

Through our many programs and services we strive to:

  • Provide a space for respectful dialogue about sexuality and gender
  • Illuminate the interrelationship of sexism, homophobia and gender bias & violence
  • Create a campus free of violence and hate
  • Provide leadership opportunities
  • Advocate on behalf of survivors of sexual, hate, dating and gender violence
  • Foster a community of women and LGBT leaders
  • Be a portal to campus and community resources on LGBT, Women, and the many intersections of identity (eg race, class, ability, etc...)

The Gender Equity Resource Center (GenEq) is a part of the Centers for Education Justice and Community Engagement, which is a cluster in the Division of Equity & Inclusion, University of California, Berkeley.

 

*We welcome all who experience life through the lens of woman in body, spirit, identity - past, present, future, and fluid.
summary: GenEq is the campus location where students, faculty, staff and alumni connect for resources, services, education and leadership programs related to gender and sexuality. We are committed to fostering a safe, equitable and inclusive experience for all.

name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps
Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Public Service Center
description:
Founded by students in 1967 as Cal Corps, the UC Berkeley Public Service Center partners with the community, student leaders and faculty to engage over 4,000 students each year as volunteers, and through jobs, internships, and courses.

The UC Berkeley Public Service Center connects ideas, resources, and people to act for social justice, build healthy communities, and foster life-long commitments to public service.
summary: UC Berkeley Public Service Center engages the University and the community in reciprocal partnerships to foster social justice and civic engagement.

name: Campus Dept | UC Berkeley Washington Program (UCDC)
summary: UC Berkeley Washington Program (UCDC)

name: Campus Dept | UCPD
description: UCPD is committed to working in partnership with our diverse campus community so together we may enhance community trust, reduce the incidence and fear of crime, and promote safety. We pledge to protect individual rights and safeguard property for our
summary: UCPD is UC Berkeley's on-campus full-service police department, responding to all police, medical and fire emergencies on campus 24 hours a day.

name: Campus Evangelistic Fellowship - Mandarin Group
summary: We are a Christian fellowship of mandarin speaking students at Cal. As disciples of Jesus Christ we aim at obtaining deeper understanding of God's creation, spreading His love, fulfilling His plan in our lives, and building strong brotherhood in His Name

name: Canadians of Berkeley Law
description: Canadian student affinity group at Berkeley Law
summary: To provide a welcoming community for all Canadian students of Berkeley Law.

name: Capital Investments at Berkeley
description:
Founded in 2012 and reincorporated in 2014, Capital Investments at Berkeley was created by and for students striving to obtain real trading experience and provide investors superior risk-adjusted returns. In a perpetually changing market environment, CIB prides itself in our creative approach to trading, implementing a wide variety of strategies using a large selection of financial instruments. CIB operates as a general partnership investment club actively managed by managing general partners Aman Arain, Chandni Pari Jain, Sreetej Kalapatapu, and Hayley Lai.

 

Our investment philosophy is founded on the belief that capital preservation is more important than capital gains and in the long run a dynamic asset allocation and reactivity to market inefficiencies can generate above market returns. Further, we believe that as students, we have a unique perspective and differentiated views on markets, economies, and current events which provide rare opportunities for investors. Finally, we believe that as stewards of capital we have a deep responsibility to consider all stakeholders affected by our decisions, including our investors, employees of publicly traded companies, our communities, disadvantaged groups, the environment, and more. Only through active management and dedicated equity research can these responsibilities be fully materialized in investing. 

 

Our team leverages the unique skill-sets of our members and their varied academic and vocational backgrounds to deliver these returns to our partners. CIB draws on the combined experience of our members as employees of investment banks, hedge funds, asset managers, federal regulatory agencies, technology companies, legal firms, and start-ups notably including Morgan Stanley, JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Lazard, BlackRock, Blackstone, Centerview Partners, IMC, JMP Securities, the Federal Reserve, Dodge and Cox, Point72, Bain & Co., Vista Equity Partners, and Google.

 

Our culture is data and performance driven; we combine the financial acumen of our veteran members with the entrepreneurial philosophy of our school to create dynamism within existing investment structures. This creativity and unique synthesis of information is the cornerstone of CIB’s idea generation.

 

Our portfolio utilizes hedging strategies and a “risk-management first” approach to realize consistent returns that outperform the market. Trades are made through quantitative evaluation of a risk-reward profile and the ever-changing market environment.

 

Capital Investments at Berkeley’s long term goals include achieving capital preservation and gains regardless of market conditions, maintaining our loyal investor base, continuing to leverage our extensive alumni network, and providing students interested in finance and investment management real world opportunities to create value and preparation for careers.
summary: Founded in 2012, CIB is a student-run investment fund and finance club at the University of California, Berkeley, dedicated to providing investing knowledge, experience, and training to students and superior risk-adjusted returns to investors.

name: Capri Club
description: Capri Club focuses on intentionally teaching the leaders of FicB to take on a greater responsibility within the organization.
summary: Capri Club is an organization to equip and prepare leaders to teach and lead the members of FiCB.

name: Caravan Travel & Style Magazine
description:
Caravan is UC Berkeley's only travel magazine, for which all staffers travel in a group to report on locations determined each semester. It is Caravan Magazine’s mission to offer travel-minded students the opportunity to create, and in this process of creation, grow as artists and collaborators. Our 25-person team is made up of exceptional writers, photographers, videographers, and designers who dedicate 3+ hours per week to the club over the course of a semester.

 

The magazine aims to offer readers thoughtful interpretations of the scenes our team visits together. We try our best to cover subjects that interest audiences while producing meaningful insight. If you'd like to join our club, we encourage you to apply on our website at the end of the second week of every fall semester.
summary: Caravan is an on-campus organization that produces a semesterly travel magazine, for which teams of staffers travel as a group to report on locations determined each semester.

name: Career Readiness Program at Berkeley
description: Youth are the future leaders of tomorrow, as they are the future workforce for every imaginable industry. However, there is a present lack of an effective structure that adequately equips students with the tools necessary to work within industry, expecting students to have the self-knowledge to maneuver current systems. We are dedicated to supporting youth career development through hands-on technical experiences and providing youth with a supportive community they can thrive in.
summary: CRP at Berkeley aims to empower underprivileged students with career experience, by creating a platform that bridges the gap between education and the work industry, paving the way for a new wave of industry leaders.

name: Casa Esperanza
description: Casa Esperanza serves a shelter for women and children survivors of domestic abuse in Ensenada, Mexico. We aid these families by providing financial and emotional support, as well as creating health, wellness, and social empowerment programming to help them regain stability. We plan multiple trips to Mexico throughout the year. We fundraise depending on their specific needs, including funds for cleaning and hygiene products, clothing, bills, and scholarships for higher education. We create health workshops to bring health services to the women and children and to teach them how to maintain healthy practices. We also conduct social empowerment workshops, including career and educational support, to help the families at the shelter regain independence. Our mission is to bring UC Berkeley students of varied professional pathways together to both enhance our cultural awareness and collectively serve those in need.
summary: Casa Esperanza serves a shelter for women and children survivors of domestic violence near Enseñada, Mexico. We serve these families by providing financial and emotional support, as well as creating productive workshops to help them regain stability.

name: CASCADE: Community Service
description:
Cascade is a mentorship organization dedicated to developing a culture of compassion, service and empathy. Our goal is to reach 4th and 5th grade students at elementary schools around Alameda County through an original program our members have specially developed. The program is spread over the course of 6 weeks and is intended to take place for an hour once a week during an on-site after school program.

Our vision is to develop compassion and empathy by guiding young students through applied community service.

Every semester, Cascade hopes to recruit Berkeley students to engage with students in their local elementary schools. This program will offer its volunteers the unique opportunity to develop strong bonds with both the elementary school students and the Cascade family.

In Cascade, we train our members and volunteers through weekly meetings containing material from our program. Members have the option to enroll in a decal after being accepted into the club. Attendance to general meetings is crucial in acquiring the skills necessary for members to begin teaching the elementary school students. These meetings last around an hour and 30 min and entail engaging presentations and activities tailored to help Cascade’s members to be strongly equipped with the competence required in the volunteer settings.
summary: CASCADE is a mentorship organization dedicated to developing a culture of compassion, service and empathy among elementary school students.

name: Cases over Coffee @ Berkeley
description:
We are a student-led organization that provides UC Berkeley students from all backgrounds and skill levels with resources for learning about and breaking into the consulting industry. We strive to give students a space to grow professionally and personally by removing barriers to a competitive and highly-valued industry. We do this by hosting workshops and presentations, working with mentors and professionals from the "Big Three" consulting firms (Bain, BCG, McKinsey), and organizing additional professional development opportunities, such as case competitions, interview practice, and casing sessions.

Cases over Coffee at Berkeley is open to undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate students from ALL backgrounds and levels of experience currently enrolled at UC Berkeley. Our application process is holistic and focuses on genuine interest, intellectual curiosity, and potential. Applications are reviewed each semester.

Learn more on our website & our Social Media!

Find us on Facebook, Instagram (@calcasesovercoffee), and LinkedIn!
summary: To provide help members develop professionally and succeed in the consulting industry

name: Catalyst
description:
At Catalyst, we prioritize community building alongside professional development for students with an interest or passion in the biological field. Weekly modules are dedicated to various topics such as surgery, astrobiology, coding, public health, and mental health to expose members to hands-on skill-building. Members will have a chance to lead, learn and customize their own education within Catalyst. Our hope is to expand members' horizons while preparing for careers in medicine, veterinary medicine, dentistry, research, data analysis, and other biology occupations.

 

Modules are designed by and for members to allow for the exploration of new interests. Additionally, meetings may include guest speakers from diverse STEM professions. Topics that we may explore include but are not limited to technology, current research, grant writing, and psychology.

 

Catalyst is also very community and social-based to create a sense of inclusion in the large Berkeley community. Socials, academic support, and mentorship will be easily accessible to all members. We can't wait to build our community with you!

 

Key Words: biology, leadership, inclusion, non-elite, skill development, customize
summary: Catalyzed learning through customizable peer education and professional development creating an interdisciplinary experience for future biologists, researchers, and healthcare workers.

name: Catholic Students at Cal - Newman Hall
description:
Catholic Students at Cal is the campus-based student fellowship of Newman Hall - Holy Spirit Parish, the Catholic Center for the University. We strive to foster a community where we can grow in faith and fellowship as brothers and sisters in Christ through Bible studies, Rosary group, game nights, and more! We also connect students to other groups of the larger parish community like Newman Grads,  the Student Ministry Team, and FOCUS missionaries, among many others. All are welcome!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w1VMVTgi7Po
summary: Catholic Students at Cal is the campus-based student fellowship of Newman Hall - Holy Spirit Parish. All are welcome!

name: Catholics at Berkeley Law
description: We are a community of Berkeley Law folks dedicated to living out the Catholic faith. CABL is a sibling to Berkeley's main Catholic graduate student group, Newman Grads. Our community is under the patronage of St. Óscar Romero, champion of justice and martyr for the faith. St. Óscar Romero, pray for us!
summary: We are a community of Berkeley Law folks dedicated to living out the Catholic faith. Our community is under the patronage of St. Óscar Romero, champion of justice and martyr for the faith.

name: CED Students of Color
description:
To develop and expand the academic and social support, mentorship, career networking, and advocacy efforts for students of color and other underrepresented students within the College of Environmental Design. Students of color include those who identify themselves as African American, Native American, Asian American, Latina/o, and Pacific Islander. However, CEDSOC is inclusive and embraces all forms of diversity, including LGBTQ students, low-income students, and allies who value and work for equity and justice within low-income communities and communities of color. CEDSOC also promotes and advocates for greater attention and leadership toward social justice and equity within our respective fields.

name: CEE Graduate Student Society
description: The Civil and Environmental Engineering Graduate Student Society is a social and advocacy group that seeks to facilitate networking between the graduate students of the different programs within the CEE Department, provide a voice for graduate students with respect to the University and the CEE Department, as well as facilitate the exchange of knowledge and mentoring to undergraduate students.
summary: The CEE GSS is a social group that seeks to develop networking among the graduate students of the different programs within the CEE department, as well as facilitate the exchange of knowledge and mentoring to undergraduate students.

name: Celerity Traditional Dance Team
summary: Celerity is UC Berkeley's Vietnamese traditional dance team. We aim to share our Vietnamese culture with the community through performances of various traditional dances, such as fan, umbrella, lotus, and handkerchief dances.

name: Cell Mates: The Undergraduate Biology Journal Club of Berkeley
summary: Cell Mates an undergraduate journal club where students come together every other week to discuss recently published journal articles defining current advancements in biology research and related fields.

name: Celli@Berkeley
description:
A young and passionate group dedicated to dynamic performances in concert halls and alternative environments, CELLI@BERKELEY is an ensemble comprised of UC Berkeley students who come from a diverse background in musical training. Celli@Berkeley members are involved in multiple academic fields including Music, Physics, Political Science, Journalism and Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. 

Celli@Berkeley provides students with the opportunity to perform works outside of the traditional concert hall. By assembling talented young cellists at Cal, Celli@Berkeley strives to highlight the versatility of the cello, inviting audiences to share in a world of music they might not be exposed to otherwise. Collaborations with composers in the Berkeley student and national new music community have led to newly commissioned works.

Celli@Berkeley has played classical favorites to pop song arrangements in a variety of performance spaces, including Sproul Plaza, the Berkeley Art Museum, the Berkeley Farmer's Market, and the Berkeley Half Marathon. On sunny days, Celli@Berkeley can be heard performing pop arrangements near Sather Gate as CelliPOP.
summary: Celli@Berkeley seeks to generate new works for the cello ensemble repertoire. As a student organization, our goal is to provide a creative space for individuals to discover their own musical style.

name: Central Americans for Empowerment at Berkeley
description:
Our mission is to empower folx who identify as Central American to find the right resources to navigate in and out of Cal. We strive to work with other Latinx organizations to ensure that our narratives continue to be heard at Cal and beyond, including advocating for a Central American Studies Department. 

In addition to creating a space where we can share with one another and learn about our Central American roots, we encourage future members to actively engage in solidifying this organizational space, and collectively work to ensure that it remains at the University of California, Berkeley to welcome future Central American students. 

Stay updated with current events and announcements on our Instagram and Twitter: @cafeucb
summary:
Our mission is to help folx who identify as Central American, in building community and successfully navigating higher education.

Stay updated with current events and announcements on our Instagram and Twitter: @cafeucb

name: Central Valley at Berkeley
summary: Central Valley at Berkeley's mission is to champion education equity in the Central Valley through mentoring, tutoring, and resource provision, creating pathways for low income, POC, and undocumented students to access higher education.

name: Changemakers at Berkeley
summary: In line with the Berkeley Changemaker, our purpose is to activate undergraduates’ passions and help them develop a sharper sense of who they want to be and how to make that happen, emphasizing inclusivity and building upon Berkeley’s distinct values.

name: Cheese Club
description:
Cheese Club is a haven for students to convene and enjoy cheese in community. Our mission is two-fold: to explore cheeses from different cultures across the globe, and to use cheese as a catalyst for conversation about the agricultural practices and social impact of today’s complex food systems. Our club is relaxed and lively — come for good tunes, good convo, and CHEESE!

Whether you’re a gruyère girl, burrata boy, or compté kid, Cheese Club welcomes you.
summary: Cheese Club is a haven for students to convene and enjoy cheese in community.

name: ChemE Car
description:
Please fill out this interest form to receive updates about our Fall 2022 recruitment: https://tinyurl.com/chemecarfa22interest

 

The Chemical Engineering Car team builds a shoebox-sized car powered and controlled by chemical reactions for the annual AIChE-sponsored Chemical Engineering Car competition. Every year, we build two cars to compete at the Pacific Regional against other schools from California, in hopes of qualifying for the National competition.

 

At our most recent competition in Spring 2022 at UCLA, we placed 2nd in the car performance competition, qualifying for nationals, and 1st in the poster competition. At our competition in Spring 2019 at USC, we placed 4th overall in the main competition out of 15 competitors. At our competition in Spring 2018 at UC Irvine, we placed 1st in the poster competition and 2nd in the car performance competition, qualifying for nationals. At UC San Diego in 2017, we placed 4th and 5th out of 12 competitors. We were not able to compete in 2020 due to COVID-19. 

 

For the Fall 2022 semester, we will be developing several power sources and control mechanisms, such as a Zinc Air battery, a Hydrogen Fuel Cell, and a Vitamin-C control clock. We hold weekly team meetings and lab work sessions Monday-Friday! If you have any questions, please contact us at berkeley.chemecar@gmail.com.

 

The application process is pretty simple: there is a short written application through a google form. Each applicant receives an invite to a coffee chat. The aim of both these components is to gauge your interest and enthusiasm for the club. We do not require any prior experience and want to give an opportunity to every member of UC Berkeley.

 

For more information about our team, visit our website at chemecar.berkeley.edu!

 

Follow us on Instagram to get the latest team updates at @calchemecar

 

Here are some useful links:
- Rules: aiche.org/community/students/chem-e-car-competition-rules
- Website: https://chemecar.berkeley.edu
- About the teams: TBD

name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Graduate Student Advisory Committee
description: We seek to accomplish this by organizing events that promote open communication and discussion between graduate students and faculty, benefit the greater Bay Area community, and educate students to succeed both during and after graduate school.
summary: The mission of CBE GSAC is to foster community and provide both resources and a support network for Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering graduate students.

name: Chemistry Graduate Life Committee
description:
The Graduate Life Committee
UC Berkeley Dept. of Chemistry
Email us!  |  Visit our Website!
Facebook | Twitter | Instagram
Meetings first Fri. of month 11:00 AM

summary: The CGLC provides academic, professional and administrative support to graduate students in the Department of Chemistry by advocating for student wellness, spearheading a department-wide diversity initiative, and coordinating social events.

name: Chemistry Undergraduate Research Initiative and Enrichment at Berkeley
summary: CURIE is a way for undergraduates without research experience to be mentored by undergraduates with research experience.

name: Chess Club at Berkeley
description:
The Chess Club at Berkeley is the best place to play the game of chess and any of its variants, or learn the game for the first time! We have no membership requirements, welcome players of all skill levels for casual play, and are happy to teach beginners.

Join us on Discord to find out about our schedule and talk to our other members. Feel free to ask for games or post your favorite chess puzzles!

We meet in person once every week and host a few tournaments throughout the academic year.

We also host virtual arenas and are an active team in the Collegiate Chess League (CCL), the online chess league for college students. Join our chess.com club to play online!
summary: Are you interested in playing or learning chess? Join the Chess Club at Berkeley! Players of all skill levels are welcome. We meet once every week in person.

name: Chi Epsilon - Civil Engineering Honor Society
description:
Dedicated to the purpose of maintaining and promoting the status of civil engineering as an ideal profession, Chi Epsilon was organized to recognize the characteristics of the individual civil engineer deemed to be fundamental to the successful pursuit of an engineering career, and to aid in the development of those characteristics in the civil engineering student.

 

Engineering, the application of scientific principles to the practical needs of society, is assuming a constantly increasing responsibility for the physical well-being of all people, and thus calling for competence of the highest order. This responsibility can be discharged only by a professional group whose members are possessed of a good basic technical ability, intelligence, moral integrity, and effective social poise in their relationship with the larger community of which they are part.

 

To contribute to the improvement of the profession, Chi Epsilon fosters the development and exercise of sound traits of character and technical ability among civil engineers, and its members, by precept and example, toward an ever higher standard of professional service.
summary: Chi Epsilon recognizes the characteristics of the individual civil engineer deemed to be fundamental to the successful pursuit of an engineering career and aids in the development of those characteristics within civil engineering students.

name: Chi Omega
description:
This diverse group of women supports and celebrates individual pursuits and interests while remaining united under the common bonds of the fraternity. In joining Chi Omega, our members enrich their college experience by growing as individuals, while also growing together as a sisterhood. Being a part of Chi Omega at Cal means you are among women who inspire you daily and encourage you to be the best you can be. Each woman in our chapter is unique, beautiful, and accomplished in her own way.

Contact our President, Julia, at calchiomegapresident@gmail.com, or our Recruitment Chair, Elle, at calxorecruitment@gmail.com for more information.  Go Bears, go Greek, go Chi O!
 
Please visit our website, www.calchiomega.com, our Instagram (@calchiomega), or our Facebook (UC Berkeley Chi Omega) for more information!
summary: The mission of Chi Omega is to promote lifelong friendships, involvement, scholarship, leadership, and service. Cal Chi Omegas are well-rounded women committed to personal growth and the growth of their sisterhood!

name: Chi Psi
description:
Chi Psi Fraternity is the first social fraternity of gentlemen, established nationally in 1841. This Alpha (chapter) of Chi Psi at the University of California, Berkeley was founded in 1895, making it one of the oldest and richest traditions on campus. Our Fraternity is composed of undergraduate students from across a wide range of disciplines and backgrounds, brought together by a mutual desire and respect for brotherhood. We support and inspire one another to succeed, despite the competitive academic atmosphere at Berkeley. We maintain a prominent building (The Lodge) on Piedmont Ave, a robust social calendar, intense involvement in campus life, and a dynamic alumni base right here in the Bay Area that provides career support and guidance.

Most importantly, Chi Psi is a brotherhood of gentlemen in the pursuit of excellence. Since our inception more than 175 years ago, the only requirement for membership has always been that one displays the characteristics of a gentleman. By committing ourselves to the values associated with this pursuit, we help young men mature into responsible, compassionate, and confident members of the greater community. 

Furthermore, we are committed to maintaining a diverse, equitable, and inclusive brotherhood that welcomes all kinds of gentleman. We respect and acknowledge our brothers' diverse experiences, and are strong in our unity. 

If you're interested in rushing or learning more about our organization, please email taehoonl@berkeley.edu.
summary: Chi Psi is a national, social fraternity of gentlemen committed to the pursuit of excellence.

name: Chicanx/ Latinx Architecture Student Association
description: The Chicanx/Latinx Architecture Student Association (CASA), aims to serve, support, and care for students in the Design Field. We have an open door policy to cater a safe space for all students: Undocumented Students, First- Generation/Low-Income Students, Allies, LGBTQ+ Students. In addition to professional and academic support, our familia aims to generate awareness about past and current issues in Architecture, Landscape Architecture, Planning, and Sustainable Design; while also understanding current ongoing issues that ultimately affects and impacts our communities. Learning from the past and present, will allow us to record and understand positive impacts through the efforts of design. Ultimately, we strive to create a space where our students can feel comfortable and safe, all while embracing our cultural backgrounds and designing for a better future.
summary: Our intent, as it was CASA's foundation, is to advance equal access to the University and assure diversity of students studying Architecture, Landscape Architecture, City and Regional Planning, and Sustainable Design at UC Berkeley.

name: China Law Association at Berkeley
summary:
The China Law Assn at Berkeley seeks to:

1. Connect & Serve Berkeley Chinese Scholars
2. Exchange Perspectives at Berkeley Law
3. Promote Cross-border Communication

name: Chinese A Cappella at Berkeley
description: It is the only A Cappella group on campus that promotes Chinese culture.
summary: The purpose of this group is to promote Chinese culture on campus through a cappella art form.

name: Chinese Graduate and Postdoctoral Scholars Association
description: Founded in 2011, Chinese Graduate and Postdoctoral Scholars Association (CGPSA, or Berkeley Sunshine) is a non-profit, non-political and non-religious organization whose purpose is to promote the intellectual, cultural and social communications among graduate students and postdoctoral scholars from China in Berkeley Area. CGPSA is a registered graduate student organization in the Graduate Assembly of UC Berkeley.
summary: UC Berkeley Chinese Graduate and Postdoctoral Scholars, CGPSA

name: Chinese People Union
description: Chinese People Union is the official Chinese student organization at Berkeley dedicated to promoting Chinese culture on campus. Throughout the semester, we organize various events including retreats, cultural celebrations, and one-day getaways .
summary: Chinese People Union is the official Chinese student organization at Berkeley dedicated to promoting Chinese culture on campus. Throughout the semester, we organize various events including retreats, cultural celebrations, and one-day getaways .

name: Chinese Photography Association at Berkeley
description: Chinese Photography Association at Berkeley (BCPA) is a student organization of University of California Berkeley. Our organization aims at building a network between all amateur and professional photographers at Berkeley. We can provide a friendly environment for members to communicate, help them to enrich their experiences and enhance their skills for better photography. We will organize various kind of activities like studio shooting, portraits shooting, sports shooting, photography competition, photography workshops, lectures by professionals and etc. to create more chances for members to get involve in photography.
summary: Chinese Photography Association at Berkeley (BCPA) is a student organization of University of California Berkeley. Our organization aims at building a network between all amateur and professional photographers at Berkeley.

name: CHINESE READING GROUP AT BERKELEY
description:
7pm Literature and Film Salon is initially established by a group students who hold strong interests in Chinese literature. We seek to facilitate discussions of books written in Chinese, encourage members to explore Chinese culture in depth, provide opportunities for members to develop and express their own ideas, and promote better understanding in wider university community of Chinese society.


Our website: https://www.7pmsalon.org

*All our events are open to the public. Please check our website for the latest events. You will NOT get any event notification by clicking "Join" through Callink, since we don't message our general members via Callink very often. If you have any question about us or about any upcoming event, please email us. If you want to join our team, please email us with a basic self-introduction, and we'll contact you ASAP.
summary: CRGB seeks to facilitate discussions of books written in Chinese, to encourage members to explore Chinese culture in depth, to provide opportunity for members to develop and express own ideas.

name: Chinese Student Association
description:
Founded in 1951, the Chinese Student Association (CSA) is the first Chinese organization serving the growing Chinese-American community in Berkeley. Today, we are one of the largest and most active organizations at UC Berkeley.

CSA promotes the interests and awareness of Chinese heritage and history in the Berkeley community while fostering a supportive and inclusive social community for students, alumni, and other groups. We host many events which allow participants to have fun and meet new people. We promote these values through our events, such as our annual Lunar New Year Banquet, ShuaiGe Swagoff, Mid-Autumn Festival, cultural cuisine, game nights, and more. Everybody is welcome to join us, regardless of background! Join us to find out what CSA is all about!

Find us on Facebook, Instagram, Discord, and campus throughout the year when we host events!

Learn more at: linktr.ee/csaberkeley
summary: CSA promotes the interests and awareness of Chinese culture in the Berkeley community while functioning as a means of social engagement. Some of our well-known events include the Annual Lunar New Year Banquet and the Mid-Autumn Festival.

name: Chinese Student Theatre Company
description: CSTC is the first theatre club for Chinese students. As Chinese is our native language, we will product plays written in Chinese. In this way, our members can seek the implicit beauty of Chinese expressions and also get connected and feel like home through organization activities. Performances can become not only a vehicle of imparting our imagination and appreciation for Chinese expressions, but also a cultural legacy that will be inherited by future beings.
summary: CSTC provides a platform for Chinese students interested in theatre performances. Our mission is to improve students’ physical coordination, teamwork skills, and creativeness and also to develop students’ perception of life through performances.

name: Chinese Undergraduate Pre-Law Student Association
description: The Chinese Undergraduate Pre-Law Student Association (CUPLSA) serves to build a community among Chinese international students who are currently on the Pre-Law track or are interested in law and applying to a law school. Our Instagram account is @cuplsa.cal
summary: The Chinese Undergraduate Pre-Law Student Association (CUPLSA) serves to build a community among Chinese international students who are currently on the Pre-Law track or are interested in law and applying to a law school.

name: Chinese Union Club at Berkeley
summary: As the first non-profit organization in the United States to be founded by Chinese students and  Non-profit Organization 501(c)-3. Founded in 2005, we are committed to passing on the spirit of mutual help and assistance among overseas Chinese.

name: Chris Kindness Club
description: 1. The Chris Kindness mission is to inspire acts of kindness, one community at a time through our award program and by building a kindness clearinghouse. We are developing and aggregating content focused on kindness and partnering with other similarly focused organizations, including organizations studying the science of kindness and the many psychological and physiological benefits. The Chris Kindness Club at UC Berkeley will reflect the efforts of the greater Chris Kindness project.
summary: Chris Kindness Award Program's mission is to inspire acts of kindness, one community at a time, through our award program and by building a kindness clearinghouse.

name: Christ Pursuers on Campus
summary: The purpose shall be to bring UCB students into insights of who God is and foster both personal and corporate experience of God through in-depth Bible reading, fellowshipping, worshiping, praying, singing hymns, outings, evangelism, etc.

name: Christians at BerkeleyLaw
description: We provide weekly Bibles studies and a community within the law school for those seeking spiritual support.  We offer a time for those who self-identify as Christians, and those interested in learning more about the Christian faith, to encourage one another through the ups and downs of law school.  We also provide networking opportunities to connect people to churches, other bible studies, and other faith groups at Berkeley. We also hold occasional social activities, including dinners and networking events with other graduate student groups.
summary: Christians at BerkeleyLaw provides a safe community for students to come together for weekly fellowship to talk about the Christian faith and deepen our commitment to God and one another.

name: Christians on Campus
description:
Christians on Campus is a group of students who love the Lord Jesus Christ and His Word! We endeavor to give Him “the first place in all things” (Col. 1:18). We meet simply as Christians without any denominational affiliation, because we treasure the testimony of the oneness of the Body of Christ. To this end, we warmly receive all believers as our brothers and sisters in Christ, and seek to maintain the oneness of the Spirit by keeping our focus on Christ.

Our goal is to cooperate with Him for the accomplishment of God's eternal purpose (Eph. 3:11) by ministering the unsearchable riches of Christ (Eph. 3:18) for the building up of the Body of Christ (Eph. 4:12). In addition to pursuing fellowship, we also desire to strengthen and spread the Lord's testimony on the UC Berkeley campus.

With the above as our governing vision, we hold weekly Bible studies, smaller group meetings, monthly club Fellowship Nights, fun outings, and more! For more information, check out our website at https://www.christiansoncampus.info
summary: We are a student group composed of believers from various backgrounds who love the Lord Jesus and His Word! Our gatherings include weekly Bible studies, smaller group meetings, outings, and more. Check us out at https://www.christiansoncampus.info

name: Chun Jin Ahm
description:
Welcome to Chun Jin Ahm!

We are the Korean Catholic Fellowship on Cal. Est. 1982

Meetings every Friday night 7pm at Newman Hall (2700 Dwight Way Berkeley, CA).

Join us for group activities, late night dinners, weekly meetings, semester retreats, bible study, praise, and life long friendships!
summary: Chun Jin Ahm is a Korean Catholic fellowship whose goal is to grow and practice our faith. Our weekly Friday meetings provide an opportunity to share our Christian journey, discuss our faith, and educate our Catholic conscience.

name: Cinematic Arts and Production Club
description:
Cinematic Arts and Production Club is the largest and most production-driven student film organization at UC Berkeley. Our activities are heavily centered around professional film production, as we work toward our mission of creating original, high-quality, and meaningful films to premiere on campus. We meet regularly throughout the semester to work on our film projects. Our 100+ active members aim to create 30 short films (around 6 hours of content) per academic semester.

 

Cinematic Arts and Production is the ideal organization for students interested in gaining actionable exposure to the film industry, whether that's in film production or in the business side of the industry. As our projects are all original and start-to-finish, we recruit students from various backgrounds to cover all of our organizational needs. 

 

**Fall 2023 Update: Our applications have closed this semester, but we will be recruiting again in the beginning of the Spring 2024 semester.

Visit our website, on Instagram @capclubberkeley, or our YouTube. You can watch our latest reel here.

https://youtu.be/ZAAXUWUpwds
summary: Cinematic Arts and Production Club is the most production-driven student film organization at UC Berkeley. Our mission is to create original, high-quality, and meaningful films to premiere on campus.

name: Circle K International
description:
Our mission is to develop college students into responsible citizens and leaders with a lifelong commitment to serving our community. Our club adheres to the tenets of service, leadership, and fellowship. For 29 years we have organized hundreds of service projects, racked up tens of thousands of service hours, and raised thousands of dollars for charity.

We benefit the community through these projects, in which we take on tasks such as cleaning up the environment, serving food to low-income families, putting on free educational workshops for underprivileged children, making no-sew blankets for animals in the shelter, and raising money for charities such as the Pediatric Trauma Program, The Environmental Defense Fund, the Kiwanis Family House at the UC Davis Medical Hospital, and the NAACP Legal Defense & Education Fund. In addition to all the service we do, we focus on creating a community through a variety of socials, from eating out, to karaoke, to San Francisco trips, and more, through our family system, and our mentor-mentee system and alumni network!

If you're interested in joining us here at UC Berkeley CKI for the 2023-2024 term and to stay in the loop about our activities, fill out our membership form (we accept everyone!) today: tinyurl.com/UCBCKI-Membership-2324

We also ask you to check out our website, ucbcki.org, for more information on us, and our calendar, and to sign up for events. This way, you can also keep track of the events you've attended and your hours!

And if you're interested in a board position and leadership training, we are currently accepting applications for committee heads! Incoming freshmen, junior transfers, and all other students who will be at Berkeley for the 2023-2024 term are welcome to apply. We just ask that you are enthusiastic and can dedicate your time to the club. Email cki.sabreenyaqubi@gmail.com (2023-2024 Secretary, Sabreen Yaqubi) to let us know you're interested, and then apply to board here today!: tinyurl.com/UCBCKI-BoardApplication-2324

For any important links, please check out our Linktr.ee: linktr.ee/UCB_CKI/
summary: Our mission is to develop students into leaders with a lifelong commitment to serving our community through mentorship and fellowship. We adhere to the tenets of service, leadership, and fellowship.  Check out ucbcki.org for more information on us!

name: City Planning + Public Health Master's Students Committee
description: Over the past decade the University of California has been a vanguard in combining the fields of public health and city planning. City Planning + Public Health Master's Students Committee (MCP + MPH Students) seeks to serve active concurrent degree students, as well as students interested in interdisciplinary study to advance urban health equity. MCP + MPH Students seeks to institutionalize an informal and growing network of students, and serve as an intellectual and action-oriented home for students between departments.
summary: MCP + MPH Students seeks to institutionalize an informal and growing network of interdisciplinary Master's Students, and serve as an intellectual and action-oriented home for students between departments.

name: Civil and Environmental Engineering For Anti-Racism
description: We aim to build on historical efforts in the student community and to push for immediate and sustained action to address structural racism in Civil and Environmental Engineering and the broader engineering community.
summary: We aim to build on historical efforts in the student community and to push for immediate and sustained action to address structural racism in the Civil and Environmental Engineering department.

name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Joint Fundraising Committee
description: To raise, distribute, and manage funds for Civil and Environmental Engineering student groups: ASCE, Steel Bridge, Seismic Design, Concrete Canoe, Environmental, Transportation, Sustainable Solutions, GeoWall, and Construction Competition Teams.
summary: To raise, distribute, and manage funds for Civil and Environmental Engineering student groups: ASCE, Steel Bridge, Seismic Design, Concrete Canoe, Environmental, Transportation, Sustainable Solutions, GeoWall, and Construction Competition Teams.

name: Clean Energy Leaders in Law
description: CELL is a pro-bono student-initiated legal services project that seeks to accelerate an equitable transition to renewable energy. Through CELL, law students support non-profits' efforts to address energy inequities and increase access to community-owned renewable energy projects.
summary: CELL is a pro-bono student-initiated legal services project that seeks to accelerate an equitable electrical grid transition by providing legal services to marginalized communities seeking access to and ownership of clean power.

name: Climbing Team of Berkeley
description:
Find us on instagram @calclimbing (we do not use Cal Link to maintain our roster)

Our club is centered around climbing. We love to climb, both indoors and outdoors. We also look to grow the sport of climbing and our local climbing community through both new climbers and old.

Indoors, we tend to climb at either Mosaic Boulders (our home gym) on Telegraph, or Berkeley Ironworks or Bridges Rock Gym. Members will occasionally participate in CCS (the Collegiate Climbing Series) competitions, but always in a fun and informal environment.

Outdoors, we take short local trips to places like Indian and Mortar Rock here in Berkeley, to Mt. Diablo, to Mickey's Beach, and distant trips to places like Yosemite, Smith Rock (Oregon), and even Red Rocks (near Las Vegas Nevada). 

For the past 3 semesters we have been hosting workouts like core and hangboarding, social events, and clinics all over zoom. This year, we anticipate a full return to our in-person events including trips, clinics, and social events. Join as a member to get access to the email list where we post our announcements.

 

* note we do not use Cal Link for our roster ---> https://climbing.berkeley.edu/join/
summary: We are a social club here to promote the sport of climbing at Berkeley. We climb indoors and outside, and welcome beginners and experts alike.

name: ClinicConnects
description: The ClinicConnects Club strives to reach out to local clinics and inquire with the healthcare professionals regarding the range of problems they may have—from small inconveniences to larger institutional changes—and act as the “middleman” to find local resources that solve the problems. By tackling these previously less-explored problems, connecting various resources, and finding viable methods to implement the solutions, we hope to create a positive tangible impact within our local community. In addition, we hope to help with advocacy and awareness of problems that we uncover through our interactions with the local clinics.
summary: The ClinicConnects Club strives to reach out to local clinics/inquire with the healthcare professionals about a range of problems (big and small) and act as the “middleman” to find local resources that solve the problems.

name: Cloud at California
description:
Cloud at California (CLAC) is a UC Berkeley-based technology development and education group that aims to build and support the next generation of cloud engineers through a combination of internal education programs and experience-based learning. 

CLAC is the first student organization of its kind that aims to bridge the gap between undergraduates and capable cloud engineers, while also providing a valuable service to companies around the nation. CLAC consulting and development services include, but are not limited to: cloud architecture, migration, security, and overall strategy. With a team of diverse students, with backgrounds that range from traditional computer science to bioengineering and data science, CLAC consulting provides a unique and cost-effective service to companies large and small.  

In addition to providing services unparalleled in the Bay Area cloud community, CLAC offers practical cloud experiences not offered through traditional university courses via a free internal education program. In order to bridge this gap, cohorts are guided through the original cloud curriculum. At the culmination of the course, students are prepared for their cloud certification, which is also funded by CLAC. Following this certification and completion of the course, alumni go on to join CLAC Development/Consulting, CLAC Research & Exploration, or apply their new skills in the industry.
summary: To offer UC Berkeley students of all backgrounds meaningful experiences with modern-day cloud technologies in both a classroom and real-world setting and to build the presence of cloud engineering within the computer science community.

name: CMG Strategy Consulting (Formerly Creative Marketing Group)
description: CMG Strategy Consulting is a non-profit, student-run management consulting organization at UC Berkeley that provides consulting services for companies in the Bay Area and beyond. We seek to give new perspectives to businesses while also providing experiences for our student consultants to grow professionally. We pride ourselves on delivering creative & implementable solutions developed from comprehensive research efforts.
summary: CMG Strategy Consulting is a non-profit, student-run management consulting organization at UC Berkeley that provides consulting services for companies in the Bay Area and beyond. Please contact us at berkeleycmg@gmail.com to learn more.

name: CNMAT Users Group
description: The group is a mostly graduate student group working in coordination with CNMAT staff and faculty on various things like, special projects, facilities upkeep, software upkeep, general improvements in working environments, grant writing, BNMP/ECO concert production.
summary: To assist graduate students at CNMAT (Center for New Music and Audio Technology)

name: Coalition for Diversity at Berkeley Law
description: Coalition for Diversity at Berkeley Law (CFD) was founded in 2001 to promote diversity at Berkeley Law through strategies to increase the enrollment of students of color; queer, trans, and gender-non-conforming students; first-generation and working-class students; and other under-represented law students. Over the years, CFD has hosted a number of pipeline programs for prospective and admitted law students, including the For People of Color Conference for prospective law students and a variety of programs during Admitted Students Weekend. Additionally, CFD acts as an umbrella organization for the various affinity groups on campus, and CFD’s range of perspectives has assisted underrepresented law students in finding community during law school.
summary: Coalition for Diversity at Berkeley Law promotes diversity at Berkeley Law through strategies to increase the enrollment of students of color; queer and trans students; first-generation professional students; and other under-represented law students.

name: Coalition of Concerned Medical Professionals at Berkeley
description: CCMP at Berkeley empowers students to use their skills and knowledge to help disadvantaged community members overcome systemic barriers to comprehensive healthcare. Through our club meetings and training, we will prepare our members to serve as health advocates at our local CCMP office in Oakland and make a difference in our community. There will be virtual and in-person volunteering opportunities this semester!
summary: CCMP at Berkeley aims to help provide everyone with access to comprehensive medical care. Through our club meetings and trainings we will prepare our members to volunteer at our local CCMP and make a difference in our community.

name: Coalition of Minorities in Tech Law
description: The Coalition of Minorities in Technology Law (CMTL) is a student organization established within UC Berkeley School of Law with the purpose of providing community, mentorship, career resources, and advocacy on behalf of students who are interested in technology law and who come from backgrounds historically underrepresented in the technology, legal, and technology law fields.
summary: Providing community, mentorship, career resources, and advocacy on behalf of students who are interested in technology law and who come from backgrounds historically underrepresented in the technology, legal, and technology law fields.

name: Code for Good
description:
https://codeforgoodberkeley.github.io/

Code For Good works to support non-profit organizations with technology solutions to help bring positive change in our communities.
