There is no time commitment for general members, but we encourage you to come out to as many events as possible. We accept new general members at any point during the semester!

Our mission is to help both promote East Asian culture awareness and prepare our student community with basic culinary skills. The EACC strives to develop leaders who are both are both proactive and rooted in their community values.
summary: Interested in East Asian culinary and culture? The EACC is the perfect place for you! Here at the East Asian Culinary Club, we host several events including cooking workshops, food reviews, guest speaker events and more! Come join us today!

name: East Asian Union
summary: East Asian Union is a pan-Asian organization that aims to unite and promote Asian culture to the broader Berkeley community. We aim to provide a medium for cross-cultural exchanges as well as a platform of support for intra and inter-club endeavors

name: East Bay Dreamers Project
description: The purpose of EBDP is to partner with East Bay Community Law Center (EBCLC) to provide immigration legal services to support and empower Bay Area residents. EBDP was created with a focus on DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals), but has expanded to assist with a wider breadth of immigrant petitions and applications. Many immigrants have legal claims to remain in the United States, but don’t have the resources to fight for those claims. The goal of our pro bono work is to support local nonprofits and to help them reach as many clients seeking immigration assistance as possible. Members of EBDP will have the opportunity to volunteer at workshops to help prepare and file DACA applications, assist with legal intake, and/or participate in post-conviction advocacy for clients with criminal histories.
summary: The East Bay Dreamers Project (EBDP) familiarizes Berkeley Law students with the Consideration of Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) application process.

name: Ecology Law Quarterly
description: ELQ provides a forum for environmental scholarship through publication of high-quality writing by scholars, practitioners, and students. At Berkeley Law, ELQ represents and advocates for the environmental law community, sustains and strengthens the environmental law program, encourages student writing, and fosters a diverse, welcoming, and inclusive social and academic community.
summary: Ecology Law Quarterly is the oldest and premier journal on environmental law and policy. ELQ provides fresh insight and analysis from leading authors and scholars on critical environmental affairs.

name: Economists for Equity at Berkeley (Formerly Women in Economics at Berkeley)
description:
Our goal is to increase representation in economics by dismantling barriers to participation in our field and confronting bias. We recognize that we operate within a discipline with a long history of systemic exclusion of students and scholars based on their race, gender, sexual orientation, or other historically oppressed identities. Making economics more inclusive will require breaking down these systems and building new ones that facilitate broader, more diverse, and more equitable scholarship.   ​
 
We provide academic opportunities and a supportive community for individuals from underrepresented groups to successfully complete their Ph.D. in economics. Looking past the Ph.D. program, we are invested in building an inclusive economics community through diverse faculty recruitment, graduate admissions, and undergraduate mentorship.  We maintain a public and vocal presence advocating for underrepresented economists through this website and our associated blog.
summary: The purpose Economists for Equity at Berkeley (BEE) is to provide a community for graduate URMs in the Department of Economics.

name: Educate a Child for Change Organization at Berkeley
description:
ABOUT US

ECCO is a nonprofit organization, that strives to improve lives through the Literacy and Education of children in developing countries and resettlement services for refugees and immigrants in the United States. 

VISION

We envision A world where every child gets the opportunity to attend school and pursue higher education.

MISSION

Strengthen and Create opportunities to equip impoverished children to attend school.
summary: ECCO's Purpose is to Strengthen and Create opportunities to equip impoverished children in developing countries to attend school.

name: EECS Transfers at Berkeley
description: EECS Transfers at Berkeley aims to build a community and provide resources to better ensure academic success and career readiness for transfer students interested in the field of electrical engineering and computer sciences.
summary: EECS Transfers at Berkeley aims to build a community and provide resources to better ensure academic success and career readiness for transfer students interested in the field of electrical engineering and computer sciences.

name: Effective Altruists of Berkeley
description:
Effective Altruism represents a larger growing movement of scholars, philosophers, scientists, and activists who are trying to use evidence and reason to help answer one basic question: "What is the best way to use my money, time, talent, and voice to improve the world as much as possible?" We aim to make not just a difference, but the most difference. 

Effective Altruists of UC Berkeley is a local chapter of Effective Altruism. Our primary goal at EAB is to help Berkeley students to make helping others effectively an important part of their lives and give them the resources to do it well. Among other things, we

  • Provide information on the most promising giving opportunities researchers have found
  • Host guest lectures and debates by ethicists, entrepreneurs, and nonprofit leaders from around the world 
  • Create networking opportunities and connect members to challenging, high impact internships
  • Support and counsel anyone who's considering the kind of strong, scary commitments that are often necessary to make a huge impact: pledging income, changing consumption, deciding on a career, and more.

As students at one of the best universities in the world, we have a tremendous opportunity to steer the course of the future by carefully planning what we want to care about, where we want to give, and what we want to do with our lives. 

Learn more about us at our website: https://eaberkeley.com/.  If you’re interested in what we do, feel free to schedule a time to talk to our organizers, sign up for our newsletter on our website, or join our Slack. We're most active on Slack, all our annoucements and many of our discussions take place there - we'd love to see you there!

Our current board members are:

- Mario Fontes - President

- Sofya Lebedeva - Senior Advisor

- Carolyn Qian - Vice President

- Muhammed Bakr - Project Director

- Bryan Sow - Project Coordiantor
summary: How do we use our giving to do the most good? How about our volunteering, or activism, or future careers? EAB aims to provide the resources and expertise to help everyone at Cal answer these questions and put their most ambitious plans into action.

name: Eggster Organization
description:
Eggster Organization's mission is to nurture the creativity, curiosity, and welfare of Bay Area youth! Our annual event is held at the UC Berkeley campus and is a one-day carnival of fun and learning, open to all for free. We bring the community together by integrating local businesses, reaching out to nearby schools, and collaborating with Cal students. The purpose of Eggster is to plan an annual free egg hunt and learning festival for Bay Area children and families, to expose children to the Berkeley campus and encourage pursuit of higher education, and to provide funds to support programs in the Bay Area centered around youth and education.
 
If you're interested in joining our team, finding a close-knit community of passionate individuals, and outreaching to our Bay Area community, join us for an info session!
 
Follow our Facebook or Instagram page for more information and updates!
• Facebook: Eggster at Berkeley
• Instagram: @eggsteratcal
summary: Eggster is a not-for-profit student organization located in Berkeley that hosts the largest annual egg hunt and learning festival in the Bay Area. We aim to provide exposure to higher education to young kids in a free, accessible event.

name: Egyptian Student Association at Berkeley
description: Our goal is to create and maintain an authentic Egyptian environment. We also seek to promote an understanding of the Egyptian history, culture and heritage.
summary: Also known as Egyptian Student Association at UC Berkeley (ESAB)

name: Election Law at Berkeley Law
description: Election Law @ Berkeley Law (EL@B) is a nonpartisan student organization which builds community among students passionate about democracy, equality, citizenship, voting rights, and representation. Through lectures, organizing events, and mentorship activities, EL@B stokes campus-wide interest in election law and provides opportunities to network and learn from practitioners.
summary: Election Law @ Berkeley Law (EL@B) is a nonpartisan student organization which builds community among students passionate about democracy, equality, citizenship, voting rights, and representation.

name: Electrical Engineering Graduate Student Association
description: EEGSA is an organization serving the Electrical Engineering Masters and PhD students in UC Berkeley. Our primary mission is to provide support, resources, and service to the graduate student community in EECS and to the broader East Bay community.
summary: Provide support, resources, and service to the graduate student community in the Electrical Engineering Department, including limited service as a liaison if an issue between the Department and Student arises.

name: Eleven: The Undergraduate Journal of Sociology
summary: Eleven: The Undergraduate Journal of Sociology publishes sociological papers written by national and international undergraduates. We offer membership to the Editorial and PR teams to take part in our rigorous peer review process.

name: Emerge Pursuit Fellowship
description: We want to pursue the presence of God through fellowship in worship, prayer, and Biblical teaching. Our goal is to be a family that supports one another in this walk of life, and we welcome anyone who is interested in learning about Christianity or has questions about faith.
summary: Pursuit is a Christian fellowship under Livingwater Church. We seek to be a community that pursues God's truth and mission together

name: Empowering Women of Color Conference
summary: Conference Planning Committee

name: EnableTech
description: Our Mission: EnableTech aims to design, prototype, and manufacture assistive technologies for project partners from Berkeley and the surrounding communities. Our goal is for engineering students to collaborate with designers, public health students, business students, and anyone else who can offer insight into the development of assistive technology projects. We are working with the Disabled Students Union and Disabled Students Program to see what the Berkeley community needs in order to improve their ease of access. Students can choose from one of these projects, or they can start their own assistive technology project. We provide space, materials, and group peers to turn their idea into a prototype, then into a product that could improve the lives of people with similar disabilities in the world.
summary: We design and build hardware and software to address challenges faced by people with disabilities in Berkeley and the world at large. Our students collaborate with project partners to turn ideas into solutions that could improve the lives of many people.

name: Enactus of Berkeley
description:
Enactus at Berkeley (Est. Fall 2016) is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that connects student, academic and business leaders through entrepreneurial-based projects that transform opportunities into real, sustainable progress for themselves and their communities. We are the only social impact entrepreneurship club on-campus!

 

Members at Enactus gain unique experience with startups and spearheading their own passion projects. At Enactus, we believe investing in students who take entrepreneurial action for others creates a better world for us all. Members are challenged to brainstorm with their teams and turn their ideas into reality by creating actual programs, businesses, and inventions. Projects making significant progress gain the opportunity to participate in competitions that can range from local, to national, and even international competitions. 

 

Our chapter at UC Berkeley is comprised of a group of highly motivated students from a wide variety of academic and social backgrounds. We embrace diversity in all its forms and most importantly value the passion and professionalism students bring from all walks of life. We strongly encourage the next generation of entrepreneurs to apply their innovation and business principles in order to help those in need. Through projects, we motivate our members to become leaders and be able to use the tools they’ve gained in a wide range of industries.

https://youtu.be/peeueGwoUm0

 

Check out our website to learn more: https://www.enactusberkeley.com/

 

Have questions or still aren't convinced to join? Get in contact with our Executive Team at enactusberkeley1@gmail.com!
summary: Enactus at Berkeley is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that connects student, academic and business leaders through entrepreneurial-based projects that transform opportunities into real, sustainable progress for their communities.

name: End Overdose at Berkeley
summary: END OVERDOSE is a non-profit organization working to end drug-related overdose deaths through education, medical intervention, and public awareness. Our chapter is committed to educate and equip UC Berkeley students & Berkeley community as a whole.

name: Engineering and Project Management Society
description:
The Engineering and Project Management Society (EPMS) at UC Berkeley is dedicated to educating, promoting, and connecting students with industry professionals in the AEC industry. EPMS is affiliated with the Associated General Contractors (AGC) and the Construction Management Association of America (CMAA). Our goals are: 

1. To help members better understand the nature of the construction industry and the role of construction contractors. 

2. To cooperate with the university officials and the local AGC and CMAA chapters in sponsoring meetings, field trips and other events of interest to the student members. 

3. To promote both scholarship and fellowship among the members of the Society.
summary: The Engineering and Project Management Society at UC Berkeley is dedicated to educating, promoting, and connecting students with industry professionals in the Architectural, Engineering and Construction (AEC) industry.

name: Engineering Solutions at Berkeley
summary: ESB provides a unique opportunity for technically-minded individuals to acquire practical, hands-on experience solving challenges faced in industry during the academic year. Our core values lie in academic excellence,  professionalism, and camaraderie.

name: Engineering Student Council
description: The Engineering Student Council's mission is to represent the engineering student body; support engineering societies in reaching their full potential; and promote a diverse community through successful collaboration between students, faculty, societies.
summary: The Engineering Student Council represents the engineering student body; supporting engineering societies in reaching their full potential; and promoting a diverse community through successful collaboration between students, faculty, societies.

name: Engineers and Mentors of Berkeley
description: BEAM is a student run organization that develops and teaches hands-on science and engineering activities to K-8 grade levels at local schools. Our goal is to make science and engineering more approachable and encourage students to pursue classes and careers in STEM-related fields. We train college students to be effective mentors, role models, and leaders in their community. As students ourselves, we understand that the best way to learn is to teach. Berkeley students earn course credit while improving their mentoring skills.
summary: Come teach hands-on science and engineering lessons to local elementary and middle schools! All majors welcome!

name: English Undergraduate Association
description:
The English Undergraduate Association (EUA) is an academic and social organization that serves all undergraduates interested in the study of English language and literature. The goal of the EUA is to provide a forum for students to participate actively in the English major on the Berkeley campus. We exist as a liaison between students and the English Department. The EUA works to facilitate working academic relationships between professors and the student body, as well as to encourage social interaction between faculty and students. We exist to strengthen the connection between UC Berkeley students and the local literary community.

To stay in the loop, sign-up for our newsletter, join our Discord Server and like us on Facebook.
summary: The English Undergraduate Association (EUA) is an academic and social organization that serves all undergraduates interested in the study of English language and literature. EUA is a forum for students to actively participate on the Berkeley campus.

name: Entomology Club
description:
In addition to weekly meetings, we aim to facilitate hands-on learning and practice in everything from collection and identification to raising live insects.

For Fall 2023, we are meeting Mondays from 6:30-7:30 pm in Wellman 306. Join us for weekly bug spotlights, collecting trips, practical workshops, and other fun activities!
summary: Entomology Club is a fun group of bug-lovers who come together to explore interesting topics in entomology and arthropod biodiversity!

name: Entomology Students' Organization
description: The Entomology Students Organization (ESO) is hosted by the Department of Environmental Science Policy and Management, but represents graduate students from various departments, all with an interest in insects. ESO provides peer-academic support for the entomology community through hosting workshops and events and making connections between researchers working on different areas of arthropod science. We also participate in public outreach and events such as Cal Day and Darwin Day. In addition, we co-host the Essig Brunch weekly seminar series, along with the Essig Museum of Entomology.
summary: The Entomology Students Organization (ESO) is hosted by the Department of Environmental Science Policy and Management, but represents approximately 30 graduate students from various departments, all with an interest in insects.

name: Entrepreneur Through Acquisition Club
summary: The ETA Club is dedicated to educate the Haas community on entrepreneurship through acquisition and empower future business owners with a network of searchers, investors and current operators.

name: Entrepreneurs @ Berkeley
description:
We provide a community for exchanging ideas, understanding the start-up process, and molding the next entrepreneurial minded consultants.

Visit Our Website!

Fall 2022 Recruitment Information!
summary: We provide a community for exchanging ideas, understanding the start-up process, and molding the next entrepreneurial minded consultants.

name: Environmental Conservation Outreach
description: Environmental Conservation Outreach’s (ECO) mission is to engage students in environmental law pro bono work in order to address environmental injustices, to preserve magnificent places and wildlife, and to combat climate change. We also offer research and writing opportunities for projects that can have real impacts.
summary:
Environmental Conservation Outreach is a research-based student-initiated legal services
project (SLP) at UC Berkeley School of Law. The purpose of this SLP is to allow law students to work with clients on environmental issues on a pro-bono basis.

name: Environmental Engineering Advocacy Team
description: Environmental Engineering Advocacy Team (EEAT) represents all graduate students within the environmental engineering program in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering. EEAT aims to provide a voice for students in issues related to program requirements, coursework, recruitment, faculty searches, and events related to the department. EEAT serves as a bridge between students and faculty members so that student concerns and feedback are more clearly understood and considered at the departmental level.
summary: EEAT aims to provide a voice for environmental engineering grad students in issues related to program requirements, coursework, recruitment, faculty searches, and events related to the department. EEAT serves as a bridge between students and faculty.

name: Environmental Health Alliance
summary: Environmental Health Alliance’s purpose is to alleviate environmental health inequities through awareness, collaboration, and action. We organize projects with respect to environmental health science/justice-related issues within our communities.

name: Environmental Health Sciences Graduate Students
description:
The purpose of EHGS is to provide a forum for graduate students in Environmental Health to share ideas about advancements and growth of the division, form collaborations with students and faculty, and to promote environmental health sciences interests. 

A major objective of EHGS is to promote environmental health interests within the School of Public Health- where there are many diverse interests and paths to promoting human health. One primary way EHGS will promote Environmental Health is by orchestrating the annual Environmental Health Symposium where current graduate student research is highlighted. Our ultimate goal is to develop a safe and inclusive space for EHS students by promoting community, diversity, and inclusivity among students in the School of Public Health.
summary: The purpose of EHGS is to provide a forum for graduate students in Environmental Health to share ideas about advancements and growth of the division, form collaborations with students and faculty, and to promote environmental health sciences interests.

name: Environmental Sciences Student Association
description:
ESSA's main goal is to bring students interested in the environment together in a fun, academic, and social atmosphere. Membership is open to all UC Berkeley students. We organize guest speakers, workshops, nature hikes, book clubs, and much more! When possible, we also plan semesterly camping trips. 

If you would like to join our email list, please log into your Berkeley email to view and fill out the following form: https://forms.gle/kHtyjG2iNgAWUB7aA
summary: ESSA aims to join environmental enthusiasts together in a fun, academic, and social atmosphere. Membership is open to all UC Berkeley students!

name: Environmental Team
description:
The Cal Environmental Team (Cal Enviro) is a civil engineering competition team that participates in the annual water treatment competition at the ASCE Mid-Pacific Student Conference (Mid-Pac). The goal of Cal Enviro is to impart the fundamentals of wastewater treatment and sustainable engineering design, give hands-on laboratory and construction experience, and provide opportunities for students to improve their public speaking and technical writing skills. During the school year, relevant knowledge and skills will be developed as the team works toward placing in Water Treatment at Mid-Pac.

Every year before Mid-Pac, teams are given a new scenario, wastewater recipe, material's list, and target water quality parameters. The team designs and practices constructing water filters from household materials. After a filtration system (including chemical treatment) has been finalized, the team also prepares a technical presentation, report, and poster--all of which are major components of the Mid-Pac scoring system. 

If you're interested in exploring water treatment practices, engineering design, or developing important presentation and technical report skills, you can contact us at calenviroteam@gmail.com or visit our Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/calenvironmental/ for more information!

Cal Environmental Team is sponsored by the Civil and Environmental Engineering Department. Course credit available.
summary: Cal Enviro is a civil engineering competition team that participates in the annual water treatment competition at the ASCE Mid-Pacific Student Conference. Students taking the class will learn fundamentals of wastewater treatment and engineering design.

name: Epsilon Eta
description:
Epsilon Eta is a gender-inclusive environmental service organization founded in 2017. We offer a community for undergraduate students interested in environmental service and incorporating environmentalism into their careers and everyday lives. Our members come from a variety of disciplines and majors as we aim for interdisciplinary and intersectional environmentalism. We actively promote community resource sharing for academic and professional success in the environmental realm and uplifting our members’ lived experiences. Epsilon Eta is a fraternity with multiple chapters across college campuses in the United States; we are not associated with traditional Greek life.

As students of UC Berkeley, we recognize the privilege of our education and access to resources. We understand our role in the colonization of Ohlone land and how we actively benefit from occupying unceded territory. We ground ourselves in the principles of environmental justice. Our goal as an organization is to acknowledge the intersectionality of the climate crisis and use our collective skills to serve UC Berkeley, Bay Area communities, and sites of ongoing environmental concern.
summary:
Through establishing connections between students, faculty, researchers, and agencies in the Bay Area, Epsilon Eta seeks to develop a network for those who aspire to make tangible, positive change in the
environmental sector.

name: Epsilon Pi at Berkeley
description: Epsilon Pi helps students interested in Engineering Physics cultivate the competence, enthusiasm, and social support networks essential to the advancement of the field. We focus on 1) stimulating interest in advanced study and research, 2) developing collegiality among Engineering Physics students, alumni, and faculty members, and 3) promoting public interest in Engineering Physics.
summary: Epsilon Pi is the honor society for Engineering Physics majors at Cal. Run by students, for students, our goal is to facilitate social connections and career exploration within the EP undergraduate community.

name: Eritrean-Ethiopian Student Association
description:
The Eritrean-Ethiopian Student Association (EESA), also known as the Habesha Club at UC Berkeley, is a vibrant and inclusive student organization dedicated to celebrating and promoting the rich and diverse cultures of Eritrea and Ethiopia, as well as those of the broader diaspora. Our organization was founded with a passion for cultural exchange and community-building, aiming to create a welcoming and supportive environment for both Ethiopian and Eritrean students at UC Berkeley.

This group was formerly names Habesha Club at Berkeley [12/14/23][LL]
summary: To build a community that represent the Habesha community. Habesha means Eritreans, and Ethiopians nationality of people.

name: ESPM Graduate Diversity Council
description: The ESPM Graduate Diversity Council is a graduate student group with a vested interest in the continued diversification of the students and faculty of the department of Environmental Science, Policy and Management. We work to increase the presence of underrepresented groups in environmental fields through recruitment and retention efforts including workshops, speakers, special presentations, and mentoring. We are committed to creating and maintaining a community among underrepresented groups in ESPM, while actively promoting and engaging in diversity initiatives in the campus community.
summary: The ESPM Graduate Diversity Council is a graduate student group with a vested interest in the continued diversification of the students and faculty of the department of Environmental Science, Policy and Management.

name: ESPM Graduate Student Association
description: We represent the graduate student voice of ESPM both on campus and in the community at large.  To do so we organize events and initiatives to benefit the academic and local community, and encourage students to have fun in grad school.
summary: We represent the graduate students of ESPM and emphasize sharing, support, and celebration while in grad school.

name: ESPM Graduate Student Research Organizing Committee for the Symposium
description: The Graduate Student Research Symposium is an annual event showcasing the research outcomes of graduating students in the Environmental Science, Policy & Management Department. This organization plans and implements the event.
summary: To organize and host the annual Graduate Student Research Symposium dedicated to showcasing graduate student research and facilitating interdisciplinary exchange among divisions and between students and faculty.

name: Eta Kappa Nu
description: Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) is the national Electrical and Computer Engineering honor society. The Berkeley chapter is among the most active engineering societies at Berkeley, providing academic services to fellow undergraduates and local STEM outreach.
summary: Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) is the national Electrical and Computer Engineering honor society. The Berkeley chapter is among the most active engineering societies at Berkeley, providing academic services to fellow undergraduates and local STEM outreach.

name: EthiCal Apparel
description:
EthiCAL Apparel is a student-run and sustainably-driven social enterprise at UC Berkeley. We provide custom orders of high-quality screen printing and design services on sustainable, ethically-made clothing. In addition, we have our own line of apparel that we design and sell. The majority of our profits are donated to support a new local organization each semester.

Our team is comprised of 6 departments: Design; Finance and Operations; Marketing; Sales; Social Good; and Web Development. 

We handle all operations from strategic planning, customer insights, design, and event planning, to list a few. These opportunities create a unique environment where students stretch their creativity to drive the business forward with their impactful decisions.

If you’re interested in working in a professional business setting to build industry skills and gain real-world experience, we encourage you to keep an eye out for our recruitment at the beginning of each semester. 

Thank you for checking us out, and please email us at the email below if you have any questions, comments, or concerns!
summary: EthiCal Apparel is a student-run social enterprise from UC Berkeley that provides high-quality screen printing and free design services on sustainable, ethically-made clothing. We also have our own line of apparel that we design and sell.

name: Ethnic Studies 5th Account
description:
ETHNIC STUDIES 5TH ACCOUNT FUNDING APPLICATION 2023-2024  

The Ethnic Studies Fifth Account funding is only applicable to student-initiated events that meet the criteria of departmental sponsorship, significant impact on students, and cultural education.

Once you submit your application please do the following: Email a copy of your application, or application number to Ethnic Studies 5th Account Chair, Angelica at 5thaccountchair@gmail.com. In the email:

1. Attach your budget overview, complete with the amount you are requesting

2. A flyer for the event (please note, if your application is submitted, we kindly ask you include our name on the flyer)

3. A brief overview of your club/organization/event to be shared during the meeting

*Please note, we ask that all applicants are aware we ask your event be ADA accessible, and that a land acknowledgement is read.

Once your application is completed, please allow 72 hours for your application to be reviewed and a member of the committee will reach out with next steps. Next steps include, but are not limited to: joining a meeting with the committee to review the application and allow for questions.

The Ethnic Studies Fifth Account Committee will meet to review proposals every alternating weeks at a designated time and during both the Fall and Spring semester. The committee will meet in 554 social sciences building. 

Please Also Note: All receipts must be submitted to the chair (schedule meeting through email) no later than 2 weeks after the date of the event. All funding from the 5th Account is Reimbursement Based. Not doing this step will result in not being funded.  Please follow the guidelines below carefully; incomplete proposals will NOT be considered. Good luck!    

READ ALL INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY!

Scroll to the bottom of this page to find the 2023-2024 5th Account Application.
summary:
This is the link to the Ethnic Studies 5th Application. READ ALL INSTRUCTIONS CAREFULLY!

https://callink.berkeley.edu/form/start/50936

Go the URL below or click "read more" to find the hyperlink. 

https://callink.berkeley.edu/form/start/50936

name: Europe Business Club
description: The European Business club aims to promote the European culture and its business environment through events highlighting various topics of European culture.
summary: The European Business club aims to promote the European culture and its business environment through events highlighting various topics of European culture.

name: Expanding Your Horizons at Berkeley
description:
Our group is dedicated to hosting an annual "Expanding Your Horizons" (EYH) conference at Berkeley. EYH is a non-profit organization that aims to promote female involvement in the STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics).

Each spring, we bring several hundred middle school girls to UC Berkeley's campus to participate in a day of hands-on science workshops with both graduate students and professionals. Although our conference is just one day, planning, fundraising, and publicity takes us all year, from the fall to the spring!

If you want to find out more, check out our website!
summary: Our group is dedicated to hosting an annual "Expanding Your Horizons" (EYH) conference at Berkeley. EYH is a non-profit organization that aims to promote female involvement in the STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics).

name: Expansion Pictures
summary: Expansion Pictures is a student organisation that supports passion for filmmaking, animation, & cinematic exploration. EP provides an inclusive space for experimentation, discussion & showcase of media. We nurture collaboration & expansion of ideas.

name: Extended Reality @ Berkeley
description: Founded in 2015 by a team of visionary undergraduates, Extended Reality @ Berkeley grew to become the largest XR student organization in the world. Our community consists of more than 50 members and 600 alumni, brought together by a common passion to free our experience from the boundaries of perception. As part of our efforts, we train new engineers in all aspects of Virtual and Augmented Reality, raise awareness about our technology’s potential for humanity, and advance the field through state-of-art research and development initiatives. Visit us at: xr.berkeley.edu.
summary: We are the dreamers and makers of the new reality.

name: EyeChat!
summary: EyeChat! provides students with insight about unconventional career paths that exist after graduating from optometry school. We invite guest speakers from industry, research, and alternative fields to share their optometric career experiences.

name: Families at BerkeleyLaw
description:
Families at Berkeley Law helps student parents and caregivers navigate law school while balancing the demands of family life. By providing information, advocacy, and support to students, FABL ensures a safe forum to discuss concerns that may arise while pursuing a career in law. FABL is open to all students.

(Formerly known as Boalt Parent Group.)
summary: Families at Berkeley Law provides information, advocacy, and support for parents and caregivers at Berkeley Law. FABL establishes a secure forum to discuss issues surrounding family life while pursuing a career in law. The forum is open to all students.

name: Family Defense Project
description: The purpose of the Family Defense Project (FDP) is to provide advocacy on behalf of low-income parents involved in, or at risk of becoming involved in, dependency court proceedings. In particular, Black and Brown parents are at disproportionate risk of being aggressively surveilled and unnecessarily separated from their children by the family regulation system (also known as the child welfare system). This happens because the dependency court system is highly discretionary and often conflates poverty with failed parenting, which could be mitigated by adequate provision of social services instead of by separating families. Too often, racism and bias also bleed into dependency court decisions, which leads to less institutional trust of parents of color and a misguided belief by the system that their children are better off in state custody. In partnership with the East Bay Family Defenders, FDP will help fight this racism and classism by advocating for parents in the East Bay who are at risk of unjust family separation or have already been separated from their families.
summary: The purpose of the Family Defense Project (FDP) is to provide holistic legal support and advocacy for low-income parents in dependency court proceedings, under the supervision of an East Bay Family Defenders’ attorney.

name: Fashion and Student Trends
description:
The purpose of Fashion and Student Trend is to provide opportunities for students interested in fashion or the fashion industry to learn from other students and experts in the field or find a community during college.  We hold a 100% student-led semesterly fashion show, featuring student designers and student models. We strive to provide our students/audience with professional industry experience. We also invite experts in the fashion industry to talk to us about future career development and opportunities. 

In addition to designing and modeling, we have departments for photography, videography, styling, and beauty (hair and makeup artists). We also offer opportunities to participate in public relations, professional development, marketing, graphic design, finance, and publications.

Our department applications open up at the start of each semester, be sure to follow our socials to stay up to date on all things FAST.

No experience is necessary, just a passion for fashion!
summary: FAST provides a "runway" for students interested in fashion and the fashion industry to learn from other students and experts in the field. Our 12 departments run a 100% student-led semesterly fashion show featuring student designers and models!

name: Federalist Society at Berkeley Law
description:
Law schools and the legal profession are currently strongly dominated by a form of orthodox liberal ideology, which advocates a centralized and uniform society. While some members of the academic community have dissented from these views, by and large they are taught simultaneously with (and indeed as if they were) the law.

The Federalist Society for Law and Public Policy Studies is a group of conservatives and libertarians interested in the current state of the legal order. It is founded on the principles that the state exists to preserve freedom, that the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution, and that it is the province and duty of the judiciary to say what the law is, not what it should be. The society seeks both to promote an awareness of these principles and to further their application through its activities.

The Berkeley Law chapter of the Federalist Society’s goals include: promoting thoughtful and challenging discussion of legal and public policy issues; academically and intellectually sponsoring conservative and libertarian law students; and ensuring that Berkeley Law students are thoughtfully exposed to conservative and libertarian perspectives and consider these perspectives in their analysis of legal issues. We put on a number of great events, which include bringing out leading judges, legal scholars, and practicing lawyers to address hot-button issues of importance to the Federalist Society. We are also a social club, with happy hours and some planned excursions in the mix.

Membership is open to all students who are interested in thoughtful debate and the exchange of ideas, regardless of political ideology.
summary: The Federalist Society is interested in the current state of the legal order. It believes that the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution and that it is the duty of the judiciary to say what the law is not what it should be.

name: FeelGood
description:
FeelGood is a youth-led movement turning college into a time of effective global action. On campuses across the country, students run a successful social enterprise—a grilled cheese deli— to raise money and build public support for the end of extreme hunger and poverty. In the process students gain critical business, leadership and teamwork skills that serve them throughout their lives.

Why grilled cheese? Artisan bread, gourmet cheeses, local produce and a panini press make for a mouth-watering comfort food that is sure to make you smile. The nostalgic simplicity of a grilled cheese is an irresistible invitation to everyone to make a systemic difference. 

By asking for a donation, we give everyone the space to manifest generosity by turning lunch into an opportunity to give back. People donate whatever makes them "feel good," expressing their love for humanity and our earth with every penny. 

Every dollar students raise is invested in the Commitment 2030 Fund: A select group of organizations working to fulfill the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): a global initiative to eliminate extreme hunger and poverty by achieving an economically prosperous, socially inclusive, and environmentally sustainable human presence on the planet by 2030.

www.feelgood.org
summary: FeelGood is a non-profit, student-run grilled cheese deli working towards a world free of extreme and chronic hunger by the year 2030. All donations are invested in a select group of organizations working to fulfill the Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Fei Tian Dancers
description: Fei Tian Dancers is the one & only Chinese dance team at UC Berkeley. Established in 2003 as a Registered Student Organization, FTD supports dancers of all backgrounds in developing their Chinese dance skill & technique, enhancing their comprehension of traditional Chinese culture, & in spreading greater awareness of Chinese classical & ethnic cultures to the bigger community. FTD incorporates classical, ethnic, & modern Chinese dances into its repertoire through creating original choreography & learning traditional works, performing on campus & throughout the Bay Area.
summary: Fei Tian Dancers is the one & only Chinese dance team at UC Berkeley. Established in 2003 , FTD supports dancers of all backgrounds in developing their Chinese dance skill & technique, enhancing their comprehension of traditional Chinese culture.

name: Fellowship in Christ Berkeley
description:
The mission of our ministry is to glorify God by being a people who are transformed by the gospel of Jesus Christ and who then serve as agents of transformation for God in the San Francisco Bay Area and throughout the world.

We hope to accomplish this purpose by committing ourselves to these five priorities:

Internal Priorities.
Worship – John 4:23-24, Rev. 4:8-11, 5:8-14
Teaching – Acts 2:41-42, Eph. 4:11-16
Fellowship – Acts 2:41-42, Heb. 10:23-25

External Priorities.
Evangelism / Missions – Matt. 28:16-20, 1 Pet. 3:15
Mercy Ministries / Social Justice – Luke 10:30-37, 1 John 3:17
summary: Fellowship in Christ, Berkeley (FiCB) is the campus ministry of Christ Central Presbyterian Church in Daly City. Our ministry has a joint-vision with our church to worship Christ as our Savior and to build up Christians with the message of the gospel.

name: Fellowship of Christian Optometrists Chapter at Berkeley (Formerly Christian Medical and Dental Associations Chapter at Berkeley)
description:
Purpose:

To serve with professional excellence as witnesses of Christ's love and compassion, and by advancing biblical principles of healthcare within the Church and to our culture. Our goal is to offer guidance and role models as students consider pursuing careers in healthcare and then actively support them as they navigate through their professional training years and into a life of serving the Lord in a healthcare career by going on medical missions to underserved countries abroad and within the States

 

This group [Fellowship of Christian Optometrists Chapter at Berkeley] was formerly named [Christian Medical and Dental Associations Chapter at Berkeley] - [D9/2/21] IZ (PLC)
summary: Fellowship of Christian Optometrists Chapter at Berkeley exists to glorify God by motivating, educating and equipping Christian pre-medical and pre-dental students.

name: Female Founders and Funders of Berkeley
summary: Our mission is to empower women founders and funders at Berkeley by fostering a supportive community and providing essential resources for connection, learning, and growth to drive innovation and equality in the startup and VC industries.

name: Fiat Lux Scholars Association
description:
FLSA Goals:

  1.  To develop a sense of community among Fiat Lux Scholarship recipients at UC, Berkeley. 

  2.  To enhance the educational, social, and professional experience of Fiat Lux Scholars. 

  3. To collaborate with the Undergraduate Scholarship Office on recruitment efforts through the high school Outreach Program and the Fiat Lux Overnight Program.

Click here for more information!
summary: To unify and strengthen our community of Fiat Lux Scholars and alumni through meaningful social, academic, and professional development opportunities.

name: Field Hockey Club of Berkeley
summary: The Field Hockey Club of Berkeley gives students the opportunity to participate in field hockey matches with other students. We are spreading the love of the game around the bay area!

name: Fight for Autism at Berkeley
description: FFA's goal is to serve and present new opportunities to the East Bay neurodivergent community, especially autistic individuals, as well as spread awareness and education on inclusivity. Our organization plans to work with elementary school children that are neurodivergent, collaborate on community projects with other organizations that host young adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities, and to have social fun during organization and community wide socials. Our organization is distinct from other student organizations that focus on neurodivergence as our organization aspires to reach out to the greater community of the East Bay and San Francisco, and work with neurodivergent individuals of all ages, not just students. We will be working on service projects that benefit the East Bay community as well as academic and social activities that bring us closer to providing effective education and awareness on inclusivity.
summary: FFA’s goal is to serve and present new opportunities to the East Bay neurodivergent community, especially autistic individuals, as well as spread awareness and education on inclusivity.

name: Fighting for Hope at Berkeley
description: Fighting for Hope aims to spread awareness and advocate for mental health efforts, promote student wellness, and provide opportunities for the mental health community within UC Berkeley and involve students in fundraisers, projects, and events dedicated to student mental health.
summary: To help spread awareness and advocate for mental health efforts within the UC Berkeley community and involve students in fundraisers and events dedicated to mental health. We will also routinely host guest speakers and mental health workshops.

name: Fighting Games at Berkeley
description: Fighting Games at Berkeley caters towards a community that currently enjoys or is looking to get into fighting games. Any level of player, casual or competitive, grad or undergrad, is welcome! We meet every Friday at the Cal Esports Community Center, playing a wide variety of fighting games, from Street Fighter to Guilty Gear! For the more competitive player, there are occasional exhibitions versus other collegiate FGCs!
summary: Fighting Games at Berkeley caters towards a community that currently enjoys or is looking to get into fighting games. Any level of player, casual or competitive, is welcome! We host tournaments for all skill levels!

name: Finance Club at Berkeley (BFC) [Formerly Sales and Trading Club at Berkeley]
description: At the Sales and Trading Club (also known as Berkeley Finance Club), our core mission is to help undergraduates who are interested in finance reach their individual potential. In a close-knit community, we provide mentorships, professional development, and career networking opportunities. Club members will gain practical knowledge about the financial market and how to land a job in the financial industry. Alumni and upperclassmen will help our members prepare through resume critique, networking, and mock interviews.
summary: The Sales and Trading Club (also known as Berkeley Finance Club) is a student organization dedicated to help undergraduates who are interested in finance reach their individual potential.

name: Financial Education Association of Berkeley
description: The purpose of this organization is to promote financial awareness within the student body of UC Berkeley. Our objective is to educate our members on financial planning and personal wealth management. We plan on inviting industry experts as guest speakers to educate us and share their knowledge, insights and success stories. We aim to elevate the knowledge of our members on money management, credit, loans, taxes, investments, trading, real estate, insurance, and other sectors of personal finance.
summary: The purpose of this organization is to promote financial awareness within the student body of UC Berkeley. Our objective is to educate our members on financial planning, loans, investments, wealth management and other sectors of business.

name: Financial Engineering Students Association
summary: We aim to expose its members to the finance and data science industry in order to network and establish relationships that will lead to jobs in the field.

name: First Generation Professionals
description: First Generation Professionals (FGP) is a student-led group that strives to address the needs of first-generation law students through mentorship, career advising, and social activities.  Born of the common experiences and challenges of students from working-class backgrounds who are often the first in their family to attend college, FGP is a truly diverse community that fosters inclusiveness, well-being, and academic achievement throughout students’ time at Berkeley Law.
summary: First Generation Professionals (FGP) is a student-led group that strives to address the needs of first-generation law students through mentorship, career advising, and social activities.

name: First Love at Berkeley
description:
First Love is a vibrant and energetic group of young people full of first love for the Lord. It is imperative for every young person to know that Jesus died for them.

First Love is in Universities across the United States and our motto is simple: love God and love others. Across the academic year, we host an array of exciting events that all students are welcome to attend.

We know that starting out university can be hard with all the new faces, new places and new experiences. Nevertheless, First Love is here to be one of the best chapters of your life yet! We offer fun, fellowship and above all a family.

For more information on our events, follow us on 

Instagram: @firstlovebayarea

Facebook: First Love at Berkeley, First Love Church Bay Area.
summary: The purpose of First Love, Berkeley shall be to reach out with the Gospel both at home and abroad with the desire of seeing multitudes come to a saving knowledge of Jesus Christ and to provide Christian fellowship to all.

name: First-Gen and/or Low-Income Graduate Students
description: The mission of FGLI Grads is to build community and support first-generation and/or low-income graduate students at UC Berkeley. First-Generation grad students are students whose parents or guardians earned less than a bachelor’s degree. Low-Income grad students are generally students who were Pell-Grant eligible during undergrad. We acknowledge these terms are not perfect, so we welcome any members who identify with our mission. We also invite Cal staff and faculty who wish to support, and advocate with, FGLI graduate students.
summary: The mission of FGLI Grads is to build community and support first-generation and/or low-income graduate students at UC Berkeley.

name: Food at Haas
summary: Our mission is to creatively strengthen our sense of community and bonding through our mutual love of food and we aim to do this by increasing access to resources, alumni, and career opportunities in the food industry.

name: Food Friendly Finance
description: Food Friendly Finance (Apple Pie Finance) hopes to help sustainable restaurants and food-related business make it in the marketplace. Apple Pie Finance will be training members on hospitality and restaurant industry business knowledge while offering client-facing services in streamlining business financial statements.
summary: Food Friendly Finance hopes to help sustainable restaurants and food-related business make it in the marketplace. Please contact us if you're passionate!

name: Food Institute Graduate Council at Berkeley
description:
The Food Institute Graduate Council (FIGC) at Berkeley was established to bring together students interested in studying and transforming food systems. We advocate for the needs of graduate students interested in this work, facilitate educational, professional, and advocacy opportunities, and seek to support the survival and success of the broader Food and Agriculture community at the University of California at Berkeley (UC Berkeley). During the semester, FIGC hosts a running lunch and speaker series with guest professors, cooking project workshops in the Berkeley Teaching Kitchen, farm volunteer days, monthly membership meetings, and much more.

*informally known as the BFI Graduate Council
summary: A cross-disciplinary hub for Berkeley graduate students interested in food systems issues. It provides educational and professional opportunities, promoting the empowerment of new leaders who cultivate diverse, just, resilient, and healthy food systems.

name: Food Justice Project
summary: Food Justice Project is a Student-Initiated Legal Service Project in Berkeley School of Law. This organization provides assists the Berkeley community with the appeals process for CalFresh and conducts legislative research on public benefits.

name: Food, Equity, Entrepreneurship, & Development
description:
Founded in 2016, Food, Equity, Entrepreneurship, and Development (FEED) is a premier, student-run consulting organization focused on food systems and sustainability. We are a multidisciplinary and tight-knit team that provides services to companies that work to transform the food system. Our diverse clients include restaurants, CPG start-ups, food banks, agri-tech companies, and more.

Our vision is a world where food is not wasted, agricultural practices are sustainable, and, most importantly, everyone can access whole, nutritious foods. Our mission is to turn this vision into reality through consulting.
summary: Through consulting, our UC Berkeley student group serves businesses dedicated to equitable food access, sustainability, and community building.

name: For Christ's Sake
description:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DEx11B2X8TQ
 
As a Christian a cappella group at UC Berkeley, we have come together across campus fellowships and churches to proclaim the good news of the Gospel through song to our campus and community. Our hope is that through music we can better understand and share with others the knowledge that every good thing in us is for Christ’s sake, as expressed in Philemon 1:6.
 
"and I pray that the fellowship of your faith may become effective through the knowledge of every good thing which is in you for Christ's sake." Philemon 1:6
 
We were founded by a group of Cal students in 2000. This fall, we celebrate 21 years of God's faithfulness to this group, and our prayer is that you might also be blessed by the joy we experience through Him.
summary: As a Christian a cappella group at Cal, we have come together across campus fellowships and churches to proclaim the good news of the Gospel through song to our campus and community. We believe every good thing is for Christ's sake, as in Philemon 1:6.

name: Foresight Pre-Optometry Club
description: Foresight Pre-Optometry Club is a student-run organization that seeks to unite UC Berkeley students and individuals around the area who are interested in pursuing a career in the field of optometry. We teach members the necessary skills and we provide members with the necessary tools to shape them into more knowledgeable applicants. We hold various events such as optometry school presentations, detailed workshops on the application process and strategies for tackling the OAT, and socials to allow members the opportunity to meet peers and potential optometry school classmates. We educate our members on the current issues facing the growing field of optometry, and we encourage individuals to volunteer to better prepare them for a career in providing eye care for their community. Foresight aims to create a network between the members of the club and current optometrists by keeping strong connections with professors and alumni.
summary: UC Berkeley's Pre-Optometry Club aims to unite students and community members who are interested in the field of optometry. We encourage everyone to not only learn more about optometry but to build friendships with their future colleagues. Welcome!

name: Formula Electric at Berkeley (Formerly bLoop)
description: Formula Electric at Berkeley is a team of 120+ active members that designs, manufactures, tests, and races an electric race car in the Formula SAE EV competition. We are focused on equipping Berkeley students with the technical and entrepreneurial acumen needed to help the world transition to sustainable transportation. Recruitment cycles happen twice a year, at the beginning of both the fall and spring semesters.
summary: We are a competitive engineering team that designs, manufactures, tests, and races an electric race car in the Formula SAE EV competition each year.

name: Formula SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers)
description: UC Berkeley's Formula SAE team, or Berkeley Formula Racing (BFR), is an engineering student organization that designs and builds a small formula-style race car in order to compete in the annual Formula SAE competition. Our team is comprised of about 60 students from various backgrounds all belonging to at least one of our subsystems: Aerodynamics, Brakes & Driver Interface, Business, Chassis Drivetrain, Engine, Electrical, and Suspension. Since our establishment in 2001, our dedicated members have worked their way from a simple engineering club to one of the top competitors in the nation. Each year we continuously grow and improve in both our engineering design and project management skills.
summary: We design, fabricate and compete with small formula-style racecars against other colleges from around the world.

name: Foster Education Project
description: Our organization serves foster youth in the Bay Area. We pair each student with a single child, and file paperwork with the court to become a legal education rights holder. Our main responsibility is to advocate for the youth at their school and in IEP meetings to ensure that they are receiving adequate services.
summary: Foster Education Project provides members of the Berkeley Law community with opportunities to perform direct services to foster children in the community, and to receive training in Youth, Education, and Disability Law.

name: Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children
description:
The Foundation for the International Medical Relief of Children (FIMRC) is dedicated to improving the lives of children worldwide by providing medical support and health education.

As its primary mission, FIMRC establishes and maintains pediatric medical clinics in underserved regions. This includes staffing the clinic with local physicians and nurses; hosting international volunteers at its clinic sites; and raising funds for medical equipment and supplies. FIMRC also supports existing medical facilities with funding and volunteer staffing.

FIMRC at Berkeley strives to accomplish those goals in a way that pertains to us, that is, by:

  1. Fundraising for the construction of pediatric clinics in areas currently lacking a reliable source for healthcare.
  2. Directly influence the health of children by encouraging and supporting individuals and groups who desire to travel to medically underserved areas of the world.
  3. Encourage future health leaders to become involved in our purpose by recognizing their achievements.
summary: As the FIMRC chapter in Berkeley, we strive to accomplish our global health mission by fundraising for medical projects, coordinating volunteer travel to our clinic sites, raising public health awareness, and providing service in our direct community.

name: Fraternity & Sorority Life - providing advising to the CalGreeks Community
summary: Fraternity & Sorority Life provides advising and support to all of our social fraternities and sororities and the governing councils (IFC, MCGC, NPHC, and Panhellenic).

name: Free Peach, The
summary: The Free Peach satirizes current events in the Berkeley community and beyond. Building subtext on the foundation of recurring tropes and dynamics present on campus, we examine Berkeley student life under the critical lens of comedy.

name: Free the Land Project
description: This project seeks to provide support to grassroots organizers in their land, housing, and environmental justice goals. We want to provide opportunities for Berkeley Law students to engage with BIPOC-led organizations in the Bay Area fighting for the liberation rights of the most vulnerable communities.
summary: FTLP is a Berkeley Law SLP that seeks to provide support to grassroots organizers and BIPOC-led organizations in the Bay Area in their land, housing, and environmental justice goals.

name: Free Ventures
description:
We are a program run by students, for students. Our founders have gone on to become Forbes 30 Under 30, build companies that are changing the world, and continue to develop the college startup scene by creating The House. Free Ventures has been an instrumental part of Berkeley’s startup ecosystem in its formative years, helping it to develop into the most robust college startup scene in recent years. In the process we’ve built the most comprehensive pre-seed program for Berkeley startups, tailored to each team’s specific needs and purely pro-bono.

Each day our team actively works with our venture capital sponsors, resource partners, The House, Dorm Room Fund, and other groups to build the strongest community of Berkeley founders, providing startups with a full stack of resources to guide them from ideation to investment. We have helped our 62 alumni teams raise over $40 million from top firms such as Y Combinator, Greylock, KPCB, and SVAngel. Collectively they’ve gone on to tackle problems in VR, drones, IoT, neuroscience, AI, real estate, and renewable energy, to name a few.
summary: We provide the university's brightest student founders with workspace, mentorship, academic units, funding, and resources to scale. Our mission is to free students from the constraints that hinder starting up while in school to found high-impact startups

name: Friends of MSF at Berkeley
description:
FoMSF at Berkeley aims to garner support for Doctors Without Borders' humanitarian projects and educate students on the positive impact their involvement could have both in our community and the world at large. Our goal is to raise money and spread awareness for Doctors Without Borders projects in conflict zones and in countries affected by endemic diseases. By putting on unique and interactive events throughout the community, our Berkeley chapter emphasizes education, awareness, and fundraising.

LINKTREE: https://linktr.ee/msf.ucberkeley 

This group [Friends of MSF at Berkeley] was formerly named [Doctors Without Borders at Berkeley] - [10/5/23] [LL]
summary: FoMSF at Berkeley aims to raise awareness for global crises, MSF advocacy campaigns, and humanitarian medicine. Our mission is to provide impactful service by volunteering with and raising awareness for local humanitarian organizations.

name: Friends of the Co-ops
description: The mission of Friends of the Co-ops is to provide an extension of the Berkeley Student Cooperative (BSC) community on campus. The BSC is a non-profit housing cooperative that is 1200+ members strong and is committed to providing a quality, low-cost, cooperative housing community to students. This organization will work to fight for co-op interests on campus, link the Berkeley community to the cooperative movement, and movement build using the Solidarity Economy (SE) framework.
summary: We are an organization open to all students, faculty, and staff interested in the Berkeley Student Housing Co-ops. We are a link between the UC Campus and the BSC (Berkeley Student Cooperative). Our mission is to provide affordable housing to students.

name: Frontera at Berkeley
description:
Frontera at Berkeley is composed of people with a strong interest in the U.S.A.- Mexico border region, border policy as well as the migrant experience and immigration policy. In recent times, immigration and border policy have become key agenda items at federal, regional, and local elections. With that in mind, as an organization, we strive to raise awareness among the Berkeley population about migrant issues, border policy, and the border region. Given the transnational bond between the two sides of the border, many of the residents of the regions develop a “fronterice” identity, with strong cultural connections to both sides of the border, as an organization, our mission is to give a voice to members of that region in a place like Berkeley, where policy discussion is influential at a national level. We also aim to foster an open discussion about current issues like discrimination, the migrant crisis, and the economic potential of the region.  We seek to incentivize our members to find venues of engagement and become active participants in these discussions at a national level.

 
Committees:
 
Marketing & Outreach: insta profile, relationship with other clubs & school dept
 
Activism: contact nonprofits, look for engagement opportunities
 
Policy Research: Workshops and Info sessions
 
Recruitment & Finance: Keep track of recruitment efforts and take lead on fundraisers and grant application process
summary: With Immigration and border policy becoming Key agenda Items United States politics; Frontera at Berkeley looks for solutions to the hardest policy problems, raises awareness on the "fronterice" Identity, and the southern border migrant experience.

name: Future Advancers of Science and Technology - 2023-24
description:
To connect graduate level STEAM researchers with under-resourced or underserved local high school students to mentor the students through a year long research project. In early fall, mentees will be recruited through a “pitch day” at their school where the program will be promoted through demonstrations of unknowns in science. Then, in late fall, mentors will guide recruits through brainstorming sessions to help the recruits decide on a question they want to explore. In winter and spring, students get to perform experiments to try and answer their questions. Additionally, workshops will be held to help students with career development, including applying to college. Students will also be encouraged to participate in local science fairs. At the end of the year, all FAST participants will present their work at a symposium where they will hear from professors, talk with college recruiters, earn student-nominated awards, and have the opportunity to win a scholarship.

 

This guided but student-driven research experience has several goals:

  • To help students build confidence, especially with research and presentation skills
  • To encourage students from all backgrounds to pursue education and careers in research fields
  • To enhance the high school STEAM educational experience
  • To prepare students for competitive jobs and college applications through skill and resume building
summary: Connecting graduate-level scientists, engineers, and artists with high school students to tackle big problems and create amazing projects. Expanding possibilities for students from disenfranchised or under-resourced communities to shape the future.

name: Future Business Leaders of America-Phi Beta Lambda, Inc.
description:
The UC Berkeley chapter of FBLA-PBL is one of the oldest and largest business organizations on campus providing a personal approach to professional development through client-facing projects and five project teams, known as committees, focus on different fields and intersections of business and pursue engaging and challenging curriculums in consulting, finance, marketing, tech, and biotechnology to foster well-rounded members.

Our distinguishing feature is our organizational structure and values. We are recruiting Fall 2023 committee members who will undergo an extensive and comprehensive business curriculum that will leave members with a solid foundation of business acumen and technical skills needed to succeed in their professional careers. Atop projects that cohort members will complete, leadership will lead a variety of professional development workshops that ensure you're ready to successfully recruit and land an internship at your dream company while offering a mentorship program to give you the personalized guidance you need to succeed.

Although we're a general business organization, PBL prides itself on the diversity of our members. From chemical engineering and business double-majors to CS and music students, our organization thrives by bringing together a community of people with distinct academic, professional, and personal pursuits. Given our emphasis on community, our members excel at and value collaborative teaming, opportunities to learn, and practical application of skills.

Learn more about us on our website, subscribe to our mailing list to stay up-to-date with recruitment happenings and follow us on Facebook or Instagram!
summary: The Berkeley chapter of Phi Beta Lambda provides a personal approach to professional development through client-facing projects and five project teams, known as committees, focusing on different fields and intersections of business.

name: G.I.F.T.E.D. (Give to Inspire the Future of Talented, Educated Doctors) Pre-Med
description:
G.I.F.T.E.D. Pre-Med is a non-profit organization dedicated to diversifying the healthcare field by improving access to higher education in medicine. Our primary focus is spreading awareness of and alleviating the financial barriers that many low-income and minority-identifying pre-med students face on the path to medical school.

Please fill out our interest form if you wish to stay updated about becoming a general member and for any of our upcoming events: https://forms.gle/AwhTEjv5HkZi9kQ99

For more information and upcoming dates, feel free to follow our socials!

  • Instagram: @giftedpremed
  • Email: giftedpremed@gmail.com 
  • Website: http://sites.google.com/berkeley.edu/giftedpremed

Join G.I.F.T.E.D. Pre-Med to be part of a community of diverse pre-health students fighting for a new medical field.
summary: GIFTED Pre-Med is a non-profit association dedicated to uplifting minority and/or low-income pre-medical students at UC Berkeley by alleviating the financial obstacles to applying to medical school.

name: GA Basic Needs Security Project
description:
GA Basic Needs Project Group

The Basic Needs Security(BNS) Officer coordinates and oversees advocacy efforts to address the short-
and long-term basic needs security (i.e. security in housing, food, childcare, and healthcare) for academic and professional graduate students at the University of California, Berkeley. To this capacity, the BNS
Officer works closely with the Basic Needs Center to provide a critical graduate student perspective on
the direction, accessibility, promotion, and creation of services. Other campus partners include: the
Student Advocate’s Office (SAO), PATH to Care, and so forth.
summary: GA Basic Needs Security Project - please fill out description when needed

name: GA Berkeley Business Law Journal
description: The Berke­ley Busi­ness Law Jour­nal (BBLJ) is a Berke­ley Law student-run orga­ni­za­tion that pub­lishes a bian­nual print jour­nal, a blog, and hosts events related to busi­ness law.  BBLJ works closely with the Berke­ley Cen­ter for Law and Busi­ness (BCLB) to fur­ther enhance our pres­ence nationwide.
summary: The Berke­ley Busi­ness Law Jour­nal (BBLJ) is a Berke­ley Law student-run orga­ni­za­tion that pub­lishes a bian­nual print jour­nal, a blog, and hosts events related to busi­ness law.

name: GA Business Office
description: Located in Eshleman Hall, the Business Office is currently staffed by undergraduates who work in partnership with the GA Executive Board and Project Directors to put on programming for the graduate student population. All general inquiries ranging from funding to information pertaining to current programming within the GA are handled by the Business Office. Additionally, the Business Office provides a variety of services to support the GA Projects and Executive Officers.
summary: The GA Business Office is the main administrative support branch of the GA.

summary: The Delegate Assembly is the representative body for graduate students in the Graduate Assembly. Delegates are allotted per 100 students in a department, school, or college, and they are elected or appointed in line with their department's policies.

name: GA Internal Vice President
description:
The GA Internal Vice President (IVP) is the chair of the meetings of the Delegate Assembly and is responsible for recruitment of new delegates and any issues pertaining to physical space, resources, and communications.

Examples of the administrators and committees that the GA IVP works closely with: Director of Graduate Student Life, Student Union Board of Directors

The GA IVP oversees the following internal GA committees and staff: Graduate Social Club Coordinator, Technology Director, Funding Appeals Board

Contact the current GA IVP at internal-ga@berkeley.edu if you would like to learn more about this role.

name: GA Rules Officer
description: The Rules Committee shall monitor the internal actions of the Graduate Assembly to ensure that they comply with the Charter, these Bylaws, and any Memoranda of Understanding between the Graduate Assembly and other entities. It generally shall include proposing changes to the Charter, these Bylaws, and any Memoranda as well as deciding disputes regarding the Charter and these Bylaws. The Rules Committee shall conduct an annual review process of these Bylaws and all Memoranda. The Rules Committee may make recommendations to the Delegate Assembly regarding what corrective and, if necessary, disciplinary action should be taken against members of the Graduate Assembly who, without good cause, knowingly violate the Charter and these Bylaws.
summary: The Rules Committee shall monitor the internal actions of the Graduate Assembly to ensure that they comply with the Charter, these Bylaws, and any Memoranda of Understanding between the Graduate Assembly and other entities. It generally shall include

name: GA Travel Funds (branch of GA Funding)
description:
This page is for awardees of the GA Professional Development Grant and the GA Graduate Student Parent Travel Grant.

To submit a purchase request to be reimbursed, go to "GA Travel Funds" in the ribbon on the left. From there, click the gear icon and choose "Finance." Once on the Finance page, click the button in the top right corner, "Create Request." Requests may not exceed your award total, and must include uploaded receipts and other required documentation. Purchase Requests must be received within 30 days of the end of the conference or within 30 days of the payment of professional society fees.

If you have any questions, email the GA Funding Officer at funding@ga.berkeley.edu
summary: GA Travel Funds (reimbursements for the GA Professional Development Grant and the GA Grad Student Parent Travel Grant)
