2. provide a forum of cultural, social and recreational activities designed to enhance the relationships between South Asian students on campus
summary: The primary purpose of this association shall be to organize and engage in activities designed to preserve and spread South Asian culture among its membership and the surrounding area.

name: Infectious Diseases and Immunity PhD Student Group
description: The Infectious Diseases and Immunity PhD Student Group provides a forum for the IDI PhD students to discuss programmatic issues, plan and organize activities, and foster a sense of community between the students.
summary: The Infectious Diseases and Immunity PhD Student Group provides a forum for the IDI PhD students to discuss programmatic issues, plan and organize activities, and foster a sense of community between the students.

name: Innovation Factory at Berkeley
description:
Meteor Incubator/Innovation Factory at Berkeley is a dynamic student-led initiative designed to empower budding entrepreneurs. Our mission is to provide a platform where students can evolve their innovative ideas into actionable projects, benefiting from mentorship by seasoned industry experts and accomplished entrepreneurs.

Throughout the academic term, we facilitate hands-on project workshops, fine-tuning ideas and refining business models. As the culmination of each season, typically aligning with the semester's end, we organize an internal pitch session, offering students the chance to secure investment opportunities. This is followed by a public roadshow, further amplifying student projects and inviting community engagement.

A hallmark of our initiative is the documentation of the entrepreneurial journey. With participants' consent, we chronicle the challenges faced, solutions devised, and milestones achieved by each team. These narratives are then transformed into invaluable educational resources, enriching our future workshops and creating a legacy of shared knowledge.
summary: Meteor Incubator/Innovation Factory at Berkeley is a dynamic student-led initiative designed to empower budding entrepreneurs. Our mission is to provide a platform where students can evolve their innovative ideas into actionable projects, benefiting from

name: Innovative Solutions Consulting at Berkeley
description: BIS Consulting is UC Berkeley’s premier graduate-student consulting organization which matches students to SDG-aligned clients and projects that accelerate new-economy innovations or tackle business or societal problems.
summary: BIS Consulting is UC Berkeley’s premier graduate-student consulting organization which matches students to SDG-aligned clients and projects that accelerate new-economy innovations or tackle societal problems.

name: Inside the Living Room
description: Inside the Living Room (ILR) creates meaningful internship & service opportunities for UC Berkeley students seeking to understand immigrant refugee rights, legal processes and frameworks, and immigrant advocacy through the working of legal cases and educational programs for immigrants and the public with the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant.
summary: Inside the Living Room (ILR) creates meaningful internship & service opportunities for UC Berkeley students seeking to understand immigrant refugee rights, legal processes and frameworks, and immigrant advocacy.

name: Institute of Business Forecasting and Planning at Berkeley
description: As the official UC Berkeley chapter of the national Institute of Business Forecasting & Planning (https://ibf.org/), our mission is to spread awareness among Berkeley students about careers in forecasting and planning, and to serve as a hub for networking and knowledge sharing among Berkeley students and forecasting and planning professionals in the Bay Area.
summary: We are a local chapter of Institute of Business Forecasting & Planning (https://ibf.org/).

name: Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers
description: The Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers (IISE) at Berkeley is the largest industrial engineering student organization on campus. Our mission is to provide Industrial Engineering and Operations Research (IEOR) and Operations Research and Management Sciences (ORMS) majors with the opportunity to engage with students, professionals, and alumni. We strive to create an inclusive environment for current and future students, and we focus on supporting one another in terms of academic, social, and career development. Learn more about us at https://iise.berkeley.edu and contact iise@berkeley.edu to join us and meet your fellow IEOR / ORMS students!
summary: Institute of Industrial Engineers at Berkeley holds social and professional activities throughout the semester tailored to undergraduate students demonstrating an interest in the fields of Industrial Engineering and/or Operations Research.

name: Institute of Transportation Engineers at UC Berkeley
description: The purpose of Cal ITE shall be to promote student exploration of transportation engineering by fostering meaningful connections between students and transportation professionals; to acquaint students with topics of interest in transportation through speakers and chapter-sponsored trips; and to promote common interests among students.
summary: The purpose of Cal ITE shall be to promote student exploration of transportation engineering by fostering meaningful connections between students and transportation professionals.

name: Integrative Biology Graduate Student Association
summary: IBGSA will provide a safe, inclusive forum for all graduate students in Integrative Biology, develop programming that fosters community and collaboration, and actively engage in departmental improvement.

name: Intellectual Property Law Society
description:
The Intellectual Property Society (IPLS) caters to the interests of all budding Intellectual Property lawyers! IPLS is committed to cultivating research, discussions and advocacy in the field of Intellectual Property Law. We strive to provide all kinds of fruitful opportunities for the students interested in intellectual property law, thereby strengthening their ties with the Berkeley Law community. We work towards:

  1. Building networks between intellectual property law attorneys, advocacy organizations and the Berkeley Law student body in order to promote the field of intellectual property law;
  2. Spreading awareness of intellectual property law as a career path for young scholars in the Berkeley community at large;
  3. Providing training opportunities for students and supporting the intellectual property law curriculum at Berkeley Law.
summary: Intellectual Property Law Society is organized to serve as a focus group for Berkeley Law students interested in practicing intellectual property law.

name: Interdisciplinary Studies Field Club
description: The purpose of ISFC is to create a space for students within the Interdisciplinary Studies Field major to network, share ideas, and socialize. ISFC will host events and provide resources that foster the development of students’ research interests and ultimately their research proposals.
summary: The purpose of ISFC is to create a space for students within the Interdisciplinary Studies Field major to network, share ideas, and socialize. ISFC will foster the development of students’ research interests and ultimately their research proposal.

name: Interfraternity Council (IFC)
description:
The Interfraternity Council (IFC) is one of four Greek councils at Cal that abide by the pillars of Friendship, Leadership, Scholarship and Service. We are the binding organization that ties all of the recognized fraternity chapters on campus. The number of fraternities is now over thrity, which amounts to approximately 1300 of the undergradute men at UC Berkeley. IFC serves chiefly as the official connection between the individual chapters and the University of California. As a council we are by and large self-governed through the efforts of representative delegates from each chapter, who work year long with the officers on IFC to strategize, plan, organize and execute short and long term goals to ensure the growth of the fraternity system at Cal.

IFC can also be thought of as the organization capable of doing things for the benefit of the entire community that no individual chapter has the resources to do on their own. We frequently engage in activities that include Greek-wide philanthropy and social events, public relations with the University and rest of the Berkeley community, risk management and safety of the entire community and Greek wide recruitment, to name a few.

Recruitment into IFC chapters is generally available at the beginning of every semester to every undergraduate male seeking to enhance their time at Cal by being a part of an organization that is truly greater than the sum of its parts. Greek members graduate with uncomparable experiences of the brotherhood, leadership opportunities and social life that is inherent in every chapter, regardless of the letters.
summary: The Inter-Fraternity Council represents over thirty Greek organizations on Berkeley's campus. The Council aims to ensure that its members get the most out of their time at Cal by emphasizing four pillars—Leadership, Friendship, Scholarship and Service.

name: Intermission Orchestra, The
description:
The Intermission Orchestra is a community of fans of anime, video games, and films, who enjoy playing the music from these mediums. Our goal is to spread our love for these genres of music.

Find us on Facebook, Instagram and our Youtube Channel!

 

If you are interested in joining us, please check out and fill out our website and fill out the applications!
We are recruiting players (including singers!) and staff (art, audio, and photography/video). If you don't have a lot of music experience but still want to get involved, sign up for our staff positions! They are beginner-friendly and we will be holding workshops to teach you everything you need to know!

 

How will this club work?
To put it simply, club members arrange full orchestra pieces for members to rehearse throughout the semester. This culminates into a concert where we invite people from the school and the community to come watch us play. Club members can also form small ensembles to play their own pieces in between whole-orchestra pieces.
Other than that, we have social events (dinners, boba runs, and game night) and workshops (singing, arranging, audio engineering, etc.)!
summary: The Intermission Orchestra is a community of fans of anime, video games, and films, who enjoy playing the music from these mediums. Our goal is to spread our love for these genres of music.

name: International & Undocumented Student Project (GA Project)
summary: GA account for GA IUSP

name: International Building Performance Simulation Association/ASHRAE Berkeley
description: We are a student organization recognized by the national chapter of the International Building Performance Simulation Association - USA and ASHRAE chapters. We seek to unite students and researchers from across campus who work towards the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of sustainable and healthy built environments through the use of Building Performance Simulation tools and connections to industry's professionals with the end goal of increasing quality research and scholarship.
summary: Do you work towards high-performing built environments at UC Berkeley? Are you interested in Building Performance Simulation? Join IA-Berkeley and get in touch with the diverse, inter-department community on Berkeley's campus who have the same goals.

name: International Consulting Club at Berkeley
description:
We pride ourselves on:

  • Strength in diversity & inclusion
    • We believe that localized, global innovation is best achieved with the synergy of minds from diverse majors, years, nationalities, cultural backgrounds, and skill sets. We don’t just recruit diversity — we nurture it.
  • A drive for constant growth, both personal and club-wide
    • Our members are always engaged in their own growth and the growth of our club, giving and receiving constructive feedback, and supporting each other as we progress.
  • The international nature of our work
    • We occupy a unique niche within the consulting club landscape on campus, conducting an average of four projects each from a different country every semester. We aim to bridge global knowledge gaps, and to progress in service of a globalized world.

Our goals for you:

  • To find a like-minded and diverse community of fellow students, bound together by genuine connections
  • To broaden your horizons, in working with people, cultures and challenges from all over the world
  • To develop as a leader, via an accelerated pace of opportunities in a high-growth student organization

Qualities we’re looking for:

  • Open-mindedness
    • An openness both to new opportunities and knowledge, and to new people, cultures and backgrounds
  • Synergistic
    • An ability to work well in teams of diverse people, pulling weight, contributing to team morale and adapting to different situations in a way that creates a whole more than the sum of its parts
  • Dynamism
    • A forward-facing attitude, informed by self-reflection and constructive feedback, recognizing that personal growth contributes to the growth of the club

Our Story

The International Consulting Club at Berkeley (aka Berkeley International Consulting "BIC") was founded in the summer of 2020 with the intention of helping international businesses that traditionally lack access to high-quality consulting resources grow and tackle difficult problems at hand. Since its inception, the club’s mission has expanded to offer a broader set of services to companies based all over the world. Besides working with international clients to offer recommendations in important areas like DE&I, marketing, and sustainability, BIC has partnered with student-run consulting organizations at some of the best business schools in the world. Our broad international experience ensures that we approach each project with a fresh perspective; a priority in today’s borderless economy.

Previous clients include: Emirates, Nestle, Heinz, Latam Airlines, Adobe, L'Oréal, Kering (Gucci, Balenciaga, etc), Albertsons Companies, Falabella, Challegermode, Bobacino, So Syncd, Playstories, Cleanwave, Tocco Toscano, BeforePay

Fa23 Recruitment Updates

Check out our website and social media for recruitment timeline. Application is currently live and can be accessed athttps://berkeleyint.org/recruiting.
summary: Global innovation, localized insights. Berkeley International Consulting (BIC) aims to be a diverse, inclusive home for students with a drive to apply curiosity about the world and forward-facing creativity in service of companies all over the globe.

name: International Graduate Student Ministry
description:
We are a community of international graduate students and alumni at UC Berkeley. Founded in 2003, International Graduate Student Ministry (IGSM) is a Christian student group at UC Berkeley. We meet regularly to discuss the bigger questions of life through the lens of Christianity, and we are committed to building an authentic community together and providing a home away from home experience for international graduate students.

If you want to know more about us, please contact us here, or check out any of our upcoming events!
summary: Christian student organization which provides a loving community and introduces basics of Christianity to international students at UC Berkeley.

name: International Healthcare Association
description:
The International Healthcare Association at Berkeley (iHCA) provides professional development for international and globally-minded students interested in the healthcare industry. We focus on the challenges that international students face when seeking a healthcare-related career, whether in medical or non-medical roles. We aim to be a community and support system for students in their professional careers. 

Join us for...

- Professional development workshops at general meetings

- Networking with peers and professionals in all fields of healthcare

- Opportunity for medical interpretation training and internship

- Health Policy Hackathons

 

Watch this video to learn more!
summary: To help international students better understand U.S. healthcare through experiential learning. We provide professional opportunities and foster connections between international and domestic students to create a generation of global citizens.

name: International Human Rights Workshop
description: Through careful legal research, detailed data collection, and comprehensive analysis, the International Human Rights Workshop is dedicated to working alongside international courts and organizations to protect and promote human rights around the globe.
summary: Started in 2012, the International Human Rights Workshop (IHRW) was developed as part of the Berkeley Law SLPS program. The workshop gives 1L and LLM students hands-on experience in international human rights work.

name: International Law Society
description: The International Law Society (ILS) produces social and academic events in comparative and international law. ILS’s activities include a Symposium in the spring, honoring an international law luminary and gaining traction for Berkeley Law. ILS hosts lunch time talks, job fair and social activities to help the law school and our students’ career aspirations. ILS is affiliated with the Berkeley Journal of International Law (BJIL). BJIL is recognized as a leading international law journal in the United States.
summary: ILS produces social and academic events in comparative and international law for community members.

name: International Public Policy Group
description:
The International Public Policy Group at UC Berkeley is an association and working group of policy students and professionals. We analyze and discuss global policies and issues, as well as comparative domestic policies across a range of issue areas–economics, security, health, environment, governance, and technology, among others.

Situated primarily in the Goldman School of Public Policy at UC Berkeley, IPPG welcomes students and alumni from all departments at UC Berkeley. Unless otherwise noted, all IPPG events are open to the UC Berkeley community.
summary: The International Public Policy Group at GSPP, UC Berkeley is an association and working group of policy students and professionals. We analyze and discuss global policies and issues, as well as comparative domestic policies across a range of issues.

name: International Refugee Assistance Project at Berkeley Law
description:
The International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) is a global legal aid and advocacy organization working to create a world where refugees and all people seeking safety are empowered to claim their right to freedom of movement and a path to lasting refuge.

Since its founding in 2008, IRAP has provided free legal aid to over 40,000 displaced people from over 100 different countries and has trained over 6,000 law students and lawyers in the process. Berkeley Law School's IRAP chapter is one of IRAP’s 26 student chapters across the United States and Canada.
summary: IRAP Berkeley works with pro bono attorneys, IRAP Headquarters, and IRAP chapters across the United States and Canada to advance legal pathways to safety for refugees and other displaced people through casework, policy advocacy, and litigation.

name: International Relations Council of Berkeley
description:
A relatively new organization at Cal, the IRC was formed out of a union between five different IR orgs on campus. Our goal is to consolidate interest in IR by making knowledge, events, and opportunities in the vast field of international relations widely available and easily accessible to the campus community.  We seek to engage the Berkeley community holistically on topics of international affairs including foreign service, international politics, diplomacy, human rights and academia. We achieve this by hosting various career oriented events, our Globe Bears Podcast, publishing a biweekly newsletter, and by active news generation and discussion. 

 

In essence, IRC provides a platform for students of all backgrounds to come together to discuss current international affairs and engage in meaningful development opportunities all while fostering a community of inclusion.

 

Follow our Instagram @ircofberkeley for more info and event updates!
summary: The IRC engages the Berkeley community on topics of international relations by providing a platform for IR content and discussion, along with hosting professional events to showcase the diversity of the field and increase exposure for our members.

name: International Security and Geopolitics Club at Berkeley
summary: The purpose of this organization is to bring together students interested in learning more about international security issues and global geopolitical trends.

name: International Service Club
description: International Service Club has bimonthly meetings to plan and host service events related to international causes ranging from water sanitation to ending polio.
summary: International Service Club has bimonthly meetings to plan and host service events related to international causes ranging from water sanitation to ending polio.

name: International Software Product Management Association at Berkeley
summary: The ISPMA (International Software Product Management Association) University Chapter at Berkeley intends to educate and provide experiences in software product management as well as create a community of like-minded individuals.

name: International Student Mentorship Program at Berkeley
description: ISMP at Berkeley aims to mentor international undergraduate and graduate students academically, professionally, and personally, including adjusting to culture and life in the U.S. and equipping them for career growth in the future. We will be pairing international students with UC Berkeley alumni as mentors based on their interests and needs, as well as hosting webinars and workshops to help them grow.
summary: The purpose of this organization is to mentor international students academically, professionally, and personally, including adjusting to culture and life in the US and equipping them for career growth in the future.

name: International Students Association at Berkeley
description:
ISAB is the largest international students association on the UC Berkeley campus. It was established in 2009 and has been nominated as an outstanding student organization in 2010-2011.

ISAB aims to create a positive intellectual and social atmosphere for international students, stimulate cultural awareness among all students in Berkeley, and strengthen Berkeley’s multicultural community.

We work closely with other student organizations to generate cultural awareness and strengthen multicultural ties. We also collaborate with the Berkeley International Office to create enriching and engaging events for the international community.

Recruiting for Fall 2024 currently!

Learn more at: https://linktr.ee/isabcal

Follow us on Instagram (@isab_cal) for updates!
summary: ISAB aims to create a positive intellectual and social atmosphere for international students, stimulate cultural awareness among all students in Berkeley, and strengthen Berkeley's multicultural community.

name: International Students Connection of Berkeley
description:
1. International Students Connection (ISC) is a community of international students coming together as a family, a home away from home at the colleges and universities for the next couple of years before graduating. ISC encourages and promotes goodwill among international students and transfer students to increase awareness and appreciation of other cultures and to provide an opportunity to develop lifelong friendships.
  2. ISC webpage can be checked out via: https://www.intlstudentsconnection.org/
  3. ISC of Berkeley aimed to provide valuable tips, advice, and mentorships for prospective students from Foothill College, De Anza College, Berkeley City College, and Laney College ISC clubs.
summary: ISC of Berkeley is a local chapter of International Students Connection (ISC) with the mission of connecting international students at campuses through events and services. To enhance international students' experience, and promote cultural diversity.

name: International Undergraduate Student Ministry
description:
College can be tough, especially for international students who are far away from home, and we all need a community to go through the ups and downs of life.

 

Throughout the week, IUSM gets together to study, hang out, talk about life's questions from a Christian perspective, and much more!  We also have an extensive alumni volunteer network of various disciplines and professions, giving students a wealth of wisdom and experience accessible to them. 

 

If you want to find out any of our upcoming events or join our community, check our website!
summary: IUSM is here to support and enrich the lives of international students.  Throughout the week, we meet to study, hang out, talk about life's questions from a Christian perspective, and much more!  We hope you'll find IUSM to be your home away from home!

name: InterVarsity Christian Fellowship
description:
The purpose of InterVarsity Christian Fellowship/USA is to establish and advance witnessing communities of students and faculty who follow Jesus as Savior and Lord at colleges and universities; growing in love for God, God's word, God's people of every ethnicity and culture and God's purpose in the world.

IVCF is an umbrella organization at Cal that encompasses four sister fellowships: Cal Christian Fellowship, International Student Ministry (ISM), Black Campus Ministries (BCM), and LaFe. For more information about each, search us up on Callink!
summary: InterVarsity at Cal is the umbrella organization of four ethnically-dedicated groups on campus: CCF, ISM, BCM, and LaFe -- Together we seek to discover God's heart in an authentic community.

name: Invention Corps of Berkeley
description: We are a not-for-profit, multidisciplinary student organization focused on human-centered design by partnering with professors, graduate students, and companies on specific projects that utilize design thinking to improve existing solutions on poverty, health, environment, and society. As a diverse organization of all skill sets and backgrounds, we are fueled by our individual passions and converge upon those passions to create a holistic organization by continuously prototyping with the goal of empowering ourselves and others. Our aim is to invent new ways to make a better world.
summary: We are a not-for-profit, multidisciplinary, projects-based student organization that utilizes human-centered design by partnering with professors, graduate students, and companies to improve existing solutions on poverty, health, environment, and society

name: Investments and Finance at Berkeley
summary: We strive to cultivate an inclusive finance community of all skill levels. We aim to educate our members to create a fun and engaging community.

name: Iranian Student Association in America
description: The Iranian Student Association in America (ISAA) is a non-political, non-religious, voluntary graduate student organization, acting as a source of union and support for the Iranian community at the University of California, Berkeley. ISAA strives for improving the academic, professional, and societal experiences of Iranian students, increasing the voice of Iranians within the United States, and promoting the Iranian community, identity, and culture.
summary: The Iranian Student Association in America (ISAA) is a non-political, non-religious, voluntary graduate student organization, acting as a source of union and support for the Iranian community at the University of California, Berkeley.

name: Iranian Students Cultural Organization
description: Established in 1988, the Iranian Students’ Cultural Organization (ISCO) aims to promote cultural awareness among undergraduate students at UC Berkeley through recreational events, cultural celebrations, and philanthropic endeavors. ISCO welcomes members of a variety of backgrounds and does not discriminate on the basis of race, ethnicity, national origin, gender, sexual orientation, age, or disabilities. Although ISCO is neither politically or religiously affiliated, we stand with the Women, Life, Freedom movement and hope to one day see a free Iran.
summary: The purpose of the group is to educate and promote cultural awareness among both natives and non-natives of Iran through various group activities. The group is in no way politically or religiously affiliated.

name: Iraqi Student Union
description:
The Iraqi Student Union (ISU) aims to build the Iraqi community at UC Berkeley through event hosting, projects, and outreach to the greater Iraqi community. All are welcome to any meetings!

To stay up to date with the ISU:

Follow our instagram: @isu.california

Join our mailing list here.

We hope to see you there!
summary: To support the Iraqi community on campus of UC Berkeley.

name: Issues: Berkeley Medical Journal
description: This student-run medical journal at the University of California, Berkeley that explores current biomedical, political, and ethical facets of the medical health field. This organization is designed to serve the community and supplement the education of journalism and pre-health students and therefore has two important goals: 1) successful publication of exemplary articles geared toward the student body and academic community 2) Guide students as they become successful science journalists and written communicators.
summary: Welcome to Issues: Berkeley Medical Journal (MCB 98/198), a student-run medical journal at the University of California, Berkeley that explores current biomedical, political, and ethical facets of the medical health field.

name: Italian Society at Berkeley
description:
The Italian Society at Berkeley was founded in 1999 by a group of UC Berkeley graduate students, with the goal of spreading the understanding of Italian culture, by promoting many of its aspects (tradition in the arts, history, and lifestyle).

To promote its goals, the ISB promotes events such as exhibitions, symposia, music, theater, film and food festivals revolving around Italian Culture. All ISB activities are open to people interested in discover these different aspects of Italian culture and tradition.

The ISB has a certain number of so-called Active Members, who are directly involved in organizing the ISB activities. Past members have also an important role in giving suggestion to the current active members.

Any student, staff or faculty member of UC Berkeley may become an active member; you don't have to be Italian! You just need good will, commitment and passion.

ISB is also open to people that are not affiliated to UC Berkeley, who can join the organization as associate members.

(Formerly known as Italian International Students Association aka IISA)
summary: The Italian Society at Berkeley (Formerly IISA) was founded in 1999 by a group of UC Berkeley  graduate students to spread the understanding of Italian culture by promoting many of its aspects (tradition in the  arts, history, and lifestyle)

name: Jain Students Association
description: JSA strives to foster a tight-knit community where everyone can cultivate a cultural perspective while engaging in community events that highlight Jain values in the modern world.
summary: JSA  builds a network of Jain students at UC Berkeley, furthers our understanding of Jainism and its values, and promotes Jain values within our community.

name: Jeeva Clinic
description: There is a large South Asian presence in the Bay Area which are known to be at risk for obesity-related metabolic disorders. For example, South Asians have the highest death rate from heart disease and comprise 60% of the heart disease population in the world. Our organization aims to implement a community based model in order to address cardiovascular disease in the South Asian community, a major public health concern. We previously catered specifically to the South Asian population but we now seek to expand awareness to populations that our healthcare system can better support. We hold general member meetings biweekly. Our club is an avenue for those interested in public health, in their local community or otherwise, to further explore their interest and help others.
summary: Jeeva Clinic aims to implement a community-based model to address the prevalence of cardiovascular disease in the South Asian community. We also seek to educate ourselves and others on how to best bridge gaps in healthcare across marginalized groups.

name: Jehovah's Witnesses at Berkeley
summary: The purpose of Jehovah's Witnesses at Berkeley is one of Bible education and distribution of Bible-based literature.

name: Jericho!
description:
jericho! is U.C. Berkeley's premier longform improv team. We specialize in bringing various longform improv formats to the stage, as well as digital media and live sketches!

We hold auditions each year, come to our public workshops and/or sign up for an audition time. We hope to see you there!
summary: Improvisational and sketch comedy troupe at UC Berkeley.

name: Jewish Students Association at Berkeley Law
description: We host Shabbat dinners, holiday events, and cultural excursions for Jewish students at Berkeley Law
summary: Jewish community organization at Berkeley Law.

name: Jewish@Haas
summary: Jewish@Haas seeks to unite, strengthen and empower the Jewish community at the Haas School of Business, supporting Jewish students and those interested in Judaism, Jewish culture or history.

name: Jews in Engineering
description: Jews in Science and Engineering (JEWSE) unites Jewish students with a passion for science and engineering. We utilize our knowledge and skills in these fields to serve the Jewish community, Bay Area non-profit organizations, and the Berkeley student body through hands-on projects, networking events, research opportunities, and exploring the intersection of Jewish values and the STEM fields. While JEWSE embraces Jewish values, the club is open to all students, regardless of faith or major.
summary: Jews in Science and Engineering (JEWSE) unites Jewish STEM students, serving the Jewish community and the Berkeley student body through hands-on projects, networking, research, and exploring the intersection of Jewish values and STEM fields.

name: Jugger at Berkeley
shortName: Jugger at Berkeley, formerly known as Juggers of the Seven Regents
description:
Imagine yourself as part of a post-apocalyptic battle team. The sun beating down on you, catching and glinting off your weapon. The ground soft beneath your feet. Your enemies across the field beginning to look worn down, their eyes betraying fear....

Now you can be. ;) There is a sport, popular in Germany, called "Jugger" based on a post-apocalyptic movie from Australia (incidentally, this movie was directed by a Cal grad! he also wrote the screenplays for Blade Runner and Twelve Monkeys). It has evolved somewhat from its depiction in the movie, with foam-padded weaponry and t-shirts replacing steel and armor. After a few years of learning about the game, we finally agreed that we should make a set of pompfen to play.

Now we're done, and you can join the Jugger at Berkeley formerly known as Juggers of the Seven Regents here on campus! We'll be playing weekly on memorial glade; weather, seasons, field schedules, and light permitting.

We can't promise that you might not get bruises from playing (that's a legally-binding statement, right?), but we can promise that we have made the weapons as safe as we can according to the game's Berlin-style rules. Before you come you might want to watch a quick primer on how the game works. There are also many videos of real jugger games that aren't stylized to show you what to expect.

Check our Facebook page for up-to-date events and further information!
summary: Jugger is an internationally played field sport that combines aspects of fencing, rugby, and capture the flag. Our group exists to bring the sport to the Berkeley community through playing on campus. All are welcome!

name: Junior Care Clinic at Berkeley
description: This group Junior Care Clinic was formerly named Juvenile Caduceus Clinic - 10/24/23 Harris
summary: Junior Care Clinic is a student-run clinic working to target the juvenile to adolescent aged populations within institutionalized systems using methods of preventative care and interdisciplinary practices.

name: Kairos Dance Co.
description:
Kairos Dance Co. is a contemporary-centered dance group established in Fall 2019 that aims to foster growth and passion for contemporary dance across the UC Berkeley campus through a tight-knit and dedicated community. Kairos holds weekly technique and set-building practices, puts on open workshops for the Berkeley dance community, and performs in various showcases at the end of each semester. Auditions are held at the beginning of each semester. Check out our social media platforms (Instagram, Youtube, FB) to learn more about the Kairos family!

https://youtu.be/f0dEO9YGclg

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f3VfdS32ETo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lee6xhp3gm8
summary: Kairos is a contemporary-centered dance group that aims to foster growth and passion for contemporary dance across the UC Berkeley campus through a tight-knit and dedicated community.

name: Kal Balkan Student Association
summary: KBSA strives to provide a safe space and bring together all UC Berkeley students who have Balkan heritage through gatherings, celebrations of holidays, and sharing of our cultures and traditions.

name: Kappa Alpha Order
summary: Many young Americans today think a gentleman is an age-old concept lost in the past. However we, the knights and brothers of Kappa Alpha Order, strive to live up to the highest ideals of chivalry and gentlemanly conduct in our everyday lives.

name: Kappa Alpha Pi Pre-Law Fraternity
description:
The Fraternity is designed to advance ideals of liberty and equal justice under law; to inspire the virtues of compassion and courage; to foster integrity and professional competence; to promote the welfare of its members; and to encourage their moral, intellectual, and cultural advancement; so that each member may enjoy a lifetime of honorable professional and public service.

We hold our members to a high caliber of professional competence and fraternal fellowship while promoting public service. We differentiate ourselves by the rigor of our Leadership Program and the selectivity of our members, which allows its members to develop into prominent leaders on and off campus. Additionally, we maintain a unique national network of Kappa Alpha Pi chapters, including: The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor; The University of California, Los Angeles; The University of California, Riverside; Cornell University, among others.

 

Social Justice

We are committed to improving the quality of legal access and advocacy in the Bay Area. By partnering with organizations such as the East Bay Community Law Center and hosting a biannual Free Legal Clinic, our members make impactful strides toward equality for underserved populations. Our philanthropic history also includes working with the Bay Area Urban Debate League and other similar causes.

Leadership Development

Our rigorous Leadership Development Program fosters public speaking, strategic planning and organizational skills in a positive environment. Throughout eight weeks, you will bond with a class of strong campus leaders and expand your personal horizons through a broadened sense of professionalism and the legal field. Various projects such as a legal panel, mock trial, and J.D. shadow increase exposure to the law and profession. Growth continues even after the formal program ends.

Law School Preparation

We strive to have continuous opportunities to prepare our members from law school, beginning with the big question: is law school really for you? Following the Leadership Development Program, we offer at minimum three events and workshops for members every semester to further prepare them for law school. These events include round-table discussions with Deans of top law schools, workshops on the law school admissions process, and provide other useful resources to our members.

Professional Network

We are committed to maintaining strong bonds with every professional we work with. These esteemed individuals include top consultants, private and public attorneys, and top law school deans. By maintaining relationships with firms, companies, public entities, non-profit organizations and more, we ensure continuous and unique opportunities for our members.

Alumni Network

The Kappa Alpha Pi alumni network runs deep. Our members have attended the nation’s top law schools and currently hold high-level positions both in government and the private sector. With such a diverse membership, we also have members in top business and graduate school programs. Each new member has the opportunity to connect with and learn from an alumni mentor working in their particular field of interest.

Academic Support

Our academic support resources include peer reviews of courses across a wide array of majors. We offer group study hours on a weekly basis and test banks for our active members. We also maintain strong relationships with elite test prep companies such as TestMasters and Blueprint. Membership will receive additional advantages, which include discounted prep courses.

Fraternalism

Our members forge bonds that transcend professional networks; we are family. Various events throughout the semester, from casual hangouts to weekend-long retreats, provide ample opportunity to relax and make the most of your time at Cal. If you seek a group of brothers and sisters who embrace new challenges and strive for new heights, then Kappa Alpha Pi is the place for you. We invite you to join us.
summary: The purpose of this Fraternity shall be to form a strong bond uniting students and teachers of the law with members of the Bench and Bar in fraternal fellowship.

name: Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc.
description: The Gamma Alpha Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Incorporated was chartered October 23, 1947, which now spans the campuses of the University of California, Berkeley, San Francisco State University, and the University of San Francisco.
summary: This is a sponsored student organization that is part of the National Pan-Hellenic Council (NPHC)

name: Kappa Alpha Theta
description:
Kappa Alpha Theta, the first Greek letter fraternity among women, was founded in 1870 by Bettie Locke Hamilton, Alice Allen Brant, Bettie Tipton Lindsey, and Hannah Finch Shaw. Theta has over 170 chapters with houses throughout the United States and Canada. More than 250,000 women have been initiated into Kappa Alpha Theta, forming strong friendships in chapters from all over, holding the sisterhood strong. The Omega Chapter was founded at University of California, Berkeley in 1890. Our Chapter occupied the first women's chapter house built by Omega sister Julia Morgan, the first woman to study architecture at the Ecole de Beaux Arts in Paris. 

 

Kappa Alpha Theta is proud to be national supporters of Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA). CASA is an organization that provides mentors for abused, abandoned and neglected children. These mentors establish close bonds with the children as they interact one-on-one and serve as a voice for the children during the judicial process.
The Omega chapter of Kappa AlphaTheta supports CASA in a number of ways including donations from our annual philanthropic fundraising events, Theta Dodgeball and Cafe Casa (our famous Theta Brunch held at our beautiful Theta home, open to the Berkeley community).

 

For any questions regarding Recruitment or Letters of Reference, please contact our Vice President of Membership at omegathetacro@gmail.com.
summary: At Omega Theta, we believe the bonds of sisterhood are something that can never be broken. We are so lucky to be surrounded by a group of such lovely, intelligent, and kind women.

name: Kappa Gamma Delta
description:
Kappa Gamma Delta, UC Berkeley's premier pre-health sorority, encourages the development of leadership and communication skills, and provides support academically, socially, and emotionally while promoting individuality, unity, and diversity among sisters. Our three pillars are sisterhood, service to humanity, and professionalism. 

The women of Kappa Gamma Delta are crucial members of the UC Berkeley community acting as club founders & members, research assistants, campus employees, etc. Additionally, they are highly integrated members of the greater Bay Area community, like tutors at local underserved elementary schools, volunteers at nearby hospitals, and interns at medical practices, among many roles. 

 

Read more about us at: www.calkgd.com
summary: Kappa Gamma Delta is dedicated to providing academic, social, and emotional support to the pre-health community at Cal. We are also committed to various service events and projects in the community.

name: Karisma
summary: "If you are a child of the King, nothing on this earth can satisfy you, nothing. If you want the power of God in your life, then somethings gotta go. I want to know him then some separation has to occur." Paul Washer.

name: Keebs at Berkeley
description: Keebs at Berkeley aims to be an organization for people to socialize and learn more about computer-aided design, basic electrical engineering, and appreciation of aesthetics through a view of a hobby: mechanical keyboards.
summary: Keebs at Berkeley aims to be an organization for people to socialize and learn more about computer-aided design, basic electrical engineering, and appreciation of aesthetics through a view of a hobby: mechanical keyboards.

name: Kendo Club
description:
Kendo Club is a non-profit organization which strives in the promotion of Kendo among UC Berkeley students. We practice Kendo and the philosophy of Kendo. Through rigorous and proper training, the club aims to teach members discipline, integrity, and respect to cultivate both the mind and the body.

This year, we will also be hoping to add Iaido to our practices to emphasize focus and discipline.

Everyone is welcome to join!

Official Kendo Club website: http://kendo.berkeley.edu/

Any questions? Feel free to make a post and/or shoot us an email at:
kendoclub.berkeley@gmail.com
summary: To practice Kendo and the philosophy of Kendo. Through rigorous and proper training, the club strives to teach members discipline, integrity, and respect to cultivate both the mind and the body.

name: Kerusso Fellowship
description:
We are the UC Berkeley on-campus Christian college fellowship of NorthCreek Church in Walnut Creek.

We are committed to:

  • Personal Sanctification
  • Bible Study
  • Biblical Fellowship
  • Service Opportunities
  • Local Church Involvement

We have our weekly Thursday Bible Studies in Wheeler 200 from 7:00-9:00pm! Check out our social media pages for any updates and to get connected!
summary: Kerusso Fellowship is an on-campus Christian college fellowship of NorthCreek Church in Walnut Creek. We are committed to Personal Sanctification, Bible Study, Biblical Fellowship, Service Opportunities, and Local Church involvement.

name: Kickboxing at Berkeley
description: The organization would serve as a gathering hub and community for students and faculty to congregate and train in kickboxing. Regardless of prior experience, the organization will be a place for all practitioners of kickboxing new and old to provide support and guidance to each other.
summary: To provide a community for individuals at UC Berkeley to better themselves physically and spiritually through the sport of kickboxing.

name: Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program
description: KDSAP is an undergraduate student-run organization that provides free kidney disease screenings in underserved communities across the Bay Area to improve kidney health and promote health equity. KDSAP has two main objectives: community outreach and student career development. By engaging undergraduate members to coordinate and facilitate screening events, students gain exposure to community engagement and professional development while serving the medically underserved and simultaneously addressing limitations in our current healthcare climate. The kidney disease screenings are co-hosted with our community partners and are free of charge, do not require any documentation, provide interpreters, includes a consultation with an MD, and is open to anyone who is interested.
summary: KDSAP furthers the professional development of pre-medical students by working alongside physicians to provide free screenings for kidney disease to underserved communities as well as to raise awareness of kidney disease amongst the general public.

name: Kids Enjoy Exercise Now at Berkeley
description: In partnership with Kids Enjoy Exercise Now San Francisco, we will host fun and exercise filled sessions for youth with disabilities in the Bay Area. Any and all students at Berkeley are welcome to volunteer at these sessions.
summary: KEEN at Berkeley hopes to carry on the mission of KEEN San Francisco as well as promote community service among students at UC Berkeley as well as create a supportive network for KEEN athletes and their families in the East Bay.

name: Kids in Nutrition
description: We are an organization that teaches interactive and inspiring nutrition and health lessons to elementary school children in the Berkeley community. The curriculum includes a variety of activities to complete with the students for an hour once a week. KIN’s leadership includes passionate individuals who seek to make a meaningful impact on America’s public health and environmental sustainability systems. We believe that food has direct implications on public and individual health, as well as environmental sustainability, and have decided to dedicate our time to advocating these issues.
summary: KIN aims to connect college and elementary school students in an effort to inspire and educate our younger generation to lead active and healthy lives. KIN is an educational program on the nutrition, exercise and implications on individual health.

name: Kink Club
description:
The kink club exists to educate about the world of kink, promote acceptance of sexuality, and help peers navigate the kink community safely and consensually. Meetings revolve around discussion on kink related topics where members have the chance to ask questions and find out more about things they are interested in or curious about. We also host workshops where an experienced member or a guest speaker teaches method and safety of various kink-related pursuits from bondage to safe sex. Any Bay Area student/faculty, undergraduate or graduate, from knowing nothing to (s)expert, is allowed to join us!

 

Haven't attended a beginner session? We will be having two on Saturday, 9/23 from 2-3 and 3-4. Please fill out this form to get the zoom link:

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdNPgyKA7RA7awuPeTd2nTm6NaXvXcK3xrfRsXvQmCHpPXskQ/viewform?usp=sf_link

 

To sign up for a 1-1 Meeting, please fill out this form:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1eB8B8XF70EEBk7-Q9b4tO2cLXnOFaIEofs8L7YDloyw/edit?usp=sharing
summary: The kink club exists to educate about the world of kink, promote acceptance of sexuality, and to help peers navigate the kink community safely and consensually.

name: Kojobs at Berkeley
description: KOJOBS named as Korean Job Search has been dedicated to be leading "Job searching" and Global Networking for Korean Students all around the world. Our project is focused on offering job informations and events for students' career. Our club holds the general meeting twice a month during the semester.
summary: Student-run career based organization for the Korean and Korean American student body at Berkeley. Focus on providing career related opportunities and guidance for students interested in landing a job in the United States as an international student.

name: Korea Campus Crusade for Christ
description:
KCCC's emphasis is to help out in the Great Commission as commanded by Jesus Christ in Matthew 28:18-20: 

"Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, and teaching them to obey everything I have commanded you." 

Win the campus today means for KCCC to train members to be disciples on each of their campus, sharing and witnessing the Gospel and Jesus Christ to anyone and everyone 

Win the world tomorrow means for KCCC to train members to become not just campus disciples but to extend the ministry outside of campus, to the community, and to the ends of the earth.
summary: Korea Campus Crusade for Christ (KCCC) is a Christian campus ministry driven by students.  It is established in many universities and colleges such as: UCLA, UCI, USC, UCD, UCSC, UCSB, UCSD, UCR, Cal Poly, CSUF, CSULB, CSUN, SUSJ, and much more.

name: Korea Grappling Club at Berkeley
description:
Our jiu-jitsu club is a student-led organization made up of individuals who are passionate about the art of Brazilian jiu-jitsu. We provide a welcoming and supportive environment for both intermediate and beginning practitioners, where everyone can learn and grow together.

Our club is dedicated to helping members develop their skills and technique, no matter their level of experience. Our instructors are experienced and knowledgeable, and they are committed to teaching jiu-jitsu in a safe and fun way.

We offer a variety of classes that cater to different levels of skill and experience, including beginner classes that focus on the fundamentals of jiu-jitsu, as well as intermediate classes that provide opportunities to hone skills and learn more advanced techniques. Our classes are designed to help members build strength and endurance, increase their confidence, and learn the practical skills of self-defense.
summary:
Our jiu-jitsu club's purpose is to provide a safe and inclusive environment for students to learn, improve, and build a strong community of jiu-jitsu!
We are not a nationality-based club so anyone is welcome to join!
Instagram: @berkeleyjiujitsu

name: Korean American Student Association
description: The Korean American Student Association (KASA) is an organization at UC Berkeley that allows students to experience Korean and Korean American culture. As a club that prides itself in its social endeavors, KASA hopes to create a welcoming community that grants students a "home away from home." It also aims to highlight and celebrate Korean culture through various campus events, engage in Korean American discourse, and offer professional development opportunities. By meeting these goals, KASA provides a holistic experience of what it means to be a Korean American student at UC Berkeley.
summary: The Korean American Student Association (KASA) at UC Berkeley allows students to experience Korean/Korean American culture and a “home away from home” for our members.

name: Korean Business Society
description: Our organization is a business club that aims to help members with professional development through events such as networking, professional workshops, and client work. Acknowledging the lack of specific support for Korean undergraduate student clubs at Berkeley, we seek to foster an environment where members can learn more about business – including but not limited to methods of consulting, resume building, and networking. Through these measures, we aim to foster an environment that can help members expand their professionalism in various sectors and create a supportive community at Berkeley.
summary: Our organization aims to help members with professional development through events such as client work and networking. Additionally, we seek to foster an environment where members can learn more about business through active learning.

name: Korean Compassion at Berkeley
description: As a chapter of Compassion International, we are dedicated to helping children in need by various means. We nurture them with love and appropriate care through volunteer works and fundraising events and wish to bring them hope in the unforeseen future.
summary: As a chapter of Compassion International, we are dedicated to helping children in need by various means. We nurture them with love and appropriate care through volunteer works and fundraising events and wish to bring them hope in the unforeseen future.

name: Korean Graduate Students Association
description: This is the Korean Graduate Students Association (KGSA) for PhD/MS/MEng students from South Korea at UC Berkeley. Korean PostDoc/Visiting researchers at UC Berkeley and LBNL are welcome as well.
summary: Korean Graduate Student Association (KGSA) at UC Berkeley.

name: Korean Performance Group
description: Founded in 2010, KPG Cal is a UC Berkeley-based dance team with a passion for kpop and dance. The team focuses on performance at UC Berkeley and around the Bay Area, the production of kpop covers for our youtube channel, and occasional workshops for the larger dance community. KPG strives for excellence in its productions, and aims to challenge its dancers and foster a rewarding team environment. https://www.youtube.com/user/KPGCal
summary: Founded in 2010, KPG is a UC Berkeley-based dance team with a passion for kpop and dance. The team focuses on the performance and production of kpop covers. KPG aims to challenge its dancers and foster a rewarding team environment.

name: Korean Undergraduate Networking Association
description:
KUNA, officially known as Korean Undergraduate Networking Association (KUNA), is one of the largest Korean clubs in UC Berkeley. It provides networking for Korean students in Berkeley who struggle to assimilate to the new environment by providing opportunities, such as chances to meet peers and alumni through events, involvement in sport subcommittees, and receiving recruitment information. Furthermore, KUNA aims to spread awareness about Korean culture to the general student body at Berkeley.

Email: ucberkeleykuna@gmail.com
summary: KUNA, officially known as Korean Undergraduate Networking Association (KUNA), stands in the center of UC Berkeley's Korean community. KUNA provides networking events mainly for Korean students and focuses on spreading awareness about Korean culture.

name: Korean-American Scientists and Engineers Association (Silicon Valley Chapter)
description: KSEA @ Berkeley is an organization whose purpose is to create a community of motivated students, and address topics that are related to the technical, personal and career development of Korean-American Scientists and Engineers; to educate members to become successful scientists, engineers, and/or leaders; and to train the staff members on networking, organization, and leadership skills.
summary: An organization whose purpose is to create a community of motivated students and to address topics that are related to the technical, personal, and career development of Korean-American Scientists and Engineers.

name: Koreans 4 Decolonization
description: Koreans for Decolonization is a project by and for diasporic Korean students who are interested in getting involved politically and connecting with other Korean activists. We are guided by principles of anti-imperialism, anti-militarism, and belief in decolonization and Korean reunification (tongil). We provide political education on the history of colonization and imperialism in Korea as well as past and present resistance movements on the peninsula and abroad. Toojeng!
summary: Koreans 4 Decolonization is an identity-based political organization for Korean students to learn more about Korean history and resistance efforts and form community with other Korean students.

name: KOSMOS
summary: Kosmos is dedicated to spreading K-Pop's phenomenal influence and the excellence of Korean culture around the world. We are a unique group that aims to captivate the public eye through our variety of dance covers.

name: La Raza Law Journal
description:
The Berkeley Latine Journal of Law and Policy (“Journal") produces knowledge designed to capture the imagination of legislators, stir the consciences of judges, and provide a dynamic tool for practitioners concerned with the impact of their work on behalf of the Latine community.

The Journal was imagined in 1980 and established in 1981 by Latine students and our allies at Berkeley Law at the University of California, Berkeley. The Journal is one of the few law reviews in the United States that center Latine conditions, communities, and identities.

The Journal was established to provide a forum, which previously did not exist, to analyze legal issues affecting the Latine community. Previous issues have addressed bilingual education, affirmative action, immigration law, labor law and policy, voting rights, community empowerment, new models of organizing labor, rural communities, and Latine Critical Legal Theory.

Each spring, we traditionally host a symposium to bring together law and other students, with professors, lawyers, activists and other community members to learn about and discuss current issues affecting the Latine community. Additionally, we irregularly hold colloquia and installments of our speaker series.

These events and others are part of our evolving project to transform conventional legal education at Berkeley Law in order to help Latine law students and our allies become better advocates for social justice, self-determination, and liberation in the United States and abroad.
summary: Our purpose is to provide an open forum for the analysis of legal issues affecting the Latinx community; to publish articles written by Latinx students, scholars, practitioners; and to serve as a legal research resource.

name: La Raza Workers' and Tenants' Rights Clinic
description: La Raza Workers' and Tenants' Rights Clinic provides an opportunity for Berkeley Law students to work directly with clients on issues of employment and housing law. The Workers' Clinic advises clients on wage and hour violations, employment discrimination, retaliation, and other areas of employment law. The Tenants' Clinic counsels tenants on evictions, illegal rent increases, harassment by landlords, and uninhabitable conditions. Under attorney supervision, students meet individually with clients, prepare demand letters or wage claims, and, when the clinic performs follow-up work for the client, research different areas of the law.
summary: To provide comprehensive legal services to immigrant, low-income and Latino communities in the Bay Area.

name: Labor Coach Program
description: Labor Coaches have the unique opportunity to develop personal relationships with their patients, for whom they are on-call during the last month of the patient's pregnancy. We work with limited English proficiency patients who are usually giving birth for the first time in the US. The Labor Coach Program is great for those with a soft spot for babies, multi-lingual skills, and a desire to work closely with the OB-GYN hospital staff. We currently connect with Cantonese, Mandarin, and Vietnamese speaking patients. Through this program, Labor Coaches have the potential to make a great impact in reducing the stress and pain of women, as well as share the excitement and immense joy at welcoming a new life to the world.
summary: The Labor Coach Program works with the Asian Health Services to provide support and interpretation services for mothers during their labor and deliveries.

name: LAHBA at Haas
description:
The Latin American and Hispanic Business Association (LAHBA) unites students from all backgrounds who share an interest in learning about our cultures. With over 150 members, LAHBA is one of the largest student-run organizations at Haas. Our goal is to create a sense of community among Latino and Hispanic students. To achieve this objective, LAHBA organizes several activities throughout the year including: lectures, socials and professional networking events.

One of the distinct characteristics of the Berkeley MBA is our warm, collaborative environment. LAHBA promotes collaboration through a number of events to foster relationships within the membership and the Haas community at-large. Additionally, LAHBA provides a forum where diverse experiences, perspectives, and resources can be shared.
summary: LAHBA at Haas aka Latin American and Hispanic Business Association

name: Lambda Theta Alpha Latin Sorority, Inc.
description: The purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha shall be to provide a sisterhood based on Unity, Love, & Respect. To develop strong Leaders who will then provide and practice political, social and cultural activities. To promote Latino Unity through charitable and educational programs. To maintain a high standard of learning and serve as a voice for the Universal Woman, all Latino students and disenfranchised communities. Lambda Theta Alpha is the FIRST Latina Sorority created in the Nation as well as the Largest Latina Sorority in existence.
summary: The purpose of Lambda Theta Alpha shall be to provide a sisterhood based on Unity, Love, & Respect. To develop strong Leaders who will then provide and practice political, social and cultural activities. To promote Latino Unity through charitable

name: Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc.
description:
Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. was the first Latina Sorority on the West Coast and on the UC Berkeley Campus. Established in 1986, Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. continues to provide its members with a support system based on academic excellence, community service, and sisterhood. 

The purpose of Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. is to open the doors of opportunity to the Latinas of our community. Our primary focus is academic excellence and meeting the needs of Latina women in higher education. Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. also promotes the advancement of Latinas through various campus activities and community services, and provides an environment for personal growth within a unit of sisterhood. Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc.'s priorities, however, will be placed upon academic excellence and community service.

Divine Delta Chapter | University of California, Berkeley | Est. April 6, 1991

In the Spring of 1991 three strong, brave, and intelligent Latina women, Jennifer Garcia, Maria Martinez, and Rosalinda Valdez felt the need to establish an organization that supplemented their needs as women in higher education at UC Berkeley. This need led to the formation of the Delta chapter of Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc., and the establishment of the first Latina organization at UC Berkeley. Twenty-seven years later, the Delta chapter continues it's commitment to academic excellence, community service, and sisterhood. Although we are a Latina-based sorority, we accept applicants regardless of race or color, national origin, religion, sexual orientation or handicap.

Pillars 

Academic Excellence, Community Service, Sisterhood 

Traditions

Stepping: In 1987 the sisters of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. first introduced stepping to ladies of Lambda Theta Nu sorority Inc. by inviting them to step on stage in a unity step. Our sisters at California State University, Chico added the use of machetes as a symbol of strength, a symbol with direct cultural ties.

Machetes: In 1989 Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. became the first sorority to incorporate the use of machetes in a stepping performance. The use of machetes has traditionally showcased the bravery of men. However, for Lambdas, breaking down this male-based tradition not only served as symbol of empowerment but also exemplified the determination of Latinas to integrate into every aspect of life that was not traditionally meant for Latinas. The incorporation of machetes in our performances personify our culture and our strength as women whose perseverance is multidimensional.

Strolling: Strolling, also known as party walking, is a synchronized dance used to encourage commonalities among sisters and showcase our organization and/or to compete in shows.

Lambda Theta Nu Sorority, Inc. Facts

Founded Nationally: March 11, 1986 at California State University, Chico

Founded at UC Berkeley: April 6, 1991

Colors: Burgundy, Silver, White

Nickname: Lambdas, Sexy Silver Roses

Symbol: Rose

Chapters: 44 Chapters Strong, 10 States Wide

 

Add us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/berkeley.lambdas

Follow us on Instagram: lambdathetanu_berkeley
summary: Our mission is to promote and foster Latina leaders through educational and professional development, relationship building, and community involvement. Our intent is to provide our members exposure to resources for continued growth.

name: Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity, Inc.
description:
On December 1, 1975, history was made – history on a college campus, which would transcend other colleges/universities throughout the United States; history which would have a positive impact on the Latino community and our nation; history which would forever change the Greek system, more specifically, the entity known as a fraternity. On December 1, 1975, Lambda Theta Phi was founded on the campus of Kean College in Union, New Jersey.

The ideals of this brotherhood are the following: Academic Excellence; Brotherhood; Leadership; Latino Unity; Service. On a daily basis, our brothers live up to these ideals, as set forth by fourteen young Latino men decades ago. 

Since our founding, Lambda Theta Phi has established chapters in every region of the country at both the undergraduate and professional levels. Our brotherhood continues to provide the necessary skills and resources for the advancement and empowerment of our people and for the betterment of this nation. 

The University of California, Berkeley was home to the newest chapter of Lambda Theta Phi, Latin Fraternity, Inc. in the Spring semester of 2004. Ten undergraduate students came together with the idea of introducing a positive image of a Latino fraternity to the UC Berkeley campus. They wanted to embrace and take part in the unity, brotherhood, pride and respect for all cultures that Lambda Theta Phi offered.

On May 9, 2004, Luis Sanchez, Renato Manay, Renzo Manay, Arquimides Pacheco, and Rafael Hernandez created a historical landmark and established the first Latino Greek Letter Fraternity officially recognized by the National Interfraternal Council (NIC) on the UC Berkeley campus.

Now, since its establishment and through its further development and growth, Lambda Theta Phi in UC Berkeley has continued to carry through its ideals of a service/social fraternity by giving back to the community while engaging in social activities that would allow further bondages among our members and with other organizations. Such include our participation in the Annual AIDS Walk, our service in low-income Oakland Elementary schools, and advocacy of immigrant rights to day laborers within the county of Alameda. Apart from these community service events, this chapter has sought to create strong ties and mutual respect with other Latin and non-Latin organizations through social activities and collaborative efforts.

Lastly, the main goal of Lambda Theta Phi in UC Berkeley is to pursue the educational success of our fraternity brothers. At the national level, from New Jersey to California, many go on to become doctors, lawyers, engineers, among other professionals.
summary: The FIRST and The LARGEST at the #1 Public Institution in the NATION. WE ARE THE INSTITUTION OF EVOLUTION! Beta Chi Chapter at the University of California, Berkeley.

name: Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.
description: Established with ASUC 11/9/11 SB 138 Fall 2011
summary: La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Incorporated primarily seeks to take a leadership role in meeting the needs of the Latino community through academic achievement, cultural awareness, community service & promotion of the Latino culture

name: Laotian American Student Representatives
description: The primary goal of LASR is to create a community for UC Berkeley students who originated from Laos and to establish awareness for those who are interested in the cultures and experiences of Laotians. This community on the UC Berkeley campus provides social and academic support for all the members within the club.
summary: The primary goal of LASR is to create a community  for UC Berkeley students who originated from Laos and to establish awareness for those who are interested in the cultures and  experiences of Laotians.

name: Latin American Leadership Society
description:
The Latin American Leadership Society is made up of people from very diverse backgrounds. What unites us is our profound interest in Latin America, be it the current political and economical scene, the region’s rich culture and traditions, or the growing influence of Latin American communities in the United States.

LLS members are students from Latin America who aim to eventually return to their respective countries to contribute to the development of the region, students born in the US of Latin American descent interested in finding a community, and non-Latin students who simply posses a great interest in the region and wish to be part of the growing, continent-wide LLS network.

LLS has the mission of providing students with opportunities to create professional networks and personal bonds, through social events, career development programs, and community service among other activities. We also promote engagement in discussion about topics concerning Latin America in relation to leadership, policy and entrepreneurship.

Our vision for LLS is for it to achieve recognition in Latin America for the exemplary leadership and contributions of its alumni. We think of LLS as the first chapter of a long list of initiatives nationwide.

 

To know more about LLS and to stay tuned to our future events feel free to visit our website, follow us on Instagram, or like us on Facebook.
summary: LLS strives to connect Latin American students with the purpose of creating a network of future leaders of the region. LLS also strives to promote awareness and debate on critical political, economic, social, and economic topics in Latin America

name: Latino/a Association of Graduate Students in Engineering and Science
description:
The Latino Association of Graduate Students in Engineering and Science (LAGSES) at UC Berkeley was founded in 1994 by Latino students to provide a cohesive group for incoming and continuing Latino/a graduate students at UC Berkeley.

Now a multicultural organization whose mission is to recruit and retain Latino/a graduate students at UC Berkeley. We provide academic and social activities for support and networking.

LAGSES members are committed to helping Latino/a students enter and graduate from UC Berkeley graduate programs in engineering and science. Please contact us if you are interested in attending UC Berkeley for graduate school and/or would like to join our organization.
summary: The mission of LAGSES is to promote the recruitment and retention of Latino/a graduate students in engineering and science.

name: Latinx Business Student Association
description:
The mission of the Latinx Business Student Association (LBSA) is to empower the Latinx community at UC Berkeley to excel academically and professionally in all business endeavors by providing our members professional development resources, academic support, and a sense of belonging through our LBSA family.

 

Today, we have over 10 corporate sponsors with companies like Deloitte, Goldman Sachs, Google, Accenture, and more! Join us every Wednesday at our weekly workshops to connect with recruiters from leading companies.

 

Stay connected with us through our Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/ucberkeleylbsa/

and Instagram Page: https://www.instagram.com/ucberkeleylbsa/?hl=en 

 

This group Latinx Business Student Association was formerly named Latino Business Student Association (LBSA) - 10/29/20 IZ
summary: LBSA's mission is to empower the Latinx community at UC Berkeley by providing our members professional development resources, academic support, and a sense of belonging through our LBSA family.

name: Latinx in Public Policy
description:
Latinx in Public Policy is a community of Goldman School of Public Policy students gathered to foster creative dialogue regarding policy issues impacting Latinx students and communities, including DEI, labor, immigration, poverty and social inequality, international relations, environmental justice, education, and health. 

On and off campus, LiPP leaders emphasize how important it is to have Latinx policymakers at the table. Latinx policymakers often uniquely have lived experiences or closely understand the issues affecting Latinx individuals in a way that would inform culturally appropriate policy solutions. Latinx policymakers may have foresight on why policies may not have the intended effects or what aspects of the implementation plan will be necessary to ensure success for Latinx individuals. They also often have the cultural competency to directly work with Latinx communities, many of which are predominantly Spanish speaking, to build trust and conduct community-based research.

Additionally, “diversity” and “inclusion” have become buzzwords that too often tokenize communities of color because no substantive thought is given to ensuring diverse voices are heard and supported. By having more Latinx policymakers at the table, LiPP hopes there is intentionality in truly uplifting the needs of Latinx individuals and communities.
summary: LiPP exists to provide a space for graduate Latinx students at The Goldman School of Public Policy (GSPP) to gather and foster creative dialogues addressing policy issues and concerns affecting Latinx communities and Latinx students at GSPP

name: Latinx Pre-Law Society
description: Established in fall 2002, the purpose of the Latinx Pre-Law Society is to provide a solid professional, educational, supportive, and networking foundation within the Latinx community in the legal profession, the Latine population at UC Berkeley, and the community at large. LPLS is a non-partisan organization that focuses on a progressive agenda for preparing and empowering Latine folks to pursue a legal education and career.
summary: The Latinx Pre-Law Society is an inclusive organization that strives to provide educational and professional opportunities for students pursuing a legal education or career.

name: Latinx Social Work Caucus
description:
The purpose of the Latinx Social Work Caucus (LSWC) is to build connections to ensure students and faculty feel a sense of belonging and community. LSWC is committed to closing the opportunity gap in higher education and supporting the personal and professional well-being of its members. The Caucus strives to unite the efforts of social welfare students who desire and are committed to working towards improving the quality of life of Latinx people and their communities. We enact our social justice values through political engagement and community building.

The objectives of the Caucus are to:
