description: Next Generation of Entrepreneurs is dedicated to promoting and supporting entrepreneurship among students by utilizing the tools and resources that are readily available to all. We strive to inspire and provide educational opportunities for students to develop the necessary skills for entrepreneurship. We firmly believe that every student has the potential to create multiple streams of income, regardless of their initial capital investment. While other organizations on campus may focus on specific aspects of entrepreneurship, our unique approach emphasizes entrepreneurship that doesn't require starting from scratch or launching a start-up. Our goal is to encourage entrepreneurship using accessible resources such as reselling, dropshipping, and investment opportunities with any amount of capital.
summary: We aim to support and foster entrepreneurship among students with the tools and resources already provided to all students that many do not take advantage of.

name: Nigerian Students Association
description:
Special focus will be placed on Nigerian heritage, culture, and community; however, the organization promotes solidarity and positive learning environments across different cultures and institutions. It serves as a home away from home for those aiming to further explore their Nigerian roots, while also serving as a welcoming, engaging space for others to learn and experience. Through the multitude of culturally-inspired events, activities, and programs, NSA aims to bridge the gap between Black Americans, children of African immigrants, and the greater Cal community so that we can begin to develop a better understanding of each other and embrace our similarities rather than focus on our differences.

Check out a recap of one of our biggest events: https://youtu.be/61fT56xCKKw
summary: A supportive space for Africans and those interested in Nigerian culture. It strives to promote cultural diversity, celebrate Nigerian heritage at Cal, and challenge common misconceptions about Africa typically broadcasted in the media.

name: Nikkei Choral Ensemble
description: Do you like to sing? Enjoy making friends? Have a favorite vegetable? Well then NiCE might be the group for you! Nikkei Choral Ensemble (commonly known as NiCE) is an all-inclusive a cappella group that arranges and performs primarily Japanese and English songs. We take beatboxers and singers in all vocal parts, so if you are interested in learning more, please reach out to us at nikkeichoralensemble@gmail.com. No Japanese knowledge required (:
summary: Nikkei Choral Ensemble (NiCE) is an a cappella group that arranges and performs Japanese and English songs and loves having fun!

name: Nikkei Student Union
description:
UC Berkeley's Nikkei Student Union, founded in the spring of 2002, is the biggest Japanese-American interest organization on campus. We are a one of a kind organization melding our interests in our Japanese American heritage with social and community events. And no, you don't have be Japanese to join!

We put on events such as an annual Day of Remembrance, craft and cooking socials, and organize volunteer opportunities with various Bay Area organizations. We also have joint socials with different student groups. Whether you are interested in getting involved in the JA community, looking to make friends, or want to play sports, we offer a variety of options for you. So feel free to check out our club.

 

Follow our instagram for the latest news! @BerkeleyNSU

Sign up for our newsletter at the following link! NSU Newsletter Sign Up
summary: UC Berkeley's Nikkei Student Union is the largest Japanese-American (JA) interest org. on campus. We incorporate our JA heritage in social and community events through the semester. And no, you don't have be Japanese to join! Everyone is welcome

name: NODE
summary: NODE’s goal is to increase incoming numbers and retention of URM graduate students at UC Berkeley in the Chemistry Department by providing mentorship and building a better community to aid in supporting our graduate students.

name: Noetherian Ring, The
description:
The Noetherian Ring (NRing) is a member-run organization of gender-minority graduate students, postdocs, professors, and staff in the Mathematics Department of the University of California at Berkeley.
The goal of this group is two-fold. One is to indicate a presence of women and gender minorities in the math department and provide information for students potentially interested in pursuing
mathematics. The other is to provide a network for women in the UC Berkeley math
department and facilitate social and professional development activities.
summary:
The Noetherian Ring specifically organizes for women and gender minority students at
the graduate level and above in mathematics who are affiliated with UC Berkeley.

name: Nuclear Is Clean Energy Club
summary: We aim to engage with club members, UC Berkeley students, and members of the public about nuclear reactors, waste, and technology.

name: Nuclear Policy Working Group
description: The NPWG hosts weekly interactive seminars and conducts research on pressing issues in nuclear security policy, in addition to organizing workshops and panel events.
summary: NPWG is a research-based, educational programming effort that provides opportunities for students from a variety of fields to conduct multidisciplinary research on a topic in nuclear security.

name: Nukids Nubies
description: This organization's goal is to make sure that the new students on Berkeley campus are properly welcomed. CalSO is only for two days and not enough to be properly acquainted to Berkeley. NuNu will help throughout the school year.
summary: This organization's goal is to make sure that the new students on Berkeley campus are properly welcomed. CalSO is only for two days and not enough to be properly acquainted to Berkeley. NuNu will help throughout the school year.

name: Oakland Asian Student Educational Services
description:
As a small mentoring program who served under-resourced children in Oakland, Oakland Asian Student
Educational Services (OASES) has grown into an organization of 150 volunteers that serves Lincoln and Franklin Elementary Schools in Oakland.

We mentor over 400 elementary school children each year regardless of race, ethnicity,
gender, sexual identity, or religious belief. OASES's vision is that all students in the public education system reach their
fullest potential and are supported to achieve success in school, careers and civic life. OASES achieves this by empowering youth with limited resources through education, mentorship, and service to strengthen the Oakland
community.

As a project of EBAYC (Where young people grow, thrive and lead!), we guide youth to be safe, smart, and socially responsible.
summary: OASES was founded in 1983 by a group of UC Berkeley undergraduates who wanted to provide a critical safety net for youth living in Oakland’s Chinatown.

name: Ocean Society of Berkeley
description:
Ocean Society of Berkeley is an ocean interest club that focuses on fun, educational, and hands-on events that connect Berkeley students with the Bay Area community and the outdoors.

Our full website can be found here. Join our Slack or email list for updates on meetings and events, as well as cool ocean-related news and articles!

During Spring 2023, we meet on Tuesdays at 6:30pm at McCone Hall. Everyone is welcome! Fill out this form to receive our emails about meetings and trips!

Follow us on Instagram @caloceansociety
summary: Ocean Society of Berkeley is an organization that promotes ocean awareness, environmentalism, and outreach while creating a community of students who share an interest in the ocean and related fields.

name: Odd Yard Zine
description:
OddYard strives to provide an interaction between art and the city.  We want to understand, analyze, and apply urban design and architecture to our everyday lives. One objective is to learn and research; take in all the necessary information to be well equipped and informed for our environment, to design, to build.  We hope to take and apply this information to research, writing and art, creating a product whose language is understandable. 

 

 

Because we are new to this topic of research, green in the field of urban design, we decided to focus on the needs of ourselves and our peers.  Our research, art and writing is aimed at building a framework for change in the urban environment; looking at ways to shift the relationship between planner and user.  Our observations on how people interact with the urban environment is the base for our research. Our work is starting small with the intent to widen in scope. 

Above all, we aim to display as broad a spectrum of people and issues as possible.  We will purposefully use this medium for voices of the POC, disabled, LGBTQA+ and others whose voices have been marginalized in the history of Western urban design. 

With this in common, members of OddYard step forward to become engaged and active within the urban environment through art, research and writing. 

 

Odd Yard Zine - oddyardzine.com

Pre-order First Issue Now!!!!
summary: Members of Odd Yard Zine seek to understand, analyze, and apply Urban Design and Architecture to our everyday lives. We wish to provide a better future for ourselves and others.

name: Older Wiser Law Students of Berkeley
description: Older, Wiser Law Students provides a sense of belonging and community to non-traditional and second career students, helping them transition to and anchor themselves in the Berkeley Law community. Our objective is to connect students from diverse career backgrounds and to help them thrive in their studies at Berkeley Law by allowing them to share advice and mutual support in an informal setting.
summary: Older, Wiser Law Students provides a sense of belonging and community to non-traditional and second career students, helping them transition to and anchor themselves in the Berkeley Law community.

name: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.
description:
University of California, Berkeley chapter of Omega Psi Phi Fraternity, Inc.

On Friday evening, November 17, 1911, three Howard University undergraduate students, with the assistance of their faculty adviser, gave birth to the Omega Psi Phi Fraternity. This event occurred in the office of biology Professor Ernest E. Just, the faculty adviser, in the Science Hall (now known as Thirkield Hall). The three liberal arts students were Edgar A. Love, Oscar J. Cooper and Frank Coleman. From the initials of the Greek phrase meaning "Friendship is Essential to the Soul," the name Omega Psi Phi was derived. The phrase was selected as the motto. Manhood, Scholarship, Perseverance and Uplift were adopted as cardinal principles.

U.C. BERKELEY QUES’ HISTORY MILESTONES
Ω Original chapter founded in 1925
Ω First Epsilon Mu line 6-10-83
Ω Epsilon Mu incorporated 9-28-84
Ω 2nd Vice District Representatives ’90, ‘96, '14
Ω District Chapter of the Year

Past Community Service Chapter Activities Include:
Ω Safe-sex & health awareness workshops 
Ω Academic programs 
Ω High school mentoring and tutoring
Ω Speakers series
Ω Feeding the homeless 
Ω Campus organization leaders
Ω Voter registration drives 
Ω Scholarship fundraisers 

Chapter Alumni Include:
Ω Past Basileus (President), Sigma Iota Graduate Chapter (Oakland)
Ω Former Basileus, Alpha Rho Graduate Chapter (Berkeley)
Ω Former 12th District Representative, 2012-14
Ω Many actively work in the community
Ω Senior managers in Silicon Valley 
Ω Former NFL football player
Ω Several are attorneys
�� Neurosurgery physician at UCLA

Chapter Academics
Ω 90+% graduation rate (bachelor degrees)
Ω 33% of alums obtained graduate degrees
Ω Weekly study groups
Ω Scholarship programs
summary: Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc. was founded at Howard University on Friday November 17th, 1911. Manhood, Scholarship, Perseverance and Uplift were adopted as cardinal principles. The fraternity was originally established at UC Berkeley in 1925.

name: Omniscient Tutor, The
description:
Are you interested in teaching or doing volunteer service? Join the Omniscient Tutor [iTOT] team! We are an online educational non-profit organization established to assist middle and high school students using an online network assisted by tutoring, instructional videos, and a Q&A forum. Our instructional team consists of undergraduate students from the top 100 universities. As an instructor, you will be trained to tutor students and make your own instructional video courses while answering questions on our Q&A forum. You will gain a diverse amount of experience in the educational field through: discovering your own teaching style, connecting with professionals, like employers, in the educational industry, establishing partnerships and sponsorships in teaching, as well as being able to enhance your resume while earning volunteer service hours with the Omniscient Tutor. We are seeking volunteers who are passionate about teaching and making a change in the global community. You don’t need any prior teaching experience :) Our organization also has a strong emphasis on supporting low-income students from underprivileged backgrounds and their desire to go to college with modern tools in technology. We provide them with full scholarships to utilize our services, making it convenient for them to develop the skills needed to succeed in middle and high school to prepare them for a college education. ___________________________________________
 
This upcoming semester in Spring 2022, the Omniscient Tutor is launching a DeCal Course [EDUC 98] at UC Berkeley on “How to Become an Online Educational Instructor.” Students will be introduced to the forefront of education through various pedagogical approaches and a variety of teaching mediums that can be utilized to educate learners of all ages. We will focus on how educators and instructors can tailor their curriculum to all learners through visual, auditory, and kinesthetic tools of learning. In this class, you will be able to design and develop your own online instructional course as well as learn how to use video editing software and camera equipment to enhance your lessons. The knowledge that students will gain in this course can be used to help pursue their own careers in education or set up a strong foundational understanding in the education-technology field. The course [EDUC 98] is 2 Credits (P/NP).Your facilitators are Pascale Mbeukeu (pascalembeukeu@berkeley.edu) and Elizabeth Chen (elizchen868@berkeley.edu). The weekly Lectures are on Wednesdays: 6 PM - 8 PM PST, Location and Class#: TBA. You can check out our Course Webpage here: https://www.theomniscienttutor.com/how-to-become-an-online-educational-instructor ___________________________________________
 
To join our team, please apply here (itot.berkeley.edu/apply) and hop on our DISCORD (discord.io/itot) to chat with one of our many wonderful officers. In addition, visit our WEBSITE (theomniscienttutor.com) or follow our SOCIAL MEDIAS (Facebook/Youtube/LinkedIn (@TheOmniscientTutor); Instagram/Twitter (@itot_app)) to learn more about the organization! Feel free to email us at support@itot.berkeley.edu if you have any questions.
 
https://youtu.be/0zcwQtmofXs
summary: To promote world-class education with a free prep program designed for low-income individuals using short, high quality (and easily accessible) online videos, comprehendible for any subject/concept, through the platforms of YouTube and other media apps.

name: One Love Foundation at Berkeley
summary: Our goal is to advocate for relationship health and play an active role in education prevention against relationship abuse. We want to address these topics via learning through discussion by hosting workshops and spreading awareness in the community.

name: Open Project
description: We are a group of students striving to redefine tech club culture at Berkeley. Open Project is dedicated to creating a medium for passionate students to meet and work on projects that make a positive difference in the world - without the unnecessary selective application process.
summary: We strive to build an open community for creators passionate about working on tech projects most meaningful to them.

name: Optimir Consulting
description:
Optimir Consulting is a non-profit consulting student group established in 2011 by three UC Berkeley students. Our student consultants come from a variety of academic disciplines and experiences and are dedicated to providing results-driven solutions. Our organization aims to develop and expand our consultants' skills. We offer fast-paced and unique training for our student consultants in order to optimize our clients' operations and make a positive social impact on non-profits and start-ups in the Bay Area and beyond.

Our members also foster a friendly, outgoing culture. At Optimir, we pride ourselves on making strong connections within our club to provide mentorship and support as students complete their undergraduate degrees. Activities we have enjoyed in the past include going to a food festival, trips to SF, and retreats. We recognize that student experiences will be impacted this upcoming semester, and we are determined to provide trainings, internship resources, and activities for our members. 

Past Optimir alumni have gone to work at companies such as Google, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley, LinkedIn, and PwC.
summary: Optimir Consulting is a non-profit consulting student group that aims to provide innovative and substantial strategy improvements for various industry clients in the start-up and non-profit world.

name: Optometric Business Management Club of Berkeley (formerly known as Private Practice Club of Berkeley)
description: Our purpose is to help students prepare for and make the transition from clinical education to the real world, business aspects of private practice optometry. We will inform and educate optometry students what private practice consists of and explore the opportunities, rewards, and challenges of the field. This will be accomplished with the help of guest speakers, student panels, and relevant corporation presentations.
summary:
Optometric Business Management Club at UCB School of Optometry 
(formerly known as Private Practice Club at UCB School of Optometry)

summary: The purpose of the Optometric Student Association is to enhance the education and welfare of the students at the School of Optometry and improve the visual welfare of the public.

name: Optometry Class of 2023 at Berkeley (formerly Optometry Class of 2019)
description: Optometry Class of 2023 at Berkeley is the leadership of UCBSO's class of 2023. Our purpose is to enhance the education and welfare of the students at the University of California School of Optometry and to improve the visual welfare of the public.
summary: Optometry Class of 2023 at Berkeley is the leadership of UCBSO's class of 2023. Our purpose is to enhance the education and welfare of the students at the University of California School of Optometry and to improve the visual welfare of the public.

name: Optometry Class of 2024 at Berkeley
description: This group also aims to spread awareness of current issues affecting the profession of optometry, and to fundraise for social and professional events, and community projects.
summary: The Optometry Class of 2024 at Berkeley is a student organization whose purpose is to encourage fellowship among optometry students, faculty, and the optometric profession as a whole.

name: Optometry Class of 2025 at Berkeley (Formerly Optometry Class of 2021 at Berkeley)
description: This group aims to educate the community of current issues affecting the profession of optometry, and to fundraise for social and professional events, and community projects.
summary: The Optometry Class of 2025 at Berkeley is a student run organization whose purpose is to promote communication between optometry students, faculty, and the optometric professionals.

name: Optometry Class of 2026 at Berkeley
summary: This group aims to educate the community of current issues affecting the profession of optometry, and to fundraise for social and professional events, and community projects.

name: Organization of Jewish Graduate Students
description: We are dedicated to enhancing the cultural and social life of graduate students at the University by providing the opportunity to connect with other graduate students while exploring and engaging in Jewish cultural and religious practices.
summary: We are  dedicated to enhancing the cultural and social life of graduate students at the University by providing the opportunity to connect with other graduate students while exploring and engaging in Jewish cultural and religious practices.

name: Orthodox Christian Fellowship at Berkeley
description:
Orthodox Christian Fellowship (OCF) is the official collegiate campus ministry program under the Standing Conference of Canonical Orthodox Bishops in the Americas.

There are OCF members with a variety of religious beliefs. We welcome all followers of God, orthodox or not!
Please join us on Tuesdays for enjoyable and enlightening OCF evenings: 
 
Divine Liturgy, 6:00 PM
Warm dinner, 7:00 PM
Spiritual discussion, 7:40-8:30 PM
summary: Our mission is to support fellowships on college campuses, whose members experience and witness to the Orthodox Christian Church through community life, prayer, service to others and study of the faith.

name: Our Monologues (formerly V-Day at Berkeley)
description:
“Our Monologues” is a student-led production featuring the real stories of students at UC Berkeley, and sponsored by the Gender Equity Resource Center.

The show welcomes all students to participate so long as they are committed to fostering a safe and inclusive space– with a prioritization of BIPOC, femme, nonbinary, women,* transgender, differently-abled, and queer students and allies as well as their relationships to gender, race, sexuality, and other intersections of their identity. Our mission is to end gender-based violence and promote gender equity on our campus and in our world. All proceeds of the show go to organizations around the Bay Area that align with our values. 

*We welcome all who experience life through the lens of woman in body, spirit, identity- past, present, future, and fluid. 

Check us out at Calapalooza and our Info Sessions for more information about the show and how to audition! 

Also feel free to stop by the Geneq space or email us at ourmons@berkeley.edu with any questions.
summary: Our Monologue places students with historically marginalized identities at the center. It is the largest educational performance platform for gender-based violence on campus, manifesting a community of healing, liberation, resistance, education, and more

name: Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
description:
oSTEM aims to unite the LGBTQ+ students within the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to foster a strong professional and social network as well as to promote awareness of their presence in all communities.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are preparing for Fall 2023 meetings however, we currently conduct club contact through:

 

Discord

Instagram

Linktree

In Person FA 23 Meetings:

*tentative* Bi-weekly Wednesdays from 5-6 PM
summary: oSTEM aims to unite the LGBTQ+ students within the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics to foster a strong professional and social network as well as to promote awareness of their presence in all communities.

name: Outdoor Photography Society at Berkeley
description: The Outdoor Photography Society at Berkeley brings together students interested in exploring the outdoors through photography. The club is open to all students and encompasses a wide range of photography styles, including landscape, wildlife, travel, urban, outdoor portraits, and astrophotography – any photography that takes place outdoors! We host bi-weekly workshops and photo trips, as well as photography talks and club socials. If you’re interested in joining, please send us an email at opsb.berkeley@gmail.com!
summary: The Outdoor Photography Society at Berkeley aims to provide a community for students interested in exploring the outdoors through photography.

name: Outlet
description:
Outlet aims to build a unified arts community at UC Berkeley and open access to all visual arts to beginners and advanced artists, thus creating a centralized organization where artists of varying interests and backgrounds can come together and grow creatively and socially.

We further serve both the campus community and the wider bay area community by providing access to arts education through workshops and classes taught by student studio heads in areas where such opportunities may not be available, such as local schools and hospitals. Outlet also encourages guest studio heads to spread awareness and appreciation for art.

Our workshops are held as scheduled from 7-9pm (weekday TBA). Members may submit works to be showcased on Discord or be featured on our social media pages, as well as hang out with other members during socials. Join us to meet new artists and learn new techniques or mediums in a friendly, open environment!
summary: Outlet aims to provide a space for budding visual artists to develop their skills, showcase their work, and have an outlet for expression.  We strive to serve the campus and the larger community by providing open access to the arts and arts education.

name: Outsiders
description: California is home to gorgeous mountain ranges, coastal beaches, forests and deserts––yet there is constant lack of diversity and unequal access to nature/outdoor activities. Outsiders is a new outdoor club created by and for people of color. Noticing the lack of diversity and inclusion in outdoor activity spaces on campus, this club was created to break down racial barriers and enrich local experiences for POC-identifying folks looking to spend more time in nature. Outsiders encourages POC-identifying to partake in exciting trips, coordinate passions and hobbies, and connect with others that want to explore our gorgeous state and the outdoors. There will be coordinated trips that explore hiking, backpacking, climbing, kayaking or paddle boarding, and much more.
summary: Outsiders is an outdoor club created by and for people of color. Members will be encouraged to partake in nature-based activities as well as gain the experiences and knowledge to comfortably lead trips.

name: Overwatch at Berkeley
summary: Overwatch at Berkeley focuses on uniting and supporting students who are passionate about Overwatch. We provide a space for students to play together, to learn, and to grow through gaming.

name: Palate
description:
We’re Palate. We bring you good food and better company. Join us at our table as we explore, experience, and enjoy cuisine adventures together in Bay Area and beyond. We are a team of friends who share a common love for food, fellowship, and fun. Palate is a reflection of our friendship and love for food. As we continue to share a table, we invite you to join us as we cherish good food and better company.

 

Please fill out our General Membership Application here: https://tinyurl.com/joinpalate
summary: We’re Palate, and we create a community to bring you good food and better company.

name: Paleontological Society of Berkeley
description:
The Paleontological Society of Berkeley is a community at Berkeley that connects students interested in paleontology to one another. We meet once a week at VLSB 3007 (Fridays, 5:30-6:30pm) to discuss paleontology news, share student presentations about paleontological topics of their interest, and provide connections into the paleontological research world. We also do field trips to nearby fossil sites and parts of our university's fossil research collections, as well as talk with guest speakers including UC faculty, grad students, and other paleontologists. Anybody interested in anything about ancient life is welcome to attend our meetings!

 

Join our discord server at: https://discord.gg/gWPq445sas
summary: The Paleontological Society of Berkeley aims to connect students interested in paleontology with each other and the UC paleontological community at large.

name: Panhellenic Council (PHC)
description:
The Panhellenic Council (PHC) is the governing body for 13 sorority chapters on campus.  Twelve chapters are associated with the National Panhellenic Conference (an umbrella organization for 26 international women's fraternities and sororities), and one is a local chapter, unique to UC Berkeley's campus. Berkeley PHC includes Alpha Chi Omega, Alpha Delta Pi,  Alpha Phi, Chi Omega, Delta Delta Delta, Delta Gamma, Delta Sigma, Gamma Phi Beta, Kappa Alpha Theta, Kappa Kappa Gamma, Pi Beta Phi, Sigma Kappa, and Zeta Tau Alpha.

The council serves to promote CalGreeks’ core values: leadership, scholarship, friendship, and service.

Please visit our website at www.calpanhellenic.com/fallprimaryrecruitment for more information on how to register. The registration link is also linked below.
summary: The Berkeley Panhellenic Council is the governing body for 13 sorority chapters on campus. The council serves to promote CalGreeks’ core values: leadership, scholarship, friendship, and service.

name: Paper Crane
description:
We are Paper Crane, a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that provides weekly creative art workshops at UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital in Oakland. Our big aim is to contribute a relief and support system for children who spend a lot of time there. Currently, we are designing and donating art kits to the kids, but we are hoping to begin in-person workshops at the hospital! 

--

In Japanese culture, the crane is referred to as the “bird of happiness” and an ancient Japanese legend promises that anyone who folds a thousand paper cranes will be granted a wish by the gods. Just like folding one paper crane at a time, we hope to spread smiles, one at a time, to create something beautiful. We know that even though a single person (or a single organization) can’t change the world, changing a single person’s world for even a moment is worth the effort.

--

Through artistic expression, we hope to alleviate some of the burdens of illness and injury and provide these kids with an inclusive environment in which they can feel safe and happy. We believe strongly in the cathartic powers of art, and the ability to empower and spread positivity and community using art as the medium. Hopefully, through our workshops, we can aid the children in their process of healing.

--

By recruiting volunteers on campus, we hope to expand to more hospitals and increase the number of weekly workshops to form even more meaningful connections with kids who need it the most.

--

If you would like to learn more about our club, we will be holding info sessions towards the beginning of fall semester (TBD). More information and zoom links on our FB page: https://www.facebook.com/PaperCraneBerkeley 

--

Applications are due (TBD, sometime in late august/early September). Interview invites are sent on (TBD, sometime in late august, early September) and interviews are held on Sat and Sun of the same week.
summary: Paper Crane aims to create a support and relief system for hospitalized children by providing expressive art workshops at hospitals.

name: Paragon Consulting at Berkeley
description: Paragon Consulting is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that serves BIPOC entrepreneurs and small businesses by providing pro-bono consulting services. Our mission is to increase the representation of first-generation, underrepresented, and low-income Berkeley students in the consulting practice. The purpose of Paragon is to provide its members with the tools and experience to successfully compete in today’s demanding workforce while giving back to the small and POC business community.
summary: Paragon Consulting provides BIPOC-owned small businesses in the Bay Area innovative and creative solutions to industry-defining challenges, while providing opportunities for a diverse group of undergraduate students.

name: Parliamentary Debate at Berkeley
description: Parliamentary Debate at Berkeley is the most competitively successful student-run debate team in the history of the National Parliamentary Debate Association. We accept members of all experience levels, whether you’re a former debater or have never seen a debate round before, and the team guarantees that all members can attend tournaments for no personal cost. NPDA is a limited-prep style of debate, with arguments about domestic policy, international relations, scientific research, philosophy, and critical theory. Unlike other types of parliamentary debate, our team focuses more heavily on critical thinking and argument construction rather than speaking style and persuasion. Members compete in partnerships, sharing responsibilities for pre-round preparation and in-round argumentation. Parli at Berkeley will be continuing practices and competition online during the fall. We’ve put together lectures and other resources to get new members on board, and we’re planning to offer 8-10 practices a week to make sure we can adapt to your schedule.
summary: Parliamentary Debate at Berkeley (PDB) is UC Berkeley’s NPDA debate team. We provide individuals of all experience levels with the opportunity to successfully compete in intercollegiate parliamentary debate.

name: Partners In Health Engage at Berkeley
description:
Website: https://tinyurl.com/pihebwebsite

Our application for Fall 2023 is currently available on our website. 

 

At PIH Engage at Berkeley, we recognize a call to action against vast global health inequity.

We leverage our position as members of the UC Berkeley community to support the work of international non-profit, Partners In Health, in improving health outcomes in the poorest regions of the world.

We accomplish this through 3 core committees: Advocacy, Education, and Fundraising.

We seek to treat not only the symptoms but the causes of vast health inequity, and to do so whilst prioritizing the dignity of patients and partnering with local organizations.

We are committed to building a fun and diverse community of individuals from across disciplines, experiences, and skills: all championing the cause of global health.

In everything we do we keep the advancement of the right to health at the forefront of our actions.
summary: PIH Engage at Berkeley is committed to advancing individuals' right to health locally, nationally, and globally. We accomplish this through 3 core committees: Education, Fundraising & Advocacy.

name: Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinxs
description:
The Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinxs (P4), is dedicated to the advancement of Pilipinxs, Pilipinx-Americans and People of Color (POCs) in law, business and other professional fields in lieu of the economic, legal and social condition of Pilipinxs and the a Pilipinx-Americans across the United States. We, the core of P4, will develop, empower, and establish strong leaders to combat systems that oppress Pilipinxs, Pilipinx-Americans and POCs generally in said fields.  We will strive to build a network of pre-professionals and professionals that persist as a support system after we leave the space. We will encourage and demystify graduate and professional programs while promoting and uplifting underserved communities. 

We will organize our communities to continue the fight for social, political, legal, economic equality and justice for all; and do therefore ordain and establish our Constitution.

P4's Mission is: 

  • To support those interested in business, law and other professional fields
  • To establish a community motivated to advance the socio-economic status of POCs via professional development
  • To build a network of pre-professionals and professionals that continues to support one another after graduation
  • To increase diversity in graduate and professional programs, specifically, but not limited to, law and business related programs
  • To encourage career paths and service in all sectors: private, public, and non-profit
summary: The Partnership for Pre-Professional Pilipinxs (P4), is dedicated to the advancement of Pilipinxs, Pilipinx-Americans and People of Color (POCs) in law, business and other professional fields.

name: Patient Advocacy Student Group
description: Patient Advocacy Student Group (PASG) offers unique patient-centered clinical experiences in partnership with UCSF for students interested in providing healthcare. Students have the opportunity to interface with providers and patients while learning clinical technology and systems in partnership with UCSF. PASG promotes patient-centered and trains students to advocate for patients. The student group offers professional development and networking opportunities oriented towards healthcare and medicine.
summary: Patient Advocacy Student Group (PASG) offers unique patient-centered clinical experiences in partnership with UCSF for students interested in providing healthcare.

name: Paws for Mental Health (Formerly De-Stress with Dogs)
description:
Paws for Mental Health is an organization that seeks to promote mental health through canine companions. The unconditional love of a dog can relieve feelings of stress, anxiety, and/or depression. However, having a dog is oftentimes not a viable option to students here at UC Berkeley. Our objective is to host regular gatherings and events of local dogs along with their owners and other students to provide a positive and safe space for de-stressing and relaxing. This can allow for students to forget about the daily rigors of academia and unwind.

 

This group Paws for Mental Health was formerly named De-Stress with Dogs - 9/25/20 IZ (PLC)
summary: Paws for Mental Health is an organization that seeks to promote mental health through canine companions.

name: Payment for Placements at Berkeley
summary: The purpose of the Payment for Placements chapter at Berkeley (P4P at Berkeley) is to foster community amongst graduate students who are required to complete a field placement or internship to graduate.

name: Peer Wellness Coalition
description: The Peer Wellness Coalition (“PWC”) is a student organization dedicated to increasing wellness and mental health resources in Berkeley Law and in the legal profession more generally. The legal field has historically struggled with high rates of substance abuse, depression, and anxiety. PWC is committed to reversing this trend by providing Berkeley Law students the resources necessary to (1) manage their wellness and mental health needs and (2) develop the skills and habits required for maintaining work-life balance. PWC aspires for students to take these skills with them as they enter the legal and other professions.
summary: The Peer Wellness Coalition (“PWC”) is a student organization dedicated to increasing wellness and mental health resources in Berkeley Law and in the legal profession more generally.

name: Perennial QT Film Club
description: Perennial is a film club that focuses on LGBTQ+ representation in film and media, holds discussions over these themes, and aims to write short film scripts with those same themes in mind. Our goal is authentic and real feeling representation and we intend to achieve that through holding writer's rooms where there will be a collaborative writing process, and by holding discussions so we can talk about what issues we see present in queer and trans representation today. We intend to be a part of the solution, and create representation through our own short films that incorporates exactly what we think is currently missing.
summary: Our purpose is to write and produce short films with a focus on LGBTQ+ representation and themes. We intend to discuss issues of queer and trans representation in media and use that to create our own original short film scripts.

name: Perennial: The Undergraduate Environmental Journal of Berkeley
description: A forum for the Berkeley community to share insights on environmental issues. We hope to encourage student action and scholarship, discuss solutions to critical issues, and promote diversity of identity and opinion in the field. We publish editorial articles and research papers on a wide variety of environmental topics each semester.
summary: A forum for the Berkeley community to share insights on environmental issues. We hope to encourage student action and scholarship, discuss solutions to critical issues, and promote diversity of identity and opinion in the field.

name: Perfect Fifth
description: Perfect Fifth is a small student-directed all-gender a cappella choir taking classically inspired singing to new heights. Specializing in music of the Renaissance, our repertoire ranges from the beginnings of western polyphonic music in the Middle Ages all the way to contemporary art music. Founded in 1978, for three decades Perfect Fifth has put on eclectic and inspired concerts, performing across the Bay Area and collaborating with groups around campus, and will continue to do so for decades to come.
summary: Perfect Fifth is a small all-gender a cappella choir in UC Choral Ensembles. We specialize in choral music of the Renaissance, but our repertoire ranges from early polyphonic works to contemporary chamber pieces.

name: Performance Studies Research Collective
description: The Performance Studies Research Collective (PSRC) is a graduate student group which works in conjunction with the Department of Theater, Dance, and Performance Studies to facilitate critical discussion of performance in culture and society. The PSRC is involved in the organization of events, including lectures, panel discussions, live performances, and film and media screenings throughout the year. Such events seek to foster deeper connections between the field of performance studies and other disciplines on the campus. To this end, the group works regularly with graduate students and faculty in the Departments of African American Studies, Asian American Studies, Comparative Literature, Ethnic Studies, Film and Media Studies, Gender and Women's Studies, and Rhetoric, to name just a few; as well as with research centers at Cal including the Arts Research Center, the Berkeley Center for New Media, the Center for Race & Gender, the Center for the Study of Sexual Cultures, and the Gender Equity Resource Center.
summary: The Performance Studies Research Collective (PSRC) is a graduate student group which works in conjunction with the Department of Theater, Dance, and Performance Studies to facilitate critical discussion of performance in culture and society.

name: Period Project at Berkeley, The
description: Through our three pillars --education, advocacy, and service -- The Period Project at Berkeley is constantly advocating for freely accessible menstrual products, providing menstrual products to those in need, and elevating the conversation about periods by raising awareness on menstrual health.
summary: We are an organization dedicated to fighting period poverty and removing the stigma surrounding menstruation through service, education, and policy.

name: Phalanx: Pre-Medical Consulting
description:
The pre-medical path is a hard one - which is why Phalanx is here to help. As an independent, student-run and founded group, we seek to provide free pre-medical consulting, long term mentorship, and a myriad of resources from experienced pre-medical students to incoming freshmen at Cal.


We particularly seek to encourage initiative, innovation and the pursuit of unique passions among our clients. In this way, we hope to instill in them the values and skills needed to succeed not only as a pre-medical student and medical school applicant, but also as the future physician-leaders in science, medical technology, and public health.
summary: An organization dedicated to providing pre-medical consulting services, mentorship, and a network of support to a select group of incoming pre-medical freshmen at UC Berkeley.  Services are provided by a team of upperclassmen consultants.

name: Phi Alpha Delta Law Fraternity, International
description:
Phi Alpha Delta is UC Berkeley's oldest and largest pre-law fraternity, providing its membership with unrivaled leadership experience, tailored professional development, and access to an accomplished alumni network. Involvement in PAD is enriching, not only in terms of professionalism, but also in terms of personal development. As we explore the legal field and take important steps towards law school admission, we learn to work successfully alongside one another, developing broad interpersonal skills, tolerance, and mutual respect for our brothers and sisters.

 

Cultivating Professionalism

Our fraternity wants to do more than simply create a space where students interested in the law can come together. We want to provide our members with the skills and knowledge to go on to law school, careers in the legal field, and any other professional aspiration they may have. Through our Membership Development program, our professional events, and our many networking opportunities, members will find themselves graduating with a plethora of tools for their futures.

 

Investing Service

Law is not a field solely aimed at making money and gaining influence. Members of PAD find that we put just as much emphasis on the fairness and equity of law. To that end, our members take the skills they've acquired at Berkeley and in our fraternity to help the wider community and make a positive impact in the lives of others. Our Philanthropy committee makes it a point to provide accessible opportunities to reinvest time into making a difference.

 

Promoting Fraternalism

PAD may be a place to hone your skills for the future, but ask any member and they will say that one of the most important pieces of PAD for them is the community. By creating an environment where new and old members can get to know each other and form lasting friendships and meaningful connections, our fraternity ensures that, by joining, you become a part of the biggest family at Cal.

 

Encouraging Leadership

We take pride in giving members the tools they need to become leaders in the fraternity, on campus, and beyond. After the completion of Membership Development, new members have the opportunity to become more involved by applying to committee directorships. Others take the skills they've learned to become active in other organizations. We've had PAD members take leadership roles in the ASUC, Daily Californian, Undergraduate Political Science Association, Berkeley Project, and many many more.

 

Recruitment Video
summary: The Berkeley Chapter of Phi Alpha Delta Law Fraternity was established to provide its members with unrivaled leadership experience, tailored professional development, and access to an accomplished alumni network, all focused around the legal profession.

name: Phi Alpha Theta
description: Phi Alpha Theta, Chi Chapter, is an undergraduate honor society which facilitates a wide range of activities every year designed to give history students the opportunity to better get to know one another, their graduate students, and their faculty on campus. Throughout the year, we sponsor events ranging from the intellectual to the purely social, including a stimulating lecture series, faculty-student dinners, and the History 101 undergraduate thesis colloquium at the end of every spring.
summary: Phi Alpha Theta, Chi Chapter, is an undergraduate honor society which facilitates a wide range of activities every year designed to give history students the opportunity to better get to know one another, their graduate students, and their faculty.

name: Phi Chi Pre-Health Fraternity
description: We are, first and foremost, a co-ed pre-health interest group for undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley. Within the society, we have a brotherhood between members who share a common goal of entering the health field. Members receive exclusive access to lectures and advice from accomplished guest speakers, including members of the admission board of graduate schools, and to a network of Phi Chi alumni and supporters for informative and career-seeking purposes. Aside from the academic benefits, we are also members of a brotherhood – we help students form relationships with each other and within the pre-health undergraduate population through collaboration with groups of similar interests on campus.
summary: We are, first and foremost, a co-ed pre-health interest group for undergraduate students at the University of California, Berkeley. Within the society, we have a brotherhood between members who share a common goal of entering the health field.

name: Phi Delta Epsilon
description:
Phi Delta Epsilon was founded in 1904 by Aaron Brown at Cornell University Medical College.  Our UC Berkeley Chapter (CA Iota) was founded in 2007 by Tony Chen and Felix Wong, with the sponsorship of Dr. Bernard Greigo. Today, Phi Delta Epsilon has over 70 medical school chapters and over 50 premedical chapters all over the United States and abroad.

Phi Delta Epsilon is UC Berkeley's premier international co-ed medical fraternity.  Phi Delta Epsilon not only offers an environment for professional networking opportunities, but also establishes long lasting friendships of brotherhood, sisterhood, and family. Members are offered opportunities to build solid foundations in ethics and philanthropy. Through active participation in leadership workshops, members also develop professional skills pertinent for the path of medicine. We provide members with contacts and resources to help them through their undergraduate career.
summary: Phi Delta Epsilon International Medical Fraternity creates physicians of integrity with a life-long commitment to our guiding principles of philanthropy, deity, and education though fellowship, service, mentoring, and formal training.

name: Phi Delta Theta
description:
Phi Delta Theta was organized with three principle objectives: The cultivation of friendship among its members, the acquirement individually of a high degree of mental culture, and the attainment personally of a high standard of morality.

These objectives, referred to as the Cardinal Principles, have guided over 225,000 men since 1848 when the Fraternity was founded at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio.

The Fraternity teaches men that these areas of commitment, outlined in The Bond of Phi Delta Theta, are not to be viewed as separate ideals, but as areas of discipline for daily life. Developments intellectually, in leadership, and human service (to name a few) are vital to the men of Phi Delta Theta. A member will support, and in turn have the support of, his brothers as these principles are lived out.
summary: The oldest continuous chapter at Berkeley.  A brotherhood with a rich tradition that emphasizes academics, honor, and fraternal bonds.

name: Phi Kappa Psi
description:
Over 150 years ago, two college students, William H. Letterman and Charles P.T. Moore, in the college town of Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, were nursing and watching their stricken friends during an epidemic of typhoid fever. Through the long night vigils, an appreciation of the great joy of serving others came into their lives. Calling a number of others to join them, a Brotherhood was founded on February 19, 1852. It flourished, and gradually extended to other colleges and universities throughout the country. Pragmatic idealists, the founders of Phi Kappa Psi sought a new fraternity – a fraternity that should complement the work of the university by cultivating those humanities without which the educated man fails of his greatest usefulness, founded upon the great joy of serving others.

The centennial anniversary Phi Kappa Psi was at the old home of the Widow Letterman in Canonsburg, Pennsylvania, on February 19, 1952. Over 100 members of the Fraternity gathered together for this occasion including three of the grandsons of the Founders. A bronze tablet commemorating the centennial was moved to the Pennsylvania Alpha chapter house. In the Fraternity’s first 100 years, Phi Kappa Psi had grown to 56 chapters, 40 Alumni Associations and 40,000 initiates. Phi Kappa Psi today has ninety-seven chapters in thirty-four states and the District of Columbia with 4,778 active student members. There have been nearly 113,000 men initiated. Unlike most national fraternities, the constitution of Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity vests control over its affairs in the student members through the election of six of the ten members of the Executive Council and voting control at the GAC. The Endowment Fund of Phi Kappa Psi Fraternity is a foundation that provides financial support for education programs of the Fraternity and financial support through scholarships and grants to its members. The Endowment Fund has approximately $50 million in assets, and ranks largest among the endowments established by other fraternity and sorority organizations.
summary: The Cal Gamma Chapter of Phi Kappa Psi has grown to be a driving, dynamic force in the campus community. Brothers enjoy a vibrant social calendar, pursue active leadership roles on campus and contribute to various philanthropic endeavors.

name: Phi Kappa Sigma
description: The vision of Phi Kappa Sigma is “Lifelong growth and development of the Fraternity and its members.” This focus makes a perfect practice field for growing personally, refining life skills, developing leadership, and experiencing real-world situations in a safe, supportive environment.

name: Phi Kappa Tau
description:
The UC Berkeley Chapter of Phi Kappa Tau
• Was founded in 1921 as the Nu (13th) chapter.
• Has the distinction of being one of the few fraternities on campus to have never lost its charter.
• Boasts 26 spacious rooms in our Chapter house which is owned by the brothers of the fraternity.

Our National Chapter:
Phi Kappa Tau was founded March 17, 1906 at the University of Miami in Ohio. Since then, 146 chapters have been chartered and over 100,000 men have been initiated into our brotherhood. 

Philanthropy:
The brothers of Phi Kappa Tau work every semester to raise money for the SeriousFun Children’s Network (formerly known as Hole in the Wall Camps). This organization was founded in 1988 by Phi Tau alumnus Paul Newman. The money we raise helps facilitate camps in 31 countries for children with life-threatening illnesses. Over 100,000 children have attended these camps free of charge as a result of Phi Tau’s national efforts.

Leaders on Campus:
Members of Phi Kappa Tau at Berkeley have prominent roles in Berkeley’s Model United Nations, campus administration, and intramural sports. Brothers of Phi Tau also take part in club sports, boxing, and the Interfraternity Council.

More than just a four year Experience:
Membership in Phi Kappa Tau not only enhances each brother’s college experience, but provides opportunities to enrich one’s life after graduation. Our alumni network flourishes from coast to coast, even showing a presence internationally. Graduates often find work after college as a result of recommendations from other Phi Tau alumni. Moreover, the friendships created within our fraternity last decades longer than the time spent in school.
summary: The UC Berkeley Chapter of Phi Kappa Tau was founded in 1921 as the Nu chapter, and has the distinction of being one of the few fraternities on campus to have never lost its charter. The house has a commitment to brotherhood.

name: Phi Lambda Rho
description:
On August 14, 2022, a group of 6 Latina/Chicana women established the Iota Chapter of Phi Lambda Rho at UC Berkeley. They brought forth this beautiful organization in order to uplift women of color at Cal through sisterhood, mutual support, & love. We hope that bringing Phi Lambda Rho to Berkeley will create a supportive sanctuary within this historically white-serving institution for the growing number of Latinas on campus to flourish.

Phi Lambda Rho Sorority Inc., is a multi-cultural Chicana/Latina sorority popularly known as “Rhosas” or “Rhos.” Sisters of Phi Lambda Rho organize and execute events catered to their four pillars -- Academics, Cultura, Philanthropy, and Sisterhood --throughout the year, making them an active and professional sorority in the community.

The sorority serves as a retention group for aspiring young women in college who wish to leave a positive impact in their communities by engaging in service to the community while displaying a sense of cultural pride and fostering life-long bonds.

Follow us on Instagram: @ucberkeleyrhosas

For more information, contact us at flr.iota.president@gmail.com
summary: Phi Lambda Rho

name: Phi Sigma Rho
description:
Founded in 1984, Phi Sigma Rho is a sorority for women in engineering and engineering technologies with over twenty-five chapters nationwide! Through Phi Sigma Rho, our members develop a lifetime sisterhood.

Our Objectives:

 

  • To foster and provide the broadening experience of sorority living with its social and moral challenges and responsibilities for the individual and the chapter. 
  • To develop the highest standard of personal integrity and character. 
  • To promote academic excellence and support personal achievement, while providing a social balance. 
  • To aid the individual in the transition from academic to the professional community. 
  • To maintain sorority involvement with the alma mater and the community through responsible participation. 
  • To maintain the bond of sisterhood with alumnae members through communication, consultation, and participation in Sorority functions. 

 

For philanthropy, Phi Sigma Rho (both at Berkeley and nationally) works with the Girl Scouts and Leukemia/Lymphoma organizations. At Berkeley, we also look for other opportunities to give back to the community, especially the STEM one.

For academic and professional development, we have study groups, resume/interview tips, career panels, and tech talks.

For more information, visit https://www.calphirho.com/ or our national website http://www.phisigmarho.org/.
summary: Phi Sigma Rho is a social sorority for women in engineering and engineering technologies.

name: Philosophy Forum
description:
Join us on Thursdays from 6-8 PM, meeting room TBA. 

Phil Forum fosters a lively and active community of Berkeley undergraduates brought together by our interest in and love of philosophy, while encouraging a campus-wide interest in philosophical inquiry. At our weekly meetings professors and students present their philosophical work and discuss these issues in an open, responsive environment.  We also invite professors and graduate students from different disciplines to give lectures throughout the semester, exposing students to current issues in philosophy and affiliated fields.
summary: Join us Thursdays 6-8 PM at Howison Library! Phil Forum fosters a lively and active community of undergraduates brought together by our interest in philosophy. Make friends, watch interesting presentations, and discuss a variety of philosophical topics!

name: Phoenix Consulting Group
description: Phoenix Consulting Group is UC Berkeley’s premier healthcare consulting organization. We’re a diverse community of scientists, engineers, business leaders, and policymakers that hope to change the world through our passion for healthcare. We develop dynamic business strategies to help companies solve problems, working with companies as established as Pfizer and startups like Hubly Surgical. We have also built our own healthcare accelerator, Health Engine. Come to our events to learn more about our community!
summary: Phoenix Consulting Group is a UC Berkeley management consulting group focused primarily on businesses and startups in the pharmaceutical, medical, and healthcare industries providing strategic and technical consulting opportunities.

name: Phoenix Symphony at Berkeley
description: Phoenix Symphony at Berkeley is a music group that blends East Asian traditional instruments with western and other instruments, to lead people to explore East Asian culture and exchange diverse minds through the enchantment of music.
summary: Phoenix Symphony at Berkeley dedicates to the spread of East Asian traditional music, cooperation with multicultural arts, and promotion of East Asian culture.

name: PhotoCubs
description:
We are the joint student chapter of the SPIE (International Society for Optical Engineering), Optica (formerly, Optical Society of America), and the IEEE Photonics Society at the University of California, Berkeley. The club is operated by students who are dedicated to advancing the field of optics. Our members are affiliated with several departments on campus including Electrical Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, Astronomy, Vision Science and Optometry. We are commited to promoting the optics community on campus. To become involved in PhotoBears, attend a PhotoBears meeting or contact the current members.

(formerly known as Photobears)
summary: PhotoCubs is the joint student chapter of the SPIE (International Society for Optical Engineering), Optica (formerly, Optical Society of America), and IPS (IEEE Photonics Society) at the University of California Berkeley.

name: Pi Kappa Phi
description:
Mission: We Will Lead.

For over a century, the brothers of Pi Kappa Phi have been building better men on college campuses across the nation. From our humble roots at the College of Charleston in South Carolina to over 130 campuses today including UC Berkeley, Pi Kappa Phi stands for a commitment to fundamental values.

We are a first CLASS fraternity who firmly believes in the tenets of Character, Leadership, Academics, Sportsmanship, and Service. These ideals are not only valued but instilled through leading-edge educational, service, and leadership opportunities including national level internships.

Our strengths include our brotherhood and diversity; Our members come from a variety of different backgrounds, have a variety of interests, and are involved in many different activities on campus including Cal athletics, band, and various on-campus clubs. We have a very active alumni group which participates in chapter events and also provide members with many opportunities and connections for the future. We have the second-largest house on campus, which includes newly remodeled rooms and a basement with a jacuzzi. Besides date parties and sorority exchanges, our chapter holds bonding activities such as weekend getaways in Tahoe or trips to LA for football games. The driving motivation for Pi Kappa Phi is to create life-long friendship for the future.

Pi Kapp is the only fraternity to own and operate its own national philanthropy, Push America. It remains the exclusive service learning project of the Fraternity, with the purpose of instilling lifelong service in our members and serving people with disabilities. Pi Kappa Phi members have raised nearly $8 million dollars as well as donated thousands of man hours to renovate facilities that serve people with disabilities across the country. Expanding the education and values of America’s finest men, we will lead.

What We Offer:

Rushing Pi Kappa Phi promises to be a life-changing experience. You will build friendships and relationships that will last a lifetime. You will develop leadership and communication skills. You will also receive career and academic advice from experienced members and alumni and job connections for the future.
summary: Rushing Pi Kappa Phi promises to be a life-changing experience. You will build friendships and relationships that will last a lifetime. You will develop leadership and communication skills. You will also receive career and academic advice from experience

name: Pi Lambda Phi
summary: Founded at Yale University in 1895, Pi Lambda Phi (Pilam) was the first non-sectarian fraternity in the United States, accepting men of good character without regard to race or religion. Today, Pilam chapters at colleges and universities in the United

name: Pi Sigma Alpha - Iota Chapter
description: Pi Sigma Alpha, the National Political Science Honor Society, is the one and only honor society for college students of political science and government in the United States. Pi Sigma Alpha is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies (ACHS) and is designated as a "Specialized, Upper-Division" society by ACHS. Pi Sigma Alpha is dedicated to academic achievement, service in the community, and participation in political activity and thus offers Political Science students a forum for intellectual thought and opportunities to volunteer and network.
summary: Pi Sigma Alpha is dedicated to academic achievement, service in the community, and participation in political activity and thus offers Political Science students a forum for intellectual thought and opportunities to volunteer and network.

name: Pi Sigma Epsilon
description:
Check out our website: http://www.berkeleypse.org

Check out our facebook: https://www.fb.com/berkeleyPSE/

At Pi Sigma Epsilon, we pride ourselves in our professionalism, close-knit community, leadership opportunities, and diversity. Our brothers grow together through sales & marketing projects, case competitions, professional development workshops, internal events and more. We’re here to help you succeed at Cal and beyond.
summary:
PI SIGMA EPSILON
The only co-ed marketing, sales, and management business fraternity on campus.

name: Pi Tau Sigma
description: Pi Tau Sigma is the national Mechanical Engineering Honors Society. We pride ourselves in connecting our members with faculty, industrial contacts, and other ME students as well as helping out in the community, all the while having fun.
summary: Pi Tau Sigma is the national Mechanical Engineering Honors Society. We pride ourselves in connecting our members with faculty, industrial contacts, and other ME students as well as helping out in the community, all the while having fun.

name: Pickleball at Berkeley
description: Pickleball at Berkeley is a competitive pickleball team. We hope to play recreationally, practice, and challenge other college pickleball clubs.
summary: Pickleball at Berkeley aims to create a inclusive space for anyone interested in pickleball. We will promote camaraderie and an active lifestyle with recreational practices, friendly tournaments, and competitions with other college pickleball clubs.

name: Pickleball for Cool Grads Club
summary: The purpose of our pickleball club is to foster a vibrant and inclusive community of pickleball enthusiasts and graduate students.

name: Piedmont Consulting Group
summary: Our primary objective is to provide quality consulting services to our clients while fostering an inclusive community. We differ from other communities on campus because we emphasize inclusion and low barriers of entry.

name: Pilipino American Alliance
description:
Our Mission Statement: "In the ongoing attempt to serve and interact with the Pilipinx community, the Pilipinx American Alliance stands to promote a network of social support through the encouragement of political action, academic excellence, and cultural awareness while celebrating cultural diversity."

Our website is currently under construction. For now, you can find a central hub to all of our ongoing events and applications at the link below! 

linktr.ee/ucbpaa

In the mean time, please email any questions to paa.chair@gmail.com and follow our social media handles below to stay updated on our organization and how to get involved! Hope to see you around :)
summary: The UC Berkeley Pilipinx American Alliance is a student organization dedicated to strengthening campus solidarity by promoting cultural awareness and addressing the often unseen issues of the Pilipinx community past and present.

name: Pilipino American Graduate Student Association
description: Pilipino American Graduate Student Association (PAGaSA) aims to provide a supportive social, intellectual, & political space for Pilipino graduate students to organize for the following purposes: academic retention, community advocacy, mentorship, networking, community service, & research about Pilipino & Pilipino-American studies.
summary: Pilipino American Graduate Student Association (PAGaSA)

name: Pilipino American Law Society
description: The Pilipino American Law Society (PALS) at Berkeley Law seeks to create a supportive community for Filipino American students during their time in law school. PALS facilitates this through mentorship, social events, and professional networking. PALS welcomes all individuals, regardless of ethnic background.
summary: The Pilipino American Law Society (Berkeley Law) hopes to encourage the pursuit of a legal profession and create a supportive community with an emphasis on Pilipino American students by facilitating discourse and networking.

name: Pilipino Association for Health Careers
description:
The Pilipino Association for Health Careers started through a group of students who recognized the need for a support system among Cal pre-health students. PAHC aims to promote current health issues in and around the Pilipino community, as well as extended communities. We develop a structure of dedicated students to integrate their knowledge, experience, and skills to seek information on various health issues and careers. PAHC provides information and services to aid the Pilipino community especially and, in addition, to all who are health conscious both academically and individually.

Mission: To serve as a support group for those who are interested in health careers and to educate the community of health-related issues relative to Pilipinos and their extended communities.
summary: The Pilipino Association for Health Careers started by a group of students who recognized the need for a support system among Cal pre-health students. PAHC aims to promote current health issues relative to Pilipinos and their extended communities.

name: Pilipino Basketball Association
description: The Pilipinx Basketball Association, more canonically known as PBA, is committed to providing a relaxed environment for any and all Pil-identifying students who appreciate the passion and camaraderie that comes with playing the organized sport of basketball. Our mission is to develop meaningful relationships rooted in the sport, and we accomplish this by hosting weekly open-gym sessions, semesterly tournaments, and other seasonal events.
summary: The Pilipinx Basketball Association, is committed to providing a relaxed environment for any and all Pil-identifying students who appreciate the passion and camaraderie that comes with playing the organized sport of basketball.

name: Pilipinx Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers
description:
Our Mission: Established in 1988, the Pilipinx Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers (PASAE) serves as a close-knit support group for students in the technical fields, providing student members a space for social interaction, cultural understanding, professional guidance, and academic support.

What We Do: PASAE provides a variety of events and resources for our members. We provide a social and cultural space for students in the technical fields to cultivate connections with students of similar backgrounds and de-stress through events like PAS’Glade and Chill and PASAE’ce Skating. Professionally and academically, we provide workshops and access to our network of alumni working in industry through events like our Alumni Mixer and Gilead Panel.

Reach out to us via Instagram or email, and we hope to see you soon :)
summary: Established in 1988, the Pilipinx Association of Scientists, Architects, and Engineers (PASAE) serves as a close-knit support group for students in the technical fields, providing student members a space for professional, social and cultural connections.

name: Pioneers in Engineering
description:
PiE's mission is to create engaging STEM experiences that provide students in the East Bay with the tools, resources, guidance and inspiration to build their own future. Staff members design, build and lead a variety of programs and lessons in a project-based environment, with the goal of making things that can also inspire and educate others.

We stress mentorship and "learning by doing," which is why our flagship program is a high school robotics competition that we design, produce and host every year. We also develop hands-on lessons to bring directly to classrooms, and workshops for DIY projects or basic technical software

That's why we design, produce, and organize the competition in-house for about 20 high school teams in our community. Our vision is that everyone involved -- high school students and college mentors and staff -- have the opportunity to be both students and teachers to each other. All our STEM programs create a learning community where students have role models and resources going into the future -- and they in turn can 'pay it forward' by perpetuating this kind of philosophy.
summary: PiE creates engaging STEM experiences for students in the East Bay. Design, build and lead: produce a high school robotics competition, create hands-on lessons, and lead workshops that enable students to learn while building and having fun.

name: Plaintiffs' Law Association
description:
The Plaintiffs’ Law Association (PLA) is a student organization at Berkeley Law and an official AAJ* chapter dedicated to cultivating future plaintiff-side attorneys. We are a comprehensive resource for students interested in plaintiff-side careers–providing community support, professional guidance, and exposure to a variety of practice areas.

PLA hosts speaker events with prominent practitioners, connects students to mentors, and shares employment opportunities with current and former members. We are also committed to fostering community. We provide a space for students to support and encourage each other from day one, and engage with a robust alumni network.

More broadly, we want to dispel the myth that the only career opportunities for law students are in BigLaw, government, and the nonprofit sector. A career as a plaintiff-side lawyer is fulfilling, financially rewarding, and impactful.

We are also dedicated to making the profession accessible to underrepresented groups. That is why diversifying the plaintiffs’ bar is a priority for PLA.

Overall, the Plaintiffs’ Law Association aims to equip members with the tools, knowledge, and relationships they need to succeed as future plaintiff-side advocates.

*The American Association for Justice is the largest nonprofit organization for plaintiffs’ lawyers in the United States.
summary: PLA is dedicated to cultivating future plaintiff-side attorneys. We are a comprehensive resource for students interested in plaintiff-side careers–providing community support, professional guidance, and exposure to a variety of practice areas.

name: Planning Students Association
description:
Who are my Planning Students Association (PSA) Leaders?

Organizational Positions - January 2023 to December 2023

 

President - Nervana Fadle, nervanafadle@berkeley.edu

This person organizes the PSA meetings and makes sure that other officers and event organizers have what they need to get their jobs done. The president also meets regularly with the Department Chair and acts as a primary contact between the students and the Department on all issues including, but not limited to, course offerings, departmental operations and the PDST (also/formerly known as the PDF).

 

Vice President/Treasurer - Daniel AdrianAguinaldo, danieladrian@berkeley.edu

This person works closely with the President to keep the PSA humming through joint agenda-writing and acting as a sounding board. The officeholder also tracks the finances of the PSA, helps other officers and event organizers submit funding and reimbursement requests, and prepares funding applications to the Graduate Assembly.

 

Social Chairs -Andre Soucy and Sean Goss 

andre_soucy@berkeley.edu, ssgoss@berkeley.edu

This person is responsible for planning student involvement in the Holiday Party in the fall and the Planner Prom in the spring. The Social Chair helps out organizers of other events to manage logistics and get volunteers. The Social Chair also organizes and facilitates small, informal lunch discussions and happy hours with students and faculty members. GTKY get-togethers provide an opportunity for students and faculty to meet to discuss topics such as: planning as a career, advice for budding planners, personal experiences in the planning field, etc. Major responsibilities include: contacting professors to set up times/dates and sending out lunch announcements to the MCP current students email list.

 

Alumni Liaison - Sidrah Marotti and Keyanna Ortiz-Cedeno

sidrahmarotti@berkeley.edu, keyanna_ortizcedeno@berkeley.edu

This person works with departmental faculty, staff and students to plan for the development of a robust alumni network.  This will include facilitation of creating an alumni database and drafting of an overall plan for alumni engagement. The liaison will be the student point of contact for a large alumni event, a facilitator of smaller events, and responsible for continued upkeep of the network.

 

Communications Chair -Laurel Denyer, lrdenyer@berkeley.edu

This position oversees the Google group for incoming students, the MCP current students email list and the Planning-Announce email list.

 

Recruitment Chair - Kat Cuiffo and Nikesha Medard

kcuiffo@berkeley.edu, nikesha@berkeley.edu

This position helps the Department plan and recruit student volunteers for events targeted at prospective and incoming students, serving as a critical point of contact during this annual process. The team will work with the admissions team, keep current students informed of developments, and get to know the Department and College staff.

 

American Planning Association (APA) Rep - Angie Chen,

angiechen@berkeley.edu

This position sits on the board of the Northern California APA section, makes sure the PSA is meeting its requirements as an official student organization, and keeps the students informed of APA events.

 

CED Interdepartmental Group (CEDIG) Rep - Samuel Rodriguez and Lekshmy Hirandas

samuelrodriguez@berkeley.edu, lekshmy.hirandas@berkeley.edu

This position for DCRP stands as part of a college-wide effort to bring the four different departments within the CED out of their silos. In cooperation with the CED Graduate Student Council, the CEDIG representative advocates for and facilitates interdepartmental collaboration through workshops, seminars, peer reviews, social events, etc. These events, whether academic or social, create spaces where CED students can come together to form a stronger sense of community.

 

MCP Student-Faculty Co-Chairs - Divya Jain and Sophie Gabel-Scheinbaum

divyajain@berkeley.edu, sgabelscheinbaum@berkeley.edu

Along with the President, this position is a primary contact between the students and the Department. The job entails attending faculty meetings and curriculum-related meetings where they represent student views and takes minutes to keep students informed.  The representative should solicit broad student feedback on items needing student input. This representative is informed of all faculty meetings, regular and ad hoc, and should attend all possible.
