Graduate Assembly (GA) Reps - Aneesh Mugulur and Mallika Gupta

aneeshmugulur@berkeley.edu, mallikagupta89@berkeley.edu

The GA Rep is required to attend at one GA-wide meeting per month (Thursdays at 6pm, usually 3-4 hours) as well as participate in one committee, which typically meet 1-2 times per month. Committees include external affairs (UC lobbying, etc), environmental, etc. The GA is responsible for funding for graduate organizations (like the PSA) and is the representative for graduate student interests within and outside of the University.

 

UAW – Union Liaison - Rio Morales

riomorales@berkeley.edu

By attending monthly UAW membership meetings, the PSA Union Liaison acts as a representative of DCRP to UAW meetings and will report back on important information pertinent to DCRP graduate students. This will provide for open communication between DCRP students and the Union, ensuring PSA members are informed about labor and equity issues on campus.

 
Mutual Aid Chair - Sandra Romero
 
sandra_romero@berkeley.edu
 
This person works closely with CEDSOC and other CED student organizations to build and maintain a new program: a CED-wide lending library and mutual aid system. This program, launching in Spring 2022, will offer direct support to students with financial need, a library of reusable materials and shared space for community building activities.

 

Lounge Ambassador - N/A

contact: nervanafadle@berkeley.edu

This position is responsible for overseeing and maintaining the MCP student lounge, which includes orienting new students to the space, arranging locker distribution, organizing the cleaning schedule, and advocating for the lounge when necessary.

 

Swag Chair(s) Katie Heuser and Hillary Nguyen Pham

kheuser@berkeley.edu, hnguyenpham@berkeley.edu

This position is responsible for designing, selling and delivering DCRP swag (clothing, mugs, tote bags, etc.) to DCRP students. Funds raised from sales go back to the PSA general budget to support events.
summary: The Planning Students Association (PSA) works with graduate students, faculty, and staff in the Department of City and Regional Planning (DCRP) to support career advancement; organize social events; and represent graduate interests within the department.

name: Plant & Microbial Biology Graduate Student Group
summary: We are the representative body of the graduate students of Plant & Microbial Biology! We serve as the platform for department-wide updates on policy, Graduate Assembly meetings, faculty meetings, upcoming events, and recruitment, among other activities.

name: Plant Futures at Berkeley
description: Increasingly, young adults are recognizing the broad based potential of a plant-centric food system to (i) address the climate crisis directly and urgently, (ii) prevent and heal diet-related chronic diseases, and (iii) ease nutrition insecurity. Plant Futures Initiative aims to meet students at an opportune moment in their lives, helping them to become enlightened eaters and advocates for positive food systems transformation, and bridging education, advocacy, and right livelihood.
summary: Plant Futures is focused on accelerating the transition to plant-based food systems at the intersection of social justice, public health, and environmental sustainability by building a community around plant-based eating.

name: Planty Social
description: Planty Social is a club for all plant enthusiasts and those interested in learning about plants! No plant biology experience is required. Join us for guest speakers, plant scavenger hunts, planty crafts, field trips, and more. Follow us on Instagram and join our private Facebook group by clicking on the icons below.
summary: Planty Social brings together plant enthusiasts from all backgrounds connect with each other to learn more about plants by doing hands on activities and going on excursions.

name: PlexTech
description:
Our club's main operation is to provide software development consulting services to a broad spectrum of companies, including Atlassian, Zendesk, 100Thieves, and more. With a team of 5-6 other members, you can build a complete, high-impact product for clients in the course of a semester.

We also provide a rigorous full-stack web development curriculum to new members; this track will equip you with the skills necessary to excel in software engineering positions, including but not limited to: React, Flask, MongoDB, and Figma.

PlexTech's 50+ members are very tight-knit and we hold social events very frequently, ranging from chill hangouts to trips to Hawaii.
summary: PlexTech abides by one crucial mission: to equip motivated, ambitious, and eager students with the necessary technical skills to advance the modern technological landscape.

name: Pointe of Berkeley
description:
Pointe of Berkeley provides ballet technique training for students of all levels and identities who are interested in building a strong dance foundation without the cost. We strive to create a welcoming community that highlights and builds upon our dancers' strengths. All classes are free, drop-in, and open to everyone.

 

 

FALL 2023 CLASS SCHEDULE

  • Beginning Ballet: Tuesdays 5:30-6:30 @ Hearst Gym 230
  • Intermediate/Advanced Ballet: Wednesdays 5-6:30 @ Eshleman 240
  • All-Level Ballet: Saturdays 11am-12:30pm @ Eshleman 240

 

REGISTER FOR FALL 2023 CLASSES HERE:

https://forms.gle/Zi47CQAPPASJ9yD5A
summary: UC Berkeley's ballet club that offers free drop-in ballet classes. Inclusive to all dance abilities, genders, and backgrounds!

name: Pokemon Club at Berkeley
description:
Interested in Pokémon? The Pokémon Club at Cal strives to unite Pokémon fans in and around Berkeley.

What you can expect from the club:

  • Welcoming atmosphere for casual trading and battling
  • Official console-game tournaments, including: within the club, intercollegiate, and at regional championships
  • Online simulator tournaments: no preparation necessary!
  • Metagame discussion
  • Non-game-related activities: movies, trivia, etc.
  • And more!

Sound good? For information on meetings and events, please ask to be added to our mailing list by emailing pokemonclubcal@gmail.com, or join our discord server at https://discord.gg/jXxpc65XSt
summary: Pokémon Club at Cal connects all Pokémon enthusiasts interested in battling, trading, or just meeting fellow Pokémon lovers.

name: Poker at Berkeley
description:
Poker at Berkeley intends to bring the Poker community at Berkeley together through events, socials, and providing educational resources. Players of all skill levels are encouraged to get involved!

Members of Poker at Berkeley also teach the Introduction to Poker Decal, Stat 198. The Decal intends to take students from having little to no experience to being able to win against their friends and at most low stake games. The course focuses on understanding the probabilistic and heuristic aspects of playing effective poker.

The club serves a separate purpose from the Decal, with the Decal being intended to educate newer players while Poker at Berkeley primarily focuses on holding events. Poker at Berkeley hopes to build a strong community of players on campus through a variety of offerings to help students of all backgrounds get involved.

Poker at Berkeley understands the ethical implications of gambling. At no point during any event affiliated with Poker at Berkeley will students be required or allowed to wager real money. Poker at Berkeley further intends to provide resources for students concerned about their relationship with gambling. 

As this is our first semester of (re)activity as a club, we will primarily be working on building out a member base, fundraising, and handling logistics for future club events. Prospective offerings include:

- Speaker Series of famous players such as Bill Perkins (who spoke at last semester's Decal)

- Large-scale Berkeley Poker Tournament once per semester

- Access to club poker solver software and computing resources

- Club coaching, study groups, and hand reviews to improve at the game

- Access to poker courses and further study resources through the club

- Frequent club socials and poker events

Please contact us below if you are interested!
summary: Poker at Berkeley intends to bring the Poker community at Berkeley together through events, socials, and providing educational resources. Players of all skill levels are encouraged to get involved!

name: Police Review Project
description: The Police Review Project (PRP) focuses on holding police officers accountable, organizing grassroots community safety practices, and supporting survivors of police brutality.
summary: The Police Review Project is a UC Berkeley School of Law student pro bono project. Through the project, law students assist people who file with the Berkeley Police Review Commission complaints alleging police misconduct.

name: Policy Debate (Cal Debate)
description:
Policy Debate (Cal Debate)

The policy debate team teaches critical thinking skills and persuasive communication techniques to an elite group of students who compete at a national level. Our program trains students to debate diverse issues such as immigration reform, nuclear weapons policy, antitrust law, and global alliances.

Cal Debate is one of the most successful intercollegiate debate teams in the country; since 2000, Cal Debate has won the prestigious Copeland award for the number one ranked team in the nation three times, and has had a team in the Octafinals or farther of the National Debate Tournament for 11 of those years.
summary: The Policy Debate Team at Berkeley

name: Polish Club of Berkeley
summary: The purpose of the PCB is to celebrate and promote Polish culture at UC Berkeley.

name: Political and Election Empowerment Project
description: Voter suppression and threats to our democratic process are increasingly prevalent in the United States. The Political and Election Empowerment Project (PEEP) supports nonprofit organizations in California and across the nation fighting for voting rights and democracy reform. We focus our efforts on historically marginalized and oppressed populations, recognizing that structural racism is inherent in the systems of American democracy. Only when all citizens have equal and easy access to the polls will politicians represent community interests and the government represent the people. Over the years, PEEP students have worked towards this goal with Campaign Legal Center, Demos, and the Asian Law Caucus. Our projects have included strengthening electoral language-access, supporting redistricting efforts to better represent Asian American communities, impacting campaign finance laws, researching potential policy reforms for the voting process, and fighting for judicial election reform.
summary: The Political and Election Empowerment Project (PEEP) provides students at Berkeley Law who care about the deep connection between politics, elections, the law, and social justice with a place to learn more about these challenging issues.

name: Political Computer Science
description: Berkeley is universally known for its cutting-edge computer science research and politically-active student body, but there isn’t much overlap between the two. PCS @ Berkeley brings together students' passion for technology and governmental affairs with discussions, projects, and socials.
summary: We are a group of students interested in the intersection of politics and technology. Our club hosts a variety of projects, discussions, and socials for those who share this same interest!

name: Political Strategy at Berkeley
summary: A group of young and passionate UC Berkeley students, dedicated to bringing pro-bono political analysis and strategic consulting to candidates, campaigns, activist organizations, and ballot initiatives.

name: Popup at Berkeley
summary: Introducing Berkeley students to diverse global cuisines through the pop-up concept

name: Post-Conviction Advocacy Project, The
description:
P-CAP is a Student-Initiated Legal Services Project (SLP) whose purpose is to train Berkeley Law students to assist incarcerated people with the parole process. Students meet with their clients in teams, prepare them for their parole board hearing, and help represent them at that hearing. Students also assist clients in preparing for a life outside of prison by helping them secure stable housing and providing information on mental health or medical services that will be available to them in their communities. P-CAP may also provide opportunities for students to assist with appeals of individuals who have been denied parole by engaging in legal research and writing a habeas corpus petition.

P-CAP’s mission is justice for the thousands of men and women who may spend the rest of their lives in prison, even if they pose no threat to society. Indigent and incarcerated individuals regularly receive inadequate representation from attorneys appointed by the parole board. Student support can help ensure that these individuals are well prepared and have a fair chance at their hearing.
summary: P-CAP trains Berkeley Law students to assist incarcerated people in California with the parole process.

name: Potluck Club
description: Potluck Club aims to create a safe place for people to come together over food. In hopes of bonding over food, members will also learn about different cultures and if comfortable, share their own. A monthly potluck will provide the space for leisure and comfort through food.
summary: Potluck Club aims to create a safe place for people to come together over food. In hopes of bonding over food, members will also learn about different cultures and if comfortable, share their own.

name: Power of a Princess
description:
Power of a Princess ("POP") is a student-run organization that aims to spread magic to children in need around the Bay area and beyond. Our team of princes, princesses, superheroes, and Jedi provides storytelling, crafts, sing-alongs, Q&As with characters, and much more to bring a magical experience to children in hospitals, low-income schools, or other in need groups free of charge. Character interactions give sick or underserved children a chance to forget their worries and focus on simply being a kid.

Alongside sparking joy in children around the Bay Area, Power of a Princess brings our members together into a tight-knit community of Berkeley students that truly feels like a family. Our Ohana unites under our love of Disney and our desire to help kids in need. To join our club, you do not have to have a background in acting or the arts, although it is preferred, and you do not have to look a certain way (no one looks like the unrealistic body standards of Disney princesses)––we are dedicated to bringing a diverse, kind group of people together to do what they are passionate about! We will provide you with all necessary gear (i.e. wigs, costumes, etc.) to become your character at no cost.

We hope you will join our Ohana and look forward to reading your applications. Hakuna Matata!

Learn more about our organization here and find links to our application: linktr.ee/powerofaprincess
summary: Power of a Princess is a student-run organization that transforms volunteers into children’s characters to visit hospitals, children’s organizations, low-income schools, and any other in need groups free of charge.

name: POWER-Bay Area: Physical science Opportunities for Women in Education and Research
summary: POWER-Bay Area is a mentoring program and workshop series for Bay Area community college students and UC Berkeley transfer students interested in the physical sciences.

name: Pre-Medical Honor Society
description:
The UC Berkeley Pre-Medical Honor Society (PMHS) is an organization for hopeful pre-meds and aspiring physicians to meet health care professionals, hear from medical school representatives from across the country, talk to professors and distinguished faculty, gain unique clinical experience, and attend workshops focused on the successful navigation of the Berkeley pre-med scene. Students are invited to join our open and positive community where people can learn from their peers and share helpful advice. 

The following are a few benefits of membership:

- Medical school information sessions hosted by medical schools throughout the country

- Opportunities to shadow physicians in the Bay Area in various specialties

- Professor luncheons with club sponsors and other distinguished faculty members

- Informational sessions regarding the MCAT, resumes, interviews, and the application process

- Hefty discounts off BluePrint's MCAT course

- Opportunities to participate in a variety of club-sponsored community service activities

- Advice from past and present medical school applicants

- Medical school tours

- Mentorship from senior PMHS members and alumni

 

 

Please visit https://pmhs.berkeley.edu/ for more information.

If you are a prospective member, please complete this form: https://forms.gle/vhKmCezSBKskGtQY7
summary: To provide service for pre-medical students at Berkeley, with the specific purpose of recognizing distinguished pre-medical students who have proven themselves exceptional in the academic and campus community.

name: Pre-Nursing Society
description:
Pre-Nursing Society at Cal seeks to support all UC Berkeley Pre-Nursing students both academically and socially by providing opportunities to learn about nursing specialties, academic and career pathways, and nursing schools through guest speakers and visits to various nursing schools in the Bay Area. Pre-Nursing Society offers students a network of peers with shared motivations and provides solutions to pre-nursing challenges through social support and educational interaction. The goal of PNS is to raise student awareness and establish nursing as a critical and rewarding occupation in health care.

Learn more at www.berkeleypns.weebly.com
summary: An organization to support UC Berkeley Pre-Nursing students academically and socially with opportunities to learn more about the career and to network them with peers. PNS hopes to raise student awareness and establish nursing as a rewarding occupation.

name: Pre-PA Club at Berkeley
description: The Pre-PA Club is UC Berkeley's only club geared specifically toward the Physician Assistant path! The Pre-PA Club will offer a multitude of guest speakers from the PA field, numerous workshops to help in every aspect of the PA school application, volunteer opportunities and social events to connect with other Pre-PA students. All are welcome!
summary: By providing educational tools, Pre-PA school resources, and a space to meet other Pre-PA students, the Pre-PA Club at Berkeley aims to create a community at Cal for all students who are considering pursuing a career as a Physician Assistant.

name: Pre-Pharmacy Informational, Learning and Leadership Society
description:
The Pre-Pharmacy Informational Learning and Leadership Society (PILLS) is dedicated to assisting students interested in the field of pharmacy. As the main pre-pharmacy organization on campus, PILLS was founded in response to the lack of support and resources available to students interested in pursuing a PharmD. PILLS provides Cal Students with the information and support needed to pursue pharmacy as a career and to apply to pharmacy school. PILLS has created a variety of programs aimed at educating our fellow Cal students about the field of pharmacy. Our goal is to provide information about pharmacy and related fields, as well as opportunities to explore the field, and to guide students through the transition from UC Berkeley to pharmacy school.

** PILLS is not exclusively for pre-pharmacy students. All students regardless of if they are planning to attend pharmacy school or if they are still undecided about the field, are welcome at all events.
summary: The Pre-Pharmacy Informational Learning and Leadership Society (PILLS) is the main pre-pharmacy organization on campus and is dedicated to assisting students interested in the field of pharmacy. Students pursuing other pre-health careers are welcomed too

name: PreDental Society
description:
Our Mission

The Pre-Dental Society is the only dental oriented and registered student organization of University of California, Berkeley. We are dedicated to improving the oral health of the surrounding communities while providing professional development for our members through initiatives in education, advocacy, and ethical professional standards.

Our Commitment to Our Members

Cal PDS supports fellow students by providing a forum to address their concerns regarding preparation for dental school and the field of dentistry. We make an effort to assist our members in becoming competitive dental school applicants through educational opportunities, community service, and exposure to the dental field. Past programs sponsored by PDS include conferences, dental professional presentations, dental school tours, socials, shadowing opportunities, practice DATs resources, dental student Q-and-A panels, in addition to a growing range of other events.

Our Commitment to Our Community

Cal PDS members are greatly encouraged to participate in community service activities offered. Many of our community projects are aimed at advocating dental education as well as oral and general health in underprivileged school-aged communities around the Bay Area. Our biggest project is the Dental Education Outreach Program (DEOP), with which we strive to make a lasting difference in the community through education of our youth.
summary: The Pre-Dental Society is a registered student organization of University of California, Berkeley. We are dedicated to improving the oral health of the surrounding communities while providing professional development for our members through initiatives.

name: Privacy Law at Berkeley
description:
Privacy Law at Berkeley (formerly the Berkeley Information Privacy Law Association (BIPLA))

With members from across Berkeley Law, we track the evolution of information privacy and seek to understand its wider implications. We work at the intersection of law, technology, society, the government, and the market. We engage with scholars and practitioners, lawyers and information scientists, policy analysts and software coders, and others in the Bay Area and across the world. We strive to prepare students for careers in the field of privacy law.

PrivLAB promotes cross-disciplinary examinations of information privacy. We host talks by eminent privacy experts, write briefing notes and opinion pieces, analyze foundational and cutting-edge privacy scholarship, and promote a multifaceted and inclusive understanding of information privacy in Berkeley and beyond.
summary: PLAB promotes cross-disciplinary examinations of information privacy. We host talks by privacy experts, write briefing notes and opinion pieces, organize crypto-parties and privacy events, analyze foundational and cutting-edge privacy scholarship.

name: Pro Bonotes A Cappella
description:
Berkeley Law's a cappella group.

[Formerly known as Boalt A Capella]
summary: Berkeley Law's a cappella group.

name: Product Management Club of Berkeley Haas
summary: Help students become product leaders who drive change and embody the Haas leadership principles.

name: Product Space
description: Product Space @ Berkeley is the UC Berkeley chapter of Product Space, a nation-wide family of students who are passionate about product management. We strive to cultivate a tight-knit community of product leaders who are well-prepared to guide impactful products in industry. As an organization, we offer the fellowship program and client projects for our members who come with various levels of experience. Check us out at https://product.berkeley.edu/!
summary: Our mission is to promote an understanding of the Product Management role within the UC Berkeley community, facilitate networking and recruiting opportunities, and cultivate the product leaders of tomorrow.

name: Project Coordinator Liaison
summary: PCL

name: Project Lux at Berkeley
summary: To register student volunteers as health insurance enrollment counselors in order to help eligible but uninsured individuals register for health insurance.

name: Project Reproductive Health Justice
summary: Project Reproductive Health Justice educates, advocates, and builds a supportive community for reproductive justice.

name: Project RISHI, The Berkeley Chapter
description: Project RISHI is a non-profit organization whose mission is to promote the sustainable development and growth of rural Indian communities. In partnership with local people and social enterprises, we identify issues central to our target communities and provide the resources to implement solutions through extensive field research and on-campus initiatives.
summary: To provide for the basic, social and healthcare needs of rural Indian villages and to provide UC Berkeley undergraduates with exposure to community service, international outreach, and rural development.

name: Project Sunshine at Berkeley
description: Looking for a unique clinical experience + community service opportunity? Project Sunshine is a chapter-based organization of volunteers that brings comfort and joy to pediatric patients across the United States. Project Sunshine volunteers serve as companions to pediatric patients, and bring creative art activities (i.e. drawing and coloring) and other opportunities for social interaction and learning. Amidst the pandemic, Project Sunshine has transitioned to TelePlay, a program where you work with children via remote activities over Zoom. Project Sunshine has chapters at schools such as USC, UCLA, Harvard, Duke, and more. Please check us out if you are interested in joining the Project Sunshine chapter at UC Berkeley! You can read more about Project Sunshine at https://projectsunshine.org/
summary: Volunteer to bring joy and play to meet the psychosocial and developmental needs of pediatric patients!

name: Prytanean Women's Honor Society
description:
This group Prytanean Women's Honor Society was formerly named women in leadership - 9/3/20 IZ(PLC)

Prytanean Women’s Honor Society, founded in 1901, is the oldest collegiate women’s honor society in the United States. The founders engaged in issues relating to student health care and housing; their efforts contributed significantly to ameliorating student life on campus, notably by establishing the Tang Center, UC Berkeley’s medical clinic. The organization has since expanded to funding awards and providing support for outstanding scholarship and volunteer work on behalf of the University. Founded and actively maintained by Berkeley women, Prytanean is the emblem of high quality scholars and leaders who aim to make a difference in the world.
summary: Founded in 1901, the Prytanean Women’s Honor Society is the oldest collegiate women’s honor society in the US.  Members engage in issues relating to student health and housing; promoting women in leadership; and giving back to the Berkeley community.

name: Psi Chi
description:
We are the local chapter of the International Honors Society in Psychology. Psi Chi is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies and is an affiliate with the American Psychological Association (APA) and the Association for Psychological Science. Membership provides lifelong access to awards, grants, and research opportunities offered through the international organization. On campus, we host club meetings with professors and graduate students, Q&As, study groups, and socials.

 

Membership is open to graduates and junior/senior undergraduates who are involved in the psychology program or a related discipline and meet the minimum qualifications. 

 

Applications for the next semester are available at the beginning of each semester. Please attach an unofficial printout of your transcript with your GPA (a printout of CalCentral is fine). Payment is not due until you are accepted as a potential member. 

 

OUR WEBSITE: https://psichi.berkeley.edu

(Applications open at the beginning of each semester; updates will be posted here and on the website)
summary: Psi Chi is the International Honors Society in Psychology. Membership gives lifelong access to awards/grants/research opportunities offered through the International Organization as well as an invitation to all on-campus club meetings and events.

name: Psychedelic Science at Berkeley
description:
Psychedelic Science at Berkeley is an educational organization where students work to develop an understanding of the place that the careful use of psychedelics may have in medical, legal, and cultural contexts. Our objective is to create a space where those interested in psychedelic science can discuss recent trends in research, hold events to promote awareness and education, and help students network with professionals in this field.

Fill out this form if you are interested! https://forms.gle/S64qCQVmC27z8wGv9

and JOIN OUR DISCORD, our main hub for the club where we send out information on our events and chat - https://discord.gg/xs3Fk2P5dM
summary: Our mission is to provide students with a space to cultivate their curiosity for the expanding field of psychedelic research, therapy and policy advocacy.

name: Public Child Welfare Student Group
summary: The purpose of the Public Child Welfare Student Group (PCWSG) is foster community and collaboration between title iv-e students, students with interested in Public child welfare and faculty.

name: Public Health Advocate
description:
The Public Health Advocate (PHA) is an undergraduate publication featuring current public health issues with local, national, and international perspectives. PHA was established in 2005 along with the UC Berkeley Public Health major, and the publication has since been awarded “Best New Magazine” in 2006 and “Best News Magazine” and “Outstanding Article in a Student Publication” in 2011.

The Public Health Advocate is dedicated to giving students interested in health the opportunity for their work to be published in our print issue or our online platform. Print issues of the publication are made available to the campus community towards the culmination of every semester and are distributed locally upon request.
summary: The Public Health Advocate (PHA) is an undergraduate publication featuring current public health issues with local, national, and international perspectives. We publish a biannual journal and regular online content throughout the year on our website.

name: Public Health Law at Berkeley
summary: Engage Berkeley Law community around public health law issues and career opportunities.

name: Publications Group Category (undergraduate)  - Advised by Millicent Morris-Chaney
description:
Welcome to the LEAD Center Publication Group Community page. This Callink page is a virtual gathering place for organizations in this category to share information with each other, share goals, challenges, questions, concerns and events with each other in this virtual space. Members can discuss copyrights, how to maintain editorial boards, how to engage members who do not have an active role, and share resources regarding design. We invite you to engage in dialogue using the Callink page features described below.

 

We will also be launching a monthly virtual “Town Hall”, actual time and date TBA, where we will invite campus partners and student organizations to bring their knowledge and expertise to you in real time!

 

Membership in this page is open to anyone that is interested in this category and community. Signatories of this category are invited to join by the LEAD Center advisor AND Signatories have the ability to invite other members of their organization to this community page. Students who are not affiliated with this category can request to join this group if they are interested in this category by emailing studentorgadvising@berkeley.edu with a request to be invited to the Publication Group page roster.

 

Roster Members of the Category can post news articles to share with each other and use the Discussion feature to inform or dialogue across groups. For instructions on how to post a News Article, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How to use the News Article feature

 

Roster Members of this category can use the forms feature to create surveys or polls to get an understanding of their shared community. i.e.: what events you want to see more of; ideas for advocacy initiatives. For instructions on the forms feature, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I upload/use the Forms feature? 

 

Roster Members of the Category can create a relay that messages other signatories of this category or specific members. For instructions on how to use the message relay, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I message individual members or all organization members using the messaging tools on CalLink?

 

Roster Members of the Category can use the discussion board to post questions, ideas, concerns at this page at any time. Roster members can use their own Notification options to customize how they receive notifications from this page. For instructions on the discussion board, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I communicate with other members using the discussion board?

 

If you would like to talk to Millicent Morris-Chaney, please book an appointment at millicent.youcanbook.me
summary: Umbrella for management of the Callink Publication Organization tree

name: Puente at Berkeley
description: The purpose of Puente at Berkeley is to be a support group for academic success. Puente at Berkeley will help build leadership skills, create a purpose of drawing the community closer, as well as other educational institutions, while promoting student unity and responsibility. Puente at Berkeley will provide a safe space for Puentistas and become a home away from home.
summary: Puente at Berkeley is a support group for academic success. Puente at Berkeley will also help build leadership skills, and create a purpose of drawing the community closer, as well as other educational institutions, while promoting student unity.

name: Puerto Rico Se Levanta
description: Puerto Rico Se Levanta is a space for students of Puerto Rican descent and allies to raise awareness and support for the Island and its Hurricane recovery efforts through cultural events, speakers and service trips.
summary: Puerto Rico Se Levanta is a space for students of Puerto Rican descent and allies to raise awareness and support for the Island and its Hurricane recovery efforts through cultural events, speakers and serv

name: Punjabi Art Collective
description:
Punjabi Art Collective historically emerges from the long lineage of Punjabi art that was once produced in Punjab, disseminated, re-owned, and spread across the diaspora. In response to the lack of ownership of our historical art that exists in the West, PAC seeks to reassert and recenter Punjabi art. 

PAC was a small idea initially thought of by Tanvi Saran who met Jashdeep Dhillon whereby they distilled this idea into a zine and “Sikhs of Berkeley” in 2019. Later upon developing a relationship with Mehnaz Grewal, Punjabi Art Collective received its name and took off in 2020. In 2020 PAC hosted its first meeting, in 2022 PAC hosted its first in-person art exhibition. 

As PAC grows older we hope for our Punjabi community to continue to inform PAC history and celebrate Punjabi art.

PAC Principles

  1. No barriers of entry
  2. Zero experience necessary
  3. No art experience or art interest required
  4. Just gotta be Punjabi
summary: In response to the lack of ownership of our historical art that exists in the West, PAC seeks to reassert and recenter Punjabi art.

name: Punjabis at Berkeley
description: ‘Punjabis at Berkeley’ is aimed to be a cultural, intercultural, and interfaith organization bringing to light the culture, language, identity, and religious backgrounds of the Punjabi students at Berkeley and the greater Local community. It is aimed to promote intercultural and interfaith understanding. Punjabis worldwide may have the same culture, but religion has proved to be a drastic divide between relations. Therefore, it will promote and encourage a greater interfaith acceptance and tolerance. It hopes to foster a greater understanding of the Punjabi heritage, tradition, and culture through several lucrative events and festive celebrations. Additionally, it also aims to build a close-knit community within the organization.
summary: ‘Punjabis at Berkeley’ is aimed to be a cultural, intercultural, and interfaith organization bringing to light the culture, language, identity, and religious backgrounds of the Punjabi students at Berkeley and the greater Local community.

name: Q at Haas
description:
Q@Haas is the organization for LGBTQ+ MBA students, partners and allies at Berkeley Haas. However a community member identifies, we are proud and honored to welcome them. The mission of Q@Haas is to create a community where all LGBTQ+ people are accepted in their full identities.

We have four main GOALS to help us accomplish our mission:

  1. Connection: build and support lasting connections both within the LGBTQ+ community and with our broader community of classmates, faculty, staff, and alumni
  2. Inclusion: welcome all individuals across the spectrums of gender identity and sexual orientation 
  3. Education: raise awareness around diversity and intersectionality
  4. Development: Enhance the professional and personal development of LGBTQ+ students at Haas
summary: Q@Haas

name: Quantum Computing at Berkeley
description:
To create a community for students interested in quantum computing and also both Physics and Computer Science. To make quantum computing more accessible and to provide a platform for students, faculty, and industry to exchange ideas and knowledge. 

We do not handle memberships on Callink! Please visit our website qcb.berkeley.edu to apply to be a member or email us at contact@qcb.berkeley.edu to be added to our roster/mailing list.
summary: To create a community for students interested in quantum computing and also both Physics and Computer Science.

name: Queeks
description: Queeks is a club for Queer guys, gals, and nonbinary pals in Greek life here at Berkeley. We aim to provide a safe space for LGBT+ students to express themselves within the queer community.
summary: Queeks

name: Queer + Allied Pre-Health / Pre-Medical Association
description:
We hope to tackle LGBTQIA+ health disparities and social justice issues in medicine through outreach and education at the undergraduate level, as well as the social, professional, and academic development of our members. Five pillars define our mission: [Q]ommunity, Allyship, Philanthropy, Professional Development, and Academic Support. QAPPA welcomes anyone interested in sexual and gender minority topics! Our regular events throughout the semester include guest speakers, attending conferences, and an article-based journal club. Meetings for the Fall '23 semester will be announced shortly! Sign up for our listserv for more details! 

Check out our Linktree!

Sign up for our email listserv for events and meeting topics!
summary: Our mission is to tackle LGBTQIA+ health disparities and social justice issues in medicine through education and outreach at the undergraduate level, as well as through the social, professional, and academic development of our members.

name: Queer Alliance & Resource Center
description:
The Queer Alliance and Resource Center, formerly the Queer Resource Center and Queer Alliance, was united for the first time in 2008 by a Senate Bill written by Gregory Stevens and Senator Corey Jackson and sponsored by Senator Corey Jackson. QARC is one of UC Berkeley’s oldest student organizations, established 1969 shortly after the Stonewall Riots. 

The Queer Alliance and Resource Center is a student-run organization in charge of providing social, educational, and safe sex programming for the queer and trans community on campus, and also acts as an umbrella organization for all active queer/trans communities on campus. QARC hold bi-weekly meetings, acting as a caucus for all active queer/trans organizations on campus (as well as queer-allied organizations), taking place every other week at a time set by the Board. QARC empowers and enriches the experiences of QT+ students, faculty, and staff at UC Berkeley through advocacy, service, and engagement. 

The Queer Alliance and Resource Center also maintains 2 QARC lounges in space A15 of the Hearst Field Annex; they are safe spaces and open to all students and QT student groups, with sexual wellness, wellness and academic resources.  Our current list of resources available remotely can be found here: queer.berkeley.edu.

 

QARC would like to remind everyone to support the queer and trans (and queer-allied) groups on campus including: 

-Bear Closet

-Beyond the Binary

-Cal Queer & Asian (Cal Q&A)

-Cal Ace Space

-Student Athlete Gay-Straight Alliance (Cal SAGSA)

-De Colores / Queer Trans Latinx Collective

-Gamma Rho Lambda (GRL)

-GIA MAG

-Queer and Ally Pre-Health and Pre-Med Association (QAPPA)

-QJew (Queer and Jewish)

-Out for Business (O4B)

-Out in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (oSTEM)

-Oscar Wilde / Johnson Rivera House

-Queer Student Union (QSU)

-Queer Trans South, Southwest Asians, and North Africans at Berkeley (QTSSWANA)

-Queer Art & Fashion Show (QAFS)

-Sigma Epsilon Omega (SEO)

-T-Cal: A Transgender and Gender Non-Conforming Space at Cal

-Unity House

-Zawadi / Black QTs at Cal
summary: The Queer Alliance and Resource Center (QARC) provides social, educational, and safe sex programming for the queer community on campus. QARC also acts as an umbrella organization and caucus for all active queer and queer-allied organizations at Cal.

name: Queer and Trans Geographers of Berkeley
summary: To provide an opportunity for support, collaboration, and discussion for all queer and trans geographers and their allies at Berkeley in order to create a safe space for current and future members of the Berkeley Geography community.

name: Queer and/or Women’s Anime Association
description: Gekkou, also known as the Queer and/or Women’s Anime Association, is a social club for women, trans, and/or queer individuals who love anime, games, and other related media!
summary: Gekkou, also known as the Queer and/or Women’s Anime Association, is a social club for women, trans, and/or queer individuals who love anime, games, and other related media!

name: Queer Grads
description:
【Updated 2023 Fall】Queer Grads is a student organization that aims to provide a community for LGBTQ+ graduate students in all academic disciplines. Our main goals are: (a) to act as an information source, offering informational referrals and aid in navigating university services for LGBTQ+ students; (b) to provide an arena for activism and discussion; and (c) to provide opportunities for social networking.

Learn more about us in our Google Doc

Join our mailing list at: https://tinyurl.com/queergrads

Join our Facebook Group at: https://www.facebook.com/groups/queergrads

We also have a discord server. Join the mailing list for more information!
summary:
【Updated 2022 Spring】
Queer Grads is a student organization that aims to provide a community, an informational source, an arena for activism and discussion, and opportunities for social networking for LGBTQ+ graduate students in all academic disciplines.

name: Queer Justice Project
summary: The Queer Justice Project aids LGBTQIA+ advocacy organizations in their efforts to provide assistance to LGBTQIA+ people in their fight for equality, safety, and liberation.

name: Queering Public Health
description:
The Queering Public Health group is a space dedicated to fostering community for those who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, intersex, allies, or other identities (from here on, referred to as queer); creating a learning environment where students and faculty produce and share research that represents queer individuals and queers the norms of Public Health; and leading advocacy and service in the name of underrepresented individuals on our campus and in our broader communities.

The Queering Public Health group was formed in response to the lack of space to discuss queerness in the context of Public Health. This group is intended to fill this gap by providing a number of opportunities including social networking, research, and service for queer students and their allies interested in advancing health.
summary: Queering Public Health fosters a community for those who identify as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, questioning, intersex, allies, or other identities (from here on, referred to as queer) related to the field of Public Health.

name: Queers in Computer Science and Engineering
summary: We are a social organization that puts on events like lunches, coffee breaks, happy hours, and more to foster community among the LGBTQ+ grad students, post docs, faculty, and staff in the EECS department.

name: qui parle: Critical Humanities and Social Sciences
description: For over thirty years, qui parle has published outstanding theoretical and critical work in the humanities and social sciences. Run by an independent group of graduate students since its founding at the University of California, Berkeley, the journal aims to foster critical conversations and introduce new analytic modes by bringing together diverse scholarly and artistic voices.
summary: Twice a year Qui Parle publishes provocative articles covering a range of outstanding theoretical and critical work in the humanities and social sciences.

name: Quidditch League at Berkeley
description: Our club competes in the fast-growing, full contact, and co-ed sport known as Quidditch.  With regional, national, and international competition, players get the exclusive opportunity to travel, develop leadership skills, and compete all over the world. Our team competes in about four-six tournaments each year with the goal of qualifying for World Cup. Some of the notable tournaments include Western Cup, our regional tournament, and the Big Sweep, our match up against Stanford.  Our club welcomes anyone interested to learn more about Quidditch, make friends, and compete.  We have a traveling competitive team and a noncompetitive team.
summary: Our club competes in the fast-growing, full contact, and co-ed sport known as Quidditch.  With regional, national, and international competition, players get the exclusive opportunity to travel, develop leadership skills, and compete all over the world.

name: Quiz Bowl Club
description:
We hold buzzer-based academic question-and-answer trivia competitions that contain questions relevant to the interests of all majors and academic inclinations! Come see what we're about!

New members can get involved with our organization by emailing Rohan Venkateswaran at vrohan@berkeley.edu. We usually hold practices on Saturdays and Mondays from 8-10PM, and we're a very relaxed club that does not require anything of its members (apart from those who wish to travel for national tournaments). We compete in several college tournaments a year, including ones at Berkeley, and host multiple high school tournaments a year. Contact us if you want to compete at tournaments or learn how to help out!
summary: We facilitate participation in academic quiz competitions held at Berkeley and other universities. Everyone is welcome to join!

name: Ra-On
description:
버클리 밴드 <라온> 공식 페이지입니다.

Welcome to Berkeley's Korean Rock Band Ra-On's official page!!

We are Ra-On, the only Korean band on campus, established in 2006! We are a group of musically inclined students who are looking for a time to spend on music as a group. Our purpose is to bring performing arts of Korean culture mainly through - but not pertaining to - rock music, which is know for its difficulty of access for Koreans in the American culture. Our project every semester is to hold a two-hour concert at the end, right before dead week starts. We perform both Korean and English cover songs, write original music, and film our practices to advertise our genre, not only to the Korean community, but to all, diverse groups forming Berkeley.

Please e-mail raon.staff@gmail.com for inquiries.
summary: We are Ra-On, the only Korean Band in UC Berkeley, established in 2006.

name: Raas Ramzat
description:
UC Berkeley Raas Ramzat is Cal’s official competitive Raas/Garba team. Raas & Garba are folk styles of dance native to the Indian state of Gujarat. These dance forms originated in celebrations of the festival season of Navratri and often use props such as dandiyas. At a collegiate level, it has evolved to be a high-energy dance that draws from aspects of both South Asian and Western culture. In our last competitive years, we won 1st place at our competition in Indiana, and 2nd place at our competition in Virginia! We are proud to be a close-knit team that shares a common passion for dance and beyond. Join UCB Raas Ramzat as we take on the Raas Circuit!

 

​Check out our 2021-22 routine! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cCuJBTFHdJQ

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ucb.raasramzat/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/calraas

Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCkgR1tMDsMqAUb6LCVcJAg 

Email: ucb.raasramzat@gmail.com
summary: Raas Ramzat is Berkeley's premier competitive coed Raas and Garba dance team. Raas and Garba are folk dance styles from Gujurat, India. We hope to spread this high-energy dance form and build a valuable community of dancers and friends!

name: Radical Geographers Working Group
summary: Geography students interested in radical organizing.

name: RAKUGO Club at Berkeley
summary:
1.Celebrating and promoting the rich tradition of Japanese comedic storytelling, known as Rakugo.
2. Enhancing language proficiency and building bridges between diverse groups through Rakugo

name: Real Talk Buddies
summary: Real Talk Buddies supports undergraduate students by providing them the opportunity to receive mentorship from graduate student mentors.

name: Redefine Her Street at Berkeley
description:
***OPEN TO NEW MEMBERS IN FALL 2023***

Redefine Her Street is a growing international organization trying to create the largest women’s undergraduate finance network. We already have chapters at Swarthmore, Stanford, Mcgill, and more! Our intercollegiate network helps provide women with important educational resources and information about recruitment while also building professional relationships with Wall Street firms looking to diversify the finance pipeline. We work closely with our national board of directors who have experience working at Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, Barclays SIG, DWS, and more! 

We will meet bi-weekly to host workshops, recruitment prep, fireside chats, etc on all topics finance (Investment Banking, Asset Management, Sales & Trading, Recruiting, etc)
summary: RHS is a national organization with an intercollegiate network that provides women with educational & recruitment resources, while building professional relationships with Wall Street firms.

name: Redwoods at Haas
description: Redwoods @ Haas is dedicated to building community at Haas through enjoyment of the outdoors, increasing access to recreation by providing resources and education, and building a sense of stewardship for natural spaces.
summary: The premier MBA outdoor recreation, adventure, and stewardship society in the world. Dedicated tirelessly to expanding outdoor access, educating participants to be responsible visitors to outdoor spaces, and  building lasting friendships under the stars.

name: Reentry Advocacy Project
summary: RAP is a Student-Initiated Legal Service Project that provides Berkeley Law students the opportunity to volunteer with Root & Rebound, a non-profit legal organization dedicated to providing services for people impacted by our criminal justice system.

name: Reformed University Fellowship
description: RUF is a Christian student fellowship centered around experiencing and expressing the love of God to our classmates, our community, and our campus. No matter who you are, what you've done, or what you believe, everyone is welcome at RUF. Because grace changes everything.
summary: RUF Berkeley is a community centered around two things: experiencing and expressing the love of God.

name: Regents' and Chancellor's Scholars Association
description: The Regents’ and Chancellor’s Scholars Association (RCSA) is dedicated to fostering a community for Regents’ and Chancellor’s Scholarship recipients at the University of California, Berkeley. By hosting a diverse set of events, from alumni industry dinners to faculty game nights, RCSA provides around 900 scholars with numerous opportunities to connect with others and share vital resources. Membership is an included benefit of the scholarship, and scholars can extend their involvement by joining one of nine committees.
summary: RCSA hosts a diverse set of events, from alumni industry dinners to faculty game nights, in order to foster a community for Regents’ and Chancellor’s Scholarship recipients at the University of California, Berkeley.

name: Renters' Legal Assistance (Formerly ASUC Renters' Legal Assistance)
description:
Renters' Legal Assistance, formerly known as "ASUC Renters' Legal Assistance", was established in 1981 as a joint project of the ASUC, CALPIRG, and the Municipal Lobby to help educate tenants about their rights. Renters' Legal Assistance offers free advice to U.C. Berkeley students and the surrounding community through counseling, education, and public interest research. RLA provides in-office counseling, group counseling, phone counseling as well as workshops and seminars for the public. To aid students in asserting their rights, RLA distributes pamphlets and sample letters covering numerous topic. RLA maintains a comprehensive library containing material on housing issues and tenant's rights, current California Civil Codes, Berkeley Rent Control regulations and other housing related legal texts.

RENTERS' LEGAL ASSISTANCE INTERNSHIP PROGRAM

UC Berkeley student can apply to intern at Renters' Legal Assistance every semester. Initially, interns will familiarize themselves with California and Berkeley rent law through trainings, reading and observation. As interns become more familiar with the law, they may begin counseling clients. Interns can expect to develop skills such as public speaking, counseling, legal researching, problem solving, program development and enhanced writing skills.

Interns must hold a minimum of 4 office hours per week and attend weekly meetings. Interns must also attend a training session early in the semester and pass a written exam.

 

This group [Renters' Legal Assistance] was formerly named [ASUC Renters' Legal Assistance] - 3/15 IZ
summary: RLA offers assistance to U.C. Berkeley students and the surrounding community through counseling, educational workshops, and public interest research.

name: Representation of Asian and Pacific Islander in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering (RAPID-CEE)
summary: We aim to foster academic growth, professional development, and cultural exchange, while providing a platform for collaboration, mentorship, and support for API graduate students in CEE.

name: Reproductive Justice Project
description: The Reproductive Justice Project (“RJP”) at Berkeley Law provides legal support to attorneys working on various reproductive rights and justice issues across the country.
summary: The Reproductive Justice Project (“RJP”) at Berkeley Law provides legal support to attorneys working on various reproductive rights and justice issues across the country.

name: Republican Jewish Coalition
description: The RJC is the unique bridge between the Jewish community and Republican decision-makers. We are committed to building a strong, effective, and respected Jewish Republican voice in Washington and across the country — and with your help, we can continue this important mission.
summary: Fostering & Enhancing Ties Between the American Jewish Community & Republican Lawmakers

name: Residence Hall Assembly
description:
The Residence Hall Assembly shall maintain and improve the quality of life within the Residence Halls by:

  1. Serving as an advocacy group for student concerns with the Department of Housing and Dining Services, to the Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC), to the larger university, and to the City of Berkeley;
  2. Providing a forum for residents to communicate with each other and work together to resolve common concerns and achieve common goals;
  3. Providing resident representation on committees of the University and local community;
  4. Facilitating in the planning and execution of programs on a systemwide and local level;
  5. Initiating any activities and programs necessary and proper to ensure and improve the quality of life within the Residence Halls.
  6. Remaining non-partisan and ensuring all functions in the residence halls do not promote or oppose any political biases including, but not limited to: political parties, candidates, etc.
  7. Advocating for the best interest of the residential community through issue-specific correspondence as approved by a three-fourths majority of the Assembly on specific propositions, measures, ordinances, and laws.
summary: The Residence Hall Assembly shall act as the primary representative body for all residents at UC Berkeley and as the umbrella organization for all Hall Associations.

name: ReUSE
description:
The ReUSE Store is a campus not-for-profit thrift store run by student volunteers in the ReUSE Club. We take donations and trades of clothing and other household items from the Cal community and give them back to the community via our store. We are committed to creating a more sustainable environment through promoting reuse and making items affordable for students. Textbooks, readers, and office supplies are all free, and everything else in the store is $3 or less. Things we can’t sell or give away are donated. All proceeds go to charity and maintaining the club.

We also host various special events, such as Tie Dye during Earth Week and Super Sproul Sales. Members of committees plan and host special events. Volunteers generally help in the store for one or two hours a week when their schedule allows and receive store credit as well as first dibs on new items. Contact ucberkeleyreuse@gmail.com to schedule a training session and start volunteering!

Get involved for Fall 2023 by following our Instagram @reuseberkeley for updates and more!
summary: ReUSE is a student organization that runs the ReUSE Thrift Store in MLK, gives away free textbooks, and hosts other special events. We also manage the ReUSE Stations on campus. We are committed to creating a more sustainable environment through reuse!

name: Rhythm at Berkeley
description:
We play osu! (and other rhythm games)

join the discord: https://discord.gg/br9Ubfb

 

Rhythm at Berkeley aims to create and foster a community for people who play rhythm games, particularly focusing on the game osu! and its related gamemodes.  We host biweekly meetings and tournaments, promoting engagement within the rhythm game community at Berkeley.
summary: We play osu! (and other rhythm games)

name: Riot Games at Berkeley
description:
Through hosting a variety of open admission events, Riot Games at Berkeley (Berkeley Legends) ensures that students with any interest in League of Legends, VALORANT, and other Riot Games have a place to create relationships, thus diversifying the quality of life at Berkeley.

Find out more at our Discord, or email us at berkeleyleagueoflegends@gmail.com.
summary: Riot Games at Berkeley aims to unite the community of League of Legends, VALORANT, and other Riot Games enthusiasts on the UC Berkeley campus. It aims to bring together players of all skill levels and seeks to foster and promote friendships between them.

name: RoboBears
description: RoboBears is a competitive combat robotics organization where we design, build and compete combat robots against top Universities. We are dedicated to teaching how to design and manufacture robots from scratch with the intent of competing in our main event each Spring: UC Berkeley's Combat Robotics Competition. We welcome everyone of any major and any experience level. Join our team and experience the thrill of building combat robots!
summary: RoboBears is UC Berkeley's premier robotics club specializing in competitive combat robotics.

name: Rocket League at Berkeley
description:
Rocket League at Berkeley is here to create a community for Rocket League players at Berkeley. Come join if you enjoy the game of Rocket League and want to play with Berkeley friends, are new to the game and want to improve, or are experienced in the game and want to learn more about playing competitively. We will host weekly Rocket League nights as well as fun events with all our members!

Join our discord!: https://discord.gg/XqhevzG6qa

Interest form:  https://forms.gle/BuTr8JbeR8NPKy2R6
summary: Rocket League at Berkeley is here to create a community for Rocket League players at Berkeley.

name: Romanians at Berkeley
summary: We celebrate Romanian culture and unite Romanians at UC Berkeley, no matter from how near or far we’ve come. By fostering lasting friendships through shared Romanian cultural understanding, we aim to make Berkeley feel like home.

name: Room One Thousand
description: Room One Thousand is dedicated to representing a variety of disciplines in contemporary architectural discourse by producing and selling an annual journal.
summary: Room One Thousand is dedicated to interdisciplinary research and discourse around the topic of architecture.

name: Rubik's Cube Club at Berkeley
description: Video
summary: Dedicated to the development of novel problem-solving approaches to Rubik's cubes and educating community members about them. Teaches two DeCal classes (https://cube.berkeley.edu/decal.html), and runs official competitions year-round.

name: Russian Speaking Student Association
description: The Russian Speaking Student Association (RSSA) is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that strives to highlight the culture and traditions of the Russian-speaking community on our campus. If you are interested in expanding your knowledge of Russian/Eastern European/Central Asian history, culture, and the Russian language by participating in educational and fun social activities, our student organization is the place for you. Speaking fluent Russian is not necessary - everyone is welcome to join us!
summary: The Russian Speaking Student Association (RSSA) is a student-run organization at UC Berkeley that strives to highlight the culture and traditions of the Russian-speaking community on our campus. Follow us on Instagram to learn more!

name: SAAS (Student Association for Applied Statistics) [Formerly SAAS]
description:
We are a community of UC Berkeley students with a shared interest in data science. We offer consulting projects, workshops, resources, and professional events.

 

We strive to foster an inclusive community for students at UC Berkeley with an interest in applied statistics. Through hands-on learning opportunities, we hope to equip our members with the confidence and technical skills needed for a successful transition from academic to post-graduate life. Our internal events provide opportunities for members to build relationships with like-minded peers through both friendship and mentorship, and our external events allow members to connect with faculty, companies, and other campus organizations.
summary: We are an organization of students from various academic disciplines who share a passion for statistics and data science. We offer a community of resources, workshops, professional events, and research and consulting projects.

name: SACNAS for Graduate Students at Berkeley
description:
We are the graduate division of the official SACNAS chapter at the University of California, Berkeley. SACNAS fosters the success of Hispanic/Chicano and Native American scientists – from college students to professionals – to attain advanced degrees, careers, and positions of leadership in science.

We share the goals and values of SACNAS, striving to meet them through our various outreach activities. Our chapter seeks to improve recruitment, retention, and success of students underrepresented in STEM fields. We welcome all students who share our goals, no matter their background.

Please see our website:

Berkeley SACNAS – A graduate student organization at UC Berkeley (wordpress.com)
summary: To promote the recruitment, retention, and success of underrepresented minorities in science. We attend the annual SACNAS conference; organize fellowship workshops,  career and mentoring events, social hours; and volunteer for recruitment events.

name: Sage Mentorship Project, The
description:
The Sage Mentorship Project is a one-on-one mentorship organization created to address the major

disconnect between tutoring and mentoring programs. The program is meant to build “real”

connections, which with consistent time and effort by the mentors, will turn into powerful

relationships. The program’s ultimate goal is to provide youth with a personal connection to

mentors through academic and extracurricular activities in order to foster life skills and personal

growth.

Sage matches hundreds of committed UC Berkeley students to an elementary school-aged mentee each year. Our mission is to provide youth from the ten Berkeley, El Cerrito, and Oakland elementary schools we reach with a personal connection to mentors through academic and extracurricular activities in order to foster life skills and personal growth. 

Every semester, The Sage DeCal is offered to all mentors and is worth 1 unit. The classroom and mentoring portions of the class each run concurrently all the way through the semester, allowing the students to directly apply lessons learned in the classroom and utilize the classroom as a resource for issues that come up while mentoring. This course offers UC Berkeley students a unique opportunity to critically engage in the theory and practice of working with the youths in our community. This course will teach what it takes to be an effective mentor, tutor, and big brother or sister for

their mentee. By the end of this course, students will be able to:

1. Develop the skills to forge strong personal relationships with the youths in our community

2. Think critically about the theory and practice of working with children

3. Learn and use pedagogical methods relevant to elementary age students

4. Recognize the potential legal and ethical boundaries a mentor must navigate

5. Apply team-building and leadership training to collaborate on a group project
summary: The mission of the Sage Mentorship Project is to provide youth with a personal connection to mentors through academic and extracurricular activities in order to foster life skills and personal growth.

name: Sahaara at Berkeley
description:
Human trafficking is a crisis that affects millions of people around the world, with South Asia standing near the top as a major hub for trafficked individuals.

The silent nature of trafficking is what allows it to thrive all over the globe today. Sex trafficking is modern slavery and a horrific violation of basic human dignity.

The goal of Sahaara at Berkeley is to raise awareness about the growing issue of sex trafficking across the globe and to raise money for major organizations in South Asia and the Bay Area. We also hope to educate our local community and volunteer our time in the future!

Committee/General Member App for Fall 2023: https://forms.gle/BV4B32kZth3MWaWRA

Instagram: @berkeleysahaara
summary: Sahaara at Berkeley is an organization that focuses on raising funds for and awareness of anti-trafficking efforts in South Asia and the Bay Area.

name: Salsa at Cal
description:
Salsa at Cal is a group of university students who would like to spread their appreciation and knowledge of Salsa and other Latin dances to students on campus. We host dance events, trips to local clubs, and FREE classes in Salsa and other styles. We've taught everything from Rueda Cubana and Bachata, but our main focus is on Salsa.

We teach a weekly series of beginner and intermediate classes in Hearst Gym as part of our for-credit DeCal course for students only. Dancers of all levels--from complete beginners looking to learn for the first time, to seasoned Salseres just looking for a fun crowd to dance with--are welcome in our classes and events, and no partner is required. 

Be on the lookout for upcoming community events including "Open Práctica", Salsa on Sproul and other social dancing opportunities! More info can be found on our instagram: @Salsaatcalberkeley
summary: A club hoping to spread the fun of salsa dance. We offer free beginner classes, and hold free social dancing events on campus.

name: Saudi Arabian Association at Berkeley
summary: The Saudi Arabian Association at Berkeley provides its members a community that expresses Saudi culture and traditions.  It also creates a strong network among Saudi UC Berkeley students and alumni.

name: SBC Strategy Consulting [Formerly known as Seed Base Consulting]
description:
SBC Strategy Consulting is a premier student-run management consulting agency that provides business solutions to clients of all growth stages, ranging from seed to Fortune 500 companies. Our members are selected carefully to create a diverse pool of top talent with various academic backgrounds from UC Berkeley. We are on a mission to catalyze student growth and client impact. Our organization aims to provide every member with the unique experience of collaborating with a wide range of clients and delivering insightful research and data-backed recommendations across a multitude of industries. These semester-long engagements are dedicated to creating measurable impact for our clients and members.

[Formerly known as Seed Base Consulting]
summary: SBC provides business solutions to international and local companies of all stages and helps them achieve product-market fit through market research and budgeting, and provides real consulting experience for Berkeley students.

name: Scholars of Finance
summary: Scholars of Finance is a nonprofit organization dedicated to developing undergrad finance students into the next generation of highly capable financial executives - who will act and lead with integrity and a commitment to serving the greater good.

name: School of Education Graduate Coalition (formerly known as GSESA)
description:
The School of Education Graduate Coalition is a graduate student group in the Berkeley School of Education (BSE). We are a standing body of graduate students dedicated to advocating for the interests of graduate students within the BSE. Our primary purposes are:

  1. to advocate for a more democratic BSE,
  2. to serve as a centralized point of communication between BSE (faculty and administration) and the graduate student body,
  3. to ensure that graduate students are included as key stakeholders in decisions and processes within the BSE, and to select students to serve on BSE committees,
  4. to serve as a forum for graduate student concerns, and
  5. advocate for equitable representation and treatment for diverse groups of students, paying special attention to: race, immigration status, gender, sexuality, student parent status, language, religion, ability and access, socioeconomic status, academic discipline, and research interests.

Our secondary purposes are:

  1. to encourage interdisciplinary and collaborative research,
  2. to build community within the BSE, and
  3. to organize department-wide student academic/professional opportunities.

School of Education Graduate Coalition name changed from Graduate School of Education Student Association 3/19/22 - MMC
summary: The School of Education Graduate Coalition is a graduate student group in the Berkeley School of Education. We are a standing body of graduate students dedicated to advocating for the interests of graduate students within the BSE.

name: School of Public Health Student Government
description: With the firm belief that student participation in the University of California, Berkeley (UCB) School of Public Health (SPH) is important in improving the quality of student life and representing students in decision making processes, the students of the UCB SPH hereby create this Constitution which shall be the bylaws of the School of Public Health Student Government (SPHSG) of the University of California.
summary: The University of California, Berkeley (UCB) School of Public Health (SPH) Student Government strives to work with administration to improve the quality of student life and represent students in decision making processes.

name: Science Fiction and Fantasy Short Story Workshop
description:
Do you like science fiction? Do you like fantasy? Do you like to read, or write, or interact with others who have similar interests? If you said yes to any of those questions, you are more than welcome to join the Science Fiction and Fantasy Writing Workshop.

 

We specialize in wacky writing warm-ups, writing contests, attempted NaNoWriMos, and workshopping stories in constructive and insightful ways. We accept all sorts here - whether you like time travel, dragons, space, castles, demons, ghosts, it doesn't matter what you write as long as you're passionate about it.

Do you have a story you want to workshop? Then drop on by. Do you want to practice your writing skills but can't dedicate more than an hour a week to do so? Us too, so come and join! Do you want a good de-stresser during midterms and crazy work weeks? This club was designed to do just that. We are a club that doesn't take attendance all that seriously - if you want to come for a meeting, we are happy to have you, and if you stay every week, then all the better.  

In short, we are a club filled with members who love science fiction and fantasy in all forms. If you share those interests, you'll fit right in.
summary:
Science Fiction and Fantasy Writing Workshop
We write and workshop stories. New members always welcome.
For more info, join our mailing list: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeYojuXGiX1XehkXZjtg17Xx0n9qR6MHxRG2eVWWC4YgeNWUA/viewform

name: Science Leadership and Management
summary: SLAM, a program for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the sciences, fosters and supports the development of effective leadership and management skills for individuals seeking to reach their full potential in a variety of career paths.

name: Science Olympiad at Berkeley
description: BSO organizes volunteers from the Berkeley community for an annual Science Olympiad Invitational at Berkeley. We also strive to play an active role in our local community through outreach initiatives.
summary: BSO organizes members of the Berkeley community to volunteer at an annual Science Olympiad invitational tournament at Berkeley. We strive to play an active role in supporting Science Olympiad at the high school level and fostering a scientific spirit.

name: Science Policy Group at Berkeley
description:
The Science Policy Group at Berkeley is an organization of UC Berkeley students across all disciplines that strive to actively engage and participate in the intersection of science and policy. Goals of SPG include: increase conversation among students and the campus community at large on science policy issues; enable students to advocate for science and evidence-based policies at the local, state, and national level; provide educational and professional development opportunities for students to become strong advocates for science now and in their future careers; support and advocate for strong federal funding for science, technology, and engineering.

Join our mailing list at sciencepolicy.berkeley.edu/subscribe.
summary: SPG at Berkeley is an organization of UC Berkeley students across all disciplines that strive to actively engage and participate in the intersection of science and policy.

name: SCUBA at Berkeley
description: We extend a warm welcome to all members of the Berkeley academic community - students, faculty, and staff - to join Scuba at Berkeley, a recognized student organization (RSO) dedicated to the thrilling world of scuba diving and ocean conservation. Whether you're an experienced diver or a curious enthusiast, our inclusive community offers unforgettable experiences with monthly excursions to Monterey's captivating waters, special club discounts, and opportunities to forge lasting connections with like-minded dive buddies. No prior certification is required, as we believe in nurturing newcomers to earn their first SCUBA certifications. Take the plunge and dive into a world of exploration, camaraderie, and a shared commitment to marine conservation with Scuba at Berkeley!
summary: SCUBA @ Berkeley is the only student organization on campus dedicated to students that have an interest in scuba diving.

name: SDG Undergraduate Research Group
description:
SDG Undergraduate Research Group is an undergraduate research group affiliated with the UC Berkeley Office of Sustainability and guided by the UN Sustainable Development Goals. We strive to research local cross-cutting issues, empower undergraduate voices, and increase the accessibility of research on campus. Researchers will join working groups that tackle an area of sustainability tied to the UN SDGs  that interests them, contribute to a collaborative research report, and present their findings to key stakeholders.

To learn more about SURG, check out linktr.ee/surg.berkeley and get connected to our Instagram and website!

 

This group [SDG Undergraduate Research Group] was formerly named [Students for Environmental Advocacy and Global University Leadership on Sustainability] - 9/9/20 IZ
summary: SDG Undergraduate Research Group is an undergraduate research group affiliated with the UC Berkeley Office of Sustainability and guided by the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

name: SEAONC at Berkeley
description: SEAONC at Berkeley is a graduate student organization committed to connecting students in the Structural Engineering, Mechanics, and Materials program with relevant, professional, and academic resources. Primarily, SEAONC at Berkeley sets students up for success in their studies (whether it be the Master’s program or pHD track) and beyond. We aim to facilitate mentoring programs with industry professionals, organize office visits with local workplaces, and coordinate other opportunities (like study groups, seminars, workshops, etc.) for students to feel more confident learning the challenging, structural engineering material and entering the workforce. We also work closely with the Civil and Environmental Engineering Department to accomplish these goals, and offer support/feedback to improve the graduate program for future years. This organization’s specific goals of bettering the SEMM program are unique and increase students’ opportunities beyond the graduate curriculum.
summary: SEAONC at Berkeley will be an organization committed to connecting graduate students in the Structural Engineering, Mechanics, & Materials program with relevant, professional, academic resources.

name: SEEDS: Strategies for Ecology, Education, Diversity, and Sustainability
description:
