SEEDS is a chapter of the national SEEDS program established by the Ecological Society of America. The purpose of this club is to promote accessible opportunities in the field of ecology for underrepresented students at the University of California, Berkeley. We seek to diversify ecology by engaging students interested in the field with hands-on experiences with science. We provide students with opportunities to interact with a diverse group of their peers and ecologists to deepen students’ understanding of the science as well as future career options.

Examples of what we do:

1. Graduate student or faculty panels to showcase cutting-edge research and the diversity of ecology

2. Field trips and educational opportunities for Berkeley students to learn more about the field from top experts 

3. Volunteer projects to promote ecological principles and sustainability in our community

4. Research and job opportunities, networking, and professional development resources

5. Support and social community of like-minded peers at Berkeley
summary: SEEDS is a student group committed to increasing diversity and opportunities for underrepresented students to engage with the field of ecology. We are a chapter of the national SEEDS program of the Ecological Society of America (ESA).

name: Self-Supporting Graduate Professional Degree Programs
description: Per GA Resolution #2209D, this page supports the working group for Self-Supporting Graduate Professional Degree Programs AKA SSGPDP working group
summary: Per GA Resolution #2209D, this page supports the working group for Self-Supporting Graduate Professional Degree Programs AKA SSGPDP working group

name: SEMM DSR
description: SEMM DSR is a graduate student organization committed to building community among doctoral students and researchers (DSRs) in the Structural Engineering, Mechanics, and Materials (SEMM) program of the Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE) department at UC Berkeley. DSRs include MS students with the goal of including research in their graduate work, students on the PhD track, post-doctoral researchers, and visiting scholars. Prior to the formation of this group, there have been no distinct avenues towards connection or peer support among DSRs. To amend this deficit, SEMM DSR aims to establish four initiatives: (1) Connection Forum, (2) Community Events, (3) Industry Information Sessions, and (4) Research Facility Upkeep.
summary: Build community among doctoral students and researchers (DSRs) in the Structural Engineering, Mechanics, and Materials (SEMM) program of the Civil and Environmental Engineering (CEE) department at UC Berkeley.

name: Service Group Category (undergraduate) - Advised by Millicent Morris Chaney
description:
Welcome to the LEAD Center Service Group Community page. This Callink page is a virtual gathering place for organizations in this category to share information with each other, share goals, challenges, questions, concerns and events with each other in this virtual space. We invite you to engage in dialogue using the Callink page features described below.

 

We will also be launching a monthly virtual “Town Hall”, actual time and date TBA, where we will invite campus partners and student organizations to bring their knowledge and expertise to you in real time!

 

Membership in this page is open to anyone that is interested in this category and community. Signatories of this category are invited to join by the LEAD Center advisor AND Signatories have the ability to invite other members of their organization to this community page. Students who are not affiliated with this category can request to join this group if they are interested in this category by emailing studentorgadvising@berkeley.edu with a request to be invited to the Service Group page roster.

 

Roster Members of the Category can post news articles to share with each other and use the Discussion feature to inform or dialogue across groups. For instructions on how to post a News Article, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How to use the News Article feature

 

Roster Members of this category can use the forms feature to create surveys or polls to get an understanding of their shared community. i.e.: what events you want to see more of; ideas for advocacy initiatives. For instructions on the forms feature, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I upload/use the Forms feature? 

 

Roster Members of the Category can create a relay that messages other signatories of this category or specific members. For instructions on how to use the message relay, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I message individual members or all organization members using the messaging tools on CalLink?

 

Roster Members of the Category can use the discussion board to post questions, ideas, concerns at this page at any time. Roster members can use their own Notification options to customize how they receive notifications from this page. For instructions on the discussion board, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I communicate with other members using the discussion board?

 

If you would like to talk to Millicent Morris-Chaney, please book an appointment at millicent.youcanbook.me
summary: Parent group for all organizations advised by this category advisor. (formerly used as asuc sponsored service groups)

name: Sexual Orientation & Gender Advocacy (GA Project)
description:
The Sexual Orientation and Gender Advocacy Project (SOGA) seeks to improve the lives and experiences of queer and gender-diverse graduate students at UC Berkeley. SOGA works closely with other GA projects to initiate outreach targeting graduate queer and gender-diverse students at UC Berkeley. Additionally, this coordinator serves as an advocate for queer and gender-diverse graduate students, addressing specific needs and concerns of the community to ensure their success in higher education and beyond.

If you are interested in getting involved, contact the SOGA Project Director at sogaga@berkeley.edu
summary: SOGA

name: Sigma Alpha Nu
description:
Sigma Alpha Nu is Cal's premier co-ed pre-law fraternity. Our fraternity offers its members a chance to explore the intricate field of law with the support of its tight-knit community. As a member, you will learn to polish your basic professional skills, such as interviewing and speaking in a way that allows your unique voice to shine. Members will also be prepared for applying to law school as well as a future career in the field. Sigma Alpha Nu connects members with law professors, judges, and attorneys on a personal basis, leading to exclusive internships in the field of law. Join us at our rush events to meet our members and learn more about the fraternity!

Fall 2023 Rush Details will posted on our platforms very soon! 

Instagram: @sigmaalphanu

Website: www.calsan.org

 

Rush Events:

MEET THE CHAPTER - Tuesday, September 5, 8-9 pm, Wheeler 130 (yes, MTC is in a different room than the other events!)
LEGAL NIGHT - Thursday, September 7, 8-9 pm, Wheeler 30
PROFESSIONAL NIGHT - Monday, September 11, 8-9 pm, Wheeler 30
SOCIAL NIGHT - Wednesday, September 13, 8-9 pm, Wheeler 30

*All events will be held in-person from 8-9pm in Wheeler Hall.

Applications for Fall 2023 will be due Thursday, September 14 at 11:59pm at calsan.org
summary: Sigma Alpha Nu is a co-ed pre-law fraternity created to help its members become competitive law school applicants and successful members of the profession.

name: Sigma Chi
description:
Please visit CalSigmachi.org for more information on the Alpha Beta Chapter of Sigma Chi. 

Sigma Chi is a brotherhood with roots in the collegiate experience that cultivates a lifelong commitment to strive to achieve true friendship, equal justice and the fulfillment of learning as part of our overall responsibilities to the broader communities in which we live. Sigma Chi best serves this purpose by developing, implementing and monitoring programs that foster leadership, build character and promote positive relationship skills that, in turn, enable our members to become productive and caring participants in their families, colleges and communities.

Moreover, Sigma Chi offers a host of social life rewards, but it does so in the context of molding good character within its members. Integrity, sound judgment and loyalty are all lofty goals that can occasionally be found contradictory to the impulses of collegiate life. Our fraternity provides a medium for character development that assists young men in developing the qualities of their character. Our direct input in developing American leaders is so thorough that on June 13, 2005, Sigma Chi was the first Greek-letter society to be honored by the United States Congress for the fraternity's 150th anniversary.

The Alpha Beta Chapter here at the University of California, Berkeley was the first Sigma Chi chapter to be founded on the West Coast. Started in 1886 with the help of former Confederate General Harry St. John Dixon, our fraternity expanded to all corners of the United States. In 1913, the fraternity moved into its current location on the corner of College and Channing. The house is a block away from the biggest dining hall at Cal, Crossroads, and only two blocks away from campus. Currently, our chapter consists of 50 members, 22 of which live in.
summary: Sigma Chi is a character building organization that serves to provide a community and brotherhood for motivated students at Berkeley, focusing on the ideals of friendship, justice, and learning. For more information please visit calsigmachi.org.

name: Sigma Epsilon Omega
description:
Sigma Epsilon Omega (SEO), UC Berkeley’s only queer fraternity, provides students of all genders a unique opportunity to be included in a safe space focused around respect, community, and acceptance. Founded by three students at UC Berkeley, SEO has continued to break barriers and stereotypes of both the queer and Greek communities.

SEO recently celebrated its ten year anniversary, and we already have incredible accomplishments under our belt. While SEO started in 2007 with an alpha class of 23 brothers, we now have over 130 siblings, both current students and alumni, challenging norms and succeeding in their fields around the world.

As siblings, we aim to improve our community by getting involved in various philanthropy and activism events by raising money, creating awareness, and participating in volunteer work. We seek to foster and maintain a siblinghood that is based on individual and collective strength, equality, and opportunity. We strive to provide an exciting and vibrant social space specifically for queer, trans, and gay folks.

If you have questions about us, please email president@sigmaepsilonomega.org and we'll be happy to answer.
summary: Sigma Epsilon Omega (SEO), UC Berkeley’s only gay and queer fraternity, is a siblinghood, inclusive of all genders. We endeavor to create a familial, supportive community that queer and trans students can call home while they navigate Cal and beyond.

name: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc.
description: Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc. was founded on November 12, 1922 on the campus of Butler University in Indianapolis, Indiana by seven accomplished community-driven young educators. They believed that the self-respect, knowledge and discipline gained through study would help individuals to recognize their duty and responsibility for their society. Founded on the precept of education, Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority, Inc., as a leading national service organization, continues to meet the challenges of the day, promoting and encouraging high scholastic attainment, and continues to grow through Sisterhood, Scholarship and Service.
summary: Beta Psi Chapter's aim is to enhance the quality of life for individuals within and around Northern California (East Bay), through public service, leadership development and education of youth.

name: Sigma Mu Delta
description:
Sigma Mu Delta is a premedical fraternity which promotes the advancement of premedical students through three principles deeply valued by our brothers: brotherhood, education and dedication. It is through these pillars that the fraternity members work together towards obtaining the primary goal of admission into medical school, while simultaneously helping to shape the physicians of tomorrow.

Sigma Mu Delta fulfills these goals of the premedical student through our rapidly growing alumni network, rich peer advising, and supportive brotherhood. We help our brothers achieve their true potential during their undergraduate years at University of California – Berkeley with resources ranging from our exclusive test bank to our partnership with The Princeton Review. In the past few years, our brothers have gone on to top-tier medical schools including Harvard Medical School, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Stanford School of Medicine, UCSF Medical School, etc.

 

 

Our members help the community through service events for organizations such as the American Cancer Society’s Relay for Life, Berkeley’s Alzheimer’s Center, and Glide Memorial Church. Members of this chapter work at Seed of Health, a non-profit organization aiming to build and support clinics in under-served communities, globally, such as Ethiopia. Finally, we offer sponsored professional events to help both actives and non-actives understand the premedical process, bringing the premedical community at Berkeley closer to fulfilling their dreams.

Sigma Mu Delta’s affiliate chapters are the Alpha Chapter at UC – Davis and the Gamma chapter at UC – Santa Cruz. In addition, Sigma Mu Delta partners with Kappa Gamma Delta – Epsilon chapter for social events, professional events, and volunteer opportunities.
summary: The mission of Sigma Mu Delta is to unify pre-medical students in a brotherhood dedicated to academic excellence. Sigma Mu Delta's foundation is based on the principles of brotherhood, education, and dedication.

name: Sigma Nu
description:
Our Mission:

To develop ethical leaders inspired by the principles of Love, Honor, and Truth.

To foster the personal growth of each man’s mind, heart, and character.

To perpetuate lifelong friendships and commitment to the Fraternity.
summary: Founded in 1868, the Beta Psi chapter of Sigma Nu Fraternity aims to excel with honor in all aspects of life. We develop ethical leaders inspired by the principles of Love, Honor, and Truth.

name: Sigma Omicron Pi
description:
The sisterhood of Sigma Omicron Pi was established at San Francisco State University in 1930 by ten Asian American women: Elizabeth Hall, Frances Hall, Dorothy Lau, Gertrude Lee, Hannah Lee, Louise Lee, Fannie Lim, Nancy Lim, Emma Lum, and Beatrice Ng, pursuing the interest of teaching. They chose the Greek letters, Sigma, Omicron, and Pi to represent themselves as the "Sisters of Pedagogy." The Constitution was derived from an existing "Honorary Society of Education." 

     The sorority was active in the Asian Community for the next fifteen years. At the advent of World War II, the organization was forced to become inactive. In 1946, a group of women from the University of California, Berkeley re-established Sigma Omicron Pi on their campus. Since its inception, Sigma Omicron Pi has grown in membership with student chapters at: 

Beta Chapter: San Francisco State University, 1988

Gamma Chapter: San Jose State University, 1992

Delta Chapter: University of California, Davis, 1993

Epsilon Chapter: California State University, Sacramento, 1993

Zeta Chapter: University of California, Santa Cruz, 1995

Eta Chapter: University of Maryland, 1997, retired 2000

Theta Chapter: University of California, Irvine, 2001

Iota Chapter: Pennsylvania State University, 2001

Kappa Chapter: University of California, San Diego, 2002

Lambda Chapter: The Johns Hopkins University, 2002

Mu Chapter: University of California, Riverside, 2003

Nu Chapter: Binghamton University, State University of New York, 2008

     Though the sorority no longer centered around the interest of teaching, it still maintained its commitment to the Asian American community. All of the chapters became extremely involved in their respective communities, volunteering their time at community agencies and raising money to donate to favorable charities. Sigma Omicron Pi earned a respectable reputation as a benefactor to the Asian American cause.

     The purpose of Sigma Omicron Pi is to promote unity, lifelong friendships, leadership, and community service. This organization offers women a supportive network of sisters to achieve academic and social growth. The sisterhood of Sigma Omicron Pi provides an environment where sisters may utilize and develop their organizational skills.

     Each one of our sisters has different interests and aspirations, yet we all share one common ground - SOPi. We have based our sisterhood on four objectives: UNITY, FRIENDSHIP, LEADERSHIP and SERVICE. In addition, Sigma Omicron Pi has a tradition of lifelong friendship that has prevailed for over eight decades.
summary: The sisterhood of Sigma Omicron Pi, established in 1930, is the first national Asian American Interest sorority. SOPi remains dedicated to its four objectives of unity, friendship, leadership, and service.

name: Sigma Pi
description:
We pride ourselves on being one of UC Berkeley's most active and diverse social fraternities, and look forward to meeting the future brothers of Sigma Pi. Come out, meet the brothers, see what we're about, enjoy yourself, and see if we're the right house for you!

As a brother of Sigma Pi, you’ll forge some of the best friendships and deepest social connections you’ll ever make. From pals to shoot hoops with to lifelong companions and business partners, the connections established here form easily and last for a college tenure and beyond. In addition, we pride ourselves on taking active leadership roles in our community and fully committing ourselves to our academic and extracurricular passions. We frequently enjoy social events with sororities, both participate in and host a variety of philanthropy and community service events, and regularly host highly anticipated social events such as Galaxy. As a house full of outgoing and self-motivated individuals focused on making the most out of our Cal experience, we welcome like-minded men who share our social and academic vigor.

Our house is incredibly diverse—From Haas to EECS majors to presidents of clubs, our brothers are involved in a huge variety of academic and extracurricular endeavors at Berkeley. Brothers of Sigma Pi are highly collaborative and the brotherhood will be a terrific resource in helping you work towards achieving your academic and career goals.

The commitment our house has to both extracurricular and academic excellence is exemplified in recent graduates of our chapter, who have gone on to work for companies such as J.P. Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Tesla, etc.


The Sigma Pi Fraternity house is located on 2434 Warring St, Berkeley, CA 94704.
summary: We pride ourselves on being one of UC Berkeley's most active and diverse social fraternities, and look forward to meeting the future brothers of Sigma Pi!

name: Sigma Pi Alpha Sorority, Inc.
description:
Sigma Pi Alpha is a Chicanx/Latinx based Sorority. It was founded in the Spring of 1996 at the University of California,  Berkeley by nine women who saw the need to create a close network of Chicanx/Latinxs who want to make a difference in the community, starting with themselves. Sigma Pi Alpha addresses the academic, cultural, communal, and social needs of its members.
 
For ourselves, we are a sisterhood of academic and personal support, trust, and understanding. We base our work on our three pillars of Campus Involvement (includes Academics), Community Service, and Sisterhood. For our campus, we sponsor informative and social activities. We support our fellow Latinx and Multicultural Greek organizations and network with other campus resources and groups. For our community, our priority is to promote higher education through mentoring, tutoring, scholarships, and to support Chicanx/Latinx youth. Most importantly, we support Chicana/Latina youth and address many community issues. 
 
We uphold our following seven goals: 
1. To enhance Chicana/Latina heritage within the sorority.
2. To be involved within campus and our communities.
3. To promote higher education in future generations.
4. To address academics, sisterhood, and personal and individual needs.
5. To create a sisterhood in which we can communicate and express ourselves with trust and security.
6. To form a sisterhood where we can receive support and a commitment that will last a lifetime.
7. To follow a code of conduct representative to us as a sorority and as Chicana/Latina women.
summary: Sigma Pi Alpha Sorority, Inc. is a Chicana/Latina Sorority. It was founded on May 2nd, 1996 at Berkeley by nine women who saw the need to create a close network of Latinas who wanted to make a difference in their communities starting with themselves.

name: Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc.
description:
Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Inc. is a progressive and multicultural, Asian-interest Greek Organization that provides a means to success and support for womxn, particularly womxn of color. The sorority builds on the unity of strong and independent leaders to affect change in our organization, our campuses, and our local communities. Sigma Psi Zeta is an official partner of It's On Us, the White House Initiative to end sexual assault on college campuses.

We aim to be a community of pioneers and innovators offering opportunities for womxn to develop professional and interpersonal skills in service of education, cultural awareness, and our national philanthropy.


The Alpha Iota Chapter of Sigma Psi Zeta was established on October 25, 2014 by a group of nine womxn. We are part of the Multicultural Greek Council (MCGC). We strive to build a sisterhood that is rooted on the principle of trust and to establish an organization that would continue to have a positive effect on the community for generations to come.
summary: Sigma Psi Zeta Sorority, Incorporated is a multicultural, Asian-interest Greek Organization that strives to promote unity among womxn and the awareness of Asian culture and heritages.

name: Sikh Law Association of Berkeley
description: The purpose of this organization is to create a network of Sikh undergraduate prelaw students across campus. Our organization aims to connect Sikh prelaw students at UC Berkeley with Sikh lawyers and Sikh law students in order to help students to gain resources to help them through their legal experiences. Additionally, our organization works with Sikh lawyers to host legal clinics across the bay area in order to provide free legal consultations for the Sikh community regarding issues such as immigration, domestic abuse, and worker rights.
summary: Our organization aims to create a network of Sikh prelaw undergraduate students and connect Sikh prelaw students at UC Berkeley with Sikh lawyers and Sikh law students.

name: Singapore Student Association
description:
The SSA is a community of Singaporeans and students interested in Singapore culture. We organize activities for leisure and recreation like trips into SF, freshman BBQs and retreats, cultural celebrations like annual Chinese New Year dinners and National Day celebrations, as well as networking and professional events, linking students with companies offering internships and recruiting opportunities in both Singapore and the United States. For the past few years, we have worked hard to increase the student body's awareness of Singapore, brought students together and given a sense of home for many Singaporeans abroad. We continue to aim to be an inclusive and open organization sensitive to the Berkeley and Singaporean community.

(formerly Singapore Malaysia Student Association)
summary: The Singapore Student Association is a community of Singaporeans and students interested in Singapore culture providing a closely knit yet open community which preserves Singaporean heritage, spreads awareness and connects members to their roots.

name: Skateboarding at Berkeley
summary: At UC Berkeley's only skateboarding organization, we provide a space and community for skateboarders of any level to progress in themselves as an athlete and as a student.

name: Ski and Snowboard Team at Berkeley
description:
The Ski and Snowboard Team at Berkeley is a group of skiers and snowboarders from the University of California, Berkeley.

We compete in the NorCal conference of USCSA (United States Collegiate Ski and Snowboard Association) against Stanford, UC Davis, University of Nevada, and Sierra Nevada College among others. We have both men's and women's teams in Alpine ski and snowboard racing, ski and snowboard Freestyle, and Skier-X and Boarder-X. We have sent individual competitors and teams to USCSA Nationals competitions around the country.

We do not require potential members to try out or have prior competitive experience--instead, potential members should be skiers or snowboarders who are passionate about their sport and enjoy spending time in the mountains.

We hire expert ski and snowboard coaches every season and everyone improves tremendously. Competition and training is a large part of what we do, but there is plenty of time for freeskiing and earning gnar points.

We get season passes every year; for 2022-23 we will be getting a discounted Ikon pass in order to ski primarily at Palisades Tahoe/Alpine Meadows. Many members travel to Tahoe each weekend during the ski season, so getting up to the mountains is very accessible. 

In the Fall we prepare for the season with optional dryland workouts and social events to get to know everybody on the team and stay in shape during the off-season. During the last two weeks of winter break, we will all live in Tahoe and ski early every day and have the times of our lives.

Cal Ski Team #1. Keeping Tahoe Blue and Gold.
summary: We are a group of skiers and snowboarders who are passionate about our sport. The team competes in both race and freestyle events in the USCSA for men's and women's skiing and snowboarding. We also work to improve our free-skiing and riding.

name: SKY Campus Happiness Club at Berkeley
description:
SKY at Berkeley aims to build a community of empowered college students and promote wellness in the face of stress and uncertainty. Through evidence-based meditation, creative expression, and social connection, we support students as they explore their relationships with mindfulness, happiness, and themselves. SKY does not force a belief system; our goal is to promote the formation of open and non-judgemental spaces where wellness is explored together. 

SKY at Berkeley offers the SKY Happiness Retreat, a comprehensive well-being and resilience program designed to help students, faculty, and staff achieve their fullest potential. The cornerstone practices of our programs include the SKY Breath Meditation, whose effects have been studied in open and randomized controlled trials, both in healthy populations and in those with psychopathology.

SKY at Berkeley also offers the Step Out of Overdrive DeCal, which features the SKY Happiness Retreat, through the UC Berkeley Psychology Department.

We host game nights, art therapy sessions, meditation events, yoga gatherings, and organize service initiatives to improve ourselves and our community. 

Email us at club@skyhappiness.berkeley.edu for more info and check out our instagram @skyberkeley!

Come join us on our mission to put a smile on every person’s face :)
summary: SKY at Berkeley uses evidence-based breathwork and service-oriented leadership to decrease student stress and increase happiness. By improving the clarity of the mind, we support students as they aim to conduct themselves with greater purpose.

name: Smart Ass, The
description: The Smart Ass is a campus forum for progressive issues and public policy concerns with a mixture of news, humor, features, commentary, satire, and analysis.
summary: Come join the Smart Ass team this semester and become part of one of the best-named publications on campus! We work with the Cal Berkeley Democrats to publish progressive pieces on current events in politics.

name: Smash At Berkeley
description: We are a Smash community on campus that hosts tournaments and other Smash-related events! We welcome everyone interested in Super Smash Bros., whether you play Melee or Ultimate, whether you're looking to compete or play casually and hang out. Please join our Discord (https://discord.gg/G7RmUGG) and follow us on Twitter (@smashatberkeley) to stay updated with our events!
summary: The purpose of this club is to bring together and create a solidified Smash community on campus, expand our presence through crew battles and tournaments, and provide a welcoming environment for people to learn and play a game rich with history.

name: Social Welfare Association for the Greater Good
description:
1) To exemplify social work values such as service, social justice, integrity, and the importance of human relationships through volunteerism and advocacy throughout the community.

2) To enhance the experience of social welfare undergraduates by connecting students with each other, the campus, and the larger community.

3) To become a liaison between UC Berkeley students and the social welfare community through  sponsoring charity fundraising, guest speakers, advocacy and lobbying events as well as promoting and educating about the profession of social welfare.
summary: Social Welfare Association for the Greater Good seeks to exemplify social work values such as service, social justice, integrity, and the importance of human relationships through volunteerism and advocacy throughout the community.

name: Society for Conservation Biology Berkeley Chapter
description:
The SCB Berkeley Chapter is a professional organization with over 200 members composed of Bay Area grad students, undergraduates, and professionals. We were founded at UC-Berkeley in 1997.

Our mission is to promote scientific research, dialogue, and policy awareness on matters related to the conservation of biological diversity, and to connect students with conservation professionals and activists in the Bay Area through networking events, seminars, workshops, and volunteer opportunities.

Our chapter engages in a range of activities on and off campus to provide members with hands-on conservation experience and professional development opportunities. These activities include:

  • Field trips and networking events with local agencies, NGOs and universities
  • ‘Meeting Conservation’ seminar series, connecting conservation professionals with students on campus
  • Professional development workshops 
  • Bay wetland restoration
  • Forums to discuss local conservation biology controversies
  • Regional conservation conferences

 

KEYWORDS:

environment

ecology

sustainability 

networking 

conservation 

community 

empowerment
summary: We promote scientific research, dialogue, and policy awareness on matters related to the conservation of biological diversity. We connect students with conservation professionals in the Bay Area through seminars, workshops, & networking events.

name: Society for the Study of Modern Visual Culture at Berkeley
description: Genshiken, short for "Gendai Shikaku Bunka Kenkyuu Kai" (Society for the Study of Modern Visual Culture) is a social club dedicated to Japanese visual culture.
summary: Genshiken, short for "Gendai Shikaku Bunka Kenkyuu Kai" (Society for the Study of Modern Visual Culture) is a social club dedicated to Japanese visual culture.

name: Society of Engineering Sciences
description: This is the primary social and professional group for students in the Engineering Science department (our "home base"). Check out our Linktree or shoot us an email at sesofficers@berkeley.edu to find out more!
summary: We encourage a sense of community among students in the Engineering Science discipline, advise and provide academic support to students in Engineering without a declared major, and serve as a representative of Engineering Science to the community.

name: Society of Linguistics Undergraduate Students
description: The Society of Linguistics Undergraduate Students (SLUgS) is a club that organizes social activities, guest speakers, field method simulations, living catalogs and much more for all undergraduates interested in linguistics.
summary: The Society of Linguistic Undergraduate Students (SLUgS) is a club affiliated with the department of linguistics that facilitates interaction between students interested in topics within linguistics and aims to promote linguistics on campus.

name: Society of Physics Students at Berkeley
description:
We encourage and assist students interested in physics to develop the knowledge, competence, enthusiasm, and social responsibility that are essential to the advancement of physics; stimulate interest in advanced study and research in physics; develop collegiality among physics students and faculty members; promote public interest in physics; and provide liaison between students and the member societies of the American Institute of Physics.

Anyone and everyone is welcome!
summary: The Society of Physics Students is an organization dedicated to physics-related ideas and cutting-edge research.

name: Society of Women Engineers
description:
Society of Women Engineers is an international nonprofit organization. Our objective is to encourage and empower women and non-binary students to reach their full potential as engineers. SWE strives to highlight the achievements and contributions of women and non-binary folks as leaders and engineers. Supporting both students and professionals, SWE consists of over 17,000 members in 90 sections and 300 student sections.

The UC Berkeley collegiate section has been established for over 30 years and strives to support the next generation of women and non-binary engineers by: providing professional development resources and networking opportunities to help students navigate the start of their careers; hosting socials to connect engineers with others in their area of study; organizing STEM advocacy and inclusion workshops, to encourage both women engineers and allies to fight for an equitable workplace; and leading outreach programs for local K-12 students — geared especially towards young women and underrepresented students — to help them learn more about STEM.

For any additional questions on our chapter or how to get involved, please email swe.berkeley@gmail.com or visit our website swe.berkeley.edu. You can also find more information about SWE by visiting their website swe.org.
summary: We are a multi-faceted organization, holding academic, professional, service, and social events. Everyone is welcome to attend: the only requirement is that you support women and non-binary individuals in engineering!

name: Songwriting at Berkeley
description:
We are a student group that offers songwriters, producers, musicians, and singers a space to collaborate and share their passion for music. Through weekly club meetings, regular performance events, and recording opportunities, we encourage our members to develop as artists and become a part of our music community.

How Do I Get Involved? 

Step 1: Like our Facebook Page

Step 2: Stay posted with our Mailing List, social media links (Linktree), and Google Calendar!!

Step 3: Come to any meeting, busking, or event. New members are always welcome!

Step 4: Repeat Step 3.
summary: We are a student group that offers songwriters, musicians, and singers a space to collaborate. Through weekly club meetings, regular performance events, and recording opportunities, we encourage our members to develop as artists!

name: Soon Movement
description: Our purpose is to win, build, and send. We WIN students for Christ through sharing the Gospel on campus. We then BUILD them to disciple others through small group discipleship meetings with trained SOONjangs (disciplers). Finally, we SEND them to the nations on summer missions to fulfill the Great Commission stated in Matthew 28:19 ("Therefore go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit"). This organization encourages 2nd and 3rd generation Asian American college students to be a part of the Christian movement, teaching them to be disciple-makers of Christ amongst their friends, families, communities, churches, to the ends of the earth.
summary:
WIN students by sharing the gospel on campus. 
BUILD them by helping them in their relationship with God through group and 1 on 1 discipleship meetings.
SEND students to the next place where God will grow them and win, build, and send others.

name: Soul
summary: Soul strives to raise awareness of Korean culture through, but not only limited to, singing, vocal performance, instrument performance, and other artistic exhibitions, as well as networking between other school’s performing/cultural groups.

name: South Asian Business Association
description: Our mission is to foster relationships amongst individuals in the Haas MBA community interested in South Asia, through social, cultural and professional events. We strive to unite the entire South Asian region across borders - from India, to Kazakhstan, to Sri Lanka and everywhere in between and beyond. SABA is open to all Haas MBA students and partners.
summary: Our mission is to foster strong relationships amongst individuals in the Haas MBA community interested in South Asia, through social, cultural and professional events. We strive to unite the entire South Asian region.

name: South Indian Society
summary: UCB South Indian Society aims to increase awareness about South Indian culture on campus. We serve as a venue for the celebration of South Indian culture at Berkeley.

name: Southeast Asian Mentorship
description:
Our mission statement is "to empower high school youth and mentors by utilizing academic advising and mentorship as a way of addressing political and socio-economic issues facing the Southeast Asian community; to build a two-way exchange of knowledge and resources, instilling within both mentees and mentors the power to create social change.”

Southeast Asian Mentorship academically and politically works to motivate and empower high school youth from all over the United States. We provide virtual mentorship to both college and non-college bound mentees.
summary: SEAM is a virtual mentorship program that aims to serve Southeast Asian (SEA) high school students across California/ U.S. Our goal is to foster a culturally informed community by providing the next generation with college student mentors and opportunity

name: Southeast Asian Prison Outreach Project
description: Inspired by the African American Studies Department’s Prison Pen Pal Program, a SASC member, by the name of Amy Tran, developed a similar project for the Southeast Asian community in prisons during the spring of 2009. The following semester, Larry Bach, Kristine Nguyen and Irene Van formed the first committee with Amy to execute the goals and vision of this project. From three initial contacts, the project today now connects Berkeley students and community members with over 35 incarcerated men and women.
summary: Through the power of communication, the Southeast Asian Prison Outreach Project seeks to bridge the gap between overlooked Southeast Asain communities in prison and in free society.

name: Southeast Asian Student Coalition
description:
SASC Mission Statement:

"SASC’s founding in 2000 was initially focused on the refugee experience, which aimed to unite individuals bounded by the historical context of the American Wars in Southeast Asia. We hope to continue to preserve this space of growth and inclusivity. Together, our goal is to foster a space to explore Southeast Asian American identity and culture. As a coalition, we unite and empower our communities by addressing the social injustices, economic inequalities and political under-representation that our communities may face.” 

SASC Hxstory:

In 2000, Professor Khatharya Um hosted a Southeast Asian Conference at UC Berkeley to commemorate the 25th year of the Southeast Asian diaspora after the war in Southeast Asia (more familiarly known as the Viet Nam War). She asked a few Southeast Asian UC Berkeley students in her class and some she knew to help get involved with the conference. Their role was to head up the youth portion of the conference. Using data information collected the conference Professor Um along with the UC Berkeley students developed the booklet that SASC has called A Dream Denied about Southeast Asians and their struggle to gain access to higher education.


After the conference, the youth summit organizers, consisting of members from the Laotian, Hmong, Cambodian, and Vietnamese student groups felt connected and saw a need for a space/coalition to address issues across the community. They recognized that there were distinct groups that already existed to promote cultural awareness and knew that that was not one of their primary goals. They were also aware that they wanted the group to be more than just a student organization, but a coalition between the Cambodian, Vietnamese, and Laotian students coming together on common issues to strengthen the community as a whole, hence the name Southeast Asian Student Coalition. The name was created by the students as they sat at Sproul Fountain. Their goals at the time included greater promotion of higher education, community building between the different groups, outreaching to the larger community.

At the time they believed that there was a niche that needed to be filled – an organization that would work with the different cultural groups as well as the recruitment and retention center to address the SEA community in particular. Their goal was to both build coalition as well as empowerment, and to step beyond the needs at Berkeley to incorporate the communities we came from. They went around the East Bay community asking and understanding what it is exactly that they can do. After all of that, in 2002 SASC Summer Institute was born. They wanted something where they can effectively outreach, teach, and learn to/from young people.

Since then SASC has grown into a larger community and has expanded its reaches into the community. SASC’s current programs include SEA Grad, SEAMentorship, SEA Prison Outreach Project, and Anthology.

In 2005, a group of SASC folks had multiple meetings about the rebuilding of SASC, due to issues of sustainability and finding leaders in the community. From these meetings SASCommunity, a non-hierarchical committee, was created. SASComm strives to create a community of committees hoping to explore SASC’s mission statement in different and multiple dimensions. The Round-Table structure for SASCommunity is set up to create a cohesive unit and non-hierarchical organizing system.
summary: Together, our goal is to foster a space to explore Southeast Asian American identity and culture. As a coalition, we unite and empower our communities by addressing social injustices, economic inequalities and political under-representation.

name: Space Enterprise at Berkeley
description:
Co-founded in October 2016, Space Enterprise at Berkeley (SEB) is a student run liquid-fuel rocket team dedicated to achieving spaceflight and developing rocket technologies at University of California, Berkeley.

SEB is one of the most ambitious college rocket teams in the world, with the goal of achieving spaceflight with a liquid-fueled rocket. Working toward this dream, SEB launched multiple test-bed rockets and gained a wide array of technical knowledge and skill in rocket subsystems such as composite airframe manufacturing, in-flight data acquisition, and propulsion. We currently hold the University record for speed and altitude, set by our LAD-4 testbed vehicle in March 2020.

Aside from the rocket projects, SEB takes pride in our inclusive, diverse, and friendly team culture. SEB is one of the few student organizations on campus that maintains open admission policies for interested students. This involves not screening students by resumes, majors, or specific engineering-related experiences. SEB firmly believes that these elements are not as important to becoming a contributing member of the team as pure commitment and willingness to learn new skills and have fun! The team’s pattern of also mentoring newcomers and turning them into team veterans helps to keep the organization constantly growing as a rocket team and close friends!

 

Find out more on our website, berkeleyse.org, or contact us at info@seb.berkeley.edu with questions or comments!
summary: Co-founded in October 2016, Space Enterprise at Berkeley (SEB) is a student-run liquid-fuel rocket team dedicated to achieving spaceflight and developing rocket technologies at University of California, Berkeley.

name: Space Technologies and Rocketry
description:
The goal of Space Technologies and Rocketry is to create new and innovative technologies for use in high-power  rocketry and other space-related vehicles, and enter associated competitions. 

Among our many projects, we research propulsion, develop avionics and software, and, of course, design, build, test, and fly high-power rockets out of spaceports in the Central Valley and the Mojave Desert. Another primary function of our club is hosting outreach events in the Berkeley community in order to engage children and adults in the fields of science, engineering, mathematics, and aeronautics.

This year, we will be participating in ESRA’s Intercollegiate Rocket Engineering Competition, where we will design, test, and build a high-power rocket capable of reaching an altitude of 10,000 feet.

The ultimate goal of STAR is to be successful in Rocketry competition, using that experience to send a student-designed and built rocket into space.

Check out our website at https://stars.berkeley.edu/ and our documentation at https://rocketry.gitbook.io/docs/!
summary: We are a competitive high-power rocketry team. We engineer payloads, avionics, control systems, and rocket engines. Additionally, we host local STEM outreach events and work with local companies to create a stronger aerospace community on campus.

name: Space Technologies at California
description:
Space Technologies at Cal (STAC) is a student-run engineering organization at the University of California, Berkeley with 60+ highly motivated undergraduate and graduate students focused on developing innovative space technologies and research. We are creating a collaborative student space platform, incorporating multiple research labs and industry partners, to enable research projects such as microgravity experiments, a CubeSat qualifying and testing a quantum gyroscope, an Autonomous Lunar Rover project, space bioengineering for astronaut health, and a jumping robot for exploring lunar landscapes. 

As student researchers, scientists, and engineers, we aim to push the frontier of space innovation with each of our projects and provide valuable experience for our members. With QubeSat launching to the ISS next year and TIME II launching with Blue Origin this winter, STAC is eager to send UC Berkeley to space and beyond!

 

In addition to innovating and working on cool projects, STAC is committed to energizing the UC Berkeley aerospace community. In 2022, we hosted the third Space Tech Symposium @ Berkeley, with over 200 attendees from all corners of the Bay Area space community. Our events' past speakers have included CEOs and Co-founders of companies like Planet, Astra, Google's Project Loon, Astranis, NASA and UC Berkeley researchers, and investors from venture capital firms. We're committed to continuing our annual tradition of bringing together the best and brightest in space.
summary: We are advancing the frontier of student space exploration at UC Berkeley through team-based projects focused on satellite fabrication, lunar rover and robot prototyping, and microgravity and bioengineering experimentation for space applications.

name: SpaceForm
description: SpaceForm is an organization committed to expanding the frontiers of materials and structures within the aerospace field. Researching, ideating, and building innovative solutions at the forefront of the aerospace industry, SpaceForm aims to promote the advancement of materials, structures, and in-space manufacturing through cutting-edge projects and industry collaborations.
summary: SpaceForm is a student organization committed to expanding the frontiers of materials, structures, and manufacturing within the aerospace field.

name: Spare a Pair at Berkeley
description:
Spare a Pair is a volunteer organization dedicated to providing Berkeley’s homeless population with socks and sneakers through fundraisers and donations. We strive to help the less fortunate get back on their feet - one pair at a time!

 

Don’t know what to do with your unwanted shoes? Spare a Pair serves as a liaison between the Berkeley community and the homeless population who lack essential footwear. We look to work closely with donation centers and volunteer organizations to help create easy access to shoes for individuals in need. Students, staff, and all members of the Berkeley community are invited to join us in the cause!
summary: Spare a Pair is a volunteer organization dedicated to providing Berkeley’s homeless population with sneakers through fundraisers and donations. We strive to help the less fortunate get back on their feet - one pair at a time!

name: Speak Out Now (formerly Students for Social Change)
description: We are a group of students and revolutionary socialists who want to take activism beyond the campus. By reading, discussing, and organizing events, we can deepen our understanding of the world we live in and gain a critical perspective on the tactics and strategies for changing society today.
summary: We are a revolutionary socialist student group at Berkeley! We host events and organize for a free, democratic society based on the needs of people, not the profits of a few! To learn more, follow our instagram and DM us at @sonberkeley.

name: Speaker Series: India at Berkeley
description: The vision of Speaker Series: India at Berkeley is to engage with the rich Indian cultural fabric and tackle the most pressing issues facing the Indian society at large through facilitating conversation at Berkeley
summary: We are a team of students dedicated to creating a community of social, political and economic awareness of the connections that exist between the two countries: India and the United States of America.

name: Spectrum: Autism at Cal
description: Our mission is to foster and promote an inclusive campus community, and a safe space for autistic students. We raise awareness and acceptance throughout the Berkeley community, offer a variety of volunteer opportunities, and hold fundraising events and monthly meetings. We also aim to educate students about Autism Spectrum Disorder and debunk misconceptions, in part by spotlighting autistic advocates.
summary: We aim to raise acceptance of and awareness about ASD, provide local volunteering opportunities, fundraise, and create an inclusive environment and a safe space for all. Our org is dedicated to autistic and neurodivergent students and non-autistic allies

name: Speech at Berkeley
description:
Speech at Berkeley, formerly a part of Speech and Debate at Berkeley, now utilizes only the "speech" aspect of "speech and debate." We are a student-run, peer-coached team of speech enthusisasts committed to bettering ourselves through competition in collegiate speech events. We offer members the opportunity to perform all 11 AFA-sponsored events competitively at local and national tournaments. We meet weekly to construct and practice our speeches (including those with limited preparation) and attend multiple tournaments throughout the academic year, including the prestigious American Forensics Association's National Individual Events Tournament.

There are no auditions to be on our team--all that is required to join is enthusiasm to learn the practical skills that come with learning how to perform in a speech event. We are an awesome, strong, competitive team, consistently taking home individual and team sweepstakes awards at tournaments. As we do have limited resources and this activity is a big time commitment, we ask that our members show their own dedication, diligence, and discipline. If you have what it takes, you will find this activity incredibly rewarding. As one Speech at Berkeley member said, "Getting good at speech is basically cheating for school, in that it prepares you to think really critically, really well, really fast."

 

Students can join the discord at https://discord.gg/Q9DEWHRfuB for more information.
summary: We compete in the 11 AFA-sponsored speech events at speech competitions hosted by colleges on the local and national level. Our competitive team seeks to push the envelope of research, performance, and rhetorical skill.

name: SPICMACAY at Berkeley
description: Purpose: Society for Promotion of Indian Classical Music And Culture Amongst Youth (SPICMACAY) at Berkeley is dedicated to preserving and cultivating an appreciation for the rich and varied cultural heritage of South Asia. Through the mediums of classical music, folk and traditional dance, craftsmanship, yoga, meditation, cinema, theater, and enlightening discussions, we strive to spark and nurture a profound cultural awakening among today's youth. We achieve this through direct engagement with esteemed artistic pioneers.
summary: Purpose: Society for Promotion of Indian Classical Music And Culture Amongst Youth (SPICMACAY) at Berkeley seeks to conserve and promote an awareness of the rich and diverse cultural tapestry of South Asia.

name: Spiritual Organizations Category (undergraduate) - Advised by Millicent Morris Chaney
description:
Welcome to the LEAD Center Spiritual Group Community page. This Callink page is a virtual gathering place for organizations in this category to build an interfaith community, share information with each other, share goals, challenges, questions, concerns and events with each other in this virtual space. We invite you to engage in dialogue using the Callink page features described below.

 

We will also be launching a monthly virtual “Town Hall”, actual time and date TBA, where we will invite campus partners and student organizations to bring their knowledge and expertise to you in real time!

 

Membership in this page is open to anyone that is interested in this category and community. Signatories of this category are invited to join by the LEAD Center advisor AND Signatories have the ability to invite other members of their organization to this community page. Students who are not affiliated with this category can request to join this group if they are interested in this category by emailing studentorgadvising@berkeley.edu with a request to be invited to the Spiritual Group page roster.

 

Roster Members of the Category can post news articles to share with each other and use the Discussion feature to inform or dialogue across groups. For instructions on how to post a News Article, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How to use the News Article feature

 

Roster Members of this category can use the forms feature to create surveys or polls to get an understanding of their shared community. i.e.: what events you want to see more of; ideas for advocacy initiatives. For instructions on the forms feature, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I upload/use the Forms feature? 

 

Roster Members of the Category can create a relay that messages other signatories of this category or specific members. For instructions on how to use the message relay, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I message individual members or all organization members using the messaging tools on CalLink?

 

Roster Members of the Category can use the discussion board to post questions, ideas, concerns at this page at any time. Roster members can use their own Notification options to customize how they receive notifications from this page. For instructions on the discussion board, see the Callink User Guide FAQ at Q: How do I communicate with other members using the discussion board?

 

If you would like to talk to Millicent Morris-Chaney, please book an appointment at millicent.youcanbook.me
summary: Parent organization for Spiritual organizations advised by Millicent Morris Chaney

name: Splash at Berkeley
description:
A Splash program is an educational event that brings local high school and middle school students to UC Berkeley for one day of for-student-by-student learning. Students who come take classes of their choice from a wide selection of both conventional and unconventional subjects taught by Berkeley undergraduate and graduate students.

If you would like to get involved, please visit our webpage for more information https://berkeley.learningu.org/teach/splash.html. If you make a teacher account on our webpage, you will be informed about all Splash related events.
summary: Splash at Berkeley hosts educational events that bring local high school and middle school students to UC Berkeley for one day of for-student-by-student learning, with short classes in conventional and unconventional subjects taught by Berkeley students.

name: Splatoon at Berkeley
description: Splatoon at Berkeley offers players of all skill levels the opportunity to meet other students who share a passion for Splatoon! We provide opportunities for all players to compete in collegiate tournaments and leagues. Our goal is to establish Splatoon as an official esport at Berkeley.
summary: We aim to gather and assemble a Splatoon community within the UC Berkeley community. We want to welcome all people interested in Splatoon and provide a learning environment for all members, including beginners and veterans.

name: Spoon University at Berkeley
description: Spoon University at Berkeley is a college-flavored online publication centered on food content of all article types—from restaurant reviews to kitchen tips and recipes. We strive to be the resource that Cal students with any amount of experience in the kitchen turn to when they crave food-related guidance or inspiration.
summary: Spoon University at Berkeley is an on-campus online publication that creates weekly food articles and host several food-related events throughout the semester. Our publication will give students a way to share, learn, and teach each other about food.

name: Sports Analytics Group at Berkeley
description:
Analytics and data science are taking over every part of the billion-dollar sports world. Major sports teams, agencies, and media outlets alike have begun revolutionizing their decision-making strategies across all parts of the industry - not just in how the game is played and how teams are built, but also now touching on everything from biomechanics to brand health. The Sports Analytics Group at Berkeley aims to give members learning and practical experience doing sports analytics work wherever it interests them within our three divisions: Projects, Business, and Data Journalism.

The Projects division works on sports strategy consulting projects for professional and collegiate sports organizations, teams, and agencies. Whether its predicting free agent contracts or visualizing baseball player swings, SAGB Projects continues to explore ways to revolutionize sports through data.

The Business division works with the business departments of professional sports organizations from around the country - helping teams with a variety of operational tasks such as ticketing, marketing, and overall brand development. Working with teams such as the Red Sox and Clippers, SAGB Business has grown extensively over the past few years in size and scope, and has continuously given members the opportunity to grow and experience what it is really like in the business side of professional sports.

The Data Journalism division discusses trending topics in the sports world using evidence backed by analytics and statistics. Visit our website sportsanalytics.berkeley.edu to see some of the articles and podcasts that our members have published.

Stay tuned to our Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, and website (sportsanalytics.berkeley.edu) for any news and updates regarding our application, upcoming infosessions, and other events we'll be hosting throughout the semester. If you have any other questions, feel free to reach out to us at sagberkeley@gmail.com.

Application Link: https://tinyurl.com/SAGB-applyFA23 (due September 3rd at 11:59 PM)

Upcoming Infosessions: 

- Infosession #1: 8PM-9PM Thursday, August 24th 2023, @ Wheeler 222

- Underrepresented Applicant Infosession: 8PM-9PM Monday, August 28th 2023, @ Wheeler 224

- Infosession #2: 8PM-9PM Tuesday, August 29th 2023, @ Wheeler 130

- Meet and Greet: 8PM-9PM Thursday, August 31st 2023, @ Wheeler 224
summary: The Sports Analytics Group at Berkeley educates and prepares members for careers in the field of sports analytics and to pursue sports-related research through participation in one of three divisions: Projects, Data Journalism, and Business.

name: Sports and Entertainment Law Society
description: The mission of the Sports and Entertainment Law Society (SELS) is to educate the Berkeley Law community about legal opportunities and issues in the entertainment and sports industries. SELS also strives to facilitate opportunities for students to network not only with each other, but also with legal professionals in these industries. SELS regularly sponsors many events during the academic year, including both guest lectures and social events. SELS thereby provides a resource for students to connect with alumni and other industry-leading professionals and seek employment opportunities in the sports and entertainment industries.
summary: The mission of the Sports and Entertainment Law Society (SELS) is to educate the Berkeley Law community about legal opportunities and issues in the entertainment and sports industries.

name: Sports Clubs - Berkeley Recreational Sports
description: https://recsports.berkeley.edu/programs-events/sport-clubs/
summary: Cal Sports Clubs bring together students with similar interests to participate in one of 35 competitive sports.

name: Spring Foundation
description: Spring Foundation is a nonprofit student-run organization founded in the University of California, Berkeley in 2011. We strive to improve the living standards and education accessibilities of underprivileged children in rural China. Each year, we organize fundraisers to fulfill our financial commitment and raise awareness through podcasts, forums and other events. Every summer, our members bring project-based learning to children in rural China through our annual summer camp. In the future, we hope to leverage Spring Foundation’s experience to help other college charity organizations with similar missions and develop strong cooperation through long-term sponsorships, partnerships with organizations and businesses in the Bay Area and within China.
summary: Spring Foundation is a student-run nonprofit organization at UC Berkeley dedicated to raising awareness and fund for education and healthcare of underprivileged children in rural China.

name: Standup Comedy (at Berkeley)
description: To provide UC Berkeley students with an accessible outlet to explore stand-up comedy through collaboration, mentorship, and performance opportunities.
summary: To provide UC Berkeley students with an accessible outlet to explore stand-up comedy through collaboration, mentorship, and performance opportunities.

name: Startup Law Initiative, The
description: SLI is a transactional pro bono student-initiated legal services project at Berkeley Law and connects members to law firms and diverse clients. It provides professional development opportunities for members and involves drafting formation documents under the supervision of attorneys.
summary: The Startup Law Initiative (SLI) is a pro-bono student-initiated legal services project, which provides law students hands-on transactional work experience and helps underrepresented minority startup founders overcome cost preventative barriers.

name: Statistics Graduate Students Association
summary: Our purpose is to safeguard the interests of graduate students in statistics and biostatistics, to serve as the formal link between students and faculty, and to organize social events for students or for students and faculty.

name: Steel Bridge Competition Team
description:
The Steel Bridge team is the UC Berkeley team that will be competing in the National Student Steel Bridge Competition sponsored by American Institute of Steel Construction (AISC).


We design, fabricate, and compete with a bridge that is generally around 20ft long. We teach new members how to use industry standard software such as AutoCAD, SAP2000, and SolidWorks as we design our bridge in the fall. We also train students how to use all the machinery in the Davis welding shop and give opportunities to get trained in the Etcheverry machine shop, where students can learn to use the mills and lathes. In the spring we fabricate the bridge and compete in our regional and national competitions.


For Fall 2023, please join us 6:30-7:30pm on Mondays and 6:30-7:30pm on Thursdays in Davis Hall. Please view our website at
steelbridge.berkeley.edu or email us at team@steelbridge.berkeley.edu for more information! 

 

https://youtu.be/4sGy8FKufJ0
summary: The Steel Bridge team at UC Berkeley competes every year in the AISC sponsored steel bridge competition. Our team challenges students to apply the theoretical knowledge they have obtained in their courses to a practical project.

name: STEM Ed. at Berkeley
description:
STEM Ed. at Berkeley is a nonprofit student organization dedicated to empowering and inspiring students interested in the STEM fields and those interested in broadening their academic and career horizons in the increasingly isolated and competitive environment the pandemic has brought. The organization hopes to address this gap by providing an array of STEM-related resources for all grade levels. 

 

Please fill out the STEM Ed. Interest Form to receive Info Session and Calapalooza zoom links. It should only take 2-5 minutes of your time. In addition, by filling out this form, you will receive updates and more up-to-date information regarding general member applications for the Fall 2022 semester through email. 

 

STEM Ed. Interest Form: https://forms.gle/ZUQ6UWnoMnysQceF7

  • Info Session 1 (online): 8/31 (6-7 PM)
  • Info Session 2 (online): 9/9 (7-8 PM)
  • Virtual Calapalooza (online): 9/7 (4-6 PM)
  • In-Person Calapalooza: 9/8 (3-7 PM)

 

For more information and upcoming dates, follow our page on social media! 

  • Instagram: @stemed.berkeley
  • Facebook: @StemEdOnline

 

Join STEM Ed. at Berkeley to be a part of a community of STEM enthusiasts for students by students!

 

For college students, we provide the following:

  • Resource Bank: the resource bank will be available on our website and consists of study guides, note sheets, and more created by students for the STEM classes they have taken in college. We cater to all STEM majors, so all STEM-related resources are welcome! As a general member, to gain and maintain active membership, a donation of 3 resource documents is required per semester.
  • Speaker Events: We contact and facilitate an array of speakers, both professors, and professionals, to speak on their area of expertise and engage with students in a Q&A fashion. Professional development speakers will help facilitate workshops regarding resume building, requirement tips, and advice they have to offer pertaining to the array of STEM careers. 
  • External Opportunities: This can be split into two aspects.
    • We offer listings of local and remote volunteering, research, and internship opportunities; we are aware of how many students lost their opportunities due to the pandemic and may have difficulties looking for new ones. We hope to provide listings on our websites for individuals to visit and apply. 
    • We partner with local low-income high schools and middle schools to be able to help their students bridge the gap between different school districts and their resources for STEM education. By providing mentorship, tutoring, and hosting college panels, we allow our students to share their experiences and knowledge with younger ages at these schools. 
  • Student Blogs: We believe every student should have a voice. Our website offers students the ability to submit an article of writing on the topic of choice--sometimes, we also provide prompt ideas for submission. We encourage students to write a piece on STEM topics and current research and events so that they can be published on our website!
summary: Provides accessible educational resources in STEM subjects while creating a network of students interested in broadening their academic horizons in the increasingly competitive environment. We offer speaker series, resource bank, volunteering, and more!

name: Student American Academy of Optometry
description: The UC Berkeley Optometry Chapter of SAAO reflects the values, goals, and interests of the American Academy of Optometry (AAO) at the student level by encouraging optometrists in training to maintain and enhance excellence in optometric practice. We promote the art and science of vision care while encouraging personal growth, education and active participation within the optometric community.
summary: The UC Berkeley Optometry Chapter of SAAO reflects the values, goals, and interests of the American Academy of Optometry (AAO) at the student level by encouraging optometrists in training to maintain and enhance excellence in optometric practice.

name: Student Assistance for Public Health at Berkeley
description:
Student Assistance for Public Health at Berkeley (STAPH at Berkeley) is an official student organization at UC Berkeley that provides graduate students the opportunity to gather hands-on experience and training, as well as build their professional networks, in the field of public health.

Through partnerships with state and local health agencies located throughout the Bay Area, our members are able to gain and utilize valuable skills in the various specialties of public health, including emergency response, analytical research, community health, environmental health, public health nutrition, health and social behavior, and health policy. We aim to provide two main services to local and state health agencies: 1) surge capacity during disease outbreaks and other public health emergencies, and 2) assistance with routine, non-emergency activities such as data management and analysis. This organization will further enhance the educational, career, and professional development of public health graduate students at UC Berkeley and directly serve the public health community in California.
summary: STAPH at Berkeley is a graduate student organization that serves state & local health agencies by providing surge capacity during outbreaks and other public health emergencies, and assistance with routine, non-emergency activities.

name: Student Association for Environmental Justice and Health Equity
description: We intend to investigate the science behind environmental issues impacting community health to advocate and raise awareness. We produce digital archives to collect student blogs making the research results available to the public. We partner with environmental organizations to provide learning opportunities for getting involved in community-based outreach programs such as clean-ups, monitoring efforts, and regional conservation and education events.
summary: SA-EJHE aims to empower students to connect environmental justice and health equity by investigating the science behind environmental determinants of health and advocating in fair and just practice.

name: Student Association for Fire Ecology at Berkeley
description: We are the only student group whose sole focus is wildland fire.
summary: To inspire future scientists, managers, and citizens to promote fire research, responsible management, and education by building a fire community.

name: Student Food Collective
description: We're dedicated to providing fresh, local, healthy, environmentally sustainable, and ethically produced food at affordable prices to the Berkeley campus and greater community. We seek to educate students about nutrition and food systems, empower new leaders, and train youth to work in and manage a sustainable business. Through inclusive, democratic decision-making, we operate a cooperative grocery market that promotes community-building and environmental stewardship.
summary: The Berkeley Student Food Collective works to provide healthy, sustainable, and affordable food for the East Bay community.  A volunteer-run grocery collective, the BSFC is a local hub for both leadership development and food-related education.

name: Student Nutrition Advocacy Club
description:
The Student Nutrition Advocacy Club (SNAC) is a student-run organization that works to promote nutritional awareness on the UC Berkeley campus and around the Bay Area.

 

SNAC is a resource for students interested in ANY sector of the nutrition field -- personal interest or career! We provide opportunities on student nutrition projects, networking events, academic assistance, and (remote) volunteer and job opportunities. In the past, we've partnered with Kids in Nutrition, The LifeLong Health Center, Cal Dining, Registered Dietitians, and more. We hope to continue our cooking socials at the Cal Teaching Kitchen in the future.

 

SNAC Committees:

  1. Dietetics
  2. Outreach
  3. Digital Marketing/ Nutrition Education 

------------------------

Why Join SNAC?
• Connect with Registered Dietitians, professionals, and peers in the nutrition field
• Collaborate on student nutrition projects
• Gain skills in dietetics, teamwork, leadership, outreach, and/or marketing
• Create a warm and welcoming community at UC Berkeley

------------------------

Questions? Want to join our email list?
Contact ucbsnac@gmail.com

Find us:
Facebook: UCB Student Nutrition Advocacy Club
Instagram: @ucbsnac
LinkedIn: UCB Student Nutrition Advocacy Club
summary: The Student Nutrition Advocacy Club (SNAC) is a student-run organization working to promote nutritional awareness around/on the UCB campus. SNAC is a resource for students interested in ANY sector of the nutrition field -- personal interest or career!

name: Student Organic Gardening Association
description:
Student Farms of Berkeley is a student-led agro-ecological association that manages a coalition of 7+ gardens on and around the UC Berkeley Campus. Student Farms of Berkeley is a transparent and non-discriminatory student-led organization that prioritizes coalition building, systematic inclusion, and equitable distribution of fruit and land through collective action and resistance. We sponsor several DeCal courses throughout the year, which focus on teaching Bay-area residents everything from basic organic garden skills to land acknowledgement. Our goal is to prioritize BI-POC/LGBTQ leadership and build alliances between marginalized community members inside and outside of the Cal community.

For more information on the organization and our gardens, check out our Instagram @BerkeleyStudentFarms.
summary: The Student Farms Berkeley coalition is a transparent and democratic student-led and community-based organization that prioritizes movement building, meaningful inclusion, and equitable distribution of food, land, and knowledge through collective action.

name: Student Parent Food Donations Program
description: The Student Parent Food Donations Program focuses on mitigating food insecurity faced by the student parent community (including students with dependents) at UC Berkeley. We understand that student parents operate at heightened stress levels due to a complex mix of academic, financial, and family responsibilities. With the primary goal of alleviating some of these stresses, and the secondary but equally important goal of supporting efforts to reduce food wastage, this program was established in 2014 to rescue over 2,000 lbs of food donated by local community grocery stores and distribute them to the student population at UC Village every week.
summary: Student Parent Food Donations Program aims to provide UC Berkeley student parents and their families with fresh and healthy food in a way that promotes community building, social justice and alleviates pressures of food insecurity among these families.

name: Student Policy Institute at Berkeley
description:
The Student Policy Institute at Berkeley is an interdisciplinary, student-led policy think tank that brings students from diverse backgrounds to get involved in the policy discussions that affect our everyday lives. We are open to all students at UC Berkeley and are most interested in helping students of any experience level grow their skills and experience in public policy.

Please feel free to visit us or email us to join or connect!
summary: The Student Policy Institute at Berkeley is an interdisciplinary, student-led policy think tank that seeks to help students and RSOs develop skills and projects in policy writing, research, and advocacy.

name: Student to Student Peer Counseling
description:
Student-to-Student Peer Counseling (SSPC) is a group of undergraduate students that offers free, confidential, one-on-one mental health counseling for other undergraduate students.

SSPC also provides workshops and participates in on campus events to promote mental health and wellness such as Stress Free Week and Suicide Awareness Week.

To become a Peer Counselor with SSPC, you must attend one of our two information sessions that take place at the beginning of each semester. Visit our website at sspc.berkeley.edu for more information or send us an email at sspcemail@gmail.com and we will get back to you ASAP.
summary:
Student-to-Student Peer Counseling offers free and confidential counseling and referrals for UC Berkeley students on a drop-in or appointment basis. 
For more information, visit our website at sspc.berkeley.edu.

name: Students for Adam Schiff
summary: Students for Adam Schiff aims to educate fellow students about Adam Schiff’s policies and advocate for his candidacy for the United States Senate. We hope to empower students to participate in the democratic process and upcoming election.

name: Students for Life at Berkeley
description:
Students for Life at Berkeley: Mission Statement

As UC Berkeley’s pro-life student group, Students for Life (BSL) recognizes the inherent and inviolable dignity of human life, from that of the unborn to that of the aged and terminally ill. We are dedicated to working within our campus and local community to put an end to abortion, embryonic stem cell research, and euthanasia.

Since BSL is based at a prestigious educational institution, we see the need to educate our community about the truths surrounding offenses against human life. To that end, we facilitate and engage in intellectual discussion on relevant issues, challenging widely held relativist assumptions on the dignity of human life, the role of individual autonomy, and society's role in protecting human life.
