We seek to engage both the minds and hearts of UC Berkeley's student population as well as those of our surrounding communities in addressing these issues. We desire to change the prevailing mindset in today's society so that it might be more receptive to a culture of life that fully recognizes the dignity of every human being.

Furthermore, we aim to form leaders that will encourage the development of a more just society grounded in the recognition of the inherent and transcendent value of human life. We seek to enter our respective professions armed with the knowledge and tools needed to uphold the dignity of life in every facet of society.

Also at the heart of BSL’s mission is its commitment to community service. We believe that socioeconomic circumstances do not justify the taking of human life, and we affirm that such difficulties can be overcome. To that end, BSL provides information to assist women facing crisis pregnancies and refers them to local crisis pregnancy centers that provide women with what they need to bring new life into the world. We also volunteer at local crisis pregnancy centers to help promote their mission to encourage the cherishing and welcoming of new life into our community.

Though the focus of our outreach is primarily local, we collaborate with other pro-life organizations from across our state and nation and are united to them by virtue of our common cause. As a member of Students for Life of America (SFLA), BSL engages in the fight for life at the state and national level. As an organization that concerns itself with matters of great public relevance, BSL strives to do everything in its capacity to shape public opinion on relevant university, state, and federal policies, as well as to influence said policies, so that these might more accurately reflect our vision for a world in which every human life is valued and protected.
summary: Students for Life at Berkeley recognizes the inherent, inviolable dignity of human life in all its forms. We are dedicated to working within our campus and local community to engage in discussion and action directed towards protecting the right to life.

name: Students for Racial justice, Inclusion, Diversity, and Equity
description:
• To provide a space for Joint Medical Program students and other allies to discuss matters related to racial justice, inclusion, diversity, and equity.

o   To provide a space for members to propose, organize, and implement interventions related to racial justice, inclusion, diversity, and equity.

o   To apply the discussions and interventions to various settings, including but not limited to the Joint Medical Program, the School of Public Health, and the larger Bay Area community.
summary: Providing a space for Joint Medical Program students and other allies to discuss matters and implement actions related to racial justice, inclusion, diversity, and equity.

name: Students for Sensible Drug Policy UC Berkeley Chapter
description:
Students for Sensible Drug Policy (SSDP) is the only international network of students dedicated to ending the war on drugs. At its heart, SSDP is a grassroots organization, led by a student-run Board of Directors. We are a network of students who are concerned about the impact drug abuse has on our communities, but who also know that the War on Drugs is failing our generation and our society. We create change by bringing young people together and creating safe spaces for students of all political and ideological stripes to have honest conversations about drugs and drug policy. 

 

Meetings will be held on the second and last Friday of the month location is subject to change so get on our email list to stay in the loop!
summary: SSDP mobilizes and empowers young people to participate in the political and social processes, pushing for sensible policies to achieve a safer and more just future, while simultaneously fighting back against counterproductive Drug War policies.

name: Students for Sexual and Reproductive Freedom
description:
Our organization will organize a community of UC Berkeley undergraduate activists who can participate in events on UC Berkeley campus and in their surrounding communities to: 

  • Take action for reproductive freedom and demand change in a post-Roe America.
  • Raise public awareness about reproductive health and rights including where people can receive abortions, STI testing, and gender-affirming care and the local law surrounding such procedures.
  • Educate young people about sexual health including issues like STIs, PrEP use, condom use, consent, safety when exploring kink, drug use, prostitution, and more.
  • Discuss the connections between reproductive health and other issues like race, LGBTQ rights, civil rights, immigration, the environment, and identity. 

Our focus on sexual health and abortion rights is vital in a time of terrifying attacks on our human rights including the recent destruction of Roe v. Wade and the wave of anti-trans legislation across the nation. Join us and take action!

The group Students for Sexual and Reproductive Freedom was formerly named Planned Parenthood GenAction at Berkeley - 10/27/23 LL
summary: We equip the UCB student body with the organization and advocacy skills necessary to lead the nation-wide reproductive and sexual rights movement and fight stigma through education campaigns, election awareness and participation, and more.

name: Students of Applied Science and Technology
summary: The community of graduate students of Applied Science and Technology.

name: Students of Color Emerging in English (Formerly Latinxs Emerging in English)
description: Students of Color Emerging in English or SOCEE (formely Latinx Emerging in English) is a student organization on campus that is geared to support students of color who are interested in literature or interested/already pursuing a degree in English. By focusing on community building and academic support through study groups, workshops, panels, and events, we hope to increase the recruitment and retention in the Undergraduate English Department at Cal.
summary: Students of Color Emerging in English or SOCEE (formely Latinx Emerging in English) is a student organization on campus that is geared to support students of color who are interested in literature or pursuing a degree in English.

name: Students of Color Environmental Collective
description:
This group is intended to be a healing space for students of color to seek refuge from white-dominated environmental and social justice spaces, to learn more about the intersections between environmental and social justice, and to raise conversation about environmental racism and justice on and off campus. If you self identify as a person of color, this is a space for you to share thoughts, experiences, ideas, and educational resources. It is also a space for venting, dialogue, and healing, as well as planning future events, organizing, and outreach.

Please be respectful of this space as existing for students of color, and of the privacy of people in our community.

Stay Up to Date on Facebook: facebook.com/SoCEnvironmentalCollective/!

Follow Our Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/scecberkeley/

Visit Our Website: https://socenvcollective.berkeley.edu
summary: Students of Color Environmental Collective centers marginalized voices in environmental and social justice movements to dismantle systems of oppression.

name: Students of Color in Public Policy
description: SCiPP's mission is to ensure the serious consideration of issues of racial and ethnic diversity in policy design. SCiPP provides a support network for students of color at the Goldman School of Public Policy (GSPP) and a forum for discussion of policy implications for people of color. The group holds a number of programmatic events throughout the year, including an annual race and policy symposium and coordinates the SCiPP Peer Advising program.
summary: SCiPP's mission is to ensure the serious consideration of issues of ethnic and racial diversity in policy design.

name: Students vs Pandemics at Berkeley
description:
Students vs Pandemics is a public health club that aims to improve communication about a different disease each year through education and outreach. Join one of our committees: Public Health Research, Supporting Houseless Populations, and Supporting Local Schools.

We are open to all majors! Follow us on Instagram @berkeleysvp or check out our website for more info: studentsvspandemics.com/berkeley-chapter!
summary: Students vs Pandemics is a public health club that aims to improve communication about a different disease each year through education and outreach.

name: Students With Direct Action Everywhere At Berkeley
description: Students With Direct Action Everywhere At Berkeley is a community of students who take direct action to stop animal cruelty and slaughter, especially cruelty and slaughter performed or funded by the University of California Berkeley.
summary: We strive to create a community of students who take direct action to stop animal cruelty and slaughter, especially cruelty and slaughter performed or funded by the University of California Berkeley.

name: Suitcase Clinic
description:
The Suitcase Clinic is a student and volunteer run organization founded by students from the UCB-UCSF Joint Medical Program (JMP) and UC Berkeley’s School of Public Health out of a desire to address the unmet needs of the city of Berkeley’s homeless and low-income population. Structured around the principles of public health, social welfare, community activism and empathy, the Suitcase Clinic currently operates three weekly multi-service drop-in centers in the city Berkeley: the General Clinic, the Women’s Clinic and the Youth Clinic. In addition to providing services, the Suitcase Clinic strives to educate students, promote health care access, engage in community organization, and support public policy efforts that address homelessness and the needs of the underserved in the local community.

The mission of the Suitcase Clinic is to promote the health and overall wellbeing of underserved individuals through service provision, cooperative learning, and collective action among community and professional volunteers, students, and participants.
summary: The Suitcase Clinic is a student and volunteer-run organization that promotes the health and overall wellbeing of homeless individuals through service provision, cooperative learning, and collective action among volunteers, professionals, and clients.

name: Surf Team at Berkeley
description:
ST@B's mission is to unite Berkeley’s surfing community through cooperative trips and events, and to provide a friendly, exciting community for students who want to surf, regardless of skill level or experience.

We plan a bunch of surf trips, NSSA Competitions, and other cool things throughout the semester. If you've never tried surfing before but want to learn, or just want to meet a cool bunch of people, then come hang out with us!
summary: ST@B's mission is to unite Berkeley’s surfing community through cooperative trips and events, and to provide a friendly, exciting community for students who want to surf, regardless of skill level or experience.

name: Surfrider Foundation Club in Berkeley
description:
We are the UC Berkeley chapter of the Surfrider Foundation, a nationally-recognized 501(c)(3) nonprofit grassroots organization dedicated to the protection and enjoyment of the world’s ocean, waves and beaches for all people, through a powerful activist network.
 
Our specific chapter works to host beach and campus cleanups with other registered student organizations, partners with Community Resources for Science with their Bay Area Scientists Inspiring Students (BASIS) program, has gotten UC Berkeley certified as the first college campus in the world with all of our dining halls registered as Ocean-Friendly Restaurants, runs a #NoSolo campaign in efforts to make UC Berkeley the first campus with 100% single-use-plastic-free social events, will soon have a Blue Water Task Force to allow us to provide critical water quality information to protect public health in the East Bay, measuring fecal indicator bacteria levels in the Berkeley Marina and comparing those results to local water quality standards.
 
We invite anyone to join our organization at any point of time in the year, no recruitment, applications, interviews, or experience required. Feel free to email us or contact us on any of our social medias to learn more about us or future events!
 
linktr.ee/calsurfrider
Join our Slack!
 
 
 
last updated 2/27/23
summary: Our mission is the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves, and beaches through a powerful activist network focused on sustainability.

name: Surge - Electric Endurance Motorcycle Team at Berkeley
summary: Our mission is to push the boundaries of electric motorcycle endurance racing, crafting cutting-edge race-quality bikes while pioneering innovative range-extending technologies for the future of electric mobility.

name: Survivor Advocacy Project
description: The Survivor Advocacy Project (SAP) builds generations of lawyers dedicated to preventing and combatting sexual assault, sexual harassment, and sexual violence. SAP provides the communities within UC Berkeley and the Bay Area with legal support aimed at empowering and supporting survivors of sexual violence. SAP instills skills of prevention, advocacy, training, empathy, cultural competency, and healing.
summary: Our mission is to explore legal avenues to support prevention, advocacy, and healing efforts related to sexual violence issues.

name: Sustainable Efforts in Environmental Design (Formerly Sustainable Environmental Designers Interacting Networking Connecting)
description:
Sustainable Efforts in Environmental Design (SEED) aims to build a strong community amongst the Sustainable Environmental Design major while creating connections in the professional field. Through community based projects, social events, and career building opportunities, one can join a community of SED majors.

This group "Sustainable Efforts in Environmental Design" was formerly named "Sustainable Environmental Designers Interacting Networking Connecting" - [9/29/21] AM
summary: Sustainable Efforts in Environmental Design (SEED) aims to build a strong community amongst the Sustainable Environmental Design major while creating connections in the professional field. Through community based projects, social events, and career build

name: Sustainable Entrepreneurship at Berkeley
description: As the world finally begins to shift toward climate neutrality, sustainability will be increasingly essential in every aspect of life — especially with regard to entrepreneurship, which will require a new level of climate consciousness to continue developing successfully and innovatively. We feel the intersections between these two sectors are drastically under-addressed, and hope to bridge the gap between sustainability and VC culture to cultivate a more interdisciplinary understanding of the present and future. By encouraging students to invest responsibly and familiarizing students with diverse aspects of the ESG space, we hope to equip students with the unique ability to consider profit and sustainability in tandem, thriving in their post-college careers.
summary: Sustainable Entrepreneurship At Berkeley is a UC Berkeley-based professional development network initiative that hopes to connect, educate, and mentor students interested in impact investing and the sustainable startup sector.

name: Sustainable Housing at California (Formerly THIMBY/Solar Decathlon)
description:
SHAC is designing and building a more sustainable world through interdisciplinary building projects focused on energy, affordability, and scalability. We work closely with professionals and our community to promote and implement equitable building development processes and informed sustainability educational programs. All of our work draws heavily from political, urban planning, architectural, systems, and engineering theory. 

 

As a student-run organization at UC Berkeley, we provide opportunities for eager learners to apply academic knowledge to hands-on projects and gain experience in cutting-edge technologies and tools. Through our projects, members of the team will gain a better understanding of design processes, sustainable technologies, construction, marketing strategies, and other valuable technical and social skills. We participate in local and international competitions (eg. The Tiny House Competition and Solar Decathlon, respectively) where team members are encouraged to deepen their knowledge on their areas of interest. 

 

Through participation in these hands-on projects, members of the team will gain a better understanding of design processes, sustainable technologies, construction, marketing strategies, and other valuable technical and social skills, all the while gaining real world experience. By applying this knowledge to the creation of highly efficient houses that rely entirely on renewable energy sources, students will have the opportunity to convert abstract concepts into a tangible learning experience and product. Our projects will serve as a platform to showcase solar and renewable energy technologies in addition to contributing to an ever-broadening body of work about sustainable building practices, embodying Berkeley’s innovative spirit and leadership in the realms of sustainability, engineering, and interdisciplinary collaboration.

Check us out at shac.berkeley.edu!
summary: Sustainable Housing at California aims to design and build a more sustainable world through interdisciplinary housing projects focused on energy, affordability, and scalability.

name: Swim Club at Berkeley
description:
The Swim Club at Berkeley aims to be a fun, supportive, and competitive community for swimmers of all skill levels to practice and compete together. 

 

We provide resources and opportunities that are geared to help you enhance your swimming talents, make improvements, and achieve personal and team goals.

 

​We practice together and compete with the California Intercollegiate Swim Club Association (CISCA), regional schools including the UC's, Stanford, Cal Poly SLO, U of Oregon, U of Utah, among others. We are registered with the College Club Swimming (CCS) organization, a larger collective organization that unifies college club swim programs across the country supported by U.S. Masters Swimming. 

 

Learn more about SCB during our Spring 2024 info-sessions.

Email: swimatberk@gmail.com

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/swimatberk/?hl=en
summary: The Swim Club at Berkeley aims to be a fun, supportive, and competitive community for swimmers of all skill levels to practice and compete together.

name: T-Cal
description: Want to talk about the issues you encounter as a transgender, nonbinary, gender-non-conforming, or gender-questioning person? T-Cal is a supportive social space for students like you. T-Cal holds weekly meetings to support each other though the rough patches, celebrate the successes, and to provide a warm community space.  Further, our leadership advocates for transgender students on campus.
summary: A supportive social space for transgender & gender non-conforming students.

name: T.I.n.Y. Chinese Theatre Group
description: We provide an environment for students interested in Chinese performing arts to gather and explore various types of Chinese performing arts, especially in the field of Chinese drama, short film and Chinese song writing. We aim at building a platform for self-expression in the form of Chinese performing arts. We also offer customized event-organizing service and other activities to help external clubs, organizations and individuals in various aspects.
summary:
Non-profit and non-political student organization
Produce Chinese dramas, short films and Chinese songs
Provide customized event-organizing service

name: Taiwanese American Student Association
description:
The Taiwanese American Student Association (TASA) is a social and cultural student organization that promotes the integration of Taiwanese and American culture! We aim to create a community that both celebrates Taiwanese culture and fosters an environment that welcomes students from all cultural backgrounds who are interested in all-things Taiwanese or share any interest in the culture! Every semester, we hold biweekly events on Thursdays from 7-9 PM or 8-10 PM PST and host a variety of other opportunities throughout each semester, ranging from different family events to big/little pairings!

 

To learn more about our organization, check out our website at tasa.berkeley.edu and browse through our photo gallery to get a glimpse of our community/events!

 

Be sure to follow our Instagram, where we post all of our announcements, updates, and upcoming events! Also, follow our Facebook page and join our Discord server to get to know the community better throughout the semester:

 

‣ Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/tasa.berkeley/

‣ Discord: https://discord.gg/XYRacvEGTx

‣ Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/tasa.berkeley

‣ Mailing List: https://berkeley.us6.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=9eec0da79b013380e34061d39&id=38d3c5d02c

‣ To get even more involved with TASA, join one of our families this semester by submitting the family preference form on the website: https://tasa.berkeley.edu/join

 

We hope to see you around! :)
summary: To promote Taiwanese American culture and identity to Berkeley and build a strong community of Taiwanese Americans through social, cultural, community service, and professional networking events.

name: Taiwanese Student Association
description: The purpose of this non-profit organization is to promote general understanding of Taiwanese culture within the student body. Through our events we strive to provide an environment where students from different ethnic backgrounds can come together to appreciate and learn from each other. There are many Taiwanese students in U.C. Berkeley who have just come to the U.S., and it is also one of our main objectives to provide guidance and resources for these students to adapt well to college life here.
summary: The purpose of this non-profit organization is to promote understanding of Taiwanese culture. We strive to provide an environment where students from various backgrounds can bond, and where Taiwanese students can find themselves a platform to adapt.

name: TAMID Group
description:
Join UC Berkeley’s Chapter of TAMID consulting!

During your time as an undergraduate student, finding an experience that positively impacts both your education and social life is essential in optimizing your college experience. Whether you have any experience or not, joining a professional club can be a highlight of your four years. 

At TAMID at UC Berkeley, our members have the incredible opportunity to gain 

  1. Hands on TECH AND BUSINESS CONSULTING experiences working with CEOs and high level executives of fast growing startups on our consulting track
  2. Work experience through an ALL EXPENSES PAID SUMMER INTERNSHIP ABROAD
  3. Fundamental knowledge in financial models, stocks, etc for a FUTURE FINANCE CAREERS through our fund track
  4. A vast PROFESSIONAL NETWORK with students and alumni from 50+ UNIVERSITIES in the US and around the world 
  5. PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT through speakers, case competitions, alumni panels, interview simulations, networking, etc.

 

For more information check out our website ucbtamid.com, follow us on Instagram @tamidberkeley, and come out to our info sessions!
summary: TAMID develops the next generation of entrepreneurs and business leaders through experiential learning. Members consult for Israeli startups, manage a live investment fund, develop a professional demeanor, and possibly spend a summer interning in Israel.

name: TASSEL at Berkeley
description:
TASSEL (“Teaching And Sharing Skills to Enrich Lives”) is a U.S. 501(c)(3) public charity established in 2012. Initially TASSEL's sole activity was having U.S.-based, trained volunteers provide free English classes over video conferencing to the poor in rural Cambodia. But it has quickly evolved to include actively encouraging, recruiting, training and funding high potential Cambodian adults to become teachers as well as providing food aid, medical care access and other support services to the poorest families who have limited capabilities to earn income. 

 

In just seven years, TASSEL has grown from six U.S. volunteers, two local teachers, and 20 local children to 800 volunteers, 24 local teachers, and 2,300 local children (as of August 2019.)  Volunteers are located in the U.S., U.K., Japan, South Korea, China, Singapore, and Israel. The Cambodian teachers and children are in five rural villages in Battambang and Kampong Cham provinces.
summary: TASSEL is a non-profit organization focused on changing the lives of rural Cambodians through English education; creation of teaching jobs; food and medicine aid; and sponsorships.

name: Tau Beta Pi
description:
Tau Beta Pi is the oldest national engineering honor society in the country, and one of the most recognized national societies. Members experience a wide array of activities and opportunities throughout the year. TBP stresses scholarship, personal character, and service to the profession, community, and college. Every semester, we invite the top fifth of seniors and the top eighth of juniors from all engineering majors to join.

Professional Development

TBP provides many opportunities for students to develop their professional side while still in school. All candidates have their resume individually critiqued by TBP's professional development committee. Additionally, members' resumes are put into a resume book for our corporate sponsors. TBP also helps students hone their professional relations skills through interview workshops.

Community

Tau Bates are members for life. Tau Beta Pi offers a chance for students to work and socialize with their fellow engineers outside of a school setting and to form lasting bonds with their peers.

Fun

Tau Beta Pi loves to have fun! Throughout the semester there are over a dozen fun events to destress and have a good time. Everything from ultimate frisbee to karaoke is welcome here.

Opportunity

Joining Tau Beta Pi means becoming part of an organization that is bigger than any one person or university. With over 200 chapters, Tau Bates initiate into an active network of information and support.
summary: Tau Beta Pi, the Engineering Honor Society, is a group which supports the top students across all engineering disciplines. TBP stresses scholarship, personal character, and service to the profession, community, and college.

name: Tau Kappa Epsilon
description:
TKE Nu at Cal was created in 1919 and was the first chapter of Tau Kappa Epsilon in all of the West Coast.

Tau Kappa Epsilon Overview:
-Founded in 1899 at Illinois Wesleyan University.
-TKE is the Largest Social Fraternity in the World.
-274 Chapters Nationwide

Tau Kappa Epsilon's vision is to create lifelong relationships that enhance educational, interpersonal, community, and professional success.

Follow @caltke on Instagram. 

Go bears.
summary: TKE Nu at Cal was created in 1919 and was the first chapter of Tau Kappa Epsilon in all of the West Coast. We are diverse and driven men who strive to become better men for better world.

name: Taylor Swift Society of Berkeley
description:
We are Berkeley's only Taylor Swift fan club! We come together for karaoke nights, listening parties, general Taylor discussions, and so much more! 

Follow our instagram @swiftiesofucberkeley to receive updates, and hear about our meetings and events. You can also email us with questions at tsocberkeley@gmail.com.
summary: Our mission is to create a community for Taylor Swift fans to come together and celebrate her work and accomplishments.

name: TBD Comedy
description:
TBD Comedy is the only troupe on campus performing both longform and shortform improv as well as sketch comedy. We work together to explore the fun of improv comedy and make ourselves and other people laugh. 

Auditions & Shows
TBD holds auditions at the beginning of each fall semester. We look for dedicated and diverse members who will bring a new perspective and a friendly attitude - no prior experience in comedy or improv is necessary!

Look out for audition and show announcements on our Instagram (@tbdcomedyy)!!!

For more info visit https://linktr.ee/tbdcomedyy
summary:
Longform and shortform improv troupe at UC Berkeley

Check out audition and show info in our description!

name: Teach in Prison
description: We are a student -run collective working towards building knowledge, connecting to community, and being active in abolition/ care work. The organization consists of two main components: once a week tutors assist students inside the prison, and once a week they attend the on-campus class where they learn about the current issues affecting the California prison system. Students will learn best tutoring practices and the current state of mass incarceration and the prison industrial complex. Additionally, students study prominent issues around rehabilitation and reentry of formerly incarcerated populations. Specific issues may include the history of incarceration in the state of California and the intersections of carcerality with settler colonialism, disability, gender, queerness, race, poverty, houselessness, and more.
summary: We are a prison abolitionist student-run collective. Our DeCal involves specific topics surrounding carceral histories and apparatuses. The other component involves Cal students assisting with education programs inside of San Quentin.

name: Team Handball at Berkeley
description:
This organization is established to promote and create a community of team handball players through playing team handball and participating in several tournaments.

Also, team handball is a different sport from American handball. This sport is an indoor/ outdoor team sport with 7 members in a team and aims to throw a ball into a goal by passing and dribbling a ball using hands.
summary: Team Handball at Berkeley is the first Student Team Handball Club in Cal and in California (even Stanford has not have it). Moreover, the sport has more than 39 million players all over the world and it is still growing.

name: Tech + Social Impact
summary: The long-term vision for our organization is to create a tight-knit community that can help promote the benefits of technology and develop conversations that make use of the strong tech culture in Berkeley.

name: Tech Chair
summary: TC

name: Telegraph for People
description:
Telegraph for People is a student organization at UC Berkeley fighting for safe and vibrant streets for people in our city. Our flagship priority is making Telegraph Avenue car-free near the UC Berkeley campus (on 3 blocks from Haste to Bancroft). We want to create a vibrant public realm, more space and safety for pedestrians and cyclists, faster and more reliable public transportation, and reimagined public safety while centering equitable and radical urbanism. We proudly embrace a mobility justice centered vision, with disability and racial justice at the forefront of our work. We take an all-of-the-above approach to organizing and believe that students have the power to make real change in Berkeley if we organize and fight for our needs.

 

For Fall '23, our weekly meetings are Mondays 8-9 PM in Wurster 314B. Fill out this form if you are interested in joining: https://www.telegraphforpeople.com/take-action/become-a-member
summary: Telegraph for People wants to create a vibrant public realm, more space and safety for pedestrians and cyclists, faster and more reliable public transportation, and reimagined public safety while centering equitable and radical urbanism.

name: Tetris at Berkeley
description:
Welcome to Tetris @ Berkeley!

Our club was founded in Fall 2022, and has about 85 members as of October 2023, including 4 top 1000 ranked players.

---

Purpose

We define Tetris as a broad genre of puzzle/“stacker” games, subdividable into multiple subgenres (including Classic and Modern), but united by these universally recognized gameplay elements:

Tetris is a game where you move and rotate square geometric shapes, which fall to the bottom of the screen and pile up. If a line is filled horizontally, it disappears and the player receives positive feedback. If the shapes reach the top of the play area, the player receives negative feedback.

—Game developer osk in his 2023 blog post Is TETR.IO legal?

---

We strive to foster a community encompassing all clients implementing this concept, including TETR.IO, Jstris, Puyo Puyo Tetris 2, NES Tetris, Tetris Grandmaster 3, Tetris Effect: Connected, and Tetris 99. To do so, we discuss strategies, share tips and tricks, and study the game, with emphasis on its technical depth. Lastly, we participate in internal, as well as external, competitions, both as individuals and school team(s).

---

Join our Discord!

https://discord.gg/tY9sPQgcvz
summary: Our club fosters a community built around the video game Tetris, defined as a broad genre of puzzle/"stacker" games, especially modern clients. We discuss the game with emphasis on its technical depth, and partake in individual and group tournaments.

name: Thai American Cultural Association
description:
Interested in learning more about Thai food, culture, and language? Looking to explore the Thai American identity at Cal? Then the Thai American Cultural Association (TACA) is for you! 

 

TACA aims to provide all students with a tight-knit community united by a common Thai American identity and interest in Thai culture. We hope to provide a space for all students to explore cultural identities and learn about Thai culture, food, and language (you do not have to be Thai to join)!
summary: TACA aims to provide all students with a tight-knit community united by a common Thai American identity and interest in Thai culture. We hope to provide a space for students to explore cultural identities and learn about Thai culture, food, and language.

name: The 510
summary: Our goal is to introduce the Hip-Hop dance community to mainstream events and activities across campus. We strive to bring dancers of different training and cultural backgrounds together to parallel the diversity that makes up the Bay Area.

name: The Animal Law and Advocacy Project
description:
The Animal Law and Advocacy Project (ALA) assists supervising attorneys at Animal Partisan to end the suffering of animals in slaughterhouses, farms, and laboratories by discovering, exposing, and challenging unlawful conduct.

 

Animal Partisan uses the law to disrupt and weaken the primary industries of animal exploitation in the United States by creatively engaging legal advocacy tools to undermine the ability of these industries to abuse and exploit animals, thereby making cruel practices less profitable and exposing unlawful conduct to the public. Animal Partisan explores a breadth of legal tools to achieve this goal – including animal welfare, food safety, permits, accreditation, zoning, environmental, administrative, procedural, business contracts, financial, criminal, and others.
summary: The Animal Law and Advocacy Project (ALA) assists supervising attorneys at Animal Partisan to end the suffering of animals in slaughterhouses, farms, and laboratories by discovering, exposing, and challenging unlawful conduct.

name: The Beauty Hub at Berkeley
description:
In today's rapidly expanding beauty world, numerous talented individuals provide services ranging from professional makeup artistry or hair styling, to nail or lash application. Our organization seeks to bridge the gap between these student-run beauty businesses and the student community by facilitating meaningful connections.

Our organization introduces a novel concept in Berkeley's history, as it is entirely devoted to the amplification of beauty-related services. What sets us apart is our distinct focus and innovative approach to using social media platforms and a "hub" for business growth, enabling us to create a genuinely one-of-a-kind organization that connects student entrepreneurs with student clients.

By specializing solely in the beauty service sector, we can direct all our resources and efforts towards becoming a specialized and unparalleled force in the industry. This unique positioning allows us to cater to the specific needs and demands of beauty enthusiasts and small beauty businesses. We offer various forms of mentorship via our Entrepreneurial, Legal, Finance, and Media mentors who cater to whatever help or advice our student-run beauty entrepreneurs need.

Our innovative approach empowers entrepreneurs to establish a robust online presence and reach a broader audience, which is often challenging for small businesses in traditional settings. By bridging the gap between entrepreneurs and clients, we facilitate a deeper understanding of preferences and needs, leading to exceptional and tailored beauty services.

As pioneers in this domain, we are committed to revolutionizing how beauty-related businesses operate in Berkeley, fostering direct connections, and enriching the overall beauty landscape in the community. Through our dedication to advancement and adaptation, we aim to create a lasting impact on both entrepreneurs and clients alike.

Foremost, we aim to dispel stereotypes surrounding beauty enthusiasts. With a substantial portion of students regularly indulging in beauty services, this platform stands to be mutually advantageous for participants across the beauty service spectrum, whether they are providers or consumers.
summary: We aim to provide students with a “hub” of local beauty products and services, strengthen beauty businesses through entrepreneurial mentorship, and deliver beauty-related content catered to students!

name: The Berkeley Group
description: Established in 2003, The Berkeley Group (TBG) is a professional student group committed to providing pro-bono consulting services to nonprofits and social enterprises in the Bay Area. We work with individual organizations to create solutions to the vital challenges they face in today's society. We believe that helping social sector organizations with business challenges is a unique way to impact the community by providing long-lasting, sustainable effects.
summary: The Berkeley Group is a professional consulting group on campus that provides services to local, national, and international nonprofits.

name: The Berkeley Project
description: The Berkeley Project began in 2006 as a one-day service event. We have since expanded Berkeley Project Day to an annual 2,000 person event where volunteers work on service projects throughout the City of Berkeley. From working at elementary schools to planting trees and making meals for the homeless to helping out at senior centers, our volunteers devote a total of 12,000+ hours and save the City of Berkeley over $400,000 every year. Members may join a committee to help plan the service events, volunteer, site lead, and/or become a Core Director. Sign up for Berkeley Project Day today at www.berkeleyproject.org!
summary: The Berkeley Project is the largest student-run volunteer organization on campus. Every semester, we host Berkeley Project Day with over 2,000 volunteers at 70-80 sites in the City of Berkeley.

name: The Defendance
description: The Defendance seeks to create space for Berkeley Law students to celebrate dance and movement. The Defendance will be an oasis for which to move and groove the stresses of law school away, collaborate choreographically, explore different dance genres, and give space for students to teach their colleagues the dance wisdom they know. Though the centering force of The Defendance is dancing for pure enjoyment, we will remain open to exploring performance opportunities at Berkeley Law and beyond.
summary: The Defendance is a dance group for Berkeley Law students, to move and groove the stresses of law school away.

name: The Dialectic
description: The Dialectic was formed by a group of individuals who yearned for a space to discuss all kinds of issues related to politics, social justice, economics, etc. Dialectic General Meetings are informal discussions on predetermined topics. Our goal is to involve the UC Berkeley student body in informational and non-partisan dialogue.
summary: The Dialectic promotes an open space where members of the UC Berkeley community can advance their political knowledge and opinions through dialogue, panels, debates and other events, whilst sharing this knowledge with the greater public through media.

name: The Environmentalist
description: The objective of The Environmentalist magazine is to educate Berkeley students and locals about the various environmental issues in Berkeley and the greater Bay Area. The student-run magazine will cover student and University actions on these environmental issues through a multimedia format. It places an emphasis on investigative journalism that aims to give a voice to marginalized communities impacted by climate change and keep Berkeley students and University administration accountable for their ecological footprint and contribution to climate change. It also aims to cultivate a community of environmental reporters, photographers, and designers equipping them with the skills to become professional environmental journalists.
summary: Educating UC Berkeley students and Berkeley residents on local environmental issues. Aiming to give voice to marginalized communities impacted by climate change and keep students and administration accountable for their contributions to climate change.

name: The IT Club at Berkeley
description:
We aim to address the global e-waste problem by promoting right-to-repair. We also work with universities, corporations, and retailers to repurpose phased-out, RMA'ed, or returned computers to support underserved communities. We also fix computers for free. If you want to work on computers, learn to build your own computer, have a device that needs fixing, or just want to hang out because computers are cool, feel free to join!

 

We also offer free computer repair and upgrade services to Berkeley students.
summary: The IT Club strives to address the global e-waste problem by promoting right-to-repair, offering computer repair/upgrade services, and refurbishing disused computers for underserved students. We also provide free IT services to Berkeley students!

name: The Read Everyday And Discover (READ) Initiative
summary: The READ Initiative aims to incentivize reading by providing reading materials to young students in the Oakland area. This will allow for more accessible books, early introduction to reading, and higher education as a more tangible pathway.

name: The Rebel Alliance of California
description:
┌──────────── ⋆⋅✦⋅⋆ ────────────┐

A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away...UC Berkeley's famous Star Wars club was born! Whether you're a Sith or a Jedi, Rebel trooper or Imperial spy, all are welcome to the one-and-only Rebel Alliance of California. 

└──────────── ⋆⋅✦⋅⋆ ────────────┘

 

Our goal is to foster camaraderie among our members, forging a robust social environment for those invested in all Star Wars media. Through ongoing activities, such as film viewings, scheduled roleplay meetings, and themed game nights, TRAC strives to facilitate long-lasting connections between all its members.  

Aligning with the social activism of Star Wars' legendary protagonists, TRAC undergoes several themed volunteer initiatives throughout the year. Trash cleanups, social media awareness campaigns, and food donation drives are among the means by which we demonstrate our commitment to the saga's timely lesson: the galaxy's greatest heroes are dedicated to helping those in need. 

We look forward to seeing you at our meetings, and may the Force be with you!
summary: Welcome to the premier club for everything Star Wars! We foster a tight-knit community that freely exhibits its passion for the personalities, landscapes, and legends of a galaxy far, far away. Meet fellow Rebels and embark on cosmic adventures!

name: The Wildlife Society at Berkeley
description:
Wildlife Society is a social and professional club for students fascinated by the natural world. We aim to facilitate a welcoming, interdisciplinary, and environmentally-conscientious community -- supporting anti-racism, representation, and belonging in this historically inequitable field. To this end, we provide a career network and weekly meetings, as well as free and subsidized events, including a diverse array of speakers, service events, and outdoor activities.

If you have blurry insect pictures on your phone, a deep sense of wonder for ecological processes, or simply like wandering around outdoors, Wildlife Society is a group of nature nerds that would love to have you.

We’ve camped at Mt. Diablo, hosted a Cal Falcons founder, toured the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, hauled invasive eucalyptus, enjoyed funny and heartfelt member lectures, and celebrated the spring equinox. We’ve gone night salamander hunting, found the Cesar Chavez burrowing owl, and run around campus for our annual halloween scavenger hunt. More to come this year!

We have no membership requirements and welcome you to one or many meetings, and support a diverse community of students from across all disciplines. The linktree below takes you to all our channels of communication, including our membership registration form, discord, and instagram. 

Look out for information on our first info sessions and weekly meeting times on our socials!
summary: The Wildlife Society at Berkeley is a social and professional club for all fascinated by the natural world, aiming to increase access and community in the field of wildlife ecology and conservation.

name: The [M]ovement
description:
Caroline Kim and Trisha Mitra founded The [M]ovement in the fall of 1999. They began with a vision of bringing together a diverse group of people sharing a passion for dance. Starting with only 20 members, the group has expanded to over 100 members introducing different styles of hip-hop, jazz, and swing to the UC Berkeley campus.

Aside from having free workshops on Upper/Lower Sproul, The [M]ovement also hosts semesterly showcases (which are highly attended and anticipated!) to highlight the hard work of our dancers and choreographers. 

Despite our continued growth, [M]ovement members work to cultivate a supportive environment for all dancers; we have endless love for our dancers and welcome all to be a part of our fa[m].
summary: The Movement is one of UC Berkeley's premier dance groups featuring open choreo, jazz/contemp, and swing. With over 100 members, Movement maintains a large but close family environment that is supportive of each member and our passion for dance.

name: Theater for Charity
description:
Theater for Charity is a non-profit theater group on the UC Berkeley Campus that puts on a bunch of awesome shows each semester, and donates all the proceeds to charity! 

Everything is student run, written, directed, produced, and performed. We do 2-3 shows a semester, so keep an eye out if you want to try out! Even if acting isn't yo thang, we are always on the look out for writers, directors, and technical people as well!

If you have any questions, email us at ucbtheaterforcharity@gmail.com
summary: UC Berkeley's premiere student-written comedy theater group, where every penny goes to charity! Your home for foul-mouthed philanthropy!

name: Theta Chi
summary:
The Mu Chapter of Theta Chi is proud to uphold over 100 years of tradition and brotherhood.

Contact us at calthetachi.com

name: Theta Tau
description:
The purpose of Theta Tau is to develop and maintain a high standard of professional interest among its members, and to unite them in a strong bond of fraternal fellowship. The goals of the fraternity are to promote the social and professional development of its members during and after their college years. Today, Theta Tau is the oldest and largest professional engineering fraternity in the United States, with a diverse membership of men and women studying engineering at more than 40 campuses, and is the only professional co-ed engineering fraternity at UC Berkeley.

Want to learn more? Check us out!
Website: http://www.calthetatau.com/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/thetatauepsilon/

Instagram: http://instagram.com/thetatauberkeley

YouTube (Rush Video Playlist): https://www.youtube.com/RushVideoPlaylist
summary: The purpose of Theta Tau is to develop and to maintain a high standard of professional interest among its members and to unite them in a strong bond of fraternal fellowship.

name: Theta Xi
Thomistic Institute at Berkeley, The
description:
The Thomistic Institute's Campus Chapters program began in 2015, and has since expanded to over 80 campuses worldwide.

What are chapters?

Campus Chapters are student led organizations recognized by a university. Student leaders are the 'protagonists' and the main catalysts of the events. We encourage undergraduate and graduate students to collaborate with each other, with us, and with their faculty to develop lectures, events, and programs built upon the Christian intellectual tradition.

Thomistic?

St. Thomas Aquinas stands at the heart of what we do. We believe Aquinas provides a theological backbone for intellectual evangelization. With St. Thomas as our touchstone, our speakers and events open endless possibilities for discussion and growth in intellect and faith! Many speakers are experts not only in areas of Thomistic research, but in philosophy, science, literature, theology, and more.

Events

There are many different kinds of events a chapter can organize: select a speaker from our network of academics for a lecture hosted at your university, organize a reading group, or even a conference! There are many new and interesting ways to be involved, and we would love to hear your ideas and proposals.

Learn more at thomisticinstitute.org/ or search for us on social media to stay updated
summary: The Thomistic Institute at UC Berkeley organizes public lectures and student reading groups to promote Catholic Intellectual Tradition, especially the works of St. Thomas Aquinas, on campus. All lectures and speaking events are open to the public.

name: Thrive Dance Company
description: Thrive Dance Company's mission to help Berkeley students grow, develop and THRIVE in their passion for dance. We do this through promoting the art of contemporary dance through performances in UC Berkeley and other Bay Area venues that feature cutting-edge choreography, and provide a welcoming community where dancers can work on their own expression of dance.
summary: We are UC Berkeley's original and premier contemporary dance group. Our goals are to promote the art of contemporary dance and to provide a welcoming community where dancers can work on their own expression of dance.

name: Tikvah: Students for Israel
description:
Tikvah: The Zionist Voice on Campus is an independent grassroots student-led organization at UC Berkeley, founded in 2007, whose mission is to promote Zionism on campus and to educate the UC Berkeley community about Israel.

Zionism is the national movement of the Jewish people – a movement that espouses the repatriation of Jews to their homeland, Eretz Israel, and promotes Jewish self-determination and sovereignty there.

We believe in the State of Israel’s right to exist as a Jewish and democratic state and we strongly oppose any attempt to delegitimize this fundamental right.

We are committed to being a strong pro-Israel voice on campus and to combat Antisemitism in all of its forms, including Anti-Zionism. We are committed to calling out Antisemitism on our campus wherever we see it.

We are a non-partisan organization. We do not take a stance on American politics or on a numbered state solution, although our members may have different political views and beliefs, we are all united by one goal – to defend Zionism, the Jewish right to self-determination.
summary: Tikvah: The Zionist Voice on Campus is an independent grassroots student-led organization at UC Berkeley, founded in 2007, whose mission is to promote Zionism on campus and to educate the UC Berkeley community about Israel.

name: Tiny Dorm at Berkeley
summary: We’re a club that hosts concerts for Berkeley student performers to showcase their talents! Events will be hosted at dorms, art studios, or anywhere else that allows us to bring people together for music at Berkeley. Find out more - linktr.ee/tinydorm

name: To An Unknown God
description:
Vision


Therefore, the One whom you worship without
knowing, Him I proclaim to you.
—Acts 17:23

To An Unknown God is UC Berkeley’s first student-run Christian journal. Every semester, we publish writing and artwork produced by Cal students, hoping to foster dialogue both between Christians and students of other faiths and philosophies.

We are not affiliated with any church or other religious group, and opinions expressed in articles and posts do not necessarily represent those of the editors. We are completely student-run and funded by the student body as an ASUC-sponsored student publication. A large portion of our funding, however, comes from private donations. 

Distribution is free while supplies last. If you would like a print copy, please email us your mailing address.
summary: To An Unknown God is UC Berkeley’s first student-run Christian journal. Every semester, we publish writing and artwork produced by Cal students, hoping to foster dialogue both between Christians and students of other faiths and philosophies.

name: Toastmasters on Campus
description:
Toastmasters has been the world leader in teaching public speaking since 1924. Meetings are an enjoyable, self-paced course designed to get you up and running as a speaker.

We meet every Wednesday 6:15-7:30pm year-round either in-person (82D BNorth in ASUC student union) or over zoom (Online Link).
summary: Toastmasters has been the world leader in teaching public speaking since 1924. Meetings are an enjoyable, self-paced course designed to get you up and running as a speaker. Find out more at toastmasters.org or drop by one of our meetings to get started.

name: Tokiha
description:
Tokiha is a club that prepares you for a summer camp program in Japan where local high school students and college students from America gather. We aim to have high school students to be exposed to new ideas, rethink who they are, and ultimately liberate themselves from their own shells. We lead college student counselors to create their own workshops that leave an enjoyable and rewarding experience to both themselves and participants. The program which is run in English consists of student-made workshops, team activities, guest speakers, and fun events.

If you are interested in joining us, please email our director at: moniquegomes@tokiha.org
summary: Tokiha is a club that prepares you for a program in Japan where high schoolers and American college students gather. We aim to have high schoolers be exposed to new ideas, rethink who they are, and ultimately liberate themselves from their own shells.

name: Toppa at Berkeley
description:
Are you an East Asian student aspiring to become a future leader in the tech industry? Come check us out! 

 

Toppa@Berkeley is a career development and elite mentorship program initiated by Google VP, Megan Pi, and UCB Dean of College of Engineering, Prof King Liu. We stand by the mission of unlocking the full potential of the East Asian community.

 

This semester, we would be offering exclusive mentorship sessions with Google professionals, diverse projects to hone your skills, and a tight community with like-minded ambitious individuals.

 

Learn more about our mentors and projects through the following resources!

Website: https://toppa.berkeley.edu/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TOPPAatBerkeley/

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/toppa_berkeley/?hl=en

LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/toppa-berkeley
summary: Toppa is an East Asian tech club focused on professional development, mentorship program, and projects to support East Asian students along their career paths at every stage. We stand by the mission of unlocking the full potential of the East Asians :)

name: Toxicology Student Association of Berkeley
description:
ToxSA supports students interested in the field of toxicology and related disciplines by providing mentorship, career preparation, and community service opportunities as well as exploring past and current issues in toxicology. Toxicology major/minor is not required to join!

 

Mentorship and Career Prep

Our career preparation services will support students by bringing in guest speakers and mentors, providing resume and interview workshops, access to a collaborative research/scholarship/internship database, and more. Members of ToxSA will also become members of the NorCal Society of Toxicology (SOT) and be Undergraduate Affiliates with the SOT. This will give students the opportunity to interact with real life toxicologists and access scholarship and other career opportunities.

 

Community Service/Projects

In the past, ToxSA sponsored the Lead Education Awareness Program (LEAP) which spread awareness about household hazards and air pollution, and has also worked with the NorCal Society of Toxicology and the Lawrence Hall of Science to encourage and introduce students to toxicology through a variety of events and services. Members will have the opportunity to join projects and work on collaborations like these in the future. Additionally, members will have the opportunity to participate in monthly Journal Clubs where students will present and discuss relevant research studies with other members of the club.

 

Community

Our goal is to create a supportive and inclusive space for students curious about toxicology to explore and develop their interests with others. Beyond just academic and professional pursuits, we also hope to encourage personal growth and a positive environment. From study groups and resource sharing to social events, ToxSA supports students not only through their years at Berkeley, but also helps them for the future by exploring careers and networking while being a part of a growing community of toxicologists!
summary: ToxSA is dedicated to bringing together a community students who are interested in toxicology, pharmacology, environmental health and related fields by providing mentorship, career preparation/networking, and community service opportunities.

name: Traders at Berkeley
description: Traders at Berkeley is UC Berkeley's premier undergraduate quantitative finance club dedicated to hosting an inter-collegiate trading competition, teaching an introductory DeCal course on quantitative finance, and connecting with industry professionals.
summary: Traders at Berkeley is UC Berkeley's premier undergraduate quantitative finance club that partners with leading industry sponsors to host a trading competition and teach an introductory DeCal course on quantitative finance.

name: TransferMD@Berkeley
summary: TransferMD @ Berkeley is committed to creating a community for all Cal pre-medical transfer students. It aims to facilitate the transfer experience by providing a database of resources and opportunities through workshops, mentoring, and networking.

name: Transfers at Berkeley Law
description: TABL is committed to addressing the needs of both 2L and 3L transfer students through career and academic advising, mentorship, social activities, networking, and other events and programs.
summary: TABL is committed to addressing the needs of both 2L and 3L transfer students through career and academic advising, mentorship, social activities, networking, and other events and programs.

name: Translational Medicine and Stem Cell Association
description: Our mission is to spread awareness of new advancements in stem cell therapies to the public and provide professional resources to help the next generation of students advance the field. Through events such as our annual stem cell conference, networking dinner, lecture series, and Princeton Review sessions, we provide professional development opportunities to our students and enable them to meet fellow scientists and professors in a more personal setting. We also invest our time in outreach at local schools, science festivals, and other outreach events to educate students and the public about stem cell research.
summary: TMSCA is dedicated to spreading awareness and educating students about stem cell research through outreach events and stem cell conferences.

name: Transportation Graduate Students Organizing Committee
summary: To bring graduate students interested in transportation together, plan social and professional events, and maintain connections between faculty, students, staff, and alumni in transportation engineering, planning, and public policy.

name: Transportation Team at Berkeley
description: We provide our members with an opportunity to address real-world challenges in today's challenging urban landscape. We aim to compete in the regional ASCE Mid-Pacific Conference as part of the CEE Department.
summary: Our purpose is to serve as an avenue for transportation enthusiasts across all major to gain practical, hands-on experience in the design and planning of transportation solutions.

name: Transylvanian Temptations
summary: Transylvanian Temptations is committed to fostering a celebratory environment for students at UC Berkeley to find one another, perform together, and bond over a shared love of the Rocky Horror Picture Show.

name: Tri-Service Corps of Cadets
description: The Tri-Service Corp of Cadets is an organization that seeks to bring unity between the Army, Navy, and Air Force ROTC branches and veteran groups on campus. We seek to develop aspiring military officers, create inter-branch camaraderie and competition, and manage Tri-Service events.
summary: The purpose of this RSO is to plan and coordinate tri-service activities between the members of the Army, Navy, and Air Force ROTC cadet programs.

name: TrueLement
description: TrueLement or better known as “TL” was established in 1998 at UC Berkeley. Since then, the team has evolved into a well-recognized dance group among campus peers and various communities throughout the Bay Area. TL is known for its upbeat, diverse, and high-energy performances that highlight some of Berkeley’s most talented dancers. With such talent, TL has had the privilege to perform at many showcase venues, club events, and street festivals. TL was founded on the basis of not only promoting and performing the art of dance but also providing a unique experience for its dancers. That experience is meant to push its dancers physically and mentally while maintaining a positive and goal-oriented attitude. The combination of all the dancer’s strengths, training, friendships, positivity, and love of dance creates the TL family, a very rewarding experience that can only be offered through a small dance group like TL.
summary: A dance organization on campus aimed at giving students opportunities to perform and become a part of a larger dance community and family.

name: Turkish Student Association at Berkeley
description: Our organization is unique in bringing together Turkish members of the Berkeley community and promoting an environment for dialog between graduate and undergraduate students within the Turkish community. We are showing effort to keep the Turkish community at Berkeley intact and making sure that we help one another in times of need. We organize professional development events, kickbacks and networking events in order to ensure compatibility and communication within the Turkish community at Berkeley, and to help grow the opportunities of Turkish people at Berkeley.
summary: The members of Turkish Student Association at Berkeley wish to increase the campus’ awareness regarding Turkey and promote Turkish/Turkish-American community and culture.

name: Turning Point USA at Berkeley
summary: Turning Point USA at Berkeley's mission is to educate students about the importance of free speech, limited government, fiscal responsibility, and capitalism through innovative campus activism and non-partisan, thought-provoking discussions, and events.

name: Two Hands
description: Two Hands aims to provide students with opportunities to improve hand dexterity and precision through various hands-on arts and crafts activities such as wood carving, needle felting, sculpting, and more. No prior experience in any arts & crafts is needed. We welcome anyone interested in learning new skills, exploring different hobbies, and becoming skillful at using your hands! We meet biweekly on Tuesdays.
summary: Practice manual dexterity for students pursuing careers that require careful coordination on 3D objects (dentistry, surgery, etc.) and provide a space to de-stress through activities such as sewing, carving, painting, and more.

name: Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Foundation
description: Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Foundation, formerly known as the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, is an organization dedicated to charity, medical care, education, and humanity in the community. We hold weekly community service events that promote the organization's values and principles. These events include shoreline clean-up, hot meal distributions, convalescent home visits, recycling, sign language learning, flower arrangement, and much more.
summary: Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Foundation is an organization dedicated to charity, medical care, education, and humanity in the community.

name: UC Berkeley Model United Nations
description:
[Please do not request to join on Callink! Instead, if interested please visit our website for more information or sign up for our mailing list.]

UC Berkeley Model United Nations is a traveling collegiate debate team that allows college students to engage in discourse on contemporary and historical topics relevant to international relations. We travel to various Model UN debate conferences hosted by other universities, as well as host our own conference in San Francisco. In addition, we hold numerous other events, including smaller regional conferences, social events, and club meetings.
summary: UC Berkeley Model United Nations is a nationally-ranked intercollegiate team that competes on behalf of Cal at Model UN debate conferences across the country, hosts a collegiate conference, and hosts a high school conference.

name: UC Jazz Ensemble
description: UC Jazz Ensembles is the primary source for jazz performance opportunities on campus, open to students of all majors.
summary: UC Jazz is the primary source for jazz performance opportunities on campus, open to students of all majors.

name: UC Rally Committee
description:
The University of California Rally Committee’s members are charged with upkeeping Cal’s Spirit and Traditions. They serve as the ambassadors of the University, making Berkeley a fun school to attend. From cheering in the front row at football games to waving Cal flags during night rallies, the committee is behind much of the magic on campus. The UC Rally Committee is also in charge of many campus traditions, including Card Stunts, which originated at Cal in 1910, and our annual Bonfire Rally which hosts almost 10,000 students in the Greek Theatre every November dating back to the early 1900s. 

 

The Committee has much to offer to its members. Whether you enjoy yelling your heart out for the Golden Bears, learning about the University’s fascinating history, or coordinating some of the largest and most successful events on campus, the Rally Committee enables you to preserve and promote the California Spirit—all while making friendships that will last a lifetime. The Rally Committee promotes and protects the spirit that sets the University of California Berkeley apart from any other school in the country.

 

If any of this sounds interesting to you, we highly encourage you to consider joining the UC Rally Committee. Not only does membership in the UC Rally Committee include getting a super cool rugby that is proudly worn on game days and at other events where the committee upholds University traditions, but it also includes the opportunity to get a behind the scenes scoop of what planning and executing campus wide events entails and welcomes you into a big, spirited family. Just fill out our interest form at https://tinyurl.com/ucrcinterest2023!

Go Bears!
summary: The University of California Rally Committee is charged with the protection and guardianship of the Spirit and Traditions of UC Berkeley. Founded in 1901, the Rally Committee maintains over 120 years of tradition and promotes service to the University.

name: Ukrainian Club of Berkeley
description:
The Ukrainian Club of Berkeley is at the forefront of uniting members of the UC Berkeley community who stand with Ukraine and those who want to learn more about Ukraine, history and culture or who identifies her/himself as Ukrainian. 

 

Our mission is to go beyond ourselves in bringing and uniting the world’s best minds around Ukraine, for protecting the Ukrainian identity, people, civilization, culture and history, for reimagining and rebuilding Ukraine, for enriching and preserving the world’s civilization.

 

Among our current & upcoming projects: 

:: Run to Rebuild Schools (Learn more and join us)

:: Ukraine-Berkeley Forum 2023 

 

Our club is for actionable plans not just talks. 

Our club is for a global synergy and development. 

Our club is about talents who strategize and act empowered with common values of equality, justice and sustainability for peace.
summary: Our organization seeks to unite members of the UC Berkeley community who share a Ukrainian identity or an interest in Ukrainian history, culture or who simply stand with Ukraine

name: Unbounded Representation
description: The purpose of our group is to promote dialogue about different kinds of diversity among those who do work in Mathematics. We are a group of Math graduate students and have a particular interest in the Math graduate student experience at Berkeley. However, we would like to investigate how all people in math-related fields grapple with the issue of diversity. We will do so through a variety of panel presentations, round-table discussions, and surveys. Our events will be open to the wider community.
summary: The purpose of our group is to promote dialogue about different kinds of diversity among those who do work in Mathematics. We are a group of Math graduate students and have a particular interest in the Math graduate student experience at Berkeley.

name: Undergraduate Astronomy Society - Berkeley
description:
We are an organization of both undeclared and declared astrophysics majors dedicated to creating a strong sense of community within the undergraduate Astronomy Department at UC Berkeley. We help students to become involved in the Astronomy Department while guiding them and providing resources for success. 

To join our mailing list, fill out this form.

Watch our Fall 2020 Welcome Video!
summary: We are a collective of undergraduate astrophysics students at UC Berkeley dedicated to the formation of a structured representation within the Berkeley Astronomy Department.

name: Undergraduate Business Group
description: UBG is a group of diverse students in the Berkeley business community dedicated to helping our members accomplish their professional goals in investment banking, consulting, technology, and quantitative trading, as well as personal goals. Develop professionally with our extensive mentorship and resources and forge lifelong relationships with members of our connected community.
summary: Undergraduate Business Group aims to foster a close-knit community of business students on campus through career mentorship, professional training, and social activities.

name: Undergraduate Composers Club
description:
This Undergraduate Composers Club exists to inspire a community of composers and performers on the UC Berkeley campus. It is a community built upon the sharing of compositions, of orchestrations, and above all the performance and demonstration of students’ works by their peers.

Though it began in the music department and was built upon the idea of connecting music majors/minors to one another, it is not limited as such. The Undergraduate Composers Club is open to all who wish to create, share and perform the music of their peers; and to do so without any limitation in regard to genre or experience.

We are a historical club that was founded in 2005 and have been operating in unofficial capacity for many years. With the full support of the Music Department, we offer the unique opportunity for undergraduate composers to hear their works performed by their peers by hosting a concert at least once a semester in either Hertz Hall or Morrison Hall. During the school year, we also invite experienced composers and musicians to present guest lectures.
summary: This Undergraduate Composers Club exists to inspire a community of composers and performers on the UC Berkeley campus,  built upon the sharing of compositions and above all the performance and demonstration of students’ works by their peers.

name: Undergraduate Economics Association
description: Undergraduate Economics Association is a club for undergraduates at Cal who are Economics majors, considering enlisting in the major, or just interested in economics. We hope to build up interest and camaraderie among economics undergrads, and to provide resources which will help you get the most out of the department's offerings. Please come to our events to find out more about us or contact one of the UEA officers.
summary: Undergraduate Economics Association is a club for undergraduates at Cal who are Economics majors, considering enlisting in the major, or just interested in economics.

name: Undergraduate Finance Association|Undergraduate Management Consulting Group
description: Our mission is to serve as a primary contact point on campus for investment banks and management consulting firms. With our strong industry relationships, we strive to bridge the gap between students and top firms by organizing some of the largest and most successful recruiting and informational events and workshops on campus
summary: Our mission is to serve as a primary contact point on campus for investment banks and management consulting firms

name: Undergraduate Laboratory at Berkeley (ULAB)
description:
We believe that every student interested in participating in research at Berkeley should have the opportunity to do so. We are committed to individually helping new students find research on campus, developing their resume to apply for these positions, and connecting/supporting students already involved in research.

A productive and enjoyable undergraduate research experience at Berkeley requires a significant activation energy that deters many beginning students. This stems from a tendency for many programs to favor already experienced students and difficulty for new students in navigating a complex myriad of resources. Additionally, students who assist graduate mentors often do not get the chance to generate ideas themselves or interact with other undergraduate researchers in diverse fields.

ULAB proposes to create an undergraduate “research lab” to gently introduce new students to research at Berkeley as well as provide a social/mentoring experience for already advanced undergraduate researchers to learn from each other and develop professionally. “Lab members” will attend workshops on professional communications or reading research papers, go on tours of campus research labs, listen to talks by professors, and present on their own research work. The program is particularly aimed at students who are interested in research but might not be as aggressive or experienced to seek out these opportunities on their own - ULAB will be the catalyst to kickstart their Berkeley research careers.
summary: We are committed to individually helping new students find research on campus, developing their experience to apply for these positions, and connecting/supporting students already involved in research.

name: Undergraduate Legal Honors Society (Formerly Law in Practice at Berkeley)
description: The Undergraduate Legal Honors Society strives to provide access to pre-law resources for all students, regardless of race, gender, socio-economic status, or any other limitation. We educate students on the complexities one may face on the path to law school and provide them with the ability to successfully navigate their professional and intellectual paths in the legal field.
summary: The Undergraduate Legal Honors Society aims to inspire and inform Berkeley students about the vast, exciting and diverse practice of law.

name: Undergraduate Marketing Association
description:
The Undergraduate Marketing Association at the University of California, Berkeley is an organization dedicated to providing a bridge between students and the marketing and consulting world. We provide various opportunities in the marketing field and help our members reach both academic and professional goals. Our members are immersed in hands-on experience in strategy, design, and event consulting. In addition, our members are able to interact and network with professionals through our external speaker series and internal professional development events, developing their knowledge in marketing and consulting.

 

UMA is unique because our members consult and work with companies and organizations through a variety of semester-long projects. UMA is divided into three committees – Strategy Consulting, Design Consulting, and Events Consulting. Each committee consists of six to ten members, led by two experienced Project Managers.
summary: The Undergraduate Marketing Association at UC Berkeley is dedicated to providing a bridge between the students and the marketing world. We provide our members with hands-on experience in strategy, design, and event consulting with real clients.

name: Undergraduate Moot Court Team
description:
Moot court is a student organization that simulates appellate advocacy and persuasive brief writing. The ultimate aim of moot court is to help undergraduate students prepare for law school and learn valuable legal advocacy and writing skills. The American Moot Court Association (AMCA) releases a case problem on the 1st of May each year. The case problem for the 2023-24 year is linked here: https://static1.squarespace.com/static/5b660749620b85c6c73e5e61/t/644fa125e22fd95fbe224a4e/1682940198004/2023-24+AMCA+Case+May+1+2023+Version.pdf

If you would like more information, feel free to check out the AMCA website at https://amcamootcourt.org/

Also, follow us on instagram @berkeleymootcourt !
summary: Moot court is an organization that simulates appellate advocacy and persuasive brief writing that helps undergraduate students prepare for law school and learn valuable legal advocacy and writing skills. We compete nationally against other schools.

name: Undergraduate Political Science Association
