description: The Undergraduate Political Science Association seeks to elevate the voice of all political science majors, explore potential career paths beyond graduate/law school, and foster a close-knit community built on a commitment to serve. We are non-partisan.
summary: The Undergraduate Political Science Association seeks to elevate the voice of all political science majors, explore potential career paths beyond graduate/law school, and foster a close-knit community built on a commitment to serve. We are non-partisan.

name: Undergraduate Private Equity Club at Berkeley
description: Welcome to the Undergraduate Private Equity Club at Berkeley – your gateway to unlocking the world of private equity! We are thrilled to present an inclusive platform that seeks to demystify the complexities of this dynamic field, making it accessible to all aspiring students. Our mission is to equip Berkeley students with the technical knowledge, recruiting assistance, and skill-building opportunities needed to excel in the exciting realm of private equity.
summary: Empowering Berkeley students in private equity. We demystify complex concepts, foster confidence, and cultivate future finance leaders. Join us to transcend boundaries in pursuit of knowledge and success

name: Undergraduate Real Estate Club
description: The purposes of this organization are: to increase awareness of the real estate industry; to provide a network for students interested in the real estate industry; to function as a representative organization of the undergraduate student body interested in real estate at the University of California at Berkeley campus.
summary: The purposes of this organization are: to increase awareness of the real estate industry; to provide a network for students interested in the real estate industry; to function as a representative of the real estate-focused undergraduate student body.

name: Undergraduate Sociology Association at Berkeley
description:
The Undergraduate Sociology Association at Berkeley (BUSA) is committed to supporting the scholars of our department. 

The purpose of this organization shall be, but not limited to, 

  • fostering community amongst sociologists, e.g. undergraduates, graduates, professors, and professionals
  • advocating for the needs the students within the department of sociology at the University of California, Berkeley
  • cultivating relationships with partners and organizations to uplift the needs of professional development, career exploration, and self-fulfillment 
  • developing recruitment and retention efforts for the scholars of our discipline 
  • offer programming geared towards academic enrichment, research, community, civic engagement, and advocacy for social justice issues
summary: The Undergraduate Sociology Association at Berkeley (BUSA) is an organization of students interested in the sociology field. BUSA organizes valuable academic, social, service, and sociological events for undergraduates.

name: Undergraduate Street Medicine Outreach
description: An organization dedicated to reducing the barriers unhoused members of society face specifucally regarding healthcare and advocacy. All are welcome and no qualifications needed to apply. Get personal connections and meaningful volunteering along us
summary: USMO’s mission and goal is to overcome or mitigate the biggest barriers houseless communities/encampments face in relation to accessing healthcare and other services provided in the Berkeley area.

name: Undergraduate Student Council of the College of Environmental Design
description:
UgSC CED is the official governing entity of undergraduate students of the College of Environmental Design. They address & communicate the needs & desires of the student body with administration & campus officials with the goal to unite students.

 

UgSC Staff

Council Chair: Kirra Lindman (Architecture Rep)

Council Vice Chair: Eduardo Romero (Urban Studies Rep)

Council Treasurer: Yesenia Casillas Rios (Landscape Architecture Rep )

Council Secretary: Hitiksha Bansal (Architecture Rep)

Council Marketing Director: Cecilia HiuTung Ip (Architecture Rep)

Executive Committee Representative: Mimi Morgan (Sustainability Rep )

Biviana Herrera (Landscape Architecture Representative)

Marina Mezhibovsky (Architecture Representative)

Nio Howa (Urban Studies Representative)  

Contact us at cedugsc@berkeley.edu
summary: UgSC CED is the official governing entity of undergraduate students of the College of Environmental Design. They address & communicate the needs & desires of the student body with administration & campus officials with the goal to unite students.

name: Undergraduate Women in Economics at Berkeley
description:
UWEB is an esteemed organization dedicated to fostering the integration of academic resources in economics with professional development. Our mission centers on providing exceptional opportunities for enthusiastic students to engage in practical learning experiences.

By participating in UWEB, students are empowered to cultivate their knowledge and pursue their economic interests actively, thus propelling their career prospects forward. Beyond academic growth, UWEB takes pride in fostering a close-knit and supportive community. 

UWEB stands as a testament to our commitment to excellence, learning, and the advancement of women in economics, fostering an environment that nurtures academic and professional growth alike.
summary: UWEB is dedicated to bridging students with academic resources and professional development. Offering extensive hands-on learning opportunities for passionate economics students, we empower them to pursue their career aspirations and build community!

name: Underground Scholars Initiative
description:
Who we are:

 

The Underground Scholars Initiative (USI) was created to support all prospective and current UC Berkeley students impacted by issues of mass incarceration, imprisonment, and detainment of any kind.

The goal of USI is to bridge the topic of mass incarceration that is highly popularized in academia with one that is grounded in the lived experiences of UC Berkeley students. USI has the unique opportunity of making UC Berkeley a catalyst for the development of a prison-to-higher education pipeline within the University of California educational system.

 

What we do:

 

USI helps formerly incarcerated and system impacted individuals transition into the culture of UC Berkeley by providing community, peer counseling, scholarship information, financial aid advising, individual tutoring, and other personal and academic resources. 

Together we advocate for equal opportunities on behalf of previously or currently incarcerated individuals, especially those who are already attending, or may soon attend, UC Berkeley. 

 

We work directly on advocacy work for local, state, and national policies that benefit currently and formerly incarcerated individuals and move society closer to abolition and the end of mass incarceration. 

 

Why Join USI?

 

We will connect you with a community of individuals that have been through similar experiences amidst the sometimes isolating landscape of University. We have countless networking opportunities, resources only offered to USI members and programs specially crafted with formerly incarcerated and system impacted individuals in mind. We offer funding grants, assistance with getting started on research opportunities and connections with other university programs. In short, we are doing all that we can to foster a tight knit community and support formerly incarcerated and system impacted individuals navigate CAL in every way that we can.
summary: Underground Scholars Initiative aims to connect formerly incarcerated and system impacted UC Berkeley students with the resources and information that will help to increase those students' prospects of success.

name: Underrepresented Minorities in Economics (Formerly Students of Color in Economics)
description: Hello! We are UME. Founded in 2017, UME's goal is to provide a space for Black, Latinx, and Native American students who are interested in Economics. We hope to build a community for POC in this field by providing different kinds of resources and opportunities. We believe that by establishing an internally diverse coalition we can work together with fellow students and faculty to learn how to deconstruct what has become a hugely segregated academic field.
summary:
UME wants to harvest a community of underrepresented students to take on the issue of diversity
directly.

name: Underwater Robotics at Berkeley
description:
Underwater Robotics at Berkeley is a student led, engineering team on campus that participates in intercollegiate underwater robotics competitions, RoboSub and MATE. 

Members will have the ability to improve their technical skills in designing, building, programming, and testing an underwater robotic submarine. Team collaboration, presentation of ideas, and obtaining sponsor support are also key aspects of the team.

Students from ALL majors, years, and experience levels are welcome to join the club's hardware, software, or operations/finance sub-teams.

To learn more check out our website: https://urobotics.berkeley.edu
summary: Underwater Robotics at Berkeley designs, builds, and tests autonomous underwater vehicles to compete at the annual RoboSub competition in the summer.

name: UNICEF at Berkeley
description: As one of the leading UNICEF Campus Initiatives, we aspire to raise funds and increase awareness among the students of Berkeley, as well as the surrounding East Bay community. Each year, we organize several outreach events that involve our entire community; we hope that our passion for helping children in developing countries will inspire and encourage the Berkeley community to join us.
summary: UNICEF at Berkeley is an ASUC sponsored student group at Berkeley. Founded in 2001, we are proud to be one of the first UNICEF college campus initiatives! Our campus initiative focuses on three aspects: education, fundraising, and advocacy.

name: United For Health at Berkeley
description: By serving as an interface between the UC Berkeley campus and UFH clinicians, we will continue to provide services of acupuncture and nutritional counseling and education. This treatment model reduces stress, anxiety, depression, and chemical issues for UC Berkeley students and the campus community. The Hope on the Go Clinics have successfully operated at the UC Berkeley Student CoOps, the Tang Health Center, and the Moffitt Library benefiting hundreds of students on a drop-in basis. Please join our RSO so we may continue to offer our services to you and your fellow students on a regular basis to combat your daily stress! Email us at hope.unitedforhealth@gmail.com to volunteer or with questions.
summary: United for Health at Berkeley’s mission is to provide healthcare services and education that is accessible to students, faculty members, and staff on the UC Berkeley campus by partnering with United for Health (UFH), a local nonprofit organization.

name: United Nations Association of Berkeley
description:
United Nations at Berkeley (UNAB) is the official UC Berkeley campus chapter of the United Nations Association. We are an advocacy-based organization dedicated to educating the students and citizens of Berkeley about pressing global issues and empowering them to take action on them for lasting impact. As part of this mission, we host events and speakers, hold advocacy campaigns, and interact with the local community, including collaborations with other student organizations. We also work closely with our parent chapter, the United Nations Association, East Bay, and the broader Northern California region! We invite and encourage all Berkeley students to join our community and help making a lasting impact on the world!

Students in UNAB are organized into project groups designed to help further UN goals. This semester (Fall 2023) the project groups will be aiding a local UNA event, and an additional project group based on student interests.

For more information, please see our linktree https://linktr.ee/unaberkeley, contact us at unaberkeley@gmail.com or message our Instagram page.
summary: The United Nations Association of Berkeley is dedicated to raising awareness about pressing global issues and empowering students to take action on them for lasting impact. UNAB is the UC Berkeley campus chapter of UNA-USA.

name: Unity in Christ
description: Unity in Christ meets monthly with representatives from various fellowships on campus in order to plan community events, pray and discuss topics relating to Christian unity. We also support each other in coordinating prayer, teaching and evangelism efforts in the community. We do this all in the name of loving one another as Christ has first loved us.
summary: Unity in Christ is a community at UC Berkeley designed to promote unity of Christians on campus, empower one another in prayer, service, and evangelism, and provide support for students seeking churches and Christian fellowships.

name: UNITY Resource Center
description:
The UNITY Theme Program is a living-learning community designed to promote identity exploration and community engagement for students (primarily new UC Berkeley students) through a lens of gender and sexual diversity. 

 

UNITY hopes to foster strong community and leadership development, activism, and education. UNITY additionally intends to provide students with resources and support in a queer and trans community space. UNITY aims to achieve its objectives primarily through an academic seminar, residency, and resource center available to UNITY members.
summary: The UNITY Resource Center’s primary objectives are to serve students enrolled in the UNITY Theme Program as well as provide resources and a safe space for all UC Berkeley students of the LGBTQ+ community.

name: Universal Business League
summary: Universal Business League (UBL) aims to provide a completely non-exclusive opportunity for undergraduate students to develop their professional and business skills through mentorship.

name: Universities Allied for Essential Medicines
description: Universities Allied for Essential Medicines aims to promote access to medicine in impoverished countries by: changing norms around academic patenting/ licensing, ensuring university medical research meets the needs of people worldwide, and empowering students to respond to the access and innovation crisis.
summary: We advocate access, innovation, and empowerment in order to change UC Berkeley licensing policies, ensuring that medicines and medical technologies developed using Berkeley research are more accessible to people in developing countries.

name: University Housing Rights Organization
description: The University Housing Rights Organization (UHRO) aims to provide a resource for students living in on-campus housing, to ensure that living conditions are up to adequate standards. Students should have a comfortable and secure place to live in order to achieve their full academic potential.
summary: The University Housing Rights Organization (UHRO) works to provide comprehensive resources for students living in on-campus housing, to ensure that living conditions are up to adequate standards so they can achieve their full academic potential.

name: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles at Berkeley
description: We are a student organization dedicated to experimenting with and demonstrating the newest technologies available to aeronautics. Founded in 2015, we have designed, built, and tested drones over a large range of sizes and applications. These engineering challenges have strengthened our understanding of autonomous flight software, novel composite materials, mechatronics, and electric aircraft propulsion. Those who have a deep passion for tackling tough design challenges and experiencing the thrill of their efforts contributing to a drone flight are welcome to join us.
summary: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle at Berkeley is a student organization exploring forefront aeronautical technologies.

name: UPQUARK- Undergraduate Physical Chemistry and Quantum Materials Advanced Research Literature Knowledge Seekers
description: We are a weekly journal club where members can sign up to present a paper or a chapter from a textbook related to physical/materials chemistry. Our goal is to allow members to learn about and present new concepts in a casual environment.
summary: We want to be a weekly journal club where members can sign up to present a paper or a chapter from a textbook related to physical/materials chemistry. The hope is to allow members to learn about and present new concepts in a casual environment.

name: Upsilon Pi Epsilon
description: Upsilon Pi Epsilon (UPE) is the international computer science honor society backed by both ACM and IEEE. The Nu Chapter is the premier computer science society at Berkeley and provides professional development services, workshops, and events to the student community
summary: Upsilon Pi Epsilon (UPE) is the international computer science honor society backed by ACM and IEEE. The Nu Chapter is the premier computer science society at Berkeley and provides professional development services and events to the student community.

name: UpSync
description:
UpSync is a student-run, non-profit management consulting organization. We work with technology companies to help students reach success in non-technical career development. We partner with these corporations to form interdisciplinary consulting teams and develop strategic recommendations to provide answers to the tech industry’s most pressing problems.

​Though our projects always focus on technology in some way, they have spanned a variety of disciplines including but not limited to: product management, marketing, data analysis, SEO/SEM, web and app development, design and prototyping, strategy, and implementation.

See UpSync in Action
summary: UpSync is a student-led, non-profit, consulting organization at UC Berkeley. We work with companies to solve their most pressing problems, including everything from SEO & General Business Operations to Software Engineering & Data Science.

name: UX @ Berkeley
description:
If you want to design technology, join UX @ Berkeley! This is a space dedicated to teaching the principles of user-centered design: using research to guide the creation of products. Here, we will teach you how to design you own apps and websites using emerging design principles. With these projects, you will form a high-level portfolio meant to help you get User Experience Designer/Researcher internships and entry-level positions. You will also receive design and career advice from tech industry professionals. 

 

We encourage students from all academic backgrounds to join, as understanding your audience as a tech designer requires knowledge from many different fields. The application process requires no additional work, so no prior experience is needed.
summary: Teach the disciplines of UI/UX, which include design thinking, prototyping, and user testing. Create and prepare a portfolio for internships using professional tools with advice from industry experts.

name: Vagabond Multilingual Journal
description:
We seek to showcase multilingual creative works in order to foster interests in multilingualism, promote diversity, and support multiculturalism in the UC Berkeley community.

Vagabond publishes original poetry and prose, written in various languages and accompanied by English translations. Works are written by undergraduates from all around the world. Our past issues have published works written in languages like Chinese, Finnish, Hindi, Italian, Russian, and many more.
summary: Vagabond is a UC Berkeley student-run, multilingual literary magazine that showcases creative works written in various languages.

name: Valley Consulting Group
description:
Valley Consulting Group aims to provide students interested in the intersection of business and technology an opportunity to engage in real-world consulting projects with leading Silicon Valley technology companies.

Find our application and additional information at https://vcg.berkeley.edu/join
summary:
Valley Consulting Group aims to provide students interested in the intersection of business and technology an opportunity to engage in real-world consulting projects with leading Silicon Valley technology companies.

Visit: https://vcg.berkeley.edu/join

name: Valorant at Berkeley
summary: The purpose of Valorant at Berkeley is to create a community of like-minded Valorant gamers who share a passion for the game and to provide opportunities for its members to compete, collaborate, and grow within the e-sports space.

name: Vanguard at Berkeley, The
summary: The Vanguard at Berkeley aims to provide community-based watchdog and news reporting of local government and criminal justice reform. We aim to bring transparency, accountability and fairness to our local government and courts.

name: Vegan Cuisine at Berkeley
summary: Vegan Cuisine at Berkeley promotes healthy living, environmental sustainability, and upstanding moral character through plant-based diets. The organization also seeks to build community through a shared interest in consuming plant-based foods.

name: Venture Capital at Berkeley
description: We are a student-run organization that aims to develop students' interest in venture capital and startup activity on campus. Our professional work includes partnering with the on-campus fund Courtyard Ventures, working with VCs in a VC Fellowship, running a Venture Capital Decal and organizing and maintaining connections across the Bay Area startup ecosystem.
summary: Venture Capital at Berkeley is an undergraduate community that will be empowered to learn about the components of Venture Capital, work with leading venture capitalists and entrepreneurs, and develop relationships with likeminded students.

name: Venture Strategy Solutions Consulting
description:
Venture Strategy Solutions (Venture) at Berkeley is a strategy consulting group that works with high-growth startups. Past clients include Lime, Bright Machines, Niantic (creators of Pokémon Go), and more! We focus on creating actionable and impactful recommendations for the clients we work with. We also prepare our members for careers in a variety of fields including consulting, tech, start-ups, and finance. 

Website

Spring 2021 Recruitment Video
summary: Venture Strategy Solutions at Berkeley is a student-run strategy consulting group that serves start-ups and high growth clients.

name: Veritas Graduate Christian Fellowship
description:
We are a community of graduate students, post-docs, professional students, and friends--of diverse cultures, disciplines, and denominations--seeking to know Christ and seeking to thrive in our faith together.
 
Through regular gatherings of community, study, and service, we endeavor to support and love each other as we continue to grow in our academics, careers, and faith.
 
Check out our website for more information!
summary: Veritas Graduate Christian Fellowship is an interdenominational campus ministry, primarily consisting of graduate students and professionals, and is affiliated with InterVarsity, First Presbyterian Church of Berkeley, and UC Berkeley.

name: Vertical Farming at Berkeley
description:
The Vertical Farming Club at UC Berkeley is a student-led organization dedicated to developing sustainable and innovative solutions to address global food insecurity and environmental challenges. The club's mission is to create a technology that can revolutionize the way food is grown, produced, and distributed, with a focus on vertical farming.

Vertical farming is a technique of growing crops in vertically stacked layers, using artificial lighting and a controlled environment to optimize growth and yield. The club believes that vertical farming can be a solution to many of the world's biggest problems, including climate change, water scarcity, and food insecurity.

The club's primary goal is to design and implement a scalable vertical farming system that can provide fresh and nutritious produce to UC Berkeley's dining halls. By growing food on campus, the club hopes to reduce the university's carbon footprint and promote sustainable practices.

To achieve this goal, the club brings together students from various disciplines, including engineering, agriculture, and environmental science. Members work together to develop and test prototypes, collect data, and optimize the system's efficiency and productivity.

The club also collaborates with industry partners and academic institutions to stay up-to-date on the latest technologies and research in vertical farming. By sharing knowledge and resources, the club hopes to accelerate the development of sustainable agriculture practices and make a positive impact on the world.

Overall, the Vertical Farming Club at UC Berkeley is a passionate and innovative community of students dedicated to using technology and science to solve some of the world's biggest problems.
summary: UC Berkeley's Vertical Farming Club develops scalable systems for dining halls, focusing on sustainable practices to solve global food insecurity.

name: Vertical Takeoff or Landing at Berkeley
description: VTOL at Berkeley fosters engineering and business skills among students through hands-on eVTOL aircraft development and business management.
summary: VTOL at Berkeley fosters engineering and business skills among students through hands-on eVTOL aircraft development and business management.

name: Vietnamese Student Association
description:
Our Founding

Longing for their homeland, a group of immigrant Vietnamese students at UC Berkeley joined forces and created the Vietnamese Student Association in 1979.

Their goal was to create a space in which they could connect through their similar backgrounds and share their culture with each other. To further their purpose, they looked to educate others about Vietnamese culture, history, and heritage.

Through their efforts they built a family away from home for Vietnamese and Vietnamese American students, a community that continues to grow.

Cal VSA Today

Today, Cal VSA is still a student organization that embraces our Vietnamese and Vietnamese American roots and culture. Though our members are a part of a new generation, we recognize and commemorate the experiences that our parents and relatives have had while also striving to identify and to understand the emerging narratives and current issues in our community.

Cal VSA, alongside our goals, has evolved as an organization but we are still driven by the same principles that our founders embraced. These principles can be summed up by our three pillars:

  • Academics | We recognize and embrace the opportunities that we have been given and we endeavor to extend the same opportunities to others in our community.
  • Community | We recognize the diverse contemporary issues facing our community and we attempt to understand them, to promote awareness about them, and to address them.
  • Culture | We recognize that we have a unique Vietnamese heritage and tradition and we aim to preserve and to learn more about our culture.

Though we are an organization that focuses on the Vietnamese American experience, we are honored to be able to count many members of non-Vietnamese heritage as part of our family. We welcome any and all students to come see what Cal VSA has to offer!
summary: The Cal Vietnamese Student Association (Cal VSA) strives to empower its members to become leaders of their communities and preserve the history and heritage of the Vietnamese culture for future generations. We welcome any and all to come join our family!

name: VISION
description: VISION, a mentorship program under Vietnamese Student Association at the University of California, Berkeley, recognizes and understands the significance of the historical, cultural and contemporary issues the Vietnamese and Vietnamese American communities face. VISION aims to foster and encourage high school students to take away what they learn and gain from our program to become leaders of their own communities. Fundamentally, VISION empowers students to embrace their individual identities as well as the heritage of the Vietnamese culture.
summary: VISION is a 4-day, 3-night mentorship program aimed at bringing awareness to historical, cultural and contemporary Vietnamese and Vietnamese American issues.

name: Vision Development Club of Berkeley
description: A professional student organization at the UCB Optometry that aims to promote awareness of all aspects of vision therapy early in the optometric education, including perceptual training, accommodative and vergence training, sports vision, traumatic brain injury and stroke rehabilitation. Other aspects involve guest speakers and advice into creating a vision therapy practice and incorporating vision therapy to various optometric settings. Guest speakers experienced in the field will be brought to UCBSO for presentations to provide information about COVD, OEP, and other related educational meetings and conferences.
summary: A professional student organization at UCB Optometry.

name: Vision Science Club
description: The purpose of the Vision Science Club is to encourage collaborations between Vision Science graduate students across various labs, promote awareness of current issues in Vision Science, and foster social relationships through community and club events.
summary: The purpose of the Vision Science Club is to encourage collaborations between Vision Science graduate students across various labs, promote awareness of current issues in Vision Science, and foster social relationships through community and club events.

name: Visiting Scholars Ministry
description: VSM (Visiting Scholars Ministry) (http://www.berkeleyvisitingscholars.org/) is a registered student organization that welcomes all visiting scholars, visiting students and post-docs. We strive to provide enriching experiences through English programs, fun outings and American cultural experiences. Each week, we host English classes and VSM Forum, where we discuss and explore various topics on Christianity.
summary: Introducing visiting scholars to American culture, life, and faith

name: Volunteer Health Interpreters Organization
description:
**FOR MORE INFO: <www.calvhio.org>

 

Our application for 2023-2024 is currently closed! Please check back during early Fall 2024 for the next application cycle! Visit us at calvhio.org for the most up to date information.

https://youtu.be/hsomGwJ6jvM

 

VHIO strives to eliminate language barriers in healthcare settings by providing trained volunteer interpreters from UC Berkeley to healthcare organizations and facilities for underserved, limited English proficient (LEP) communities in the Bay Area.

 

VHIO is a University of California, Berkeley undergraduate student-led organization whose roots trace back to 2007, when it was established as the San Francisco Hepatitis B Collaborative (SFHBC) in partnership with University of California, San Francisco health professional students. SFHBC at Berkeley provided trained bilingual students as Asian language interpreters for two monthly UCSF hepatitis B student-run clinics, which we continue to volunteer at.

 

Dedicated to helping stop the spread of Hepatitis B, SFHBC partnered with organizations such as the San Francisco Hepatitis B Free Campaign and helped at various screening, vaccination, and education events. Four hundred million people worldwide suffer from chronic hepatitis B infection, which tragically can lead to liver cancer early in adult life. It is the 10th leading etiologic cause of death in the world. Fortunately, the spread of the hepatitis B virus is preventable with a simple, safe, and effective vaccine.

 

Due to an increase in demand for interpretation services, we have been expanding to provide interpretation and volunteering services for a broader range of issues beyond hepatitis B. In August 2010, SFHBC at Berkeley was renamed the Volunteer Health Interpreters Organization (VHIO) to reflect its expanded scope of language capacities and its service base across the San Francisco Bay Area.

 

We provide trained volunteer interpreters in several languages - Mandarin, Cantonese, Japanese, Korean, Spanish, Tagalog, and Vietnamese - from UC Berkeley to healthcare organizations and facilities for underserved LEP communities. We work closely with UCSF medical and pharmacy students, UOP dental students, health workers, and medical providers to serve patients and help them overcome the language barrier in healthcare.

 

VHIO plays an integral role in our community by outreaching to the underserved immigrant neighborhoods and assisting them at individual medical appointments and health fairs. Passionate about community empowerment, our volunteers also interpret for educational presentations on topics ranging from cancer prevention to disaster preparedness. 

 

VHIO provides the following valuable experiences for pre-health students.

Interpretation: Clinical exposure and opportunities to work with underserved communities

Outreach: Make connections with medical students and local healthcare organizations

Training: Professional training in healthcare interpretation

Members Expectations

-minimum of 10 volunteering hours per semester (20 per year)

-minimum of 3 General Events and 2 Department Meetings per semester (5 per year)

-attend training and meet shadowing requirements (if new member)

 

Proud Partners with:

Affordable Housing Associates  •   Alameda Hep B Free  •  American Liver Foundation  •  Asian and Pacific Islander Wellness Center  •  Asian Community Mental Health Services  •  Asian Health Services  •  Asian Liver Center  •  AsianWeek  •  Berkeley Food Institute   •   Bone Health Initiative   •   Breathmobile  •  Cal Pre-dental Society   •   California Pacific Medical Center  •  Center for Early Intervention on Deafness  •   Center for Empowering Refugees and Immigrants  •   Center for Elderly Independence   •   Central American Resource Center  •  Chinese American Coalition for Compassionate Care  •  Chinese Community Health Plan  • Chinese Hospital in San Francisco  •  Chinatown Public Health Center  •  Clinic by the Bay  •  Family Bridges  •   Fresh Approach  •   Korean Community Health Center  •  Street Level Health Project - School of Optometry  •  Kimochi-Kai  •   Labor Coach  •   Lifelong Medical Care  •   Mabuhay Health Center  •   Montclair Physical Therapy  •   Oakland Senior Center  •   Prevent Blindness Northern California  •   Project Open Hand  •   Rotacare Richmond Free Clinic  •   San Francisco Free Clinic  •  San Francisco Hep B Free  •  Satellite Affordable Housing Associates  •   Street Level Health Clinic  •  Team HBV at Berkeley  •  The Hep B Project  •  The Second Opinion  •   UCSF Memory and Aging Center  •   UCSF Partners in D  •  UCSF Operation Diabetes  •  UCSF San Francisco Hepatitis B Collaborative  • UOP Hearing and Balance Center  •   UOP School of Pharmacy  •   Vietnamese American Community Center of the East Bay  •  Women's Cancer Research at Berkeley 

 

 **VHIO is a nonpartisan student organization and will not endorse any candidates running for state, federal, or student government. Please do not contact us to inquire about hosting speeches or contacting our members in any way on a candidate's behalf.
summary: Volunteer Health Interpreters Organization, better known as VHIO, provides verbal interpretation and document translation for healthcare related services in the San Francisco Bay Area.

name: Volunteer Income Tax Assistance Program
description:
Berkeley VITA is a student-led UC Berkeley Public Service Center program that trains and connects student volunteers with tax sites geared towards low-income communities throughout the Bay Area.

 

FOR INDIVIDUALS INTERESTED IN RECEIVING TAX-FILING SERVICES:

Berkeley VITA itself does not host tax filing services, but rather trains volunteers to prepare tax returns so that they may serve at local tax sites. Those who are interested in free tax filing services are welcome to check out the following links to locate and schedule an appointment at their nearest site:

United Way Bay Area: https://uwba.org/tax-help/
IRS tax help website: https://www.irs.gov/individuals/find-a-location-for-free-tax-prep
UC Berkeley site @ the ASUC Legal Clinic: https://www.asucslcberkeley.org/appointments.html

 

FOR INDIVIDUALS INTERESTED IN VOLUNTEERING:

The VITA program consists of two parts:

1) Fall: Weekly 2-unit DeCal designed to prepare students to take and successfully pass the IRS-sponsored Basic Certification Test in late November. The DeCal incorporates readings and discussions about poverty, income inequality, and the public policies surrounding these issues. Training materials, including official IRS publications and software tutorials, will be provided to students for free.

2) Spring: Students begin volunteer work at one of the local sites with partnering organizations in Berkeley, Oakland, San Francisco, or a virtual site, and continue until the end of the tax season (April). Students can receive 2 additional units for their volunteer work and apply to become a Site Leader.

No previous experience or knowledge of taxes is required!

Berkeley VITA is a YEAR-LONG commitment!

Applications are released shortly after the start of the fall semester! Email us if you have any questions. Learn more about VITA through our Linktree: https://linktr.ee/ucberkeleyvita
summary: The Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA) program prepares student volunteers to provide free tax-filing services for low-income community members throughout the Bay Area.

name: Volunteers for Medical Outreach
description:
Every school year, members of Volunteers for Medical Outreach organize various events in order to raise funds for our cause. 100% of the proceeds we make go directly toward funding mobile health clinics, Hepatitis B vaccinations and corrective surgeries for underserved areas in the global community. During the summer, we travel abroad to volunteer amongst doctors, dentists, and pharmacists at the mobile health and vaccination clinics that we fund, teach public health lessons to the communities we visit, visit hospitals to view the disparities of healthcare systems in different countries, and serve the community in non-medically related ways as well. So far, VMO has established a strong presence in Southern and Central Vietnam, but we are hopeful about expanding our services to other countries as our organization continues to grow.

Applications for new trip members and general members are now open on our website (https://vmo.berkeley.edu/apply)! Please email or message us if you have any questions!

Learn more about us at Calapalooza!
summary: Members of Volunteers for Medical Outreach seek to provide free medical and health care to people who cannot afford hospital services. The organization will provide students with a way to extend their services internationally to other countries.

name: Voyager Consulting
description: Voyager Consulting is a UC Berkeley, student-run, strategy consulting organization that provides services to growth stage and Fortune 500 companies. Voyager strives to provide an environment for members to grow through real world problem solving and create a community that extends beyond Berkeley.
summary: Voyager Consulting is a UC Berkeley based non-profit business organization that provides management consulting and business strategy services to Fortune 500 and growth stage companies.

name: Wasians at Berkeley
description: Wasians at Berkeley brings together the vast and diverse Wasian community across campus. This will connect Wasians across grade levels and ethnicities to examine the interconnectedness of white and asian identity. We will learn more about each others’ unique heritage, because although we are mixed, Wasians come from different backgrounds and parts of the world- different parts of Asia, different hometowns, and different experiences with our parents. We want to bring everyone together to celebrate and bond over our shared culture. It is also a great opportunity to bond, socialize, and make new friends in the Cal community.
summary: Wasians at Berkeley aims to embrace the cultures of students of mixed white and asian heritage and provide a community that facilitates the connection of our shared identity.

name: Waterski and Wakeboard Association at Berkeley
description: We teach beginners how to waterski and provide a place for skiers to train and participate in tournaments against other universities.
summary: The purpose is to promote the sport in this region as well as provide opportunities for students to compete and socialize with people interested in waterski and wakeboard. We will teach beginners how to ski and skiers how to improve.  We want to unite pe

name: Web Design and Development at Berkeley
description: The purpose of Web Design and Development at Berkeley is to provide students with educational resources for creating materials for the web. This includes (1) web design — user experiences and interfaces, graphic design, and prototyping, as well as (2) web development — front-end engineering using HTML/CSS/JS, both of which are for programs that are not provided by the university. We solely focus on web-related design and development and work towards building a strong foundation in our members— regardless of experience.
summary: Web Design and Development at Berkeley provides students with educational resources for creating materials for the web.

name: Web Development at Berkeley
description: Web Development at Berkeley is UC Berkeley's first web development and design-focused organization, bringing full-stack web development education and hands-on industry development and design experience to UC Berkeley students. We have three initiatives, education, training, and industry. In our education initiative, we run a 3-unit DeCal called the Introduction to Full Stack Development Decal designed for students of all experience levels. Our training initiative consists of a semester-long bootcamp where rising developers and designers will build, design, and deliver several web applications to hone their development, design, and teamwork skills. Our industry initiative connects experienced developers and designers with various companies to complete a real-world software project that will end up in the hands of users. WDB unrelentingly upholds an inclusive and friendly culture where everyone can learn, grow, and flourish together.
summary: Web Development at Berkeley is UC Berkeley's first web development and design-focused organization, bringing full-stack web development education and hands-on industry development and design experience to UC Berkeley students.

name: Web3 at Berkeley
description:
Web3 at Berkeley is a trailblazing organization spearheading the UC system's growth into the Web3 sector. We are committed to laying the foundation for the integration of web3 technology into the fabric of the internet. Through comprehensive study programs, collaborative workshops, and engaging discussions, we facilitate a rich learning environment where students can immerse themselves in the multifaceted realm of decentralized networks, blockchain protocols, smart contracts, and digital assets.

Our vision extends beyond the classroom. We foster dynamic partnerships with Web3 companies, many of which are headquartered right across The Bay. These collaborations provide our members with unparalleled opportunities to contribute to groundbreaking projects, gain practical experience, and translate theoretical knowledge into impactful, real-world solutions.
summary: Web3 at Berkeley is a pioneering undergraduate organization aiming to shape the future of Web3. Our members collaborate with industry-leading companies, attend immersive Web3 classes, and forge meaningful connections in the rapidly growing industry.

name: Wine Law Society
description: The Wine Law Society is dedicated to bringing together students interested in the world of wine and, even more fun, wine law! Being a niche field, wine law lies at the crossroads of many legal and non-legal disciplines. That's why WLS offers events ranging from lectures by experts from all over the world to interdisciplinary discussions and hands-on activities (of course!). Join us to discover a new topic and have all eyes on you at the next dinner!
summary: Introduce wine law to law students and organize interdisciplinary events with other Berkeley faculties. Involve professionals from around the world to share their expertise in wine culture.

name: Women and Youth Supporting Each Other
description: Once a week, mentors travel to their middle school sites to host a group session for mentees on a specific topic. WYSE mentors use an up-to-date and program-specific curriculum to plan and build weekly sessions that are tailored to the unique needs of our mentees. Using the multi-faceted WYSE curriculum as a guide, mentors engage their mentees in decision-making games, in-depth discussions and community action projects.WYSE mentors and mentees engage in fun, one-on-one outings to spend time together and foster a relationship beyond group sessions. These extra activities are important for building trust and mutual respect between each mentor and mentee and are crucial to WYSE's high retention rate of mentees.
summary: WYSE is committed to inclusivity and belonging for all women: trans women, cis women, femmes, female-identifying, and individuals assigned female at birth. We envision a world in which we are all empowered to determine our futures and effect change.

name: Women in Computer Science and Electrical Engineering
description:
WICSE was founded in 1977 by CS graduate students Paula Hawthorn, Diane McEntyre, Barbara Simons, Mary Ann Niemat, Susan Eggers, and Deborah Estrin and celebrated its 30th anniversary in January of 2008.

This robust networking and advocacy organization has been successful in attracting and sustaining women students through sponsoring pre-college outreach and hosting activities from weekly lunches to national conferences.

Sheila Humphreys, academic coordinator for student matters in EECS, credits WICSE's success to its continuity, its ongoing contact with successful alumnae and other prominent women in the field, and to the support it receives from EECS for staff, space, and funding.

Using the WICSE model, many Berkeley alumnae—like Mor Harchol-Balter at Carnegie Mellon University and Amy Wendt at the University of Wisconsin-Madison—have initiated similar advocacy organizations on their campuses across the country. WICSE was recognized with the 2002 award from the Women in Engineering Programs and Advocacy Network for the “sustained national impact” of its efforts.
summary: WICSE promotes gender diversity in the graduate school of the Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences Department through organized efforts of mentorship, outreach, seminars, conferences, and other community involvements.

name: Women in Computing and Data Science at Berkeley
description: Women in Computing and Data Science at Berkeley (WiCDS) helps female and non-binary students at UC Berkeley improve their technical skills and receive mentorship and networking opportunities from industry professionals. We are the first student organization at UC Berkeley for women in data science and have access to a variety of resources, such as technical workshops, networking events, and hackathons, from female organizations. We also offer academic, professional, and social opportunities to our members through committees, events, socials, and more. To find out more information, please visit our website at tinyurl.com/berkeleywicds or send us an email at berkeleywicds@gmail.com.
summary: Women in Computing and Data Science at Berkeley is for women interested in technological fields to join a supportive community that teaches essential skills and provides mentorship and networking opportunities from professionals in the industry.

name: Women in Public Policy
summary: WiPP

name: Women in Tech Law
description: Women in Tech Law (WiTL) is a student-led organization that strives to recruit, support, and empower women who are interested in pursuing technology law through providing outreach, mentorship, and educational resources. WiTL aspires to use outreach as a medium to not only encourage women to enter the field, but to also expand the presence of women in the field by providing awareness to the opportunities and potential that tech law can hold for women from both STEM and non-STEM backgrounds. WiTL seeks to use mentorship and other platforms to increase members’ accessibility into tech law, in an attempt to break the glass ceiling of the technology industry. Ultimately, WiTL strives to empower women interested to excel and improve in the realm of law and technology.
summary:
Inspire and empower women to enter the field of technology law and establish a mentorship
network between prominent women attorneys practicing in the Bay Area and Berkeley Law
students.

name: Women in Weightlifting
description: Women in Weightlifting (commonly referred to as 2DUB) is a student-led organization at UC Berkeley that focuses its efforts in fostering a supportive, empowering community for women and femme-identifying individuals through the hosting of community building mixers, beginner-focused training workshops, and weekly lifting sessions aimed towards destigmatizing and reinventing the culture that has long existed within the broader weightlifting community.
summary: Our goal is to uplift and empower women in the weightlifting community by encouraging knowledge, support, and a sense of belonging so that every one of them can walk into the weight section of a gym with confidence.

name: Women of Berkeley Law
description: Women of Berkeley Law (WOBL) formerly known as Women's Association at Berkeley Law is committed to advocating for women on campus and in the legal community. We work toward advancing a more diverse, inclusive legal community through education, community service, mentorship, and activism.
summary: Women of Berkeley Law (WOBL) is committed to advocating for women on campus and in the legal community. We work toward advancing a more diverse, inclusive legal community through education, community service, mentorship, and activism.

name: Women of Color Initiative
summary: To be entered

name: Women on Wall Street at Berkeley
summary: Women on Wall Street at Berkeley was created in order to provide the Berkeley community with its only current, independent student organization for female-identifying students interested in finance.

name: Women’s Baseball Club at Berkeley
description: This club was formed with support from Baseball For All, the country's leading women's baseball organization.
summary: The purpose of this club is to provide an opportunity for students at UC Berkeley to play competitive baseball together, building community and contributing to the larger women's college baseball movement happening across the country.

name: Womxn in Politics at Berkeley
description: Womxn in Politics at Berkeley exists to empower and educate womxn on the UC Berkeley campus and help forge a path to public service. We are a nonpartisan group that aims to create a close-knit social and professional on-campus community while work.
summary: Womxn in Politics at Berkeley exists to empower and educate womxn on the UC Berkeley campus and help forge a path to public service. We are a nonpartisan group that aims to create a close-knit social and professional on-campus community while work.

name: XR Lab - Immersive Design Student Club
description:
The use of virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) has been increasingly popular in many domains such as gaming, navigation, psychological research, simulated medical treatment and skill training. In addition, the use of AR/VR could also be relevant for pre- and post-occupancy building evaluation, which could improve the building design process and enhance the usability of architectural environments.

 

XR Lab- Immersive Design Student Club consists of a group of students with an interest in immersive environments to foster a student community of research and creativity around the existing XR Lab at CED Berkeley. The XR Lab was created in 2017, at the UC Berkeley College of Environmental Design in response to the emergent fields of spatial computing and immersive environments. It seeks to develop innovative, impactful research and applications on VR/AR/MR by establishing collaborations with industry partners and academia.
summary: XR Lab - Immersive Design Student Club at CED, Berkeley seeks to foster a community of research and creativity around the XR Lab to better serve the student community with an active exchange of research ideas and approaches.

name: Yarn Arts at Berkeley
summary: We aim to provide a community space for knitters and crocheters at Berkeley, and also teach people who may be new to the crafts.

name: Yemeni Student Association of Berkeley
description: YSA aims to facilitate interconnectedness within our community to assist Yemeni students achieve success in education. We simultaneously seek to bring awareness to Yemen's culture, history and struggles through our three pillars: recruitment, retention, and education.
summary: As the Yemeni Student Association, we aim to motivate, recruit and normalize college for Yemeni students through mentorship especially those who are socioeconomically disadvantaged; and establish and sustain a space for the Yemeni community on campus.

name: YEP @ Berkeley
description: Young Entrepreneurs Program (YEP!) is a high school entrepreneurial education program for students from under-resourced communities.
summary: Young Entrepreneurs Program (YEP!) is a high school entrepreneurial education program for students from under-resourced communities.

name: You Mean More
description:
Our organization aims to promote awareness regarding mental health issues, to strengthen the prevention of suicide and self-harm amongst university students, and to reduce the stigma surrounding these topics.

Each year, our main event is the UC Berkeley Suicide Prevention Walk, which raises funds for the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. Additionally, we organize events and displays throughout the year to educate the public.

More information regarding our club can be found on our facebook page and website, and feel free to email us at youmeanmore@gmail.com with any questions or concerns!
summary: YMM aims to promote awareness and strengthen the prevention of suicide and self-harm among university students. Our main events include the Mental Health Monologues (modeled after the Vagina Monologues) and the UC Berkeley Suicide Prevention Walk.

name: Young Americans for Freedom at Berkeley
description:
Come join us to chat about conservative politics, discuss current events through a conservative lens, listen to the most prominent speakers in the conservative movement, or just socialize and party with conservatives and people from all political backgrounds. 

We focus on education of conservative values and policies, or just politics in general. YAFB stands for our Constitution, freedom, and America. All are welcome to attend meetings and events!
summary:
Young American’s for Freedom at Berkeley’s (YAFB) mission is to conduct
educational activities to spread conservative values and host prominent conservative speakers in the movement to build awareness about conservatism.

name: Young Democratic Socialists of America at Berkeley
description:
YDSA is the youth and student section of DSA––the largest socialist organization in the United States. As Cal YDSA, we fight for the immediate needs of workers and students on campus while building our capacity to push for structural changes at large.

Our mission is to educate and organize students and young people and to play a helpful and principled role in the movement for socialism. Within and throughout this struggle, we will articulate and defend the idea that true human liberation is impossible under capitalism. We seek change which extends democracy into all aspects of life -- social, political and economic. This is the struggle for democratic socialism. Our vision of socialism is profoundly democratic, feminist, and anti-racist.

 

PLEASE FILL OUT OUR SIGN-UP FORM TO GET INVOLVED (Callink is very unreliable): https://forms.gle/FkwqSTXMaJwp9UWMA

For more information, check out our website: https://calydsa.github.io/
summary: YDSA is the youth and student section of DSA––the largest socialist organization in the United States. As Cal YDSA, we fight for the immediate needs of workers and students on campus while building our capacity to push for structural changes at large.

name: Young Disciples at Berkeley
description:
Young Disciples at Berkeley is a Christian fellowship that focuses on inviting university students to participate in bible studies and fellowship.

We believe that all students should study the Bible thoroughly to find their purpose and meaning in life. We offer group bible studies, individual studies, and weekly Sunday Service with lunch fellowship. We strive to help our student disciples to know Christ and to make Him known!

General Meeting Schedule
Thursday Bible Study Fellowship: 6:00-7:00pm
Friday Prayer Meeting: 6:00-7:00pm
Sunday Service & Lunch Fellowship: 10:40am-12:40pm

What makes Young Disciples unique is that we provide many small group and individual bible studies. We will work with you to help you work out your personal faith, overcome life issues, and develop real friendships with others in Jesus Christ. Our small group and individual Bible studies are tailored and scheduled based on individual requests.

Don't hesitate to reach out to us via Instagram @youngdisciples.ucb or email for more info.
summary: Young Disciples@Berkeley is a Christian fellowship that invites university students to participate in bible studies and fellowship. We offer weekly bible studies and Sunday Services. Our goal is for student disciples to know Christ and to make Him known!

name: Youth Advocacy Project
description:
Students will work as advocates to support youth who are participating in the Youth Early Intervention Program (YEIP) in the Fall and youth who are incarcerated at Contra Costa County’s juvenile hall in the Spring.

Under the supervision of the Contra Costa County Public Defender’s Office, students will work as advocates to support justice-involved youth who are at different stages in the criminal legal process. 

In the Fall semester, students will work with the Youth Early Intervention Program (YEIP) to mentor youth following police interaction and offer support navigating the youth criminal legal system under the supervision of a youth public defender. Students will meet with their clients weekly and attend bi-weekly SLP meetings, including hands-on training experiences and speaker presentations from professionals in the youth advocacy space. Students may also have the opportunity to observe court or school disciplinary proceedings to increase their understanding of the youth criminal legal system. 

In the Spring semester, students will work with youth incarcerated at juvenile hall to support the public defenders who represent these clients in court. As a member of the defense team, students will work one-on-one, or with a fellow Berkeley student, with a client to help prepare them for re-entry. Students will meet with clients while in custody. Students can expect to familiarize themselves with their client’s case file, develop client interviewing skills, develop relationships with juvenile clients, and serve as a liaison between their client and the public defender’s office. Students may meet with clients over zoom or alternate between in-person and remote visits. Most importantly, students will have an opportunity to improve the lives of their clients.
summary: Students will work as youth advocates to support juveniles who are currently, or were previously, incarcerated at Contra Costa County’s juvenile hall.

name: Youth Empowering Nation
description: UC Berkeley YEN is a chapter of Youth Empowering Nation (https://youthempoweringnation.org) which is a non-profit organization rooted in Christian faith whose mission is to empower the youth in developing nations through education.
summary: YEN is a non-profit organization rooted in Christian faith whose mission is to empower the youth in developing nations through education.

name: Yu-Gi-Oh Duelists at Berkeley
description:
We Currently Offers: 

1. Weekly Duel Event

2. Monthly In School Tournaments

3. Join our group at Regional+ tournaments

4. and enjoy the fantastic Yu-Gi-Oh! world!

(Intercollegiate competition awaiting!)
summary: We intend to create an inclusive community of Yu-Gi-Oh players who are a lot but previously disconnected to help with preparing regional/national tournaments, daily trading and exchanging of cards, and introducing card-game and anime fans to Yu-Gi-Oh

name: Zahanat
description: Zahanat is a competitive male fusion dance team at UC Berkeley that brings together the dancing techniques of Indian film music and modern day American Music.
summary: Zahanat is a competitive Male fusion dance team at UC Berkeley that brings together the dancing techniques of Hindi film music and modern day American Music.

name: Zawadi:  Black LGBTQ Community at Berkeley
description: We are interested in increasing visibility and understanding of Black LGBTQ experiences on campus and beyond.  Furthermore, our visible presence signifies the importance and sheer existence of our overlapping sexuality, gender, and race identities to both African communities as well as the LGBTQ community on and off of campus.
summary: This group is a social, academic, and political networking organization for LGBTQ and Same Gender Loving students, alumni, faculty, staff, and post-docs of African Ancestry (African American, Multi-racial, Afro-Caribbean, Black, Bi-racial, etc).

name: Zeta Tau Alpha
description:
Welcome to Zeta Tau Alpha, Upsilon Chapter at UC Berkeley!

             We are members of the Panhellenic Community at Cal, which is comprised of 12 national organizations and one local chapter. At ZTA, we are passionate about empowering each and every sister to reach her full potential, both at this university and beyond. One of the lines in our creed is "to realize that within our grasp lies the opportunity to learn those things which will ever enrich and ennoble our lives." Our sisters live this out each and every day; we are passionate about our philanthropy, Breast Cancer Education and Awareness, which our chapter recently received a Founders Award for raising $10,000+ in the last 3 years! Our partnerships with Bright Pink and the American Cancer Society have also led us to pass out thousands of pink ribbons at the Think Pink Cal Football Game, volunteer at the survivor booth for Making Strides, and put on exciting events for the Greek community such as Sugarfest and Cookout for a Cure.

            Even more, we maintain a sisterhood that lasts a lifetime; Zetas can be found in so many organizations, be it dance, pre-professional organizations, consulting, STEM labs, or even the ASUC! The friendships formed at ZTA will follow you through your entire collegiate experience, from football gamedays with your sisters to weekends in San Fransisco or Lake Tahoe. The mentorship from older members, both in academics and in life, will be invaluable as you navigate a campus of 40,000 students, and will shape the way you see the world around you. ZTA also offers over 30 leadership positions and multiple committees within the chapter, which allow you to develop your strengths and give back!

           Last but not least, you'll always have a home at 2714 Durant Avenue; from Friday brunches to Bachelor Mondays, our sorority is undoubtedly a home away from home :)

           Zeta Tau Alpha participates in Fall Formal Recruitment as well as continuous open bidding (COB) at the beginning of each semester, so if you are interested in joining our organization, visit our website or email our vice president of membership at ztacalmembership@gmail.com. For general questions about our chapter, reach out to ztacalpresident@gmail.com.

Website: http://berkeley.zetataualpha.org

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/ztacal/
summary: Zeta Tau Alpha provides well over a hundred women each year with the intensifying of friendship, the fostering of a spirit of love, and the building up of a purer and nobler womanhood in the world -- come join our sisterhood in the Cal Greek Community!
